Recommended
199.4 hrs on record
Posted: 9 September, 2021
Assassin's Creed Odyssey is an Open World Action RPG that continues the trend of started by AC Origins, this game on its own is quite different from Origins as it tries to do a few things differently-

As for a summary, I have completed the main storyline, took down all the cultists, completed the Atlantis side quests (the one with mythical beasts), the first DLC and all its order of the ancients and also the 2nd DLC, I'm at 99% progression according to ubisoft connect.
TLDR: This game is a solid addition to the franchise and an overall 9/10 (this is the score only for the base game), the first DLC is 7/10 and the 2nd one is 7.5/10. I played the gold edition so i did not have access to any sort of xp boosts either. There's also a bunch of side quests called the Lost Tales of Greece which is a 6/10.

Now for the Pros- Ancient Greece looks stunning, there's so much attention to details, each main city has different feel to it, The map is huge and although most of it is forest and water, it has enough mechanics going on for itself to make it all engaging and immersive. The main story of the game is also really good and pretty engaging, you would end up caring for a few characters which is rare in an AC game. Now the game has choices, which tbh don't really matter, they're just different dialogue options but a few of them actually change your story and how certain parts of the world would be. The Naval combat is awesome, you can customize your ship, assign lieutenants, it isn't as great as blag flag since here you only have arrows and javelins, but overall works well to hold itself. The customization options for your character are also really well done. Each side quest in this have a whole story related to it, although they're mostly fetch quests, the presence of a story provides enough immersion. The mercenary system was extremely fun, since each of these mercenaries are almost like their own boss fight and pretty tough if 3 or 4 of them attack you at once, it made me more focused on stealth so that I wouldn't get a bounty on my head, now for the stealth, it works well for this time in history, social stealth is gone which wouldn't really work in this settings since not a lot of people roam in here, The combat is also really fun, the different abilities we have in this game makes every encounter different, you can also reassign your skill points to have a different style of play, however once you've figured out everything, you're basically a force of the nature and then the combat can get a tad bit repetitive which I'd say is fine considering you'd have to spend atleast 50 hours in the game just for the main story. There are different weapons, each of them feels different to each other and can again make the combat a lot engaging and fun. The mythical beasts are also well done and fell different to each other, each of them are challenging and add variety to the game, The game also has different tombs to raid to get loot and ability points. The motion capture and voice acting overall is also well done.

Now for the Cons- The world is huge and empty, this game could've really benefited from the random encounters and events like the ones present in Red Dead 2, the only thing that would happen is either a random camp with bandits or soldier, or some animals roaming around, The conquest battles are awesome and a lot of fun but they have no depth at all, it doesn't matter if Athens wins or Sparta, your story will still be same, This game is not an Assassin's Creed game, and I'm not saying this because of the RPG elements, I think the RPG stuff only makes it better for me, but the thing is there are no assassins or templars, this is more like a God of War game if Kratos was an okayish character, On the topic of character, Alexios or Kassandra are okay as a protagonist but not really good as compared to someone like Bayek or Ezio. The game also has level differences which means you'd have to do side quests to level up, although it isnt really a as big of a problem as some Youtubers might say, since you can pretty much get around it by just accepting all the quests from an area and you'd automatically complete them by stumbling on to whatever the side quest giver wanted. The game also has Microtransactions which aren't exactly forced at you but even their presence is an ugly sight in a really good looking game

Now there are some things that were present in the earlier games but have been removed in odyssey due to some reason, firstly the shield, although i never missed it, it could've been cool and also literally everyone has a shield except you in the game, Next are the different bow types, now i know they included it in the form of abilities but i feel those different bows could've been a great addition.

Now for the Lost Tales of Greece- This is free content that all the players who own any edition of the game will get. They are a bunch of side quests involving people you've met in the main story but the gameplay is random as its just a bunch of fetch quests, not very exciting.

Now for the 1st DLC- This is pretty much the same game, it adds a few abilities which are fun I guess, the story is super random and the characters are again okayish, It adds a flamethrower to your ship which is awesome and gives some backstory on a few characters from the broader AC lore.

Now for the 2nd DLC- The 3 different realms of this dlc are really good looking, the story is also not that bad, but its just an insane amount of meaningless filler content that brings down the dlc, again it adds a few abilities and there are a few variations to the normal gameplay loop

Now in the Season Pass- You'd get both the DLC and also Assassin's Creed 3 Remastered and Assassin's Creed Liberation Remastered, each of them are good games with a score of 8.5/10 and 7/10 in my opinion.

I'd recommend getting the gold edition or the season pass just for the amount of content it gives, maybe wait for a sale to get this game since it goes on a 70% discount every now and then. I don't recommend the deluxe or ultimate edition since the extra gear you get is pretty bad and you'd get better rewards from the Ubisoft Club for free

Assassin's Creed Odyssey is the best Assassin's Creed Game since Black Flag. Its fun, engaging and beautiful. It improves upon its predecessor Origins in every way, ditching bad aspects of that game for improvements in all the good stuff, and even adding some popular mechanics from older games, such as the bounty system from Black Flag! However, some annoying features from Origins did make it though, such as the levelling and mission system, although the side missions now reward much better items and the reasons for doing them are now much better. Visuals received a slight upgrade from Origins, although this game is much better optimised for PC.
The Story features you playing as either Kassandra or Alexios of Sparta, as you their adventure across ancient Greece. Along the way you discover your past and end disputes and issues in the present. This game has different endings where your decisions decide who survives until the end of the game, so be careful about what you say! The Story is very good and always makes you wanting to play the next mission, which however isn't always possible as the level gap will force you to play side missions, the same issue that Origins had, although these side missions are much better.
The Gameplay is much better than origins, with blocking being improved, attack abilities added and generally combat feels much smoother. It is now possible to single-handedly kill an entire army again just like in the classic Assassin's Creed Games. Joy. Weapons are largely the same, with the main difference being you don't have a hidden blade, it's instead a small spear? You no longer upgrade your armour, you instead loot and get new armour and outfits across Greece which is much better than having to hunt. Finally, Boat combat is back! And it is a lot of fun! The bounty system is also back but it feels flawed as sometimes attacking a fort as part of a quest becomes impossible as bounty hunters way above your level will stop you from doing anything.
Visuals are beautiful. Oceans, Fields, Cities and Islands are all beautiful and the team at Ubisoft really managed to capture the beauty of Greece. Especially with the Islands!
Overall, Assassin's Creed Odyssey is one of the best instalments of the series so far, as it is fun, has an epic story and has beautiful visuals. It runs well and no game-breaking bugs are present so its actually a very good game! Combat can be a bit annoying sometimes as the lock on system will have a mental breakdown during large combats (such as the nation wars) as it cant decide who you want to attack next, only for you to get bamboozled by someone you cant even see. But overall, great game.
Assassin's Creed Odyssey gets an 8/10.

For more reviews check my Steam profile
Hope you enjoyed my review, god bless you

**1.0.3 UPDATE BELOW**

AC Odyssey is massive. There really isn't a better way to describe it. It feels as if Far Cry 5 and AC Origins had a baby that only inherited the better parts of each, with a little bit of their cousin, Shadow of Mordor, thrown in for good measure.

Pros:
+ It's beautiful, vibrant, and huge.
+ All of the RPG Elements from Progression to Gear
+ Likeable Characters (NPCs and Kassandra/Alexios)
+ Branching Story/Choices
+ Character Customization
+ Breathtaking and Immersive locations
+ The Peloponnesian War
+ Endless Amount of Stuff to do
+ Engaging Combat
+ CONQUESTS
+ Photo Mode
+ Historical Locations
+ Very Free and Open World
+ Not as Buggy as Previous titles at Release
+ Large Variety of Weapons/Cosmetics
+ Runs Relatively Well considering its scope
+ Ship Combat is similar to Black Flag's
+ Tons of ways to play (Guided/Exploration Mode with Multiple Difficulties, Character Choice)

Cons:
- Some Bugs, but nothing gamebreaking for me quite yet

I have a love hate relationship with Ubisoft.
I've been playing the Assassins Creed series for quite a while now. They have kept the gameplay pretty consistent throughout the years. Depending on who you ask, it has been both a blessing and a curse.

In my opinion, Ubisoft's lack of innovation started to go downhill ever since Assassin's Creed Black Flag. This led me to turn away from the franchise for a while, seeking different genres and styles, hoping that they will eventually come back with something new and exciting... and so ladies and gentlemen, they finally have.

At first glance, Assassin's Creed Odyssey may not seem all that different from previous releases. Once you play it, you will find that it takes the old gameplay, combines, and transforms it in a very different and satisfying way. Old gameplay mechanics can be felt, but Odyssey introduces a few twists in combat, progression, and especially a well needed turn in quests and story telling.

I'm trying to keep my review relatively short and sweet so I will not go over every change and detail, but know this.

Strong graphics, satisfying combat, addicting progression, and captivating storytelling, if you love and seek these elements in your everyday games, then Assassin's Creed Odyssey is a must play.

Recommended
235.8 hrs on record
Posted: 7 April, 2020
it's the kind of game you play without a break for a while and then just drop it out of the blue, only to come back to it a few months later. The generic checklist gameplay of go to a certain spot and finish certain number of objectives should, on paper, get old really fast. Yet, the game world keeps the locales varied and the enemies interesting enough to mitigate the otherwise dull task of doing ticking things off a checklist on a map that is seemingly as big as IRL Greece itself.

Going into this game blind is perhaps the best way to get the full experience of this game. When you accidentally start a quest chain that leads to amazing views and unbelievable fights, those memories stick with you. It also helps that Kassandra is a compelling character, powered by fantastic voice acting, and a strong personality that makes you want to be her friend.

The game is not without its faults, it can get tedious every now and then, but then all you have to do is go on a sight seeing tour or sail the high seas, and you are ready to resume your journey.

148.1 hrs on record
Posted: 8 March, 2020
After destroying a fleet in your ship and traveling most of the Greek world you will remember what an awe inspiring adventure is.

The story might be a simple family tragedy, but it can keep you interested enough to think and rethink the choices you make and the characters you save.

I've played all of the Altair/Ezio/Desmond games and even though I really liked them, I understand that they ended and more and different stories will be told with the assassin's weird first civilization lore, part of the appeal of those games was not knowing what the answers were, so if you are looking for nostalgia for Assassin's Creed you are not going to relive what being an assassin feels like again, with so many answers to what the Isu are and their purpose that sense of wonder is not coming back.

But if you want an Odyssey that expands through years in the life of a character with both meaningful and trivial consequences to your actions and a really rich world with an impressive detail and great combat, this is the place.

PS: I never bought a micro-transaction and I was able to find enough xp, money and epic gear, the game is not a grinding fest. You should get the DLC though, the content is great and there are usually some sales for the more pricy editions.

Is Assassin's Creed Odyssey Better Than The Witcher 3?

Short Answer: No.
Witcher 3 has much extensive RPG mechanics, characters that bring out more emotional attachment, and better side quests among many other aspects that Odyssey cannot match. But the fact that AC Odyssey is even in the conversation with Witcher 3 is quite an accomplishment for Ubisoft and definitely a journey worth experiencing.

Ubisoft has taken what they introduced in Origins and improved it in every way from character development to combat system/RPG elements, and more comprehensive side quests in a much bigger open world environment.



While playing Odyssey I saw glimpses of the Witcher 3â€™s influence.
The rich dialogue and interactions you have with the world and the NPCâ€™s (Non-playable Characters) allows you to feel attached to them, like I did with Geralt in the Witcherâ€¦that is if you play as Kassandra. She is quick witted, funny and passionate. It's nice that Ubisoft gives you the option to play as multiple characters, but to be honest you will enjoy Odyssey much more with Kassandra. Alexios voice acting is quite bad because it's often over the top, forced and feels like a bad B or C level actor voiced him, pulling you out of meaningful moments in the game. With Kassandra though I never had that experience. Also, Ubisoft pulled back the confusing story-line of the series a bit so that youâ€™re not weighted down with the relationship the Assassins have with the Templarâ€™s as much as previous games. This makes me more invested and excited for the story than I have been in games prior to Origins


The combat system is very similar to the Witcher 3 but not as robust.

Youâ€™re able to freely spend and reset your ability points, trying different combinations of weapons and attacks. You want flaming dual swords? Check. How about remote control over an arrow for perfect shot placement? Check. Rage mode like God of War? Check. My personal favorite has to be the Spartan Kick. I find myself yelling â€œTHIS IS SPARTAâ€ in my head every time I do it. This variety and flexibility will drive you to unlock more and more abilities.

On top of the abilities of the characters, customization with your weapons is great too. Youâ€™re able to get different level of gear off enemies along the rank of common, rare, epic, and legendary. Each piece has different perks so youâ€™re able to match them to your style of play and you can even add additional ones to your gear by engraving. Such enhancements are additional critical damage, stealth bonus, faster ability recharge, breathing under water, etcâ€¦ And if you have a level one piece of gear that you really like, you can raise it to the max level if you have the necessary crafting materials.


Which game does weapons and abilities better?

Thatâ€™s up to your personal preference. I think that most people will like Odyssey more than Witcher 3 in this regard even though the latter has more to choose from. Mostly because you only get one reset on your abilities for the game on the Witcher 3, so you have to choose your points wisely as they will hold a lot more weight as you progress.


Side Missions
In many open world games, you could stick to the main quest almost start to finish without feeling that youâ€™re missing out on an epic side mission. Not the case with Odyssey though. Much like Witcher 3, Odyssey is able to pull me in with the many side quests. I found myself with very little regrets going out of my way to a spot with a â€œ?â€ and spending the time to complete it. Though I still havenâ€™t come across a side quest as memorable as The Bloody Barron in Witcher 3, which is probably an unfair comparison as that side quest is one of the best ever in gaming history. Odysseyâ€™s side quests are meaningful though. The fetch quests, as there are many in massive open world game, are even enjoyable. For example, one of my favourite fetch quest was a love triangle where you have to collect items to make a potion that will cause someone to fall in love with an NPC. You can choose different options which effect how it unfolds and who end up with the â€œhappy endingâ€. It is these kind of details that make your time spent doing extra content satisfying. Even as I was playing the other night I was flagged down by an NPC. I thought â€œOkay, this should be a 10 minute pit stop for some of that sweet, sweet XP.â€ Wrong! Two hours later I finished the multiple branching side quest with a thrilling conclusion. Every time I think, Iâ€™m going to work on the main story I get distracted by one of the many â€œ?â€ on the gigantic map. To some this may seem overwhelming (and it is), but itâ€™s an example of how good content all around helps drive people to play your game.

Final Thoughts
My final thoughts on this game and the comparison is that these type of games are best played and enjoyed at your own pace, not thinking about how youâ€™re going to 100% it or beat it fast. Iâ€™m the type of gamer that wants to burn through games, but after a few hours in the world of Odyssey I stopped trying to rush to the end and just started to enjoy the ride.

Recommended
83.7 hrs on record
Posted: 8 December, 2018
IF YOU'RE ON THE FENCE ABOUT BUYING THIS GAME, no one blames you.

Any series into the habit of annual releases deserves a ton of speculation, and no one who's played the first couple AC's can honestly say that the last few games have been very... well, good. I felt the same way about Odyssey before buying it. LISTEN TO MY WORDS: THIS IS A GOOD GAME. At the time of this post, I've been playing for ~30 hours, and there's never been a point at which I felt like I was out of things to do. The storyline alone has taken up the majority of my playtime, and I'm not anywhere near the end. I'm not a fan of games that make you grind for hours and hours on end to balance out the skill/gear requirements, and this game does a good job of making your progression feel natural and well-earned, particularly when you're playing on Hard difficulty, when enemies are always on their game.

I saw a few posts before I bought this saying that stealth wasn't a big factor in this game, and that worried me, because I've been a huge fan of the stealth aspects of the series. After playing this long, I would be willing to bet a good deal of V-Bucks that anyone who thinks stealth isn't needed in this game is playing on Easy difficulty. I've been playing it on Hard, and the majority of the time that I've felt the need to charge into an enemy fortress, I've had my ass handed to me. Stealth is the ONLY way to clear out the majority of encampments, and I wouldn't want it any other way.

I also saw a lot of people complaining about the naval mechanics, saying that it's "dulled down" since Black Flag. Well, obviously. There's no way to make a volley of arrows feel as meaty as a dozen cannons. Get over it, I guess. That being said, I've tried going back and playing Black Flag to focus on the sailing, but I can't. The combat in Odyssey is my favorite in the series so far, and so I can handle a more relaxed naval combat system in return for everything else that this game does in terms of gameplay.

I've always been a fan of the series. I left for a while when they started releasing every year, but I'm glad I came back for this. Easily my favorite in the series, I would give this game a solid 8.7/10.

Recommended
273.0 hrs on record
Posted: 5 April, 2021
273 hours later, I 100% AC: Odyssey.

If this is your first AC game, I recommend Origins before this, Black Flag before that, and AC 2 if you really want to get into the series.

This is an RPG game first which I liked very much. You can be a 'white knight' or you can be a psychopath that bangs even ugly blacksmiths. Personally I mixed it up, but absolutely banged everything I could even if it made me cringe.

Ikaros is not the best guide as he can miss a big shark just under me so I have to dive to 'mark' it.
If a shark engages you, swim directly up or down otherwise you're fish food. Picking them off from the surface of the water is best (Ghost Arrows of Artemis from the Hunter Tree are useful as well).

The first thing you should set out to do is upgrade your Spear of Leonidas as max level abilities are locked behind this requirement (have to complete main story missions).

Fully exploring areas is a good idea before you leave said area.
You have unlimited torches, so have a blast burning things.
Watch for snakes in dark interiors! And if you hear the floor moving, that's your cue to move too.

There are 3 classes: Hunter, Warrior, and Assassin.
Hunter can be surprisingly fun, but do NOT use fire as elemental damage if you're the sneaky type as you'll set the bush you're in on fire (you can snipe enemies from bushes). You do not have to craft elemental arrows, you can simply upgrade poison or fire, activate it and then shoot the arrows of your desire (you can't use both fire and poison, so it's one or the other).

Warrior is the most satisfying combat I've had in many a game. Keep in mind on 'normal' you can be killed in 3 hits so if an archer uses Spread Shot and you're too close, well enjoy your reload. Hard difficulty takes two hits to kill you (sometimes one), and Nightmare difficulty you may find yourself one-shotted by an enemies Vanish ability (which is supposed to do no damage). I played the game on Hard and switched it to Nightmare at level 80ish. It pains me to say it, but I'd recommend trying Normal then going from there,

Assassin is doable in this game, but you need gear with Assassin damage as its main damage. Don't expect to be one-shotting anything at the lowest of levels.

Gear comes in Common, Rare, Epic, and Legendary rankings. Epic is the best overall despite a legendary set granting an additional bonus. Crit Chance, Crit Damage, Crit Chance while full health, and Crit Damage while full health I found to be the most beneficial modifiers. I prefer Fire so I also looked for Fire Damage and Elemental Buildup if my ideal bonuses were not present.

This game to me is worth MSRP (ofc I only buy on sale). I'd recommend the DLC too, but maybe throw that on your Wishlist and wait until you beat the main game which is roughly $18.00 on sale. The store where they sell in-game items is trash. $20 for some re-skins and zero content whereas $18 buying the base game and I can get 200+ hours of content is no contest. Those items are in the game files themselves, hypothetically all someone would have to do is download some type of Cheat Engine to unlock them. Personally, I say its not worth all that mess, just enjoy the game because it's a damn good one.
 

Eightballjunkey

Not Recommended
40.4 hrs on record
Posted: 17 October, 2020
I really want to give this game 2 ratings, one as an open world action-rpg, and another as an Assassin's Creed game.

Skip ahead if you want to read my review of this game as a generic open world RPG.

As an AC game, it fails in almost every regard. It feels more like a 3rd-person, historically-set Far Cry game than anything else, by which I mean to say it feels like almost every modern Ubisoft title. The series can no longer be carried on the novelty that made the first few games feel so unique, we've seen the ancient world, we've met DaVinci, the novelty of these things was fun, and at the time it was enough to really make the game stand out, but ultimately the series was successful because it innovated, it tried to do things that no other game had done before, and it succeeded with the first AC game, and exceeded with the second.

I'll skip ahead to Origins and Odyssey, because this is where people claim they "got things right," but in reality all they did was create an entirely "new" franchise, and slap the AC title on it in order to drive sales, because neither of these games are AC games. They're generic open world RPG games, with all the standard Ubisoft tropes (climb the tower to mark things on your map, go to those things, rinse and repeat until the game is over). It takes away a lot of what made the AC games great, but I think it's biggest sin was simply taking such a HUGE step back in innovation. Everything it does well is something that has been done time and time again (mostly in other Ubi games) and has proven to sale games, but nothing was new, nothing felt unique. The sailing was worse than Black Flag, the climbing, while mostly smooth, has lost the "wow, I can climb that?!" feeling, since you can literally climb anything, so you don't have to think about your routes anymore, the combat isn't bad, but it just feels plain worse than games with similar "arkham" style combat, and didn't add anything to the system to make it stand out, the abilities mostly feel boring (though sparta kicking people will always be fun).

I could go on, but in general, as an AC game, it's an easy 2/10 for me, some good moments, but lost most of what I loved about the series.

As a generic open world RPG, however?

There's a lot of quests, most of them are at least SLIGHTLY more interesting than your average fetch quest (though only just slightly in most cases, this is no Witcher 3), the climbing doesn't feel as cool as in previous games, but the ability to climb anything in an open world RPG is neat and makes traversal overall more fun than in most RPGs, the combat is serviceable, nothing groundbreaking, but it's responsive and there's enough abilities that you don't have to play the same way for 60+ hours, it also doesn't lock you into any particular build. It's fun. Nothing exciting, but it's fun.

As a generic open world RPG, just like a hundred before and a hundred more to come, I'd give it an 8/10. It fills that roll incredibly well, it's just not a terribly interesting role to fill these days.

At the end of the day, the reason I gave it a thumbs down is because it just wasn't anything special. It claimed to innovate on the AC formula, but all it did was recycle ideas from other open world games, and nothing the game did was actually new, innovative or all that interesting, and after a dozen or so hours you won't have covered even a fraction of the content in the game, but it's all content you've experienced a dozen times already, just reskinned.

If you just want another open world RPG to keep you busy this will absolutely fit the bill, and if you aren't expecting anything you haven't already seen a dozen times, then you'll probably have a pretty great time, but personally, I'm hoping Cyberpunk will show these companies how open world RPGs SHOULD be done, and set a bar that other companies will have to genuinely start innovating again to compete with.

Overview
In Assassinâ€™s Creed Odyssey, players assume the role of Kassandra a â€œmisthiosâ€, starting on the isle of Kephallonia, and discover her story, her role in the assassinâ€™s creed universe. Throughout your journey, you meet with several historical figures such as Perikles, and Sokrates. You journey through the country of Greece in 430BC, crossing many historical landmarks and famous cities such as Athens. Greece comprises of a variety of biomes, ranging from beautiful beaches to lush forests and volcanic depths. Journey through this fascinating land and change the course of history.

Pros:
Visually stunning.
Easy to learn combat.
Decent exploration with occasional surprises.
Decent narrative and protagonist.
Great soundtrack.

Cons:
Points of Interests around the map might feel a little repetitive.
The map is a little too large.
Spongey enemies.

Rating: Great

In-Depth Breakdown

World and Exploration
The world of AC Odyssey is filled with sprawling towns, forests and long stretches of water. There are many points of interests ranging from military encampments to ancient temples. Exploration is mostly done on foot, (water bodies are explored on boats/ship, of course) but you also have your own horse that you can call whenever.

Water bodies are filled sharks and merchant/pirate/bandit/military ships and boats to kill and destroy while the forests sprawl with animals like bears, lions, deer, etc. There are also many ancient temples, which almost always contain a small environmental puzzle of some sort. In cities you may find military encampments and loot locations. There are military and bandit encampments in the forests too.

There are many historical landmarks such as Athens, The Grave Of Sisyphos, The Statue Of Kronos, The Statue Of Poseidon, The Altar Of Prometheus, The Sanctuary Of Delphi, The Statue Of Athena, etc.

While exploring, look out for loot, which is literally everywhere.

There is fast travel.

Characters
I personally didnâ€™t find the protagonist interesting, I felt like the dialogue choices took away from their likeness rather than supplement it in any way. There are some good and memorable characters in the game like Brasidas, for example. The voice acting, through the main storyline atleast, is good.

Cultists System
This was one of my favourite parts of the game. It is basically a list of people you have to uncover by acquiring clues about them through letters, writings and side/main quests, and then assassinate them. There was something really satisfying about going through the list and assassinating them one by one.

Scouting
Scouting is done using your trusty eagle, Ikaros. Ikaros can help you spot threats, treasures, hidden entrances, resources, etc.

Side Quests
AC Odyssey if full of quests all over itâ€™s world. There are the typical fetch quests and kill 'x' amounts of people quests present in a daily quest randomly generated format. Overall, the side quests in AC Odyssey are OK, there are some interesting quests but most to me felt mundane.

Inventory Management
You carry the following items on you: melee weapons, bows, five pieces of armour (head, arms, torso, waist, legs) and mounts.

There are different kinds of melee weapons: regular swords, axes, heavy blades, heavy blunts, spears, etc. You can initially equip one melee weapon but an ability allows you to equip two at a time.

Unlike AC Origins, there arenâ€™t different types of bows. Some abilities however allow you to acquire the Predator shot and Rapid fire etc.

Armour pieces can be slotted in and out individually and unlike AC Origins actually affect stats.

Combat
Combat in AC Odyssey feels fluid, animations flow nicely, controls donâ€™t feel wonky and the parry system works nicely. It feels better to play than AC Origins.

Combat can be hard when playing on harder difficulties and especially so when the level difference between you and the enemy is more than about five levels. There seems to be a soft cap that just doesnâ€™t allow you to do as much damage to an enemy more than 5 levels above you.

The various types of abilities in AC Odyssey makes it much more dynamic than AC Origins. You have abilities that allows you bring lighting upon the enemies, shoot arrows through walls, etc.

Stealth
Memorising enemy petrol patterns, positioning yourselves accordingly, and then striking from the shadows is the kind of stealth in this game. You pass through enemy camps while remaining crouched in tall grass, whistle to attract nearby enemies towards you, and then stick your "hidden blade" (a spear in AC Odyssey's case) through them. Stealth in AC Odyssey is very forgiving and is very easy to get into.

Abilities
There is a decent amount of abilities in AC Odyssey mainly divided into three trees â€“ Stealth, Melee, and Ranged.

Stealth: Some abilities allow you to assassinate from a distance, increase assassination damage, distract enemies by spawning friendly NPCs, apply poison damage to enemies, etc.

Melee: Some abilities allow you to apply burning on your weapon permanently, bring down lighting upon your enemies, charge like a bull, heal, etc.

Ranged: Some abilities give you access to the Predator shot, Rapid fire, shooting arrows through walls, shooting arrows with increased damage, etc.

Ship
You ride upon the Adrestia, your personal ship (which also acts a mobile fast travel point). You can upgrade your ship using resources gathered from looting and dismantling gear. You can upgrade the ships health, the rowing stamina of your sailors and the damage dealt by arrows and spear. The ship combat itself is fine, it does the job.

Expansions (Legacy of the First Blade & The Fate of Atlantis)
I played through both the expansions aswell. In short â€“ I didnâ€™t find the story of either particularly interesting, the locations of The Fate of Atlantis are beautiful though. I would suggest doing a little research before buying the expansions through the season pass/ better editions/ individually.

Final Thoughts
Overall, Assassins Creed Odyssey is an excellent open-world RPG that brings new mechanics to the series and deepens some from Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins. Gameplay is well thought out and fluid. It took me 172 hours to finish the game (including both expansions) on Normal Difficulty, while exploring the whole map(s) thoroughly and completing everything the game has to offer. I also managed to achieve 100% achievements in a single playthrough. I can recommend buying at a discount.

I'm going to keep this one short, unlike the insane grind and padding in this game.

When I first got this game a few years ago as a bundle with a Blu Yeti mic I got as a gift, I really loved it. the story seemed intriguing, the characters, and most importantly, the world is a masterpiece. The game play can be padded and exhausting which may make you give up. Let's do a few Pros and Cons before getting to the ending notes.


Pros
A MASSIVE beautiful world to explore, The team behind the world design did a fantastic job
The story, while flawed is generally good. The plot is with some twists here and there
Many characters have charm. and they do add life to this world.

Cons
After a certain point in the story, sudden "Level requirements" take a sudden jump, requiring you to do all the fetch quests and then some to reach a decent level to resume the story.
You gain EXP and a PAINFUL slow rate. Around level 30 and feeling like I was going nowhere, I stopped playing. Only way to get me back into this is to use Cheats.
The combat, while at first was quite fun, gets repetitive. It's like 78% of the game, and ALL enemies, REGARDLESS of your "Level" are sponges. This brings to the point of:
All enemies scale with you. This makes the idea of grinding to a higher level an absolute waste of time. You can be at level 99, all areas magically are 97, including starting areas. Some may be okay with this, but it makes grinding a waste of time as you have ZERO benefit of doing so.

The Bottom Line
The Padding is what turned me off. The combat could have been fun if it wasn't designed in a way to eventually become repetitive. I really wanted to like this game, the World, art, sound is all fantastic, but the gameplay really starts to feel shallow after awhile. I don't hate this game, but I just lost enjoyment after awhile. They added too much padding, which turned me off.

Don't let me cloud your judgement. but if what I said would also turn you off, then you may want to give this, and Valhalla a pass. If the issues and padding doesn't bother you, more power to you, and hopefully you get more enjoyment from this than I did.

The Verdict
Greatest Point: The World
Weakest Point: Story Progression
My final score is
6.5/10
How's it worth getting:
Get it on Sale.

Not Recommended
91.5 hrs on record
Posted: 29 August, 2020
Before you read this review, its coming from someone not massively into the franchise as a whole but has played a lot of the AC games. The last game i played to completion was black flag and I have completed all of its predecessors. Since Black Flag, the game has taken a big turn towards introducing RPG mechanics (loot, leveling), rather than the traditional "unlock more equipment as you go on"

Pros
- Huge Open world: The game is massive. Lots of quests alongside a big world to explore with lots of historical elements to get your teeth sunk into.

- Mix of Stealth / Action Game play: You have the choice to decide how to want to approach most situations, bar a few "don't get caught doing this" missions. If you want to be an archer with a mix of Stealth mechanics? You can do it. Do you want to be a Spartan warrior who kicks people from mountain tops? You can do it.

- Graphically Gorgeous: Playing this on ultra settings was a treat. The game, lighting and overall theme / setting of the game is truly a spectacle.

- History: The game is full of history anecdotes that gives you great insight to the ancient Greek world and their mythology. Plenty of interesting tales and creatures to discover. Big plus for history buffs.

- Story (No spoilers): The story is enticing. There are 3 different arcs you can complete with a mixture of reality and fantasy. Although if you haven't played the most recent games(like myself), some of the sections will seem slightly strange. They have definitely listened to the feedback of "Give us less game outside the animus, more in the world itself" which is a bonus.

- Decision Making: There is a definite sense of morality with a lot of the decision making. Actions you make will impact the result of the story / side missions as a whole. You don't feel like you are always following a story set out in front of you but instead one you can influence and dictate how it resolves. Be prepared to make tough decision to provide a greater good. You aren't just some Good Guy God who has to do the right thing everytime.

The Cons

- Variety: Although I mentioned a massive amount of content, the game suffers from the boring cycle of "I can't possibly do this myself, you have to do it" missions. Sometimes it just doesn't make sense that an NPC must unload a task on you. For example (No Spoilers): I was completing a quest chain for someone and he wanted to thank me by cooking a meal. However before this could happen he said i have to go out and hunt the meat myself. This is the equivalent of someone inviting me round for dinner, but I have to bring the dinner. The game is saturated with content like this, "I have a problem with this guy, please go there and talk/kill/steal from them and speak to me when you are done. Well what has this person done to help their own situation? Usually nothing. They were just waiting for you to come along and do it for them. This makes lot of the side missions become tedious. Also, its very annoying to go back to an NPC after completing their mission, for them to say "oh yeah, I also need this doing". Especially considering how many there are. However the "context" of the quests is always different so although you are doing the same tasks, you are doing them for different reasons. The gameplay repeats itself a lot, but the narration is varied.

- Fast Travel: Back in true AC spirit, there are locations you can climb to "synchronise". You then unlock this as a fast travel destination. On paper, not a bad thing as a lot of them give you access you stunning views. However there are wildly inconsistent. A lot of quest markers won't be near a fast travel point so a lot of time is spent travelling to point A / B then back to A. Large sections of the map will have 1 fast travel point and smaller sections will have 2 / 3+
For some reason you horse can't move faster than a gallop in city sections, making travelling very slow in some areas.

- Gear Progression: The game uses a "stat increase" type loot system. The game has legendary sets but most won't fit into your style of play. It then becomes a case of getting a sword with the same stats you have, but +10 DPS. No game play changes, simply a numbers game. If your build revolves around fire damage, any gear that gives +Posion damage will be useless for example. You can upgrade you gear to meet your current level so you never have to lose a piece of gear that rolled all the stats you need. The trouble is this makes a large portion of the loot you get entirely useless and merchant fodder.

- Level progression: As you begin there a lot of areas that have enemies that out level you. The problem is this is quite immersion breaking. "I can kill 10 wolves at once but this Peasant with a spear will kill me because he out levels me." Not a unique problem to this game, but a problem none the less. However once you get past level 50, the enemies will level with you and you will rarely find something you can't kill.

- The mercenary system: The game includes a system somewhat (albeit loosely) based on the nemesis system from the Shadow of Mordor series. The game uses a bounty meter. The more bad actions you commit (i.e stealing, murder etc) the higher your meter. The problem is the mercenaries just become an annoyance who will disrupt what you are doing. As soon as you reach a certain bounty, you will be constantly met with the message "A Mercenary is nearby" who will aggro you as soon as he/she sees you. They don't feel part of the world, they feel like they are being constantly generated and spit out next to you. This can be frustrating when exploring cities as they are always on you and offer nothing rewarding for dispatching them. The bounty can be paid off no matter where you are so its an easy problem to overcome but feels like a wasted mechanic.

Summary - Take this review with a pinch of salt depending on what type of player you are.

Overall. i did enjoy my experience with this game. The reason I am not recommending it is due to my own completionist nature. Because there is so much content, it eventually becomes a chore to go through it all. If you are looking for a game with a decent story, providing you don't mind missing areas that appear as a "?" on your map, you will have a blast. If you are like me and want to explore everything available to you to give you that sense completing what the game has to offer, I would avoid it for your own sanity. The term "wide as an ocean, as deep as a puddle" comes to mind. This game has some incredible moments but the game play loop made it a slog for me to get to them.

Ley
1,267 products in account

24 people found this review funny 0

Recommended
33.2 hrs on record
Posted: 22 January, 2019
Introduction

First of all, I don't like Assassin's Creed games. I hate them and the last time I played an AC game was a couple of years ago, with AC III. Even so, I kind of both love and hate Odyssey. I think that this is the best AC game up to date and that they had really improved upon the franchise after a couple of disastrous titles. While playing this game I am constantly reminded about open-world games and RPG's. I think this is a good thing and an improvement, however, it also diminishes the identity of what an AC game should represent.

Story

The story is really good but it is held back by the grind. Without going into spoilers, you start with a story that really moves forward and introduces to you interesting characters that are always behaving according to their belief. It's one of those stories in which you always want to learn a little more before ending your current gaming session but it has a fatal flaw, it becomes stale. At some point you will notice that the story gets "stuck" and all you are really doing is a bunch of side quest that is disguised as main story quest and this is a bummer because you will do this for at least 10 hours in a row before moving on to the next part of it. Maybe even more if you spend too much time in actual side quests.

Some Notes

The game is optimized very poorly. Like seriously badly. You are going to need a high specs machine in order to reach those 60 fps. Even so, medium specs can opt to run it at 30 FPS caps at is still a very enjoyable experience, at least at the beginning.

The grind is huge and can become quite tiresome. Ubisoft really wants to make you spend more money in this game with what they call "time savers" which are basically bonuses that make your progression faster but even with those bonuses it will still be a long journey of grind and repetitive action. The player will follow the same route over and over again: Accept quest, kill a bunch of bad guys (sometimes even good guys), kill a bunch of mercenaries that had come for your head, kill a bunch of reinforcements, kill some captains, run back to quest giver, get rewarded and accept the next quest. This grind is not for the faint of heart.

Gameplay

Gameplay-wise the game adopts a more RPG style in which the player acquires weapons and equipment which have a level attached to them. I don't like this. While one can upgrade their equipment in order to make it upscale to your current level, that takes an insane amount of resources and I am not talking about money. I am talking about wood, stones, gems, and hides. The amount you need to just upgrade one piece of equipment is enough to keep you playing for 2 hours before you are able to upgrade and those are 2 hours of just searching for the materials.

As such, the armor and weapons will become obsolete very fast. The player will need to change their equipment and hope that they get their weapon of preference or else they will be stuck with something they might not truly enjoy. I really tried to stick to my favorite equipment but is just not viable and also would require for me to sacrifice a bunch of time and sweat just to get them to my current level.

Combat is the best in the series. Finally, an AC game in which you can't one-shot everyone nor are you a god with infinite parry. While parry does stick as a core mechanic, enemies now have attacks that not only you cannot parry, but also are ferocious and fast. Each enemy has their own resistances and weakness as well as perks like having a companion animal or making extra damage when their HP is low. I particularly hate the one in which they unleash fire explosions since it can kill you easily but it nevertheless it was still fun to beat.


Sum Up

+ The story is really good.
+ Combat has more depth and has been improved by a large margin.
+ Looks beautiful in some parts, in particular oceans and skies.
+ Voice acting is great, protagonist and antagonist perform spectacularly.
+ Offers the player a wide arrange of options with 3 different skills trees.
+ While there a bunch of micro-transactions, it is still a high-quality game.

- The game requires a lot of grinding on the player part.
- The story gets stuck and doesn't move forward for 2-3 chapters(10-15 hours)
- Equipment level is an issue and makes it frustrating to keep legendary sets.
- Very poorly optimized and also presents a couple of immersion breaking glitches.
- Requires a lot of time and compromise in order to beat, can become tedious to continue at times.
- It gets very repetitive in some instances, with players repeating the same loop for hours.
- Combat is improved but at the same time, assassination and parkour are diminished.
- Sometimes objects will become blurry (even with the depth of field turned off) and sometimes they will even become pixel art.


Conclusion

Odyssey presents a major improvement to the series at the cost of sacrificing a lot of aspects that were in previous games and a large part of what an AC game should strive to be. I like the graphics, voice actors, combat, story, open world and the RPG feeling it has to it but I also dislike the assassination and parkour being diminished, the grind, the sudden halt in the story, the poor optimization and the amount of effort that is put into making the player spend extra money in the game.

If you like AC, get it. Even if you don't, consider getting it if you like open world games and have a bunch of time to play/can focus on a single game for a long while. I consider this to be the best game of AC that has ever been released and despite all of its flaws, healthy addition to the franchise.

For me, this is a serious contender for GOTY! Ubisoft has been honing their formula over the years and this game really hit my sweat spot.

Ancient Greece really comes alive in this game, and it is beautiful; you could spend the rest of your days just taking photos in-game. The open world is huge but doesn't feel overwhelmingly busy like in all previous Ubi games; it's almost manageable this time, and most locations feel fresh and not repetitive. This might be the first Ubi game I ever finished; on all the others I keep getting distracted with exploring the open world and obsessively completing its activities until I get bored and burned out well before the story wraps up.

I loved the story too but it's far from perfect. Does anybody still care about the modern day setting and crazy conspiracies? It's boring and pointless at this point, but at least it's also mercifully brief. Near the end, the story also takes a sci-fi detour involving aliens and their technology and whatnot. Dudes! Ancient Greece! What could possibly be more interesting than exploring Ancient Greece? Don't ruin it.

The gameplay is very finely tuned here and it's a blast; it really feels like you're in a sandbox and can approach problems however you want. I love the RPG detour the series has taken lately, and it's pretty cool to go through your loot and gear up and skill up to play to your strengths. All in all, a great game, and a towering achievement!

Not Recommended
12.4 hrs on record
Posted: 13 October, 2018
I feel like I should like this game. On the surface, it seems to have all of the qualities of a good third-person action rpg. It ticks all of the checkboxes for a decent Assassin's Creed. But I just don't. I can't help but feel like this game is a mix of mechanics that are all about 80% complete, and the narrative is just barely passable with tons of stilted dialogue and character interactions.

For example, the fight with the Cyclops (a local crime boss with only one eye) was some of the most confusing and ham-fisted gameplay I've experienced all year. (minor spoilers follow) I am told that the Cyclops and his men have docked on a nearby peninsula, so I scout the area out with my magical pet eagle. It looks like a harbor swarming with guards and surrounded by cliffs. I determine that an approach from the cliffs near where the Cyclops is hanging out would be the safest and most effecient for assassinating him. As I am crawling along a waterfall outside the walls, I suddenly get thrown into a cutscene.

The camera pans and reveals Cyclops drowning some guy because he called him 'Cyclops', which is apparently a name he does not like. That's when Kassandra, my character, casually strolls into the scene (when tf did she get over the walls?) and reveals the obsidian false eye that she stole from him (which was itself a stupid idea that I couldn't really object to). She then takes the eye and shoves it into a nearby goat's â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and tells the Cyclops to chase after it. No joke. She actually did that.

The game then drops me right in front of the Cyclops and all of his still living guards, and I proceed to run around like a lunatic trying my best to not die while slowly chipping away at their numbers. Eventually I succomb to the sheer number of guards and their arrows, but not before a particularly stupid moment in which Kassandra grabs a zipline instead of a ledge and proceeds to zoom to another part of the harbor with even more guards.

I feel like that whole series of events exemplifies why I dislike this game. It tries so hard to be multiple things, and ultimately fails to be good at any of them. I mean, in a game called 'Assassin's Creed', I am unable to simply sneak up and assinate a guy because the game needs to get in its own way and show a cutscene where my character shoves an obsidian eye up a goat's ass. Combine moments like that with a clunky parkour system so full of context sensitivity that your character will often do things you don't want them to do, a derpy bounty hunter system in which the AI will sometimes glitch out and just stay in one place until it suddenly teleports across multiple islands to join one of your fights already in progress, and a mish-mash of rpg mechanics, some of which mean you must get your arbitrary stats higher that the other guy's arbitrary stats before you can actually kill him when you sneak up and 'assassinate' him. In an Assassin's Creed game. And that's by no means an exhuastive list.

Add in all the microtransaction stuff too. Anyone remember when your single player games didn't have 3 ads on the main menu trying to entice you to buying stuff off their store, or XP boosts that give the developers a financial incentive to make the grind more tedious? All of these things together make me wish I could refund this game and buy it again when it is 50% off. Or just play the countless better games out there that actually have a cohesive design.

And that's not to say I don't understand why people are enjoying this game. Despite all of the above, this game can be fun and it's packed with content. I just wish Ubisoft would drop the AC brand, make a new IP, and design the full-blown historical rpg from the ground up that they so obviously want to make. The AC brand should then be refocused on the whole 'assassin' part of the name and become more like a medieval Hitman, rather than a watered down Witcher that is confused as to what kind of game it wants to be.

250 hours into the game in my first playthrough, finish everything including the dlc and you still wonder why I give a negative review?

I would begin with main quest. Main quest is poorly written and require dlc to fully understand what's going on. If you buy standard that doesn't include dlc, be ready to get confused or feels like something is missing. It would be a spoiler to mention it, so I would leave it at that.

What about side quest? Side quest is basically a mix of good and nightmare. Seems like multiple writer are hired by ubisoft to work on the story but only a few stand out such as quest related to Alkibiades. Whoever do a job portray and wrote the side quest related to Alkibiades definitely deserves a thumb up. But sadly to said, majority of the side quest feel half ass to even enjoy it.

If you buy and play this game, avoid doing contract. Contract a repetitive quest to grind exp and resources. What you need to do is accept the quest but only do it if you are near the quest location.



Next is the gear along with the resources and cost upgrade. This is absolutely a nightmare and is very lacking in balance. Cost of upgrade is particularly insane for gear especially for legendary and epic. What makes it more ironic is that despite legendary being considered the highest tier, it still perform worst than epic. This is mainly because a full set of legendary armor would have 16 engraving in comparison to epic which can have up to 20.

If you are playing at difficulty below hard or default scaling, gear isn't on par with your level won't be much of a problem. However, hard difficulty with heavy scaling means that your gear must always be on same level with you or otherwise it won't be able to deal sufficient damage to kill the enemy. This is due to the enemy level being scaled on the same par with you. The effect is very notorious as soon as your gear is 3 level below your current level.

Upgrading is a very costly process that a single piece of equipment can cost up to 200k and a gargantuan amount of resources just for an increased of 10 level for legendary gear. Sure, there is a capped limit on the cost but it still insane. At 250 hours, I could barely grind enough to upgrade 8-15 pieces of my legendary gear to my current level.

You might say the point of rpg is not to have every gear fully upgrade. I agree with that, but if I want to try different weapon and have fun with it, it become tedious that I might as well skipped it.

The game also have serious problem with copy and paste. You visit 1 tomb, you generally already visit all of it. Tomb is boring and can be very large, making you waste time exploring it. There is only spike trap and snake. No puzzle, nothing at all.... Cannot even recall 1 tomb that is being totally different or unique.

The problem with this game is that Ubisoft overextend the effort in details particularly historial site which they done well. But in the process, they make gameplay related area being copy and paste cause it is faster and less time consuming. Those historial site are pleasing to watch in the eye of beholder but they hold little to no values to the gameplay and storyline itself.

As for riddle such as Ostraka. They are fun but they can also be a pain in the ass to solve without looking into google due to the inaccuracy of the description. The riddle say it was underneath the bridge? Good luck looking down the bridge, it isn't even close to the bridge itself. Riddle say "I am at where the statue finger point at".. Hell no, not even close to where the statue is pointing.

It frustrate me to no end due to how inaccurate the description was, way too off the point.

And then you have up to 5 profile for equipment. Fun right? Until you decided to play jack of all trade build that can be assassin, warrior or hunter then the pain start begin. If you wanted to switch to others, you basically need to go to inventory menu to switch your profile. How fun it was to switch profile during combat, might as well just stick to 1 style of playing.

Cost of the profile is not cheap either and as I mention, cost of upgrade gear is pricely as well. 250 hours into the game and I only have a full set of gear for 3 profile.

People say this game got plenty of bug, here is some that I gonna list out.

Hopefully ubisoft stop making it way too grindy just to force people to buy from microtransaction shop.

Assassinâ€™s Creed Odyssey is the second opus happening in ancient history. You will be able to play as Alexios or Kassandra with for the very first time in the history of the franchise, the opportunity to decide your characters actions and fate through the troubled times of the Peloponnesian war and play a significant role in the fight for the domination of either Sparta or Athens.

Developed and published by Ubisoft, Odyssey, with the marvelous environment, scenery, gameplay, and spotless mechanics sets an entirely new level for Assassinâ€™s Creed and is probably one of the best RPG we got since the Witcher III.

+ Pros	- Cons
Graphics
Story arclines
Lots of content
Exploration
Complete immersion	Camera issues
Collision issues

9.5/10

Immersion & Questing

Assassinâ€™s Creed Odyssey is taking us through a war-torn Greece as a misthios, a man-for-hire, who is searching for answers (cue family drama) and adventures. Through multiple story arcs, each more interesting than the other is added a spectacular amount of side quests that are intricated somehow in the decisions you made.

Indeed, Odyssey emphasized dialogues and choices. Some of them can have a drastic impact on the story, others quest and how people react around you. Based on your previous decisions, NPCs are going to be referencing your previous actions and can potentially cut some quests from your storylines.

The results of this are two folds: with so many different endings and choices, there is a replayability value rarely seen in an Assassinâ€™s Creed game and it all manages to intricate your actions into the different story arcs and create an incredibly immersive universe based around your vision of your character.

Overall, Odyssey is extremely rich in content. The integration of the side quests within the main story makes it so that you will want to do more of them! We calculated that a good 60 to 70 hours can be put in the game without finishing it. You will still have plenty of work to do.

Graphics & Exploration

We played the game on Nightmare difficulty with exploration mode, the latter is a nice touch by Ubisoft because you must search for the objectives and use the skill set Ikaros, your eagle possesses to locate them and not just mindlessly go after them. These two elements together made it so that some fights and activities had to be planned in order not to die a stupid death.

Exploring the game in this beautiful reconstruction of ancient Greece unlocks little excerpts of the history behind buildings, characters and other historical elements in this country that breathe and bleeds history. A real plus for any history nerds.

Letâ€™s also mention the fact that there are no loading times between the different maps, sea, mountains or anything at all. Itâ€™s a feat considering the graphics and the fact that Greece is exceptionally vast in this game.

Indeed, through exploration, you can easily witness how everything is wonderfully tied up together. Graphically, the game is terrific, with spectacular scenery and a great photo mode, mechanics are fluid, it is the kind of technical prowess that we would expect from Ubisoft.

The scenery is just utterly gorgeous from the open sea to the beautiful forests, islands, cities and their decorations, Odyssey is a treat for the eye. Animations are superb, you can easily sense how everyone feels about whatever they are saying and how they are feeling.

Gameplay & Combat

The game is dependent to your level, you canâ€™t just wander (you can) into a zone and expect to be just fine. A few level differences mean death most of the time. Leveling is fair, it will get slower the higher your level is, but I never felt like I had to grind for levels or anything. It all happened as I was playing.

Drawing inspirations from quite a few RPGs, the skill tree is built around your game style. You have the freedom to develop it the way you want to through three main choices: Hunter (ranged), Warrior (melee) and Assassin (stealth). You can most probably mix â€˜em up as I did with a Warrior-Assassin build.

Your equipment needs to be carefully thought out and the same goes out for the bonus you are engraving within your weapons and armors. Also, fashion hunters: five pieces of equipment are going to change your in-game appearance.

Fighting in this game revolves around dodging and counter-attacking with light and heavy attacks (at least in nightmare difficulty). Mechanics are fluid, fights are challenging, but the biggest down part is that you are limited to 4 active skills from the three treelines available. This is extremely limiting, and I stopped counting the times I had to press start mid-fight to change the bounded skills to something that could be useful in this specific fight and adapt the strategy Alexios (or Kassandra) was doing to sometimes, survive. This specific issue was for me game-breaking, immersion-breaking and plain annoying.

Odyssey gives the player a vast array of choices as of which weapons they are going to use, axes, bows, daggers, maces, staves, spears and swords all have their pros and cons and are just different enough to be meaningful and give a different in-game experience.

Assassinâ€™s Creed Odyssey is also bringing back naval fights and navigation from the depths of Black flag and Rogue. While not a lot of things changed besides making your ship upgradeable, is the fact that you can now have lieutenants on your ship that gives a passive bonus. While it is not innovative, it is the best Naval fights weâ€™ve ever seen in an Assassinâ€™s Creed.

Finally, a system of mercenaries very similar to what we can find in Shadow of War is proposed, based on the illegal actions you do throughout the game, your bounty will raise, said mercenaries will then hunt for you and try to kill you. Killing them instead, induce a fun leaderboard of mercenaries, that you can climb for rewards. This is entirely optional, you can ignore this and while it is just a plus to the game, it adds a great atmosphere around it, with more immersion and some more challenging fights.

There is also an entire pan of gameplay revolving around conquering a region. Just like Shadow of War once again, you will need to conquer or defend a plot of land for either Sparta or Athens by killing local leaders, pillaging and lowering the enemy presence in the area.

Very few bugs

While everything in the game seems to be working flawlessly, the lock-on system can give you some trouble maneuvering the camera when fighting enemies in a small space. Finally, the game didnâ€™t have a game breaking bug once during my run and for such a game it is quite incredible. Odyssey suffers from a lot of collision issues though.

Conclusion

Odysseyâ€™s world is by far the biggest, most gorgeous and with the most content of the franchise. It feels like Ubisoft took what was best in recent gaming, made it their own and delivered the best Assassinâ€™s Creed of the franchise history. With marvelous environment, scenery, gameplay and spotless mechanics, Odyssey sets an entirely new level for Assassinâ€™s Creed and is probably one of the best RPG we got since the Witcher III.

There are performance issues, this game caps out at around 50 fps, its dips down to around 40 and up to 60 but average is 50 which is still ok for me, but only gets low when the areas are clutter f*cked with objects. There is mad screen tearing too but I found a fix, if running Nvidia card go to Nvidia Control Panel, find Vertical Sync, turn it ON, force that sh*t!! Restart computer, run the game, turn on in-game vsync, set in-game fps to 60 cause thats all your going to get lol. After that she's golden ;D Runs most of the time smooth and looks fantastic. More bullsh*t I have the super low sound voice bug but only in cutscenes, I've tried many fixes nothing works, just have to wait on Ubisoft to fix that - but for me I'm all about exploration, rpg elements, and combat, so subtitles are fine - do my own voice impressions hah. But still it is now January you guys should have this fixed by now, so yes this could actually kill the game for a lot of people, but not me ;P

Amazing game with some bullsh*t to be fixed, but I still will crush this game till theres nothing left to play ;P But on the another note is better to wait for a sale like me, winter sale was 50% off ;D

Recommended
282.8 hrs on record
Posted: 11 March
A Ticket to Ancient Greece Tour!
Assassin's Creed (AC) Odyssey is nothing close to an AC game, eventhough it somehow(!?) carries the bound with the series' lore. It's more of an open world rpg within ancient Greece. They started this type of approach with Origins continued (& improved) with Odyssey (then Valhalla etc.), and it works surprisingly well for the players that enjoys this genre!

I started this game on a "free weekend" promotion, and I grab the full game (with season pass) in the end of it. Not sure if it was due to;
well made ancient greece athmosphere (with a big war between greek and spartans on the side) or
Cool side characters (including famous philosophers, warriors, demi-gods and more) & quests or
the blend between real and mythology or
freedom to approach the combat (either brawler or assassin way) or
the troll legendary oiled bath rope I found from a random blacksmith (that gives me 500%+ damage if my character covered with black oil which isn't even in game)!
but something kept me intrigued and attached to the game. I must admit I wasn't big fan of the sea battles, but upgrading my ship, adding characteristic captains and crews to it, and even just traveling on the water with beautiful view was satisfying enough. (Eventually you become boss of the sea and enjoy destroying those legend ships that bullied you early on.) Also, AI was little janky and predictable, but it wasn't bad enough to ruin experience. That being said, it has cool battles, some nature interactions such as predators hunting (don't expect national geographic experience, they just kill) and attacking to people around.

I highly recommend you to buy the package with season pass on (that gives free copy of AC 3!?) since both of the DLCs are amazing (even exemplary to others about how to make a DLC), and you get access to cool skills early on. I consider myself lucky that I delayed my completion long enough to catch latest crossover content they added. It was also worth playing!

There are much more to tell and much hints to give such as;
> press assassinate button while you holding your eagle to pet it,
> paralyzing arrows works with bow skills in case you wanna recruit / tame,
> hold mount button to whistle that draws enemy,
> Spartan kick may provide amusing moments,
> you can parry arrows,
> weapon bonuses on secondary weapon slot applies to both... the list goes on and on but I'll let you discover 'em ^^

As verdict, if you are looking for an old school AC game stay away! However, if you are looking for a nice open world rpg set in the Ancient Greece with both gorgeous historical and mythical sceneries (that has some AC elements), then what are you waiting for?!

PS. You have to play this game by connecting to your Ubisoft account. So, make an account and download their launcher from here[ubisoftconnect.com] before you start playing for less headache!

Not Recommended
59.6 hrs on record
Posted: 28 September, 2019
AC:O is a game full of conflict, not only in its story.
The game offers one of the most gorgeous views you'll see for quite some time. On top of that is the game well optimized and runs quite well on older hardware. The gameplay is well done and an improvement over for example The Witcher 3. They improved most of what the other games offered. Despite all of this high praise I can't recommend this game.
While it looks stunning, most places seem copy pasted with older assets and you soon realize that the impressive temples are all the same. Gameplay is largely improved over other AC games but the endless copy pasted question marks on the map offer little variety. You always infiltrate the same stronghold, encampment and warehouse. Soon the great fighting mechanics seem dull as the enemies are just damage absorbing sponges and if you dont skill and equip into the assassination tree you soon can't kill even a topless guy silently. Also you yourself become incredibly tanky later on making fights a slog for both sides. So they implemented fire and poison that will melt your life in no time to counteract your armor. The story starts of strong and gets good again in the later parts of the game but the midgame is a total slog. After 30 hours I could not take it anymore and had to quit. Months passed before I came back for a round 2. I finished chapter after chapter but once I reached a later part of the game I asked myself: Am I having fun playing this game?
I did not.
Its grindy (even after the patches),its repetitive and just a massive slog that you have to fight through to reach its ending(s).
Unless you really like doing task after task after task of the same stuff with no end in sight, it might be a game for you.
But I have too many other enjoyable games to waste my time on this, just to see the credits.

Not Recommended
188.1 hrs on record
Posted: 1 May, 2020
Assassin's Creed Odyssey has a very confused identity. They go through great lengths to recreate incredible scenes from ancient Greece, and then they undercut the whole thing with cheap jokes, references, and modern-day politics. Some of the gameplay is fun, and some of the story moments are cool, but there's too much filler. Also, for an RPG, hardly any of your choices actually matter. Almost all of your decisions lead to the exact same dialogue, and the exact same results.

Also, the story is unfinished. You conclude nothing by the end, and are expected to buy the DLC if you actually want the story to lead anywhere. Very unsatisfying conclusion.

Not Recommended
65.9 hrs on record
Posted: 1 May, 2020
This is not a reaction to Valhalla going to Epic â€” Ubisoft has been doing that for a while. And I'd never fault a company for trying to make money, that IS, what they're in business to do. That being said, I've felt for a long time that Odyssey was missing something â€” I don't know what that something is, but I know I don't want to look for it any more.

If you don't want to read this whole thing â€” It says this: Origins is better, Odyssey seems to have missed the boat.

Origins has purpose, it's the first game to completely turn the series into a new direction and is a much better setting for a series that is essentially baked in conspiracy theories of history. Odyssey seems to taken 'sandbox' to heart and opened an entire world to explore. And to be fair, there is a TON to do, but it's all trite, banal and uninspired.

Ancient Egypt is rife with mystery. The delusional sense of paranoia that inspired the great pyramids to be created that extends into real life modern day with pyramids and triangles being imagery of the Illuminati. There is no telling how many stories could be told within that framework. Ancient Greece less so, not to mention all the other games that use the Greek mythos to provide a setting. In direct comparison, the ones set in Egypt are few and far between.

Everything you do is meaningless.
Spartan vs Athenian Conquest battles are pointless. You can not only repeat them in the same region, but you can change sides â€” this has no effect on the state of the world. They are essentially loot grind missions. I didn't touch on this before, but even if you're a completionist and simply need to clear all the things on the map â€” I cannot tell you the number of times I went into an outpost, killed the leaders and then had new leaders ready to replace them before I was done looting the place! They didn't even give me the satisfaction of having an empty outpost after killing everyone for a single minute!

The combat is less interesting â€” you are forced to use the broken spear with all weapon sets short of using a two handed weapon. Even stealth kills are less satisfying â€” regardless of whether you play as Kassandra or Alexios, you have to use the broken spear. (It that has significance to the narrative.) The spear glides through people in the animations and feels as though there is no resistance to their body. This is morbid, but you kill people in the game, that's what it's about. And when your actions don't feel significant it just adds to the feeling that your presence means nothing.

The mercenary system is as meaningless as the Nemesis system from â€œShadow of... â€œâ€” they come and go without much fanfare. You kill 'em or you don't. They come after you like police in GTA. They go away. Nothing changes. You kill the next one that takes their place. You'll gain prowess and will be placed into higher tier rankings of the mercenary system but this also has little meaning.

You can romance numerous people, which is cool. But aside from an initial quest, or in some cases, a set of quests, there is no significance to becoming a partner with them. Effectively making them one night stands. Which again, makes your presence feel trivial.

Kassandra has no agency of her own.
Juxtaposed to Bayak, a character, a being that has their own goals â€” Kassandra (or Alexios) bends to your will in every dialogue. Which is great! But what's the significance of Kassandra? Why not have a custom character? Let me truly be a proper 'Misthios'. It makes no sense. To me, it feels like Ubisoft took the core gameplay of Origins and stuck it in one of the most overused settings in games. Changing little beyond adrenaline being used for abilities and adding dialogue choices. (That in the large swathe of things, have negligible changes outside the immediate situation.)

There is no reason to hold extra types of weapons. Hunter, predator, warrior bows have been resigned to abilities that are activated with any bow provided you've enough adrenaline.

Skull & Bones.
Without a doubt the biggest improvement is the Adrestia. Allowing ship customization with crew management and assignment of leaders. Upgrades for hull armor and weapons from raw materials. All that stuff is great and I've no reason to see why those ideas won't be expanded upon in the upcoming Skull & Bones.

This part contains story spoilers:  â€” My point is that when you're playing as a character in a world, they should care about something, anything at all. And they don't. There aren't even skill checks for dialogue choices, you can just choose whatever dialogue option you want and it happens. So leveling and role playing aspects are also limited.

THE GIST:
They completely changed Assassin's Creed with Origins. With Odyssey, I feel like they built a shell of a game and stuck a bunch of placeholders in it. Then ran out of time and said, screw it, let other people make custom quests.

I think Odyssey is a stepping stone, a sort of testing ground for something else that doesn't exist yet. However, I don't think it's a great game. Not even really a good one. An interesting one, perhaps.

In all honesty, I'd prefer that Ubisoft let Assassin's Creed take a few development cycles off.

If you've read this far, consider following my curation â€” Station Argus

If you don't agree, that's fine. I'm aware I'm going against the grain. But I find little value in this as an overall product.

My AC: Origins review here.
