Before I begin; yes, the game is a bit grindy.

When I first booted the game, I was truely hyped up. I pre-ordered the gold edition just to play 3 days earlier because I just couldn't wait (I'll be hated for this, but AC is the only series I actually pre-order).

Upon first boot, I noticed some stuff I've seen before. They re-used assets from origins. You won't truely notice unless you've been playing origins a lot beforehand. The UI and some other aspects also feel the same as origins. Some may say it was due to the games being developed alongside each-other, however that's not an excuse. They could've at-least added some different graphics to some elements, or changed the looks of some stuff slightly; yet they did not.

I picked Kassandra as my main protagonist. The first few quests where you meet markos, and do quests for him didn't really exite me, and I sort-off disgusted the voice acting on that guy as well. However once you're done with him, the quests and voice acting get better.

The story has me hooked and the gameplay is really nice so far.

Decisions in quests... They are there, but for most side quests you don't really feel any impact. Example the plague quest:


The conquest system... It's nice and rewarding, but you don't really ever side with either the athens or the spartans. You're just there and you can decide who to help. You can't "pick" a faction so that they turn friendly towards you or give you any rpg like benefits. You just help, get rewarded, the winner takes control over the area and you walk off like usual. There's no reputation to build there. It has so much potential but it's just not done very well. Maybe future patches change this.

Sailing? One word; â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ yeah. I'm in love with the open seas. Occasionally I come across a sunken temple, or hidden treasures. I can't explain how nice it is, although sometimes buggy when boarding ships. And when you board a ship while his friends are still around, they're like:" Oh hey the enemy is boarding one of our boats, let's wait for the commander to kill our friends and attack them again once they're done looting!" I know it makes sense from a game designs point of view, because otherwise you wouldn't have enough time to loot a ship.


Cultists and mercenaries... I love this mechanic. The mercenaries are a pain unless you play it smart and take out the person that put the bounty on you. If you got no bounty, you'll see known mercenaries on the map but they won't do anything to you. You can still take them out if you wish.

Uncovering cultists is a fun aspect as well. You need to find clues, and once you have enough, you may uncover a cultist and hunt them down. Rewards varie but it's mostly legendary gear.

All in all, I'll give it a 8.5/10 because it does so much good, but there's still room for improvement. It's worth your money.

I'll most likely update this after some time and I did more stuff, but for now this is my review :>

Recommended
95.5 hrs on record
Posted: 2 May, 2020
Don't care for the Assassin's Creed formula? Like open-world RPGs and exploration? Interested in Greek culture and mythology? Then you'll enjoy this game.

That being said it isn't perfect. I've encounter many minor visual/animation bugs during my 90 hours of play. Nothing serious, but it can be immersion breaking. The lack of a serious relationship system is a little annoying as well - you just sorta sleep around and never settle down.

The biggest complaint I see is with the microtransactions. My feeling on the matter is that if you are comfortable and familiar with playing open-world RPGs then you won't even consider using them and they won't be an issue. This was the experience I had and I never thought they were necessary and therefore not an issue. HOWEVER: if you don't typically play these sorts of RPGs and are coming in as a fan of the Assassin's Creed series, then these microtransactions seem like an easy solution to having to play for a extended period of time. Personally, I don't think microtransactions should be in any singleplayer experience, but I also believe you can easily avoid these if you just play all the game has to offer including exploration, side missions, and mini-boss battles. If you participate in all of that, you should level up naturally.

All-in-all, a fun but flawed experience. Interested to see where they take the series in the future.

Recommended
231.3 hrs on record
Posted: 9 July, 2020
I finally finished AC Odyssey and all its DLCs, so it's time to write a (spoiler-free!) review.
I'd heard mixed things about this game, so I was reluctant to play it at first. Lucky for me, I got a taste during its free weekend a few months ago and immediately got hooked. I got the Ultimate Edition on sale. 230 hours later, here's all you need to know about Odyssey. In order: Story and Quests, World and Graphics, Gameplay and Combat, DLCs and what edition you should get.

Story and Quests

Odyssey is set in Ancient Greece during the Peloponnesian War, a conflict between the city-states of Sparta and Athens. You play as an ex-Spartan, exiled from their home due to breaking the national law as a child. Separated from your family, you grow up on the island of Kephallonia and are raised to be a misthios or mercenary. You eventually leave to explore the rest of the Greek world and search for your family, uncovering a great conspiracy. You can choose between a male or female character, but this choice will not affect your opportunities or the way you are treated in the game.

The campaign will give you roughly 80 hours of content. I personally found Odyssey's storyline to be really interesting - it didn't have the annoying anger and vengeance of earlier AC titles and I think it is really well-paced. You meet and befriend a variety of characters including famous historical figures like Socrates, Pericles, Aristophanes, Euripides, Lysander and so on. Something I quite liked is that these characters have lines which are actual, real-life quotes, and any ancient history nerd like me will be ecstatic over this. I admit that I predicted many of the major plot-twists so they aren't exactly revolutionary, but this didn't take away from my experience. What I was really surprised about is that your choices actually really affect the story - it's not at all linear! I found that this really added to immersion, and the game also has its fair share of moral dilemmas.

Odyssey is absolutely full of side quests and bounties. Many of them are entertaining and there is a good range from short to long side missions. Unfortunately, Ubisoft remains as per usual pretty formulaic and many missions are fetch quests or based only on killing someone/something. Despite this, it's still pretty easy to find enjoyment in completing them.

World and Graphics

The graphics in Odyssey are completely mesmerising. You could honestly buy the game just to explore and take screenshots and it would probably be worth it. The game has a great photo mode, too. As far as I know, you don't need incredibly high specs for it to look very pretty either; I played on mostly medium settings and was very impressed.

Content-wise, the world has an overwhelming amount of locations to complete, each with its own set of objectives. Anyone who completes the game 100% deserves to be called a demigod. The world is massive, with tons of regions to explore. There's a variety of location types, ranging from military camps to caves and forts. Generally, there's always something to do.

When it comes to historical accuracy, I was actually pretty impressed. I think Ubisoft really did make an effort to research the time period and the game is full of cool details. For example, the sea shanties are all original Greek poems from 2+ millennia ago. There are also historical locations with extra info, but this is only accessible on the map and I actually wasn't aware of this function until halfway through the game because it's not emphasised at all. The main point of inaccuracy I can point out is that there is a bit too much equality for the time period (which was very, very sexist and racist)... but hey, it's historical fiction for a reason.

Gameplay and Combat

The main thing to say here is that Odyssey isn't really an Assassin's Creed game. There are a variety of difficulty levels to choose from, but there is far less emphasis on stealth than in previous titles. A big criticism from many is that the one-shot assassination kill mechanic is NOT in the game, and that is honestly kind of annoying. You can still choose to play stealthily, of course, but Odyssey is not a stealth-based game. Instead of the Eagle Vision sixth sense, you have an eagle that you can take control of to scout locations.

However, Odyssey is a brilliant historical RPG in every other sense. There are 3 skill trees which you can upgrade as you level up, which all have cool and useful abilities to diversify and customise your gameplay. The melee combat is really fun and you can choose between a variety of weapon types like daggers, spears and staffs alongside a bow. All weapons and armour have different perks and come in different levels of rarity. This gives you the freedom to choose your playstyle.

There are also other cool combat mechanics. You get to command your own ship (which you can upgrade throughout the game) and engage in naval combat. There are other mercenaries who can be hired to kill you when you commit illegal actions; this mechanic is comparable to Shadow of Mordor's nemesis system. There are bosses from a variety of Greek myths and legends, including legendary animals. There are also conquest battles where you can join the fight between Athenian and Spartan forces, though participation unfortunately has no real effect on the development of the war plot or how your character is treated by NPCs.

As a side note, your ship, weapons and armour are all visually customizable. Though this isn't major, I think it adds to the aesthetics of the game and is nice to have.

Secrets of Greece DLC

This DLC is included in the season pass. Unfortunately, there isn't much to say about it. It basically adds a few more normal side quests, which are all fairly standard.

Legacy of the First Blade DLC

This DLC is split up into 3 chapters which are all included in the season pass or can be bought separately. I quite liked this DLC - it has an interesting story and builds on existing mechanics. It gives you a lot to do in regions that are otherwise lacking in quest content. It also adds enemies, including a ton of new bosses and cool new enemy types with new designs. The DLC also adds 3 new abilities alongside a new ship function, all of which I personally thought were quite useful and fun.

The Legacy of the First Blade DLC is great for AC lore fans as it explores the origins of the Templar/Assassin divide. It has some memorable characters and is overall quite enjoyable, but I wouldn't say it blew me away.

Fate of Atlantis DLC

This DLC is also split into 3 chapters which are included in the season pass or can be bought separately. I have to say, I LOVED this DLC. It has a brilliant story with absolute tons to do, exploring new AC lore and adding a fantasy element to the game. It adds 3 new worlds to explore, which are all full of unique locations and have distinct designs and charm. I was really impressed with each of the worlds. The DLC also adds HEAPS of gameplay extensions, allowing you to unlock ability "enhancements" (optional modifications for skills) that can really change how you play and it gives you lots of easily gained ability points. There are really interesting new enemy types and a lot of new gear. The DLC is mythology-centered and you get to meet interesting figures like Adonis and fight heroes like Herakles and Achilles.

The Fate of Atlantis is an expansion I'd recommend to all players. It adds tons of new content and is really impressive.

Conclusion

Rating: 8/10

I recommend the Gold Edition. Deluxe/Ultimate just come with a bit of extra customisation items and boosters. I really liked this game, but know what you're buying: it's a fantastic historical RPG, but not what you'd expect from an AC stealth-based game. It can be repetitive but it has a gorgeous world with hours of content.

Not Recommended
83.7 hrs on record
Posted: 9 November, 2019
It pains me to not be able to recommend this game

TL; DR:
AC Odyssey is gorgeous, has entertaining combat, and can easily keep you busy for over 100 hours with all there is to do in the enormous and lovingly crafted open world. This game is absolutely hamstrung by a story that falls apart a quarter of the way through due to the devs' decision to try to make a branching narrative that can be engaged with at any point during your playthrough, and player confidence is destroyed by questionable microtransactions.

Assassin's Creed Odyssey is one of the better games I've played in years. On paper, this game sounds like it should be in the running for best game of the last decade, as it features a HUGE and meticulously detailed open world with breathtaking sights and places to discover, a branching narrative with meaningful choices that does not impede the player's ability to engage with the world however they like, fully voiced interactions with NPCs amounting to thousands of lines of recorded dialogue, and the freedom to craft a play style that the player enjoys and can change at any time consequence free. The unfortunate reality of AC Odyssey's situation, however, is that the game breaks down beyond the first 15 hours into a barely coherent slough through endless quests, useless gear, and a story that, at best, makes no sense, and at worst, is hilariously poorly written.

To understand why the rest of the game is so bad, we need to understand what makes the first 25% of the game so good. As an overarching statement, the combat in this game is fun and satisfying to master. If you are coming from older AC titles, then you will need to throw most of your previous knowledge about combat and button mapping out the window. The new combat system is great once you get used to it, and that contributed heavily to my desire to see the story through to the end. The opening section introduces you masterfully to the core mechanics of the game by having you immediately make decisions that effect the future, explore points of interest on the map, and tackle problems in the ways you deem are best. Kephallonia, the starting island, benefits greatly from not having to be relevant for the rest of the game. You are free to explore the emotional and engaging backstory of the main character while simultaneously forging your own path forward, all the while uncovering the mysteries of your childhood.

After Kephallonia you will have essentially graduated from the tutorial section of the game and be guided by the story to Phokis. The events that take place here are some of the best in the game. In Phokis you will make unlikely allies, be introduced to the larger central narrative threads, and make a few weighty decisions that will have a lasting effect on your game, and that resolve plots opened up on Kephallonia. Exploring Phokis will also reward you with engaging side quests and beautiful scenery. By the time you end your journey in Phokis you will have had a taste of everything the game has to offer, from ship combat and large-scale warfare to espionage and betrayal. All the great moments up to this point are facilitated by the strong and mostly linear story gently guiding you from plot point to plot point. Beyond Phokis, however, is where the game loosens up and allows you to explore the open world. Unfortunately, this is also when ACO begins to decline in quality. Once the foundation of the linear story is lost, most everything that happens starts to seem much more ambiguous and manic.

By the time you get to Athens, it seems all semblance of a realistic story is thrown out the window and characters from the past start to show up inexplicably. You are introduced to cavalcade of famous figures from Greek history, which is no departure for the Assassin's Creed franchise, however having all of the characters that you will befriend be people who you'd know from high school history class makes the characters introduced for the sake of the story, I.E. the expendable characters, really very obvious. That prior point is a minor complaint, as there are some pretty significant (and painfully stupid) subversions of those expectations later on in the game, but some of the foreshadowing becomes so obvious by this point that you would have to completely stop paying attention to the story in order to derive any kind of surprise from it. After Athens the game completely comes unhinged. You are left with a choice to do 3 tasks in any order you see fit. All 3 of these tasks are mindless busy work and do next to nothing to advance the story until they are all completed. One of the tasks involves earning 50,000 Drachmae, the in-game currency. While this is not an egregious example of gating since the character that gives you this quest also gives you a handful of quests that will earn you that much in a pretty manageable amount of time, it's important now that we talk about the other underlying problem with Assassin's Creed Odyssey; Mercenaries and Microtransactions.

Until now I have avoided talking about one of the major systems in ACO, that being the Mercenary/Bounty Hunter system. If you are familiar with the Middle Earth: Shadows series, you are no doubt familiar with the Nemesis System. The Nemesis System is a unique process by which elite named enemies are infinitely procedurally generated with personality quirks, strengths, and weaknesses. Assassin's Creed Odyssey implements a watered-down version of the Nemesis System to be used by the rival mercenaries. Rival mercenaries become Bounty Hunters when you commit "crime." These crimes range from slaughtering entire cities (which obviously constitutes crime) to attacking faction strongholds and looting chests (which is often necessary for progression). Similar to the star system in Grand Theft Auto, word of your misdeeds builds up on a meter on the bottom right of the screen, and eventually bounty hunters will be sent to try and kill you. These bounty hunters range in difficulty from minor annoyance to progression brick walls, and can attack you at any time, even during boss fights. One way to lose notoriety is to spend drachmae, which can be purchased with real money from the premium store. This isn't the only money sink, as gear and ship parts will need to be regularly upgraded for exorbitant costs.

ACO suffers pretty dramatically from the Fallout 4 and Mass Effect 3 style of dialogue selection, which is to say that the option you choose may sound great as a one sentence summary, but when your character starts to speak they can often say the opposite of what you intended. A good number of heavy narrative choices come down to a "pick one of three" style of dialogue options. And while there isn't a Paragon and Renegade type system that keeps track of how naughty or nice you've been, there are clear options in most situations for kind, mean, and indifferent. The story is very obviously trying to be a Greek tragedy, so having the main character say things that are flawed and that aren't the best way to diffuse a situation is in keeping with the theme, however there is little more frustrating that picking what SOUNDS like the neutral option, only for it to actually be the evil option. To circumvent this the game provides icons near some dialogue choices to show you what the outcome of selecting a specific action will be, however in certain situations these icons are still misleading and sometimes completely seem to contradict the summary sentence. This means your character will often say things that sound completely ridiculous in the current context, and you will often be left to guess which one of the options will have your character give the response you truly want them to. In an experience where player choice and narrative freedom are key game play pillars this is a gross oversight, and directly contributes to the terrible experience that is the main story.

It seems I've hit the character limit.

More in depth:

As for gameplay , it feels strong. What I mean is , you get the level perks you get to swap them anytime you want with very low cost and completely change your playstyle and you can change the equipment maybe upgrade it and have a completely new character with the same face. Not Recommended
147.1 hrs on record
Posted: 22 November, 2021
This game exhausted me and was a good reminder why I was avoiding Ubisoft games like a plague. I knew I should have stayed away with my motto: "Life is too short to play bad games."

I actually wanted to give it a somewhat positive score after the first episode of the first DLC and The Gates of Atlantis; however they went downhill as well and sadly the negatives outweigh the positives.

Positives:
+ Spectacular world design. I mean, I actually think there couldn't have been a better description of ancient Greece and historians agree as well. Art design and the team did amazing work.
+ Memorable historical characters such as Hippokrates, Socrates and Alkibiades. Particularly talking with Socrates is extraordinary.
+ Mythological creatures and hunting them feels wonderful. The last time we have seen these creatures in God of War and I think they did well design them and had much fun.
+ Kassandra's voice actress Melissanthi Mahut is sweet in her role. Swears well, sassy and angry enough to portray a character like Kassandra. Even though it felt off sometimes, it was definitely enough.
+ Armor and weapon designs are top notch. There are good combinations that fit each other and feels unique.
+ Ship fights are cool and one of the most fun elements of the game. I liked sailing around and the storms.
+ The Gates of Atlantis is a great DLC. Elysium looks spectacular. It's the predecessor of Immortals Fenyx Rising and you can see it from the moment you step into the world. Having conversations with the gods are wonderful, definitely feels like a different game apart from the filler content. Underworld is much better than Elysium (with a particular character's quest), and Atlantis is better than the Underworld.

Negatives:
- The world filled with pointless and non-immersive quests. Game feels empty in that regards because you cannot find an immersive quest even though Greece's itself is immersive. There are hundreds of question marks that are exact copy of one another and just there for filler content. I'd suggest you do the quests in this order: Golden marked story quests > Yellow/Blue/Brown Exclamation Marks > ignore the rest. Even in this format you can ignore a lot of the yellow ones because they're just empty and non-immersive.
- Main story ends so abruptly and in an unrealistic way. You find the person you chase the whole game in your dinner table. It's just lazy writing and even the DLCs are not enough to save the game.
- You care none of the characters because the game lacks of emotion. Oh, they died? OK. Oh, they're alive? OK. I just don't care enough because the game doesn't develop any of them enough for you to care about.
- Voice acting is literally bad. It's like anyone involved read the text without having the scene played in front of them and tried to imagine. It's robotic, soulless and just plain bad.
- Music is non-existent. I thought the main theme would play much longer and we see glimpses of past game's tunes but it's just generic. Even in the heat of the battle the music is not there so it makes everything anticlimactic.
- Enemies are sponge-like and they are always equal to your level. That makes your effort to become stronger pretty unnecessary but we all know Ubisoft did this to prolong your game time.
- Skill tree is just plain boring and you will start using only couple of them after sometime.
- Enemy and NPC variety is atrocious. You fight the same guy 100 times and see that old lady 200 times and the kid 300 times in your playthrough.
- Game forces you to do unnecessary quests to gain XP so you can continue your journey. Pretty scummy because they sell XP boosts and this leads to artificial extension of gametime, which is equal with boredom.
- The Cult starts good but fall off pretty quickly as it's the same and doesn't evolve to anything. Even in DLCs you get come Cult related stuff and it was the time I said "enough with this Cult â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥".
- Mercenary system starts promising but becomes an instant chore because they're everywhere and pain in the ass. Oh you killed someone? Some mercenary teleports to your location and put their nose to everything and create unnecessary chaos. They're irritating and overused.
- Too many Malakas.
- Stealth is useless whatever you do and upgrade your skill points. Kills the name of Assassin's Creed.
- Should have been released as a different IP and continue from there with Kassandra or Alexios. Would make much more sense.

There're probably more than I could remember because the game killed all my IQ with its boring gameplay. Go play Red Dead Redemption 2 or The Witcher 3 couple of times instead of any Ubisoft games. Not recommended.

The short version:
One of the best games I've ever played.

The slightly longer version:
It is a huge game with many historically accurate details of the ancient Greece or at least way more historically accurate than any of the Hollywood movies despite having mythical creatures in it.
The map size may not be as large as games like the newer Just Cause games but it is much more populated and with way more things to do than many other open world games.
There are also many buildings that you can actually enter and with detailed decorations and furnitures.
The combat system is similar to the Origins with the main story being quite a bit longer or at least it feels that way which I personally think is great.
I mean a good game should be large enough and have enough content for the player to spend at least 50 hours or more without being too repetitive.
Some people say the game is grindy early on and punishes the low level players but personally I think it makes the game more exciting when being chased by mercenaries many levels higher and explore new areas with much tougher enemies and hostile wild animals because it encourages you to do more side quests and find new ways to kill high level enemies.
There are also multiple dialogue options with some affecting which ending you would get which is also great and reminds me of the Mass Effect trilogy and the newer Fallout games.
I don't usually care too much about music and songs in games but the soundtrack of this game is just amazing and perfectly matches the beautiful landscape and architecture.

v7ghost7v

Not Recommended
160.6 hrs on record
Posted: 20 November, 2019
If you look at my play time you will see that I played this game for 160 hours at the time of review, and I still do not recommend the game.

The reason for it is simple: the game is not fun and it took way too long for me to realize it, because it is kind of addictive.

Every mission consists out of an NPC talking to the player, the player searching for the place they have to go, then either
activating a chest to "get documents / get a weapon / get a trinket / get a map / ..."
killing "the polemarch / the commander / the leader / ..."
or freeing "the rebels / the friends / the husband / the family / ..."
Then you go back to the first NPC and get your rewards. And even though the things above sound different - most of the time I did them all anyway.
I activated every chest to get equipment and money, and also to "be done" with the place (there are "location objectives" at every more or less significant location and you have to kill the leading persons, open every chest, burn war supplies and sometimes find a stone plate of some sort).
I killed most of the people anyway, because it's annoying if they see you and suddenly the whole world wants to find and kill you
freeing the people is also "location objective"
Sometimes this is spiced up by making you run around in circles in a defined area to "look for clues" which are marked by a magnifying glass.
Those are the standard missions. Then there are the "big enemy" missions. They sound different at first, but they are all the same.

In the course of the game some standard missions (see above) derive into "big enemy" missions, in which you have to fight and kill some kind of boss enemy. That can be an abnormally strong animal, another mercenary, a pit fighter or some sort of cultist. The only different thing with that are the cultists - sometimes you have to think about where to find the cultists but in order to get to them you have to do several "standard missions", and then kill the cultist.

Yeah and you have naval battles with arrows and javelins. And big fights between Athens and Sparta with you fighting for one side.

So in conclusion there are maybe 3-4 things you do in the game over and over and over and over again. This is then made harder by having you grind ressources to upgrade your weapons to stay stronger than the enemies, grind XP to get abilities, and so on.

And that's the addictive part.
The abilities are nice to have, they are powerful and if used correctly they make the player a god among men.
The equipment has various modifiers which make you even stronger, depending on your playstyle.
There are several tiers of weapons, with the "legendary" weapons being unique and unremoveable once acquired (you can put them into storage but they're never "deleted", which is good).
There is a list of mercenaries being better (higher leveled) than the player, and it's natural that the player wants to be on top of that list.
There is a list of cultists who "are evil" and it's natural that the player wants to fight evil and kill every one of those cultists.
The map is full of quests which are automatically generated and repeat themselves again and again, there is no way to finish all the quests. And even the quests which are not automatically generated (they are golden) still follow the same basic principle ("standard missions" / "big enemy" missions).
There is a list of big animals
There is a list of big fighters,
There is a list of mystic whatevers
Here a list, there a list, and you're basically having several "to do" lists that you work from top to bottom.
And that's not fun. That is chores and if I wanted to do that, I could clean the kitchen or the bathroom and actually get things done instead of wasting my time in this game.

Additionally to that, all the "cool assassin" stuff from the games is gone. The present time sequences are neither informative nor in any way interesting. The characters are shallow and I don't care if they die or don't, on which side they are on, if they're male, female, trans or whatever. The part of "The Assassins" versus "The Templars" is completely gone in the games, you have the "bad ones" and a few "good ones", and both are somehow organizing themselves, sometimes with a structure / organisation but not like in the old games. There is no "we" feeling in the game, the player is not part of a secret underground organisation who tries to fight another secret underground organisation. You just stumble from one fight to another. There is no creed in this Assassin's Creed and the player isn't even an Assassin anymore. At least not the kind of ninja stealthy assassin that goes around completely unseen, which was possible in games earlier than Origins, but changed with the new fighting system.

When you see an enemy who chills at a cliff, and you sneak to them, you don't know if you're able to kill them or not. You have a spear that you can basically put through their throat but it may only take a third of the enemie's health. But you only know that when you're directly behind them, because then the game knows what you want to do and it shows how much of their health you take. In most cases you are forced to either sneak around completely unseen or to engage in open combat. There is a LOT of open combat in this game, and it's not like in earlier AC games, where you counter 2 times and be done with the enemy. They're actually fighting back as good as they can and it's a challenge you're forced into again and again.

There is also an ingame shop where you can buy even more precious equipment with a special ingame currency that you *can* get, if you grind it (per week there is a set amount of special missions that give you a set amount of that special ingame currency) or you can buy it with real money, of course.

Yeah. That's it from me, I'm done with Assassin's Creed. I finished the main story, I started the Legacy of the First Blade dlc and saw it's the same like the main story but with different characters. It's not fun when you think "Oh god I'm finally done with this.."

I'm done now. Thank Athena.

Posted: 6 January
Assassin's Creed Odyssey takes place in the 5th century BCE. during the Peloponnesian war, i.e. the conflict between Sparta and Athens over control of all Greece.
AC Odyssey is so much better than the storyline in Origins. The Odyssey is full of secrets to discover about your own past and know your destiny captivates from the very beginning. War is only a background here, or rather a means to the truth. It is not an outstanding storyline-winning script, but it fits perfectly with the series and fantastically justifies a journey through the ancient world.
A nicely-written story is highlighted by very well inscribed historical figures.
Each of the eminent Greeks has a small thread consisting of several tasks based on their professions and achievements. Socrates entrusts us with tasks in which we must decide whether to be guided by logic, morality or empathy.
Alkibiades tempts you to take part in his controversial games, and Hippocrates introduces you to the secrets of medicine, then treated as turning away from the gods.

Everything we have seen in Origins was included in the Odyssey. The Eagle Sen was replaced by Ikaros, the tombs of the pharaohs gave way to buildings in honor of the Olympic gods, and the endless desert turned into the Mediterranean basin. Layla Hassan returns on a very modest contemporary thread with Dr. Victoria Bibeau as her partner.

For the first time in the long history of the series, we can choose a character between Alexios or Cassandra to enjoy the story with.
-- We can't change characters later during the game --

When starting the game, in addition to the gender and difficulty level of the hero, we choose one of the two game modes.
In the exploration mode that I myself recommend, instead of a large dot on the map saying "Here's the guy you need to send to the other side", we get a hint about the location of the quest objective. Usually, these are three pieces of information, thanks to which we will narrow the circle of research. The information is easy to decode, because in addition to the name of the island, it also gives the direction from its characteristic points.

The skills that we unlock and assign to shortcuts on the pad make the difference. The skills themselves may not be many, but they fit well with the gameplay and add dynamics to the clashes. In addition to the Spartan kick, there was stunning many enemies, covering with poison, setting weapons on fire, battle frenzy, knocking down the shield, and even taming animals. In addition, opponents no longer wait in a queue for bareback, but attack in groups from all sides. True, chaos does creep in, but it's a good change anyway!

How you perceive the "AC Odyssey" is largely determined by the question of taste. Some will love naval battles and larger-scale duels, others will get bored the second time.
Some people will be delighted with the amount of activity on the map, others will find that the sandbox formula tires them a bit.

Overall.
Odyssey is an almost perfect champion of its genre and one of the best parts of the game series. It â€‹does not revolutionize the franchise, but it's a capable entry that will satisfy fans for dozens and dozens of hours.

Pros.
+ Ancient Greece is big, bold and beautiful.
+ Combat and exploration habitually encourage experimentation.
+ Kassandra and Alexios are a great duo of protagonists.
+ A world that keeps on providing.

Cons.
- Gets repititive.
- Little grindy sometimes.
- Core narrative is underwhelming at times.
- Slow pacing that can make playing the huge campaign a drag.

It may not be a story that we would compare to the Homeric epic in terms of epic adventure, but it does not lack spectacular views, historical places and characters, and plenty of opportunities to duel on land and sea.
The best part of the series and definitely worth a try.

8.6/10

Assassin's Creed Odyssey is a behemoth of a game. The world is absolutely huge, which, truth be told, after about half of it, wasn't really that great anymore. Several hundred points of interest, dozens upon dozens upon dozens of military forts, and probably a thousand or more chests later I can say I am really glad it's over. Collectocalypse aside, Odyssey is probably one of the best entries of the entire series, even although it's a far cry from AC2, which to this day remains to be the best AC game and probably will remain so in my personal ranking for quite some time.

While all the collectibles and points of interest are entirely overkill, the quests are not. Quest design, for the most part is very simple, but I personally enjoyed all those stories a lot and the support cast of characters was actually quite interesting.
While I liked the setting of Origins a lot more, Odyssey built upon the strengths of Origins and tweaked them further, steering the series more into a direction of a proper roleplaying game. For the first time in the series, actual choices were implemented. They don't change the entire story, but they do change some noticeable things in the game and this definitely was a step in the right direction. The only gripe I had with this was the fact that enemies keep leveling with you so that you constantly have to upgrade your gear or become unable to assassinate enemies due to lack of damage. That's a design choice which sucks, plain and simple. Does it take away from the fun? No, not really, even although it really is stupid.

All that being said, while I definitely do recommend Odyssey, I am quite miffed about the fact that AC Valhalla apparently is not going to get a steam release, ever. Major douchebaggery move by Ubisoft.

Recommended
135.1 hrs on record
Posted: 30 April, 2019
It is my genuine view that AC Odyssey, despite its varying differences from prior Assassin's Creed games, is the best Assassin's Creed since the Ezio Trilogy. Graphically intensive, with great attention to detail, I find the freedom the game offers to be liberating. While it is not the same as previous Assassin's Creed games, having far more in common with an RPG than prior titles, I have found the gameplay loop satisfying. Exploration feels worthwhile, which ties into the sheer scale of the world, to my knowledge one of the largest open world maps made to date, and full of historical locations, tombs to raid, forts to attack and missions to complete. I have not yet found myself bored, which I typically would be by this point in time in most open world games.

The game's attention to detail is excellent. Greek statues show the paint that they were likely bathed in in real life. Walking through a field of wheat, your character will extend their hand and brush it through. Armour and weapons are accurate to the period, consisting of a variety of spears, axes, xiphon, kopis and more of that sort. What particularly impressed me was when I looted a Mycenaean tomb and discovered an "ancient sword" that was, blow for blow (so to speak), a virtual representation of Mycenaean era weapons excavated in real life. It's very well researched and is probably the most authentic portrayal of Greek society of the time made thus far (despite inevitable liberties and idealizations brought through via gameplay and the story itself). Given how ancient the subject matter is, and how little surviving material it is, it would be a foolish conceit to say that they game is totally accurate, but it portrays the Greek world as a living, breathing place, with reference to what we do know about it and with evident passion. Quite impressive.

Story is decent, delivering some good performances and some genuinely emotional moments. It provides a reasonable framework, good world building (which is necessary even in historical games), and some decently memorable characters. The Mykonos arc sticks out to me in particular, for a variety of reasons. In the interest of avoiding spoilers, I would say that story is adequate, or even good, with brief flashes of excellence.

With this praise in mind, I find the game's optimisation to be inadequate, with continual stuttering. My computer is a decently powerful machine, featuring and RTX 2060 and Ryzen 7 2700x, parts far in excess of the recommended specs. Nevertheless, frames are not steady, and at times will even fall to twenty FPS. I'm not sure what causes it, but it points towards structural problems in the software, moreso than inadequacy of hardware.
Certain enemies have a tendency to be spongy, in the same way as other Ubisoft style games, which offsets the very real improvements made to AC's combat system. While dodging and attacking enemies feels satisfyingly kinetic, having to rely on a healthbar, as opposed, to say, enemy behaviour to gauge health breaks immersion rapidly. Especially when one has to hit a single enemy some twenty to thirty times, although this becomes increasingly rare as the game progresses. Outside of these issues, I have seen no real bugs or technical problems with this game, which has proven to be mostly stable, and generally a joy to play.

This game is a triumph for Ubisoft, and has taken its place as my most highly regarded game of 2018,

Posted: 1 February
After taking a break with a lot of the Assassin's Creed games around Black Flag I was initially really hesitant to try out Assassin's CreedÂ® Odyssey but given how long it had been, I gave it a go, and I did not regret it!

Coming from the Ezio trilogy, Odyssey is a complete 180 on the series and how Ubisoft now approaches these titles. With a bigger focus on customization (weapons, armor, skills, gender, etc.) and taking open-world gameplay to a whole new scale, I EASILY dropped 180+ hours into this game just playing through all the quests and DLC. I thoroughly enjoyed the naval warfare and the improvements from Black Flag, loved the mercenary system and how frustrating it could be when they showed up mid-quest, and I really thought the conquest system with taking over regions was a highlight for the game and hopefully something we see in the future of the series.

Now comparatively to older AC titles, I am not sure I love the new (to me) gearing system with the abundance of useless gear I would get but I guess when you factor this into the customization with the skill tree, you really need this much gear to allow the flexibility for how you want to approach combat. Similarly to other AC games, there is an abundance of useless side quests that really make the game boring so I ultimately skipped these unless I needed the experience.

I am not 100% sure if I am a sucker for Greek mythology or just really enjoy the AC series but I loved Odyssey and now I plan to play through future entries into the series.

Recommended
541.0 hrs on record
Posted: 27 April, 2019
When reviewing games I've purchased on Steam, I generally focus on all the mechanics of the game that make it horrible so that others don't waste their money. This is the first positive review I've ever felt compelled to write.

AC Odyssey is a TRUE open-world game in the arena of Fallout/Elder Scrolls/SoW. And the world is absolutely HUGE, even when using fast travel points and/or your horse. You can easily find yourself spending HOURS just running around exploring. Although Steam states I have 193 hours logged in the game, I only have 93 hours of game time (ONLY RIGHT! LOL!), and I'm not even CLOSE to completing it.

The world is BEAUTIFUL! The developers really did an awesome job building it and making it look just wonderful. In fact, after playing several hours for a few days, I decided to upgrade my graphics card (now: Gigabyte GeForce GTX 1660 OC 6G Graphics Card, 2X Windforce Fans, 6GB) simply because of this game. I wanted to see how good it looked with higher resolution textures, and I was NOT disappointed; however, you need a really good CPU/GPU to play it at its highest resolution. Even with the upgraded GPU I had to set some settings lower than maximum, which really made me contemplate building a brand new rig altogether.

If you like history, this is a great game to play. You'll learn all kinds of interesting tidbits, especially if you do some research outside of the game while you're not actively playing it.

As far as questing goes, it is pretty much a go there kill/find/steal and return for your reward, but all of the quests have full cut scenes and voice acting. And there are a TON of quests. That being said, some real time went into developing most of the quests and some of them are flat out hilarious (the blacksmith! LOL!), especially if your character is the promiscuous sort, which, of course, mine was! (I can't believe that slut was censored by Steam!)

Combat. It's a hack and slash system with assigned skill sets. Sadly, you spend a whole lot of time pressing the space bar (dodge) while playing on Nightmare difficulty. You can eventually hot key 12 abilities. 8 melee, 4 ranged. Respecting is simple if you want to try various combinations. There's also naval combat. This is the first game I've played with naval combat, so I don't have a comparison, but it's straightforward, and you end up using a MASSIVE amount of resources to upgrade your ship's combat abilities.

There isn't a level cap. Once you hit level 50, a secondary system activates that you can spend your level up points on, if you don't want to spend them on primary abilities. The secondary system lets you spend up to 20/20 in each subsection (for example: Increasing Critical Hit %) and there are dozens of secondary statistics to increase.

Replayability. You can choose to play the male or female character at the beginning of the game. I've yet to finish a play though, but as I've played, I've realized that it's possible that many of the quests would've ended up differently had I chose a different dialogue option. I'm not the type of player to replay every quest to select different choices just to see what would've happened, but on a few I did, and the tone of the encounter changed drastically. Therefore, I began playing my character as a good kindhearted murderer (that steals everything in sight) with the intention of playing the opposite gender (thankfully only two options) as the evil hard-booty (Thanks filter!) murderer (that will steal everything in sight). Yes, you pretty much murder your way through the entire game (and steal lots of things) =P

I skipped around playing AC games. I played 1, 2, and 3 and purchased several others that I didn't have time to get around to playing, yet, but the open world component of Odyssey drew me in, and it was worth it.

Overall, this is easily the best game I've played, and one of the main reasons is because I have yet to encounter a bug! While games like Fallout/Elder Scrolls REQUIRES the community to fix the multitude of bugs released in their games, AC, to date, is flawless.

I've spent the same amount of money on various games through Steam over the years (74 in my library) that haven't even come close, and I mean CLOSE, to a FRACTION of how good AC Odyssey is. For me, someone who plays single player games exclusively, this game sets the bar. If other developers can't make stunning single player games this good, without massive amounts of bugs, they'll find themselves with a lot less customers.

TL;DR - BUY IT, PLAY IT, YOU'LL LOVE IT.

Not Recommended
70.7 hrs on record
Posted: 8 December, 2018
Assassinâ€™s Creed Odyssey is a diamond in the rough to say the least of the matter. From the perspective of a gamer and a long-time fan of the Assassinâ€™s Creed series it is yet another entry to the franchise with a few minor tweaks compared to the previous years offering. As a historian it represents a rare and beautiful opportunity to explore an authentic recreation of the ancient Greek world. These two overarching ideas define the ACO experience and often clash with each other.

Touching more on the lackluster gameplay ACO treads little new ground here, the combat system while updated is still very much reliant on counter playing you opponents attacks and dodging the incredibly obvious and infrequent heavy attacks. ACO features a leveling system that always ensure enemies are damage sponges and incentivizes players to pursue gear with higher number values than their current equipment. This creates an environment where the player never feels powerful, this is accentuated further by the lack of actual assassinations. One would presume in a game titled Assassinâ€™s Creed there would be some assassinating, you would be wrong. ACO proudly features a choose your own gameplay style mechanic that effectively removes all assassinations from the game. This serves as a true disconnect from the Assassins Creed of days gone by; no longer are players be able to roam the streets of an interesting and unique town planning how to take on the guards defending the next objective. Instead the player is faced with set piece battles where Sparta and Athens resolve their differences by throwing away countless lives at hilt of your sword.

This shift in the core concept of what Assassins Creed is supposed to be has been some time in the making, I would say ever since the end of Ezioâ€™s storyline in Assassins Creed Revelations. What has transpired is that the series has moved away from being a good stealth game with a fantastic, engaging and vibrant open world; and instead become a mediocre fighting game with famous people and places plastered on top. This shift appears to be almost a successful as an attempt to drill a hole in a wood plank with a grenade.

The history in Assassins Creed fares much better, exploring the world reveals a great many interesting historical locations that will be fun to exploreâ€¦ the first time. The issue become readily apparent within the first three or four hours of gameplay. In their haste to release ACO on the annual timetable the developers recycled assets, even entire buildings and their interiors may be found dozens, if not hundreds of times. It is almost as if the ancient Greeks mastered the art of 3D fabricating an entire city block and used this knowledge to copy paste entire towns. This obviously rushed design for the world loses its appeal fast with some notable exceptions, Athens and Sparta. Both cities suffer from this issue to a much lesser degree and are simply massive. This provides players with an awesome historical environment to explore and I spent several hours running around Athens remarking on how authentically it was recreated.

Taken in its current state, a few months after release, Assassins Creed Odyssey is far from perfect and has many glaring flaws. Despite this the developers are obviously passionate about their work and the gameâ€™s historic setting is not neglected. This being stated it is impossible to ignore the flaws of the game and as such I will not be recommend purchasing this game at any price above 20$, perhaps even waiting for the obligatory DLC packages to be released may be a wise idea. If you cannot stand grindy combat systems avoid this game at all costs and it has taken the top prize for grind away from Elite Dangerous and set itself as the king of the grind.



Comment response from the author:

Perhaps I did a poor job of phrasing some of the criticism in the review above, as such I shall elaborate here. Whilst it is technically possible to assassinate enemies in ACO, there are no set piece assassinations as seen in previous titles. For example, in Assassins Creed 2 there was substantial build up to numerous assassinations such as with Bernardo Baroncelli and Uberto Alberti. Both of these rather minor characters had an arc where it is shown why Ezio wanted them dead, the process of preparing for the assassination and then the actual assassination itself with well scripted and voiced dialogue. One of the most memorable moments from the original Assassins Creed was where a templar was burning books saying that they could be used to spread false knowledge and that such a danger could not be tolerated; Altair killed him and it was later learned via interaction with the world that the books contained a ton of false knowledge that should have been destroyed, thus leading the player to view their previous actions as hasty. Such memorable missions and stories do not exist in ACO, the assassinations are simply not there. A player in ACO can atop a roof and wait for a passing guard (note not a leader or mercenary unless they are specifically vulnerable to assassinations as their health pool is far too high) and the assassinate them; this is not the same experience.

Furthermore I have been accused of not understanding what kind a game ACO is attempting to be, this is simply not true. It is my assessment that the character stats customization is done poorly; not that it shouldnâ€™t exist. At many points the game railroads the player into open combat, which forces players to interact with the inaccurate hitboxes and clunky combat system. This gameâ€™s combat system is not up to par with 2018 levels of gameplay for a melee combat system, this could be overlooked if it was realistic to avoid these systems however the player is forced to interact with them constantly.

I also feel I should add here since it is not clear in the review itself. I love Assassins Creed and I hope that Ubisoft can recover from the recent decline in quality with Assassins Creed titles. Black Flag was a great pirate game, however a poor Assassins Creed game. It appears that the primary issue facing the developers of Assassins Creed today is that they are expected to cram in so many gameplay elements that they cannot make them all fun and balanced, as such the end product is a jack of all trade but ace at none.

~OVERALL RATING~

~ SUMMARY ~
Assassin's Creed Odyssey is an epic open world adventure. The games is visually spectacular, and although Greece is beautiful, nothing compares to the worlds of the expansion - they are some of the most beautiful environments I've ever seen in a game, even competing with Toussant in The Witcher 3. I feel like I know Greece incredibly well from all the quests that take you all across the ancient world.

The characters are quite 2 dimensional, except for the protagonist and antagonist, who are interesting and well developed. The worst part of the experience was the 2-3 hour period in the first expansion where you fall in love, get married, have a child and then have it all fall apart - it was all far too poorly scripted and devoid of any emotional investment. Interesting ideas poorly executed.

Still, it was a great experience, and even though the narrative was pretty weak it was a hell of an adventure.

In English:
Now that I have almost played through the game (with the two extra content), I would like to write a review to maybe make the purchase easier for some.
First of all I have to mention that I played Kassandra's story, but I have to say that it shouldn't be that different from her male counterpart.
The individual stories and also the story itself are extensive (it took me about 100 hours for the main story) and the two DLCs bring around 70 hours of fun again. I liked the main character Kassandra very much, both in terms of appearance and style. The pleasant and beautiful graphics make the game rich in detail and many of the characters grow to your heart quickly, both in terms of story and appearance. Many side quests in the extensive and large game world ensure that it is relatively easy to level and is therefore always up to your opponents.
Of course, you also have the opportunity to get to different romances through some of the quests, which (and one can criticize that) are not very profound and contribute absolutely nothing to the actual story.
You can buy the DLCs and in the case of the Atlantis DLC I would definitely recommend it, but you don't really need them unless you want to have all the achievements. Legacy of the first blade was also a good extra, but in my opinion it was very overly technical and basically not important.
There was no problem with any of the in-game quests and the game is practically bug-free except for a few minor bugs, and I never had the feeling that I was getting stuck and you weren't just thrown into the action, but worked slowly up. I also liked the mercenary ranking system, where you can upgrade if you kill opponents who are above you.
What annoyed me here, however, is the fact that mercenaries just showed up when you were in trouble, which means that you had already fought against opponents and then suddenly one or more mercenaries came to hunt. You should be able to decide for yourself when you want to kill whom, which was always the case with all other decisions and opponents.
All in all a great game with which I have already spent several game hours and will also spend a few more.
Anyone who is a fan of the Assassin's Creed series should not miss this part and for anyone who is not a fan it would be an opportunity to get started. You should buy the game and the extensions rather in the sale, because you can save more than 60%. For me one of the best games and therefore a clear buy recommendation.

Not Recommended
133.7 hrs on record
Posted: 2 June, 2019
Game is beautiful to look at, boring and repetitive to play.

I almost always finish the main story in single player games but I couldn't bring myself to in Odyssey. I got to a point and the wind in my sails just stopped and I couldn't be bothered anymore. The quests are fun to begin with and a few major plot points early on kept me interested, but once you keep progressing you find yourself doing the same things again and again and by then the novelty has worn off. Most of the characters have forgetful personalities except for a couple perhaps.

Its a shame they built such as beautiful world and ended up putting very little in it, I saw a lot of cool looking and beautiful landmarks but had no reason to stop or explore them.

The game plays very well and the combat is very smooth. But the mercenary system which is something vaguely similar to Monolith's Nemesis system is so pointless and bland, and after awhile just starts to become a nuisance.

TL;DR
If you like beautiful open world games with repetitive and monotonous tasks to do with a 'meh' story, this is for you.

Buy it when there's a big sale if so, the scale of it warrants a AAA price tag but the experience doesn't.

Whether Iâ€™m hunting down the remnants of the sinister Cult of Kosmos, fighting mythological monsters, or hunting the great beasts of Greek legend, thereâ€™s a staggering amount of content left to discover.

Then thereâ€™s the new Mercenary system, which is inspired by Originâ€™s Phylakes but, again, is bigger and better. Instead of just 10 ultra tough enemies wandering the world trying to skewer me, there are numerous mercenaries who wander about and, if I cause too much trouble, will try to collect the bounty on my head. These mercenaries remind me of Shadow of Mordorâ€™s nemesis system, although without personalities that evolve with each encounter I have with them.

My favourite activity was to hunt down the members of the Cult of Kosmos, the conspirators who tore my family apart. . It's a lot of work hunting down these 44 cultists across Odyssey's big map, but it's a testament to how well Odyssey's systems work within each other, that this is one of the best parts of the game. Not Recommended
18.1 hrs on record
Posted: 12 October, 2018
I'm new to the Assassin's Creed series. However, I recently bought and played AC: Origins and enjoyed it despite the late-game grind, for the wonderfully detailed setting with remarkable verisimilitude, a relatable main character, and well-written quests that fleshed out the setting and the story. This set high expectations for Odyssey, which it regrettably failed to meet.

Where Origins did a remarkable job of crafting a believable Ptolemaic Egypt, Odyssey is lazy pulp. Here, mythological characters are real, the landscape is littered with twisted monumental statues, giant monstrous skeletons, and "precursor civilisation" ruins, Spartans have more in common with "300" than who they really were, and unpleasant characteristics of the Greek civilisations -- such as ubiquitous slavery and utterly oppressive patriarchy -- have been edited away. Instead of the warm and personable Bayek with his complex relationship to Aya we get tough-guy/gal Alexios/Kassandra, as clichÃ©d action-heroes as things get. And the story gets weirder and weirder, dumber and dumber from the start.

The gameplay is somewhat improved from Origins -- where brawling was merely passable in the previous instalment, it's much more varied and satisfying in Odyssey. However, this gets old around the "you have killed 100 enemies with a spear" point, however you slice (or stab) it. Moreover, the MMO-style leveling completely neuters any sense of progression, as fighting on level 5 is much the same as fighting on level 50, since you'll be fighting enemies of the same level. Instead, it imposes continuous busywork, swapping and upgrading gear and grinding cookie-cutter quests (procedurally generated or otherwise) for XP.

I was expecting a step up from Origins. Instead, I got a small step forward in one limited area (brawling) and many steps back in the areas that made Origins fun. I could only take less than 20 hours of playing this before giving up: at the point where Origins was picking up speed, Odyssey already feels like a chore. Regrettably, I'm going to have to give Odyssey a thumbs-down. It's just lazy, grindy, repetitive, and frankly boring; the only thing it has going for it is an addictive core gameplay loop with frequent rewards, but then so does Tetris and that takes up a lot less disk space.

If you think you'd like the love-child of God of War and a crappy MMO, you'd probably like AC:Odyssey. If, however, you remember fondly your time with Ezio or Altair, you probably will find this game to be a flat, boring slog.

Same basic MMO-esque mechanics where your choices matter not a whit and you have to spend an unjustifiable amount of time and effort on getting crap to buy/upgrade your equipment. Unless, of course, you delve into the veritable Hell of Ubisoft's microtransactions.

Here's my biggest gripe, though: You can't assassinate anyone. Even having every "assassin" skill unlocked, with legendary equipment geared toward stealth assassinations, a successful stealth attack of the kind you used to employ to one-hit "bosses" in prior games only takes 1/4 or 1/3 of their health away, leaving you to furiously wail on them with bizarre weapons and an array of magical skills like a League of Legends-type game. This ain't Assassin's Creed anymore.

Played as Kassandra and first thing i noticed is the huge improvement in the writing compared to Origins, it makes you more attached to the character and look forward to any funny or awkward conversation that will happen at any time, that made me fall in love with Kassandra, something that didn't happen with the previous AC games and no, it's not because she's a girl! It helped a bit, alongside me trying to sleep with each women i encountered in this game turning Kassandra into one of the most famous lesbian in the ancient world!
Choices matter and you can solve the missions and end them in a different way depending on what you decide to do, that includes the ending, i wont give more details about that because i'm trying to avoid any spoilers.

It's not a classical Assassins vs Templar story, a fresh shift from what we saw over and over again, it didn't mind that, while at time, as usual with AC games, the main story is predictable but what adds an excellent touch to it is some very nice and funny side quests, the "Gold Explanation Point" quests and not the recycled side quests and contracts that you get from boards, those are just fillers, ultra short fetch quests that might help if you are short on XP.

As for the gameplay, this is the baby child of Origins and Black Flag and it took the good things from the parents, very fun combat and skills, if you complete the game 100% you'll be close to a demigod which makes the game a bit easy toward the end, you are too powerful and extremely well geared to massacre anyone no matter which approach you'll use. I was hoping for more challenging enemies and bosses, something that will make use of the different RPG elements they added to make it a deeper, for example some enemy that makes me do a special enhanced armor for it, the perks are nice and useful but you have a feeling that you don't need most of them, that is maybe done on purpose not to alienate casual Assassin's Creed fans.

World is huge & gorgeous, you can press photo mode at any moment and end up having an excellent screenshot, each frame is beautiful, they created a rich open world with amazing views. The map is so huge that the main story doesn't even take you to half of the regions/islands.

I had a lot of fun playing this game and i'm looking forward to play the additional content that Ubisoft will be adding to it, free missions and the ones from the season pass, they are taking the game in a good direction and i would love to see deeper fighting and better enemies in the next one.

Posted: 12 October, 2018
I dont typically write reviews, not unless a game is exceptionally good, or extremely bad. This review actually falls in the middle.

Story: I find the story enjoyable thus far, I was expecting something bare bones, but there is actual story here. The player is able to make choices that can alter a story in some way shape or form, some larger than others. I havent completed the game yet, however its probably the only reason I am playing. The only complaint is now that the game plays more like an RPG/Adventure game, story missions called be level gated, forcing you to do "skyrim level" quests. By that, the quests usually are little more than "go to this fort and find this item in a chest" or "Go over here and kill something". This just bogs down the game substancially. I am only level 33 and played almost 40 hours.

Combat: This is the games achillies heel (pun intended). You see, the games combat system relies on getting better equipment from varying weapons (spears, two handed bladed, swords, daggers ect) to armor sets. As you level up you gain ability points which can be fun to use. You can get abilities such: the ability add poison/fire to your weapon, charge forward, sparten kick (like 300), rip an opponents shield from them and throw it at their head like a destruco disk, heal for a percentage of health, or unleash a large flurry of blows that depend on weapon type (daggers will strike a single target several times while hammers allow you to target a single opponent while being able to chain to 2 others). This is well appreciated and I enjoy the fact that you can choose a weapon prefference, though most of the time the damage difference is negligable.

So you get into a fight with some Spartan soldiers, one guy is duel wielding maces, another has a spear and shield, the other guy has just the spear. Combat usually revolves around you being able to attack when available and watching your opponents attempt to strike you, in which you can do one of two things. If their weapon glints like a sun striking metal at the right angle, you can perform a parry, allowing you to stun everyone in a short radius and open up those enemies. If the enemy glows red while attacking, the attack is unblockable and you can dodge, if you dodge at the right time, you can go into slow motion which allows you to get in a few attack or just get some distance.

Here we get to the part that has driven me to make this review, because it was absolutely rage inducing. You see, besides the average grunts you can fight, there are harder enemies (akin to mini/bosses) called mercenaries. Now these mercenaries will follow you to Hades and back. You gain a sort of "wanted meter" as you go about the world doing bad things, such as killing civilians, guards, soldiers, stealing, ect. These mercenaries are just like grunts, but have a bit of the nemesis system built into it, meaning they may be able to bring a pet bear with them to fight along side them, but may be weak to assassination attacks. Other than that, they are honest to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ sponges, think of a boss that is reletively easy single handed, that you can easily fight one on one, but for some reason the developers decided to give him enough health to last 100 attacks for no reason. The good news is that they can drop some sweet loot, but you have to kill them and whatever buddies they decide to take along.

Here is what drove me to make this review. As I said I am level 33 by the time this mission is around. I am tasked with killing a man in a fort, this man is a cultist and a side objective. This fort has around 30 guards roaming around. I dont want to start a fight immediately and instead attempt to assassinate my way to a brazzier (which the guards can use to call for reinforcements, which you dont want). I have a bounty on me as the game forces one on me for this mission. In my head I am thinking "there are no bounty hunters here, so as long as I am not seen no bounty hunters will show up" my train of though being they would only appear if there were rumors I was at this for. Makes logical sense right?

So I am killing EVERYONE in this fort silently and quickly. To make sure the bodies of the dead are not found, I carry their bodies and throw them off the edge of the tower to the forest below, where NOBODY will find them and summon bounty hunters here. I get about 80% through killing everyone when I see not one, not two, but THREE bounty hunters walk through the gate.

At this point, my plan to silently kill this cultist and complete my mission is screwed, because as soon as I would try to fight him, these guys would show up and screw me over. So I attempt to ambush them and kill them as quickly as I can (as quickly as you can kill a sack of health taking of as little as 3% of their health with an entire combo).

I do just that, I get a sneak attack on one of them and then realize the odds are stacked agains me. Not only am I facing 3 people at one time, but I notice they all have different weapons. One guy has duel daggers with poison applied (daggers are extremely quick and hard to tell when its save to parry), a girl has the same sets of daggers with poison, and another is duel wielding maces (reletively easy). Now if that wasnt bad enough, they are all at 2-3 levels higher than me, meaning they soak up even more damage and deal more damage.

I down the woman carrying poison daggers and the duel mace wielder, and focus on the last enemy and I am more than ready to get this fight over with. Then I see on my map not one, not two, not even three, but 6 more â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ bounty hunters with varying weapons, attributes, and levels. I am beyond pissed off.

The fight continues, I somehow down two more, but now im not really fighting, im just dodging praying to mighty zues I dont get hit by anything. So while im fighting anywhere from 2-4 bounty hunters in melee combat (some of which decided to bring animals like bears and wolves) while the remaining enemies are chucking fire/poison grenades, shooting fire/poison arrows, or otherwise being a pain in the ass. As im fighting those in melee I cant even attack anyone because im constantly attempting to parry light attacks, dodge heavy attack, dodge arrows, dodge bombs, avoid poison melee attacks, avoid basically anything and everything.

On top of that someone has called for reinforcements and I am probably fighting 15 enemies at one â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ time, half of these people I am doing so little damage to, its like I am doing more damage to my controller by repeatedly hammering either the light attack or dodge buttons, and even when I do connect its the equivelent of throwing a satin pillow at a concrete wall, halariously ineffective.

I end up dying, of course, taking out only about two more people. In total, assassinating everyone in the fort probably takes 10 minutes and the rest tas around 30-40 (I â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you not) and I had to do it, not once, not twice, but four â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ times because every time after I got in the fort, at least 3 bounty hunters show up, with even more backup on the way.

I eventually did beat it, but this huge fault in the game shows that the difficulty isnt in the enemies styles or weaponry or tactics, its sheer numbers. Games like dark souls usually have few enemies which are unique in their attacks, openings, or general strategies. Odyssey just â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ throw everything in the kitchen sink, the fridge, and the master bedroom at you and expects you to just be ok with it. Recommended
213.5 hrs on record
Posted: 26 September, 2019
Finally managed to finish the whole game. (There are still a few quests left in The Lost Tales of Greece, but all DLCs and main/side-quests are done).

I see a lot of people blame to game for micro-transactions. I don't like them either, but I don't agree with the fact that you need to buy XP boosters or any other stuff to enjoy the game.
Some of the cosmetics are really cool (others I find to be a bit over-the-top), but I do like the Horse Skins:).
In any event, the game provides so many armours: Epic, Legendary, etc that you don't need to spend a dime on the shop.

Back to the game: I found the way the story is related is quite enjoyable and better than any of the previous AC games. The addition of cut-scenes and dialogue options is a step in the right direction.

I loved the Altantis DLC and I think the Legacy of the First Blade was an OK dlc (and I didn't have any problems with the story - only that maybe they tried to make a bit more dramatic than it should have been).

The combat is fun and responsive (if you know what you are doing and don't just go smacking buttons).

The class system is a welcome addition. By the end of the game you will get all the skills unlocked, have all the legendary armour which will allow you to basically play either as an assassin or warrior or hunter in the same time. All you have to do is swap the armour (there are presets that allow you to do this) and you can either storm a fort as a warrior, be the bad-ass hunter and execute everyone with arrows or be ninja assassin that we all love:)

I noticed some people blame the wrong pacing of the game. I think the pacing is right, if you don't get side-tracked by all the exploration too much and BOY this game screams of exploration all over it:) (Which I highly enjoyed).

Regarding materials, yes the game can became very grindy. I found out, that instead of trying to level up my armour every single level, if I do it every 5 levels instead, I never had issues with materials, if I also dismantle all the items I get along the way and I don't need. I think this is the only aspect of the game where you need to be really tactical about it and have a longer term strategy, otherwise you will have to grind for materials.

Overall, I had a lot of fun with it and now that I finished it, I am thinking of playing it again from zero. (Yes, it has a NG+ mode as well - but I love unlocking all my skills again, looking for the better armour, upgrading and so on as I like to be tactical as in an RPG).

Is not a perfect game, but is definitely a very good game and I had a great time with it.
Just don't expect a 30 hours game. It will take you around 170 hours to fully finish the main game quests + side-quests + DLCS while exploring and discovering the whole map (I still have a few ? (less than 10) and I haven't cleared every single fort, but around 90% is fully completed).

I recommend it, if you like the AC universe, the game setting (Ancient Greece) and you are not intimidated by the time it needs to be completed :)

EDIT: After overcoming the AVX issue by buying a new CPU, I found that this game lived up to the hype (at least for me) and has a compelling story, amazing graphics and cool historical locations that made my jaw drop (like Odysseus's palace). This game completely changed what the Assassin's Creed franchise looks like in my eyes and has given me a new hope for future games to come. It improves on gameplay features previously introduced (like naval battles, which are much more fun now) and introduces new combat features well. Overall, I would say this game was worth the buy, just make sure that you look around on the internet a decent amount before hand instead of just basing system compatibility with the minimum requirements on the steam page.


ORIGINAL REVIEW: I was so hyped up for this game that I even pre-ordered it, which is something I don't usually do. When I went to launch it on the release day, it kept crashing after all of the company logos played on a computer that I know can easily run it, which meant that I didn't even get to see the AC title screen. The issue is that this game, like many other Ubisoft games, REQUIRES A CPU THAT SUPPORTS AVX. Since there are so many good cpus out there that don't support AVX and since so many people are having this issue, hopefully Ubisoft will release a patch that makes the game support other CPUs, like they've done with games like AC: Origins and The Crew 2. Until Then, I can't recommend this game.
