I love this game. As an infrequent AC player since the first installment, (I missed most of the entries after Black Flag until Origins), AC Odyssey is just the kind of game I want to play. I accept this game is not for everyone, but for me, the bottom line is Ubisoft has lovingly rendered the world of Ancient Greece in absolutely stunning detail and glory. The ancient Greece of AC Odyssey is a world I love spending time in, and anything I can do to stay in the world longer is worth my time. I play games to escape, and playing as the hero Kassandra is one of the best escapes in my recent memory.

I would rate very highly the armor and perk system. I like being able to tune builds for the three different play-styles, or combine for my own personal take. I've enjoyed the writing of the stories and quests. I found the quest-line where I could fight the mythical beasts particularly fun. I enjoy the combat system, first introduced in Origins, and further refined in this installment. It feels like a really solid Action-RPG combat system, and is much more rewarding to me than the combat systems of previous AC games. I appreciate that the enemies put up an actual fight instead of going down in one hit. Also, Kassandra is a simply amazing character. I place her up with Comm. Shephard as far as strong single-player game leads are concerned.

For cons, yes, this game can get repetitive. I don't care, though, because like I said, I enjoy spending time in the world so much it doesn't matter. I'm happy to have things to do. What is also frustrating is that stealth kills are not at all guaranteed to be one-hit-kills. To me this is the primary way this game goes against the AC formula. I would change the stealth kill ability to be more of a sure thing in future games. I see complaints that this game is system intensive; yes, you need a fairly beefy system to run this well, but that is because your computer is literally simulating this massive world all it once, every time you play it. I think it's incredible that our computers have the ability to do this at all.

I would recommend this game if you like the general Ubisoft style of games. That is, lots of icons on the screen, lots of tasks to complete, and perhaps a map that is a little too large. If you want a story rich Action-RPG that has a rich world and lots to do, look no further. If the holo-deck from ST every becomes reality, I want an experience on there to be like this game. Just with me in Kassandra's boots!

Posted: 8 October, 2018
I'll start with the pros:
- Graphics are good (nothing amazing, but good).
- Characters are likeable and their voice acting is generally good
- Story is engaging
- Naval combat is back and fun

But the cons just kill the game for me:
- "Time Saver" microtransactions. They're not even trying to hide the fact that they're going for a quick cash-grab anymore.
- Combat just feels broken. Time to kill is absolutely rediculous. Player does basically no damage to enemies the same level as them with the same level gear, but enemies do massive damage to player. And that's on normal difficulty.
- Assassinations aren't guaranteed instant kills for enemies of the same level, defeating the purpose of spending time sneaking up on a target.
- Leveling is slow, unlike Origins. Origins almost felt like leveling was too fast, but Odyssey feels way too slow. Constantly feeling underpowered.
- Performance is quite poor. My overclocked 4790K and 1080TI (in a custom watercooling loop) can barely maintain 60 FPS at 1440p in populated areas on a mix of High and Ultra settings. CPU gets really hot (over 65C), which I attribute to the DRM, just like in Origins.

Most of my dismay lies with the combat system. I don't buy an AC game to play as a tank character, but that's basically the build you have to make to survive combat in this game. With enemies being as tanky as they are, blatant cash-grab microtransactions, and poor level pacing I really can't recommend the game. Its a shame because the story seems really good so far compared to the last few games, but being unable to make it through combat with enemies the same level as you makes it incredibly frustrating to make any story progress.

Not Recommended
78.2 hrs on record
Posted: 27 July, 2019
First time I've felt obligated to write a brief review because this is the first time a 'very positive' overall steam rating hasn't felt deserved.

At its core AC Odyssey is a very polished, beautiful pseudo-historic open world playground for exploration, questing, and enjoyable combat. Its pacing is awful - the leveling system, the storytelling, the travel time. The game is also insanely repetitive like an MMO (the game even features its own store that would shame a F2P MMO store) but without grind enjoyment.

Most of the time you'll find yourself not doing any of the enjoyable aspects of the game like combat or stealth. Instead, you'll be traveling or in dialogue. The reason for this is because the insane amount of quests in this game are single objective quests that are fine until you realize just how tedious they are.

First, every quest puts you into dialogue, which after awhile just tells the same story.. i.e. You will go fetch something or kill something or clear something. Its cool that all the quests have a personality except any chat choice you make is pointless. Then, you have to travel ungodly distances because for some reason all the fast travel locations are sparse. Not only that, every fast travel spot is a tower that you have to jump off of - which means more time tediously jumping off - listening to the classic AC bird screeching while landing in a pile of grass. Take Athens, for instance, where they put one fast travel spot in the center of the largest city in the game. You need to 1. jump down from the tower. 2. jump down from the top of the acropolis BEFORE you even start off on the horse - which moves SLOWER in cities... its a 1-2 minutes to get to your quest giver, 1-2 minutes to talk, 2-3 minutes to then fast travel and jump off of a fast travel tower and onto a road and then its 2-5 minutes to horse over to your destination, where you spend 5-10 minutes doing something fun... THEN ITS BACK TO TRAVELING AROUND AND TALKING REEEE.

So, sitting in pointless dialogue, tediously fast travelling, jumping off the tower, having to run (typically jump down more rocks) to the nearest road, summoning your horse, then going to the mission, where all you have to do is usually kill something which puts you in combat for 2 minutes with 2-5 mins of stealth/using your bird vision. In the end, travel time and wasted time is 80% of the time a player will spend in this game. The other 20% is fantastic. Ubisoft wanted to make $$$ so they stuffed it full of roadblocks and levelgates that make you want to head to the store.. the goalposts have been elongated just for the sake of tempting gamers with microtransactions than actually rewarding them.

The failure of Assassin's Creed Odyssey boils down to there simply being too much gameâ€” an excess of sprawling, unfocused content. If the map were condensed to the more interesting areas and missions were pared down to story-focused quests, there might be a worthwhile game somewhere in here. Instead, Assassin's Creed Odyssey feels more like being forced to complete busywork between the more interesting bits (even when the more interesting bits still involve the same tired gameplay). And with a host of impossible missions that fill up your quest log that you can't attempt without hours of grinding first, playing Odyssey feels less like a fun game and more like a slog.

Compare this to benchmarks like DA:O, GTA, Witcher, and ME. It is most close to Witcher but unlike AC Odyssey, the Witcher had pacing and interesting dialogue. I've gone 20-30 minutes REGULARLY in AC Odyssey doing nothing but talking, traveling, talking again, and traveling back. I thought DA:I was filled with bloat, but this game really takes the cake.

TLDR: THE GAME IS A CHORE. The scale and pace is way off - you spend WAY more time walking around and in dry uninteractive dialogue rather than being a mercenary. Those that say there is 500+ hours of content are lying to themselves. Its 50-80 hrs of fresh feeling quality content with obsessives playing 500+, which is great for the price I got the game. However, this game was not a very positive or positive experience.

Assassin's Creed Odyssey's greatest strength is its protagonist, misthios Kassandra (portrayed wonderfully by Melissanthi Mahut), and her many wonderful adventures in the ancient Greek world. Even in the dullest moments of Odyssey -- and there were quite a few -- I always found myself compelled to complete whatever I had in my quest inbox just so that she can become that much more powerful, more in tune with her destiny. Through the base game, two DLCs and a final good-bye note in the form of the island Korfu (in which I shed a few tears), one gets to see the most ferocious brawn and the most tender emotions of Kassandra. She's easily a contender for my top 5 video game characters... so charismatic, so well-portrayed.

Odyssey is vast, almost to a fault (it took me 221 hours to finish everything in one playthrough, after all), and its activities are often repetitive... but there's always an incentive to keep going, always a silver lining. The magical abilities we can use are fascinating, and the various locales of ancient Greece are breathtaking to look at. Legacy of the First Blade is underrated, The Fate of Atlantis provides both the most fascinating and emotional moments of the entire game, and the island of Korfu gives us a small area of respite. I rolled my eyes when it started to become another grand-scale adventure, but it was in a way akin to how one would roll their eyes at a mildly annoying sibling. You can't help but love them in the end.

Farewell, misthios. It's been fun.

Not Recommended
90.5 hrs on record
Posted: 24 September, 2020
Assassin's Creed Odyssey is not an Assassin's Creed game.

The only thing this game has in common with any other games in the series is the name and the Isu, which has always really been in the background of most other AC games.

Before I get into my main review of this game, I just want to point out that AC Origins did a very good job explaining the 'origins' of the AC Brotherhood, and on top of that while Origins did have some mythological elements, they were implemented through DLC and were explained as hallucinations brought about by the pieces of Eden.

Compared to Origins, Odyssey is a slap in the face of what it means to be an AC game:

- Mythology plays a big part of the game, and you fight mythological creatures as part of the story, 

- There is a large focus on the Isu, and it really contradicts what is known about the Isu from previous games. The Isu aren't some mysterious Godly human-predecessors, but are really just petty magicians (especially if you play the Fate of Atlantis DLC).

- Origins explained the birth of the Brotherhood, but this game is set way before Origins takes place, so there isn't any mention of the Hidden Ones or Order of the Ancients (outside of a DLC), and really the Cult of Kosmos (the Templar equivalent in this game) has nothing to do with any AC lore.

- Layla Hassan is incredibly unlikable. In Origins, she didn't have much to do with the story and was a pretty forgettable character, but I guess I'd describe her as a boring Lara Croft. In Odyssey, she is an incredibly annoying, arrogant weird hipster, who would make sense as a side character in Watch Dogs 2, but doesn't really seem to belong in an AC game.

- The game is too arcadey. Compared to previous games like Unity, with proper, well-flushed out and somewhat realistic mechanics, this game just feels like it lacks substance. You can dance and dodge around 15 foes and take them all out without being hit once and you just float and jump around everywhere you go like you have wings. It just doesn't seem to belong to an AC game.

- Finally, the story. Past AC games have been known for their complicated, thought-provoking stories, but the story in Odyssey is just not worthy of its namesake. Furthermore, although I'd consider this game more a quasi-RPG than a real RPG like Kingdom Come or the Witcher games, you shouldn't really have the ability to make game-altering decisions in an AC game. The whole premise of AC games is that you are accessing someones memories, not making your own memories of people that died thousands of years ago.

Most of the issues I listed above are issues I'd say only people who have actually played other AC games would share with me. If this is your first AC game, you wouldn't pick up on a lot of this so it would be really irrelevant. If this is your first AC game, though, and you really enjoyed it and want to delve further into the series, be prepared to either be very disappointed or pleasantly surprised, because from mechanics to story and lore, all other AC games are very different to Odyssey. If you, like me, have played the other games and are familiar with the lore, you will find yourself very disappointed with this game.

I did my home-work here to help you during the current open-world sellings. I loved it at first but I uninstalled it before finishing. The game has a strong start and fun fights, but so easy to get exhausted of what surrounds it; it isn't very dense and can feel cheap. My final conclusion is only buy the main game to make sure it is worthy and only buy it during discounts. A barrage of plot holes and immersion slaughter moments awaits. If you don't take it seriously you probably can withstand it.

AC Odyssey got everything good and bad from Ubisoft

There is microtransaction in-game hoping for you to accept them. Game's big, but big is not always better. It feels rather stretched, like little butter in too much bread. There is something called "time savers" in the Ubisoft store to "help" ease it, proving they did it intentionally or they knew gameplay would worn off fast.

Why I recommend it

Because of Kassandra. She's likeable, the voice actress is a piece of ass and I'm sure most of us lesbians and trans finds her hot, its not just me. That's a plus that must count.

The mercenaries tier system is by far the reason why I played it. Forget about the empty rewards, constant level up or confusing family story. It's all about the thrill of a hard mode fight.

I miss AC 1 Templar soldiers hiding around maps that used to be so unique. That old concept evolved, it resembles the Nemesis system; as you keep trolling, NPCs will send mercenaries after you but they're not the usual dumb asseğ˜´ you meet. It can become a vicious cat-mouse hunt that can show up anywhere and brake your plans, if you can't fight you better pay off the bounty or just try to find who hired the merc. I managed to bloat the queue so bad that some merc joined others to take me down, resulting in a 25 minutes clash to defeat them, I wasn't ready with my equipment. I still consider the mercs to be a legitimate threat not easy to get rid off.

ğ—–ğ—¢ğ—¡ğ—™ğ—¨ğ—¦ğ—œğ—¡ğ—š ğ—£ğ—¥ğ—¢ğ—¦

Music sometimes does a better artistic job than the rest of the game, specially high-end fighting and ship combat. It even strikes the old vibes as if AC mysteries still lives somewhere. (it doesn't)

Conversation cutscenes are enjoyable at first, it is even human and tender. What I hate is the modern mannerism so incompatible with the time period, not always the ideal but the "best" you'll get from Ubisoft.

Voice acting for fighting is satisfying. Deep-breathing, groaning in pain and enemy taunts. Unfortunatelly the main character often talks alone trying to make effortless quests sounding cool. Some sounds lacks details, when you're bare feet or carrying heavy weapons.

Cities, land masses and the sea are all beautiful - but it totally lacks variation - it can be really repetitive. Human body is well depicted but body language is middle term. At least facial expressions are not-ME-Andromeda.

I never played Odyssey for its story. The Animus part is minimal, trying the Lara Croft's thing or something. All that "finding my mother" stuff sometimes goes nowhere, missions are absolutelly repetitive no matter the backstory. It is a perpetual fetch-quest that doesn't convince me to keep going from point A to B because I can predict what will be the "outcome" of the quest.

I like the stealth because the A.I. aren't just a bunch of dummies waiting next bush. You gotta think before you act, cause distractions. They even report to higher officials and split groups. Thanks to that, it takes a while before becoming repetitive (but it will).

Fighting goes by RPG-action so expect critical numbers. Some tough enemies won't die with headshot bows not even off helmet. You must maintain things, the problem is that you will level up very constantly. When you can finally keep it up, it is time to work the blades again and again.

Why things slowly accumulated into cons

Sometimes fighting a guard in the streets may trigger NPC reactions you would see in games from 1996. Normal people can start attacking you armed with nothing but a BROOM. Funny because hammering a crumbling old lady arêœ±e will also depend on critical chances, it looks rather ridiculous. Even a fakking CHICKEN can get angry and fight you (and win) crushing your gameplay goals into a pathetic xith show. Funny at first, very annoying after 60 hours watching it.

Romancing characters is never satisfying, there are no real consequences and you can't keep 'em going.

You can climb anything anywhere, no skills required, no limitations to challenge you, not even gravity after some skills.

The game decides when to take your weapons out of the holster, when enemies are around. It is intrusive and irritating after hours of gameplay.

It is easier to accept plot-holes than such violent immersion breaking promotional propaganda. The plot doesn't know where and how to place science fiction and/or magical mythologies, and often sounds as if it doesn't matter.

I like the sailing as I said, it can be fun and with the music. But classical civilizations had sailing steering much harder than middle age and renaissance, except for the Han Dynasty on China around the first century, it was mostly about muscles and rowing. Maneuverability has no historical accuracy because the game doesn't need it, weird direction that is and that sucks for me. This isn't Black Desert, this is supposed to be AC. Your crew also do shanties even though it was nonexistent for sailing in that age. They shouldn't be repeating Black Flag's in every time period.

No headgear on cutscenes, when people asked for it, the developers gave them a temper tantrum.

You still can't have a shore party, only the ''call to arms'' ability.

Controls are weird sometimes, you'll be constantly grabbing ledges when you just wanted to turn left. I still don't understand how my character can do professional parkour in the cooper age without any training, wasting a good opportunity to explain it.

A DLC called "First blade" is a repetition of the main story, only with new characters (that won't match any timeline, causing further dumb plot holes)

Can't turn specific hints off. "Untame animal" is one of them. It is beyond annoying after 60 hours straight and yes, developers refused to fix it with another tantrum on Ubi's forums.

You can't interact with some romantic interests like Odessa, can't interact with the world. You can't give tips, can't pet tammed animals, sit on benches or around the fire.

Horse disappears too fast for a 2018 game. I have seen better horse riding mechanics in older games.

13 people found this review helpful 1

Recommended
268.2 hrs on record
Posted: 21 November, 2018
Disclaimer: I will rewrite this review soon, so it would match my current standards.

The very best Assassin's Creed game to this day which improves a lot but it still has flaws.

Gameplay

The core of the gameplay is the same as in Origins. You need to level up your character in order to kill enemies with higher level and the rest of the world uses a level-scaling with your character and ship. You don't use shield this time, but you are equipped with the Spear of Leonidas which works like the broken sword in Shadow of Mordor. There are more abilities for every style of combat. I must say that I really had fun with the Spartan kick ability.
Stealth has more abilities too but unfortunately, the AI is again quite stupid and you can easily take out the whole camps without a problem. AI shows its retardation in combat when they're capable of setting themselves on fire by running through it or throw bombs at each other.
Now you have 5 pieces of armor instead of one suit, which is a great improvement (similar to Unity) and you can even change the look of every armor in inventory. It's like fashion souls now.
Cultist mechanic is a great addition and I would like to see this system again in the future with few tweaks and improvements.
Ships are back, yay! You can have 4 lieutenants which improve your ship with % bonuses and can board the enemy boats with you. Unfortunately, one legendary greek polemarch is a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and always kill or cripple himself (lieutenants are fine after the battle so don't worry). But I would like to see the ships more improved, like more visual upgrades, the interior of the ship and more. It's just one of the "downgrades" from Black Flag. Sure, the lieutenants are a nice addition but that's all. You also cannot hit the rocks, islands land and the ship has auto-heal. It's great to have ships again, but I feel that it was better in Black Flag.
You can help Sparta or Athens to win the province. It will launch a conquest battle which is just one big chaotic massacre. On the islands, it's often a ship battle. It's a great and new addition but I would like to see more strategy in it.
Mercenary system is similar to Shadow of Mordor. The mercenaries are randomly generated after while with their own weakness and abilities.
Mythical creatures as boss battles are better than in the Origins.

Story and quests

I think that story is ok. It has good, maybe even great moments but it also has some stupid scenes both in the historical and modern part of the game. The endings were quite a 
I am gonna write my opinion of choices into another spoiler window, it won't contain any spoilers from the quests or story, but if you're wanna be surprised if your choices have meaning or not - don't read it. 
You can choose between Kassandra and Alexios. I must say that Kassandra is now my favorite protagonist in the AC series. Her voice acting, animations and reactions were absolutely great. The dialogue options also help with forming her character.
Sidequests are on the same level as in Origins. But thanks to the characters like Alkibiades or Sokrates I enjoyed it more. One sidequest surprised me with its depth - .
There is also much more humor and I had a good laugh sometimes.

World, graphics, and sounds

The world is bigger than in Origins and is beautiful. There are many Greek city-states under the control of Athens or Sparta and all of them has it's unique structure. I must say that on Ultra settings it's probably the best looking open world game on the PC right now. It's again filled with military camps, legendary animals, caves, shipwrecks...
Unfortunately, the tombs are the second "big downgrade" from previous games. They are all same with few differences and without any puzzle or something. You just kill dozens of snakes. That's a shame.
The soundtrack is an improvement. I felt that it was weak in Origins and it's quite good now.

Microtransactions
You can safely play the game without microtransactions as in Origins. People probably never played any RPG or I don't know why are they surprised that you sometimes have to complete a sidequest to get an XP points. It was the same in Origins.
But I still don't like it's a presence there and I won't use them - you shouldn't too if you don't want to get it worse in the future games.
The "haha" joke on EA in one of the sidequests is hypocrisy at its finest when you have smaller chance to get items from microtransactions in this game than in Battlefront 2.

Updates and future content
I must say that the plan for updating the game both with free and paid content is looking really promising and Ubisoft is listening to its a community, so that's a big thumb up from me.

Not Recommended
124.9 hrs on record
Posted: 13 November, 2018
Before I spit the truth and Iambaste this game for its lazy RPG design, let me save you the trouble of purchasing this game just because you want to play a regular Assassin's Creed game. If you're looking for that experience, the game neither includes assassins nor the creed. So in my review, the criticisms will be based around what AC Odyssey markets itself to be; a fully fledged RPG.

TL;DR
Assassin's Creed Odyssey is a pretty game but a generic RPG at best with lazy game designs such as main quest level restrictions and poor crafting systems that revolve around the idea of deeply encouraging the player to buy boosters via microtransactions. LET IT BE WRITTEN IN FINE PRINT THE NOTION THAT $60 SINGLE PLAYER GAMES SHOULD NEVER HAVE MICROTRANSACTIONS OF ANY KIND.

LONG VERSION
Assassin's Creed Odyssey is definitely a step-up from Origins in many aspects despite being called a 2.0 of the latter. Still, Odyssey made a bigger leap from Origins than AC Brotherhood did with AC II. The first 20 hours of the game was amazing. I was overwhelmed at first by the amount of content found in the game, especially its huge open world. However, I soon realized that almost every component in the game was mostly half-a$$ed and somehow lacking the depth it needed.

PROS
Main Storyline and Dialogue System
The main story is the only thing that kept me motivated to actually keep playing the game after 30 hours into it. It starts off strong but slows down mid-way but picks up pace once more in its third act. The characters are interesting to interact with thru the new dialogue system; the series' first. Only problem was the ending as it lacked a specific impact. 

Combat System
Combat looks clunky but it definitely feels and plays better than it looks. It's an upgrade from Origins especially when many of the combat perks add more layers to your enjoyment. Only problem I had was the exclusion of shields, considering the fact that it was a core aspect of greek combat in the peloponnesian war. The return of the Naval Combat was also refreshing as I personally loved Black flag.

CONS
RPG Elements
Let me simply get this out of my chest first; I HATE COLOR-CODED EQUIPMENT SYSTEMS AS IT MAKES FOR LAZY GAME DESIGN. My estimate is that there are about 20 unique gear designs in this game. What it does is it basically recycles and redecorates it multiple times changing its color, name, stats, perks and rarity. It does this so that it would appear as if the game has hundreds of different weapons when in reality there's only a few amount of unique individual pieces. Also, many chests in the game has loot based on RNG (lazy design). Sure, you can make looting from corpses RNG-based but you should at least have certain items in most if not all of your chests in game because that is what truly motivates players to explore every nook and cranny of your game. Now I had the same problem with Origins but I tolerated it thinking at the back of my head they would improve on this in their next title but they didn't. Moroever, in Origins, the economy system works to a certain degree but mostly it's a meh. Now in the case of AC Odyssey, the economy system easily breaks after a couple dozen hours. That's bad news for most completionists like me who wants to squeeze all the milk from this cow down to the last teat. Adding to my frustration, most locations require you to loot chests in order to complete them but for what? If I'm already capped out and my gear is all yellow (legendary), what need have I for blue (standard) or purple(epic)? What should I do with 16543 metals or 8396 wood if all my gear has been upgraded? Again, let me reiterate and emphasize the fact that the RPG system of this game was structured with a steeper grind than Origins so as to almost force you to buy those juicy booster packs.

Open World Design
Odyssey's recration of Ancient Greece is breathtaking. Like how the sunset bleeds in the distance as its rays pierce through peaked mountains or how the proverbial moonlit nocturnal sea offers tranquility as its waves hit the bow of your ship and bobs smoothly. But it's all that it is; gorgeous. Which is not what you want if what you aim for is to sell a great game, Ubisoft. This company has the same problem in almost every open world game they release. They are pleasant to the eye but when it comes down to it, it's an ocean-wide world but with the depth of a pond. What I mean by that is the only way you can interact with the environment in this game is thru climbing. Not only that but much like the copy-pasted gear in the game, most points of interests are also recycled and scattered throughout the vast map for like a hundred times. Outposts, forts, camps and caves look generically the same and the only dfference there being where it is located on the map. Not to mention the fact that the game rewards you with such tiny amounts of XP for completing locations. Why not make exploration rewarding with good loot and huge xp boosts? Again, it doesn't do that because it encourages you more in buying boosters than actually exploring this beautiful yet uninspired world. What I would suggest in future AC titles is to make exploration more dynamic and seamless like in Skyrim and Breath of the Wild wherein they never gave the player an idea where a point of interest maybe just by looking at the map. To hell with checkmark exploration wherein you have to open your map once every 5 mins just to check which next question mark location you have to complete next. It breaks immersion and it feels like doing chores. The Witcher 3 had the same problem as well (tho it's my favorite game of all time, I'll take a p!ss at it for its checkmark exploration as well).

Side Content
Here's the thing, in no way should a player be forced to do side content just to get some xp to further progress in the main story. Any game should be playable from start to finish even without touching its side content because it is optional by nature. But with this game, they made side content a requirement to catch up on levels that is unless you buy their scrumptious booster packs boo hoo. Most players may have a problem with that but personally, I don't mind doing side content first because I prefer to not rush through the main story at once. However, this malaka of a game made me hate its grinding aspect because in order to gather resources or xp, mostly I had to do these procedurally generated quests that reminded me of the boring design from the old games. It felt like chores, Malaka.

CONCLUSION
With good intentions allow me to say this; A good game will sell itself. Most of Ubisoft's games are bland which is probably why they go above and beyond in their marketing efforts to sell their game. Look at Rockstar Games, let's say even if Red Dead Redemption 2 only had one trailer to show for, people would still be flocking to that game like moths to a candle. It's that good. With Odyssey however, it tries to be a lot of things yet fails at the very core of what it needs to be; a good RPG. Which is why I liked Origins better because it accomplished what it set itself out for; rekindle the series. Now, One can argue that Odyssey is worth $60 for the sheer volume of content it has which I can agree with. It may be worth your money, but it really isn't worth your time doing a hundred percent completion on this one tho. Play it for the main story and characters alone, it's worth your while for sure. AND PLEASE, DON'T BUY INTO THE LIE THAT YOU NEED BOOSTERS TO FINISH THE GAME. NEVER GIVE SATISFACTION TO CORPORATE PIGS WHO WANT TO SQUEEZE EVERY COIN FROM YOUR POCKET ON AN ALREADY EXPENSIVE GAME.

Cons:
- Game is very, very CPU/GPU intense. I have a high end machine and have not had any issues, but most medium to good rigs are struggling in some areas.

- I do not like killing dogs... its been difficult but I have simply avoided the woofers. Not really a con... shut up this is my review.

All in all... sigh... Cannot believe it. Ubisoft has created a fantastic Game. It does not feel one bit like Assassins Creed of the past. And I for one think that is for the better. Big time.

7hrs in... I give this game a 91% and I believe it should be Game of the Year. Good luck Fallout 76, good luck COD... But this is my bet for GOTY.

UPDATE

22hrs in... Still great. Do it, the game is terrific. Well worth a buy.

38hrs... I stand by this.

In the core It's AC:Origins and AC 4:Black Flag(for sea battles) combined with abilities like MGS:V style recruiting, Witcher 3 style dialoges and Shadow of Mordor style blink & assassination (Yes blink, you can teleport in this game with a skill in assassin tree).

So Why do I recommend this game?

Not because it's an assassin's creed game but because it's a beautiful rpg with nice dialoges, beautiful characters and fun combat. You are no longer playing an assassin. You are a sell-sword who is profiting the turmoil between Spartans and Athenians. Grand battles are super fun. You can choose your side and start butchering. The skill tree allows you to decide how you wanna play. There are 3 skill trees: Hunter(ranged), Warrior(melee) and Assassin(stealth). You can choose however you fit between them.

The choices you make have consequences for the first time in AC series. You can choose your character male/female and suit yourself however you like. Game relies heavily on looting. Once you find best pieces you might want to upgrade them.

I can run the game around 65 fps in medium-high 1080p.

+ Grand Battles
+ Spartan Kick!

Cons:

- Unrealistic abilities: Blinking, Predator Shot...

Posted: 5 August, 2019
NO-ONE'S MADE AN OPEN-WORLD RPG WITH THIS MUCH DEPTH AND BRILLIANCE SINCE THE WITCHER 3

Ubisoft really wasn't joking around when it called the latest Assassin's Creed game an Odyssey. It's not just in the Greek tragedy-inspired story, the vast, vast map or the sheer number of hours you're going to sink into it. It's the journey. The journey from one Greek island to another, with dolphins and whales cresting the waves alongside your boat. It's about the journey across the stunning Grecian landscape, ranging from forests bearing autumnal hues, to the majestic white marble buildings nestled comfortably in the cities, and absolutely everything in between. Including an active volcano that you can swan dive into. But more importantly, it's also about the journey to discover who exactly you are in Assassin's Creed Odyssey.

And I say you because this is the first time an Assassin's Creed game has given you a choice of characters to play as - Alexios or Kassandra. Deciding which of these two assassins to play as is basically your first choice in the game beyond tweaking difficulty and whether to use the guided or brand new exploration mode that strips out your waypoints in favor of a more organic discovery trail. But it's the first choice you'll make of many. Whether you're diving into main story content or working your way through one of what feels like thousands of side quests and events, you'll constantly be deciding how your assassin will react, behave and even fall in lust.

Because of that, it's easy to fall in love with this pair of assassins. I've been playing as Kassandra, but as a GamesRadar team we've seen how the same scenes play out as Alexios or Kassandra. It seems like the dialogue doesn't vary regardless of who you pick, because the weight is all on the dialogue options you choose. Although I wouldn't dare spoil any of the game's major story points - and trust me, this game has more twists and turns than a Disney World roller coaster - every choice you make can have a consequence, which may reach further than you think in that moment

Perfects everything Origins did and enhances them in ways you never thought an Assassin's Creed game could. Odyssey has it all.

137.9 hrs on record
Posted: 5 October, 2019
Easily the best AC I've played, but that being said; I will say that the only other AC I enjoyed before this one, was Black Flag. I was never able to really get on board with the old formula.

To keep this short, I feel that Ubi did a great job implementing RPG-like elements to their game. It's no Witcher in terms of depth and variation but they did a good job emulating that open world formula. 140 hours for me to explore the entire map, with 80% or so of the locations visited and every meaningful quest completed.

Story is so-so, and I wish they'd drop the Abstergo/real-world crap already but I can see where they're trying to go with it. Overall it was good enough to keep my attention all the way through the main game, and the first DLC (Legacy).

Once I got to Atlantis, I really felt like I was forcing myself to finish the game. Diminishing returns is a serious issue. The DLC's don't really add anything "new" to the game, just more of the same. If you're into that, you'll enjoy it.

Overall this is an easy recommend for anyone looking for a well-fleshed out open world, with "choice & consequence" story-telling and RPG-lite elements. Long-time AC fans will either love it or hate it due to the deviation from the old formula.

8/10

18.0 hrs on record
Posted: 11 October, 2018
Odyssey in allot of ways is several steps ahead of Origins, but somehow took more steps backwards.

The plot and story are tenfold better than Origins, even if they're strikingly similar - a family focused story and you oppose a mysterious organisation that are trying to kill you and you're family.

the ship gameplay is super lackluster and downright infuriating, despite Black Flag coming out 5 years ago Ubisoft has not been capable of getting it right since (expect the super short Rouge which is just a Black Flag expansion). Unlike Black Flag where your ship progressed powerfully alongside your character in this game its secondary, so you have no incentive to put any upgrades into it. And you would be an idiot to do so, every level you gain is way too significant a jump in damage and health and if you have no materials to upgrade your legendary weapons as you level you'll be at a massive disadvantage.

Because you put no active effort into your ship and a single level means a significant jump in difficutly it becomes unfair very, very quickly. You're ship will be ganked by groups of 3 or more pirates at every turn of the ocean and you will die very fast.

But all in all the ship gameplay is a very miniscule part of Odyssey and isn't what annoys me the most. The actual story grinds to a total halt once you reach level 13 for a short time. Then it REALLY grinds to a halt in the early 20's.

Their aren't enough story missions to get you to a high enough level to continue the story, once you finish a mission you'll find yourself grinding 3-4 levels to reach the new zone or start the next mission. It's the most insane thing I've ever witnessed in an Assassins Creed game before in its history.

And that's the catch - you literally have to pay money to get boosters to progress the story at a reasonable rate. My god. It can easily cost $20 to finish the story as it is told, otherwise head to grind town.

Not Recommended
15.4 hrs on record
Posted: 1 January, 2020
Going into this for an Assassin's Creed experience? Stop.

As a previous long time fan of the series, Assassin's Creed Odyssey is something altogether unfamiliar from the originals. I'll be honest when I say the setting for the game intrigued me, and for the most part the main story is somewhat interesting. At the start, at least. They start off really strong, but it just winds down quickly after you're able to leave the starting island.

I would've been able to give this game a decent review, had it not been for... the time savers.

The most stupidest thing to ever exist in a singleplayer game, period. You bought our game? Cool, give us an extra twenty, and you can skip some of our mediocre sidequests. Oh, that cool horse you can get? Ten dollars on our cash shop. Want to just BUY resources instead of working towards it and it feeling rewarding like in our previous games? Sure, a few extra dollars please!

The fact that there is a cash shop button in a singleplayer game is absolutely ridiculous.

As for the game itself, you slowly start to realize why it's so easy to access the cash shop. Combat is generic, with a few special abilities thrown in to keep it mildly interesting. A lot of enemies are just simply too tanky, which is a large gripe I have with this new generation of Assassin's Creed. I don't want to level up my character so I can actually kill them, I want to upgrade them with cool gadgets and abilities so I can get the job done better.

The game is spectacularly beautiful in every frame, the art and visuals team did amazing. The story is decent, but the sidquests you're forced to do to level if you don't want to buy any time savers will kill your drive to finish the main story. The combat will bore you quickly.

I don't recommend this game to anyone. If you want to play an RPG like this, you may as well play World of Warcraft.

My little Dreamativity

The great Odyssey we joined
So awesome, we'd enjoyed
We didn't follow the creed
Who the f*ck does it need
Doing under the breeze Shaka Laka
Ahoy, envy and watch us, Malaka!

One of my favorite games! Like both, Odyssey and Origins, but Odyssey is a much better version of Origins for me! One of those games that I went to full completion (map and quests).

I like Ancient Greece, and its Mythology a lot! And here you can meet it in the base game and even more in the second DLC about Atlantis. There many famous historical persons from those times and not only from Ancient Greece. I will not spoil anything, so you could see it yourself.

I like the combat and skills - action-action plus you have 4 active skills for a melee weapon and 4 active skills for a bow. There are plenty of melee weapons you can choose from. And the items (armor, weapons) have different visuals and stats + you can find sets of armor that will give even more benefits. I like that Odyssey has a loot system that you can find and get from the enemies. All items are upgradeable. Also, there is a transmog system - you can put an item visual on any other of the same category. The skills tree has many interesting features to offer, both active and passive, and you can upgrade them. You can upgrade your ship with materials that easily obtainable in the open world or as rewards. Didn't have any problems with it or with leveling - I was always several levels above the recommended and required level of the main quest. You have a mount here, and you can obtain different skins for it as well.

There are plenty of quests. I almost didn't do quests from the boards - they are randomly generated just to have XP and currencies. But I did all the quests with the story. And they can be hilarious, dramatic, exciting, and interesting. The same feeling I have about the main quest.

The game feels repetitive at some point. But you will not find the big forts or locations the same. Even small fortifications are at least slightly different. I like the world and exploring it, and this climate (though islands could differ drastically) is more to my taste than the one in the Origin. The world is beautiful and big, and you can visit some iconic places!

I like the bounty system when hunters going for your head, and you can kill them or make them one of your lieutenants on the ship. Also, you can progress at this bounty system as well and eventually become number one.

I completed the game long ago and maybe forgot something to say, but all in all - the game is cool and will give many hours to play even without a full completionist run. Though, as I say, it will feel repetitive at some point, so take it into consideration before trying the game.

Posted: 16 August, 2019
A good game? Hell yes. One of the best. This game is massive.
A good ASSASSIN'S CREED game? Well, still yes. Tbh this game is like an upgraded version of Origins. The grind might be too much for some people, for me it is just fine. I don't have to purchase any xp boost or something like that to enjoy the game. U don't have a hidden blade, but the spear of Leonidas functions in the same way (and it looks very sexy everytime u upgrade it). The story doesn't have anything about the creed vs the templar but aside from that, it is really good. Gameplay wise, much better than Origins. Now instead of parrying with your shield and doging everytime, now u have abilities to play with. They have i-frames too so u can abuse them in some tricky situation. 1 hit assassination kill is doable if u have the right skills, gears and some luck. Heck, I even 1 hit kill a mercenary 3 levels above me due to lucky crit. Graphics wise, this game is beautiful, just like Origins.
Now, about the story. Many people say this is not an Assassin's creed game because u are not an assassin. U are a mercenary. In fact, the main story doesn't have anything related to the Brotherhood. But it does focus on the Cult of Kosmos, one of the predecessors of the Templar Order. U aren't an assassin but technically, the game still plays out the same as other assassin's creed game. U fight against the cult for some reason (this time for your family and avenge the cult, kinda like Unity). And if u play the Legacy of the first blade dlc, u will know that your character is also the ancestor of Aya, an assasin in Origins.
The core gameplay mechanic is still here and they just expand it. U can play like an assassin just like any other games, or rambo style with warrior or kill enemies from a distance with hunter. They change the gameplay that now u can't 1 hit assassinate SOME type of enemies normally because that is to easy. Now, u will need to think more. To 1 hit kill heavier enemies u will need to spend 1 bar of your abilities with specific skills u learn. Normal mobs that u can 1 hit kill normally will recharge u with 1 bar (or higher, depends on your build). Elite enemies may not die even when u use your ablilites, but doing so still take them a large amount of hp and give u a big advantage in combat. Pls remember that this is a rpg game. Don't expect any of this if u are facing enemies that are much higher levels than u (unless u are well-geared and have a specific build).
Overall, a great and massive game. Highly recommend to get this game on sale so u can get the dlcs too.

Posted: 14 December, 2019
I have a few choice words for this game. I have a guilty pleasure like relationship with this franchise, and coming from someone enjoyed Origins but recognized it's flaws, this game somehow manages to be a step down from even that. First off, you can forget about any kind of immersion in this game. You can fling enemies around like ragdolls, and acquire perk points that give you god like abilities (no fall damage) and while it can be fun to play around with for a few minutes, it just further adds to the plastic nature of the world. Cities, cliffs, walls, are all just belittled down to mere speed bumps in the way of your destination. In addition, I don't mind sacrificing some realism for the coolness factor, but come on, some of these kill animations are straight out of anime, and the way ships behave in naval warfare is LAUGHABLE. You could be on shore, watching two ships duke it out, and try not to laugh as they dance around each other with the maneuverability of speed boats and then some. Sideways? Backwards? Doesn't matter. Everything's fair game.

Let's talk about the graphics. Never before have I seen a game look so good while yet still somehow unpleasant to look at. Everything within ten feet in front of you is gorgeous, but beyond that, even at ultra view distance, things become a blurry mess that you can tell was designed not to be noticed as easily on lower resolutions. Pop in is a major issue as well as stuttering in complicated areas like dense cities. The water simulation in this game is among the best I've seen, but everything else is a noticable step down from origins. (The cloud simulation is also quite impressive)

The side quests in this are pretty bland and the dialogue is mostly cringe. I hear people say the Greek accent is not very authentic in this game and while I can't verify that, I will say it does get irritating to listen to constantly. The main quest has its moments but it too is fairly bland. This whole game is just BLAND. The Egyptian tombs in origins were kind of boring but at least were interesting and were modeled and inspired after their real life counter parts, but the tombs and dungeons here are just copy paste, brain dead puzzle, piles of garbage. 90% of the location is EMPTY. You encounter maybe a couple snakes, and a couple pots to loot. What's the point of these locations? If the rest of the game is not realistic than just throw some enemies down there or something.

Lastly, this game moves at a breakneck pace. Even without the so called "time savers" you, your horse, your ship, all move at the speed of light making one of the largest game worlds to date seem quite small. You're literally showered with new gear causing you to open the inventory incessantly. This whole game was designed for impatient gamers. You get so much new gear that they start recycling low level gear with new stats cause they don't have enough models. So that ugly looking helmet you wore at level 3 and is back and better than ever to replace your badass helmet of the ancient kings, nice...

There's not nothing to this game but there's a lotta bull crap to get through before you have a few moments of fun. I just don't recommend.

No Assassin's?
Spoiler ahead.

Originally posted by Paul Tassi:
"Assassinâ€™s Creed Origins was all about the birth of the Assassin order, as the title suggests. Usually when we think about Egypt, we think about ancient Egypt, thousands of years ago when the pyramids were being built, but that's not when ACO took place. Bayekâ€™s Egyptian story starts in 49 BCE, and ends with his wife, Aya, killing Caesar, in 44 BCE.

Iâ€™m no history buff, but even I know that the Peloponnesian War, the great conflict between Athens and Sparta which is the basis for Assassinâ€™s Creed Odyssey, took place way, way before that. It lasted almost 30 years and ran from 431 to 404 BCE. That is uh, several hundred years before Bayek and Aya found the Assassin Order, which makes it pretty clear why there are no traces of Assassins at all in Odyssey. They literally do not exist yet.

So why is this an Assassinâ€™s Creed game?

While this part is still a theory, we are almost certainly witnessing the birth of something else. The birth of the Templar.

While the Assassins are not formed until the end of Origins, there is already an organized villain group, called â€œThe Order,â€ which is what Bayek is trying to hunt down and exterminate, and what the Assassins were formed to guard against.

It stands to reason that the reason we are heading all the way back to 400 BCE is that weâ€™re about to discover the origins of the Order, the Templar, whatever you want to call them. For all I know, we may even be playing as the founding member, as either Alexios or Kassandra. An alternate theory is that we could be playing as Aya's ancestor, meaning we're still on the side of the light, but I very much doubt that.

While Odyssey has been relatively light on story details so far, it makes sense for reasons other than the timeline. We are already seeing our hero wield a Piece of Eden in the form of the spear, something so powerful it will likely end up corrupting anyone that uses it long enough. And itâ€™s the goal of the Templar to acquire more of these and use them to rule the world with rigid order.

And you know who else likes rigid order? The Spartans, which would make Sparta a prime candidate to be the birthplace of a secret order of powerful warriors who want to control everything.

But ultimately, it is the timeline that does it. Since this is literally hundreds of years before the Assassins are founded, this game really cannot be about anything but the Templar, who were around first, and already finding Pieces of Eden to dominate their enemies."

Recommended
104.2 hrs on record
Posted: 5 April, 2021
At 104.2 hrs as measured by Steam, I have completed the main story line. My final in-game tally is just shy of 89hrs. This is by far the most hours I have ever spent in an AC game, having skipped only AC: Unity and AC: Origins. And I loved most of these hours.

The game is gorgeous, absolutely stunning. The setting is great and there is solid atmosphere building. As AC:Syndicate was the last AC I played, the step to massive open-world RPG was something I had to get used to, but honestly it was refreshing.

I can go on and on about the things that I loved, but I would rather state a few things that made the experience a bit less great.
The game is massive, a little bit too much so. At times it was very overwhelming to travel the world and see so many things to do. There is simply too much to do. Where do I start? What do I prioritize? And I say this having played the ever living crap out of Skyrim. I blasted through the first 50-60hrs of playing, but after that I had to slow down as I felt overwhelmed and a lot of the side quests are too similar.
The mercenary system sucks. The idea is nice, the execution terrible. It makes invading forts silently stupidly hard, especially during periods where you have a forced bounty. The mercenaries smell you the moment you are not hidden and they come zooming over like the Flash, even though no guard has seen you. This should be fixed if implemented in future games (idk if this exists in Valhalla).
There is a lot of dialogue, and I could have easily added an hour to my total playtime if I had not started skipping through it. It got boring and uninteresting to me.
Finally, the idea of choices is cool, but it should be possible to select an option where choices do not matter for your story. I just want to play the story and not have to have a guide in the overlay to ensure I get the ending I want.

All in all, though, these are my only gripes in 88hours of playing, which is super solid. I would recommend this game to rpg-lovers that wish to play in an Ancient Greek setting. The classic AC fan maybe less so, as the game is very different from games like AC2, 3, and Syndicate. Have fun!

crafiosk
173 products in account
0
12 people found this review helpful 3

Recommended
133.0 hrs on record
Posted: 29 August, 2020
I had only played Assassin's Creed 1 & 2, and while I enjoyed them well enough, I was not expecting a lot from Odyssey. But boy was I pleasantly surprised! This is a great game, though not perfect.

Graphics
Let's get the obvious out of the way first: this game is gorgeous. It's one of the few games where I would stop frequently while on my way to a quest and just look around at the landscape because of how beautiful and impressive the graphics are. The location is ancient Greece, and the graphics of the game really help to sell it.

Immersion
This is in my opinion by far the best part of the game. The dev team has clearly done an outstanding job of recreating Ancient Greece at the time of the Peloponnesian Wars. Almost everything looks believable and realistic, from the buildings to the clothes on the NPCs. I really felt like I am an actual mercenary in ancient Greece. Obviously this is a video game and there are a few things that are a-historical, but really it didn't diminish the experience for me.
For people who are interested in this setting and want to learn more, there's even a Discovery mode, where you can just go on Tours of the famous sights and experience them in the game.
Last point on this, the map is huge, and there are a lot of things to be done.

Gameplay
The gameplay is good, but I wouldn't say I was blown away by it. They introduced elements of RPG but it stays simple. You have a few abilities you can use in combat or out of conflict, but it's mostly about dodging/parrying and counter-attacking. There's also the possibility of taking a more "stealthy" approach, which I found quite enjoyable. The fights are all in all very enjoyable and you feel quite badass when infiltrating a fort, assassinating a target, and then fighting your way out.
I should also mention the naval warfare, in which you fight other ships and cleave/board them. I must say it gets really awesome when you and your crew jump on the other ship and engage in a fight to the death.

Main Plot
I'm not going to spoil anything here, but suffice to say that the plot is good, and there are some great moments, although I found it sadly lost steam towards the end. The game lets you choose between Alexios and Kassandra for the main character of the story. I chose Kassandra, and I have to say her voice acting is very good, and the game does an amazing job at showing her emotions on her face, which really helped selling the story to me.
As with other RPGs, you have decisions to make in this story, and your choices will have consequences (sometimes obvious, sometimes not so). There are also a number of interesting/funny/endearing characters that you will meet as part of this Odyssey.

Side Quests
The quality of the side quests varies a little, but for the majority it is really good. They can be funny, dramatic, or even just informative. With such a huge map, this is really important. There are too many games out there with huge open-worlds filled with uninteresting fetch quests. This is not the case here, although I could have done with a few quests less.

Soundtrack
The music is good, and I like the song of the main menu in particular.

tl;dr: It's a great game, and a must-play for anybody who's got an interest in Ancient Greece.

Recommended

Posted: 13 November, 2020
I was going to review this game once I finish it but 100+ hours in (120 on steam) I am still not halfway done. So here's a mid-game review.

This game can be summed up as a decent RPG with essence of AC series. The main story is okay but the real reason to play the game would be the gameplay. Side quest are mix bag of some being quite funny and others just repetitive.

What I really love-
Kassandra.
Beautiful Graphics- The game is absolutely gorgeous, I like to take photos in game and this game has one of the best photo modes. I am glad that I can run this game smoothly on my mid-spec laptop.
Exploring Ancient Greece- As far as exploration goes I would rank this below Origins or Black Flag but that doesn't mean it's bad. Cities are distinctive enough, often discovering question marks is fun. There's a cool feature to just tour the historic locations which I haven't tried yet.
Characters- This may not be an popular opinion but I really love how quirky some characters are. I don't think I liked any side characters since AC2. Also, I loved the cinematic cut scenes with character entries.
So far there have been only couple or more but some side quests are funny as hell. ('Family Values', 'A Town in need, indeed')
After a certain point, there's just no fall damage!
Mercenaries really bring up the challenge, often because they will show up when you are amidst a quest.
weapon/skills/engravement system

Neutral things-
Parkour- Since I grew up playing AC series, any game without parkour felt limiting to me. Being able to climb any wall just adds another *dimension*. That said compared to older AC games I found Parkour to be weird, earlier walls used to have distinctive gaps you can climb on but here you can scale even a plain wall. Scaling up sometimes feels a little rough especially while running away from arrows.
Combat- I have been playing it on nightmare mode and I like how it forces me play it more stealthily. The combat (aside from having proper weapons) relies on timing to dodge/parry attacks, making it rewarding as you use abilities which drains stamina. It's at good balance point where I can confidently take on a same level mercenary/legendary enemies but have have to worry if one more shows up.
That said I hate that enemies can use poison/fire attacks. Sometimes I might be winning a fight but all the enemies decide to attack simultaneously, ending it in one stroke.
The big map and side quests.
Inclusion of cultists tree which unlocks legendary whenever you complete a branch.
Naval warfare- Good but not as good as Black Flag.

Now all the minor complaints-
Reusing AC2 track for nostalgia points? Be original! At least Origins had it's own track.
Sequencing can be an issue- I just love exploring, sometimes I may decide to get rid of a cultist branch or decide to clear up a region BUT then I get restricted because I haven't progressed in the story enough.
Difficulty- Nightmare difficulty should be nearly unplayable, it is not, it should be really just called 'Hard'. I expected difficulty in other things like stealth instead of just amount of damage I deal.
Dumb AI enemies. Even if you kill in front of them and then break the line of sight, after a while they will just forget about it. Detection is limited on their side as well.
Why can't we fight legendary animals again? I fought those **** boars with all I had and now want to show them who is the boss with my legendary gear BUT no they don't respawn.
Sometimes dialogues are not spoken, even subtitles disappear. Gladly it's not too often but can break the flow of the game. Otherwise bugs are rare and funny.

All said I would totally recommend the game if you like AC series or want to play an rpg which is really easy to get into.
There may be bit of grind but you won't realize it if you are like me who who tries to complete all the regions/side quests.
9/10. Can't wait to spend another 100+ hours.
-Posted on 13th November 2020


Update: Another 100 hours later (240 on steam)-

Recommended
89.5 hrs on record
Posted: 5 July, 2020
As a Classics major, I feel confident enough to say that Assassin's creed Odyssey is one of the most beautifully rendered and faithfully created depictions of the Ancient Greek world in a video game to date. Anyone interested in classical history/mythology will find this game enjoyable in some way, whether interacting with NPCs based on historical figures around the time of the Peloponnesian War, or completing one of the various quests based on Ancient Greek Myths. Interacting and completing quests with Socrates, Demosthenes, Perikles, Kleon, and even Alcibiades bring the accounts of Herodotus and Thucydides to life in true form, and while the historical accuracy is not perfect, it is more that enough to sate the appetite.
However, this Classical fan-service really shines when it makes you forget about the overarching Assassin's Creed story. I have never played an Assassin's Creed game before this one (as the setting was what piqued my interest), but so far I am not a fan of the Isu plot-line, nor do I find the cultist quest-line enjoyable. When placed in the context of Ancient Greece, these plot-points seem confusing, intrusive, and just plain goofy. My opinion on this aspect of the game probably would be different if I was a lifelong fan of the series, but as a person who was mainly interested in the setting and the history on which the game is based, it feels like one of the most unwelcome aspects of the experience.
Shortly on the gameplay, exploration boils down to finding camps/temples/caves filled with soldiers, looting them, killing captains, and escaping. Quests are often rewarding and interesting with exceptions, and the cities in which quests can be found are visually vibrant, especially Athens which is bigger than some entire provinces. Overall, I am enjoying this game and would recommend it to any person with a Classical bone in their body.

Recommended

Posted: 17 October, 2018
Attention, this game is not really Assassin's Creed, it barely has 2 cutscenes about Assassin's Creed in it. And that is a good thing and let's hope it will stay this way.

First of all. it is a true God of War adventure set in Greece. You start out as a simple merc who turns into a demi-god. The epicness is everywhere and it feels like a standalone title set on explaining this world of Greece, Mythos, people and setting. The gameplay is that of a good (1st time in the series) RPG. It combines elements of many modern games such as Dark Souls in form of combat style with lock on, very good accurate dodge system (unlike Origins), and Parry, you can also roll by holding dodge longer. Getting behind opponents back is rewarded. Shooting bow finally feels accurate and steady too. It now depends upon your skill and not bad game mechanics. Enemies have good accurate hitboxes and their moveset is where you expect it to be. If you want you can play stealthy. There are plenty of abilites (3 classes, ranged, warrior, rouge) that you get to choose upon leveling up with several layers of levels to them. You can only have a certain amount of said abilities equipped at once ala Witcher 3. Overall, combat feels very very good and accruate this time around. If you have skill you can be sure you will not fail in this game. It is also fairly cinematic and bloody (if you enable blood).

The story is finally fun and has no kiddie hoodies (I am sorry I can no longer take Assassins in light of AC games seriously, they look like superheroes to me and I find them childish). The story is that of a fully fledged RPG that could be its own series, has little to do with AC games and it is good. The quests are Witcher 3 -esque. You can ask questions like in any other RPG and you get to make choices from time to time. Hell you can even romance. Quests are fun and this time around dialogue is cinematic which makes it fun to listen to (unlike Origins, in fact all the things Origins did even though it was a step in right direction are nothing compared to this game).

The exploration is fun and there is even a non-guided mod that allows you to play this game like an old school RPG where you are told to do something and there is no point to where to go, you gotta figure it out by listening to what people tell you. There are also investigation missions ala Batman Arkham series or Witcher 3. Loot is rewarding and it is fun to explore places looking for new cool boss fights and loot. Besides, the map itself is (oh again) Witcher-esque in a way that it has many locations marked with question marks that you can explore at will.

Interface is nice and is fully customizable this time around. I turned off a coupla three things straight away. Bounty meter, hidden player lightup (whatever it is called in game) etc.

Items have unique properties to them and various stats besides their good looks. You can really customize your character combining them with skills and adding engravings (like runes) with various stats to gear.

Like all movement climbing has been improved, it now feels much more realistic, fluid and fun. Kinda feels like you are doing unspeakable feats of breavery when you climb mountains like you are a part of a myth yourself climbing Olimpus. Horse navigation has been improved.

Finally, main characters. Alexios and Kassandra are both very fun and very good. I am saying this because right now there is an on-going trend which essentially tells people that Alexios is boring, bad voice acting, bland, etc well it is simply not true. First of all the animations are on par, 2nd of all the player model is great and the voicing is superb. I played Mass Effect Andromeda as Female (I'm a dude) but this time I felt more like playing as a male demi-god hero and it took me great pains to decide after hearing all this rant on how he is bad. Well he is not. In fact I like him more than Kassandra. The difference is Kassandra is lovely, she can be sad, or funny. He is more ruthless, angry, but also roguish. Both are good, but if you want to play male, don't fret pick Alexios you won't regret.

The only thing you might not like is level restriction which forces you to not engage something that is 5 lvls above you because you can do nothing to kill it. 4 levels is extremely slow and hard too, and so on. But this is not too much of an issue because game leads you from one area of level to the other so if you do not go exploring wildly you will be okay. Side quests are fun so it is not painful to level up. If you do wanna explore at will you can level up and abandon story for a bit and go explore regions that are suited to your level. Don't worry game will always be challenging in terms that enemies and quests will scale to your level if you out level them. So feel free to forget about main quest. However, if you do not want to level up you can (I strongly don't suggest) buy some boosters to level up but there are other ways to get your self level up on pc that do not require that. So if you so much desire you can get max level as the game starts and put it on hard and play it like a really really fun game that doesn't level lock you. But otherwise it is a standard RPG practice.

Graphics are crisp, terrain and architecture is top notch. It is all just so beautiful to look upon. Very very good and is very nicely done, not really taxing my system on high I get 50-60 fps in 1080 on 980 GTX and i7 980 which is an 8 year old CPU 1st gen of i7s albeit 6 cores with base speed 3,3. Ubi added AVX update in 1.03 that enables older cpus. 12 Ram.

Overall, this is the only game in Assassin's Creed Franchise that is really like while in the past I really liked AC 1, 2, Flag. Origins is not so bad but it was a 1st attempt and this is finally the mark. So please Ubisoft make quality games like this and do not do conveyor belt bad games anymore. Also, It feels good that people in your studios got tired of making the same game over and over and tried to experiment and it led you to such grand success. So use AC brand if you must but leave all the stuff that makes them Assassin's Creed and just keep making Odyssey styled RPGs.

Recommended
93.2 hrs on record
Posted: 29 November, 2018
TL:DR
If you are an AC fan or you like Ancient Greece history, this game is definitely for you.

PROS
- Like in AC Origins, you get to play two characters, here a brother and sister. And yes, main story is different for each.
- At the beginning, the game feels quite similar with AC: Origins.
- True, there are the same team and concepts behind the game. But apart from taking place in the Ancient Greece (as opposite to Origins which was modeled in Ancient Egypt), Odyssey seems a little bit more fluid than Origins in game-play and has a much longer story than its predecessor.
- Nice story, beautiful graphics, great open world.
- No need to spend a dime in the game unless you want some of the rarest items available.
- As in AC Origins, you also have an arena to play.
- Obviously, like in Origins, you get a fully narrated Discovery Tour mode that takes you along all important places in the game (the ancient Greece modeled at scale) with real historical facts about the ancient Greece.
- With several improvements in the combat mechanics and using a different jump key (this time is SHIFT instead of SPACE that now goes to dodge function) the game does a good job at immersing you into the history of Peloponnesian wars.
- At times, for the sake of the main story, the historical facts are not accurately described.
- Don`t expect to see a lot of Abstergo or the Animus tech in Odyssey though, because like in Origins, the developer opted for a low-profile on the modern part of the franchise`s story, but I can`t say it does negatively affect the game at all.
- The main story is fairly long and if you want to spend more time in the game there are plenty of side chain-quests each with its interesting own story.

CONS
- If the game was not shaped for RPG (by using those annoying multiple boring dialogues instead of structured cutscenes) it would have been a wonderful game.
- Like many similar open-world games, you have to walk, swim or ride huge distances to get to objectives. But then you can just teleport in the discovered regions, so it's not a big issue.
- In-game micro-transactions, mainly cosmetics but EXP boosters too.
- A damn shame AC Valhalla is not available for Steam. That too.

BRICKKCIRB

Not Recommended
205.7 hrs on record
Posted: 31 August, 2019
I have a hard time recommending this game; there is a genuinely good experience in there, but this is definitely a flawed product.

The first, most persistent and most glaring issue is that it is simply far too padded in almost every way. Exploring such cities as Sparta and Athens would be fun, but the sheer scale of Odyssey's world (not at all aided by the lack of variety in most of these locations) makes exploring a chore. This is not at all helped by the rinse-repeat locations; there is little variety or joy in exploring different forts, guard camps, or tombs that all look exactly alike. While each of these activities are fun the first couple of times, the experience definitely becomes grating after a while.

The leveling system in this game certainly does not help matters. Certain zones are locked behind level-caps; your own skill as a player matters little as you are almost certainly unable to beat the foes in areas even a few levels ahead of you. Early in my experience I assumed this was the worst aspect of leveling, but I was mistaken. The true issue is also tied into the gearing system.

The original level cap for this game was 50; later expanded to 70, and as of this review expanded to level 99. Once you pass an area's level cap, the enemies own level raises to about two below your own, to keep the game interesting. However, your gear does NOT automatically level up with you; you must continually either find or upgrade gear. This is a problem, as under-leveled gear severely affects your capabilities. What is more, the cost of upgrading gear - something you will want to do frequently especially for legendary set bonuses - becomes prohibitively expensive the higher your level grows. It gets to a point where you genuinely hope that you DON'T level up, so that you can remain as competent as you currently are. This is a serious issue that affects basic enjoyment of gameplay.

This padding also affects the story; many times you feel like you are going through seemingly unnecessary busywork to progress to the interesting parts. This makes much of the game feel like a chore or a job, a deadly sin for any entertainment.

What makes all of this worse is that there are good moments in the story; your character's interaction with their family both found and by blood, the feeling of being an Greek hero straight from the epics. This is an RPG in the truest sense, where many storylines depend both on skilled gameplay and decision-making, often with unintended consequences. I do think that the game would have found more success if they had dropped the connection to the Assassin's Creed franchise altogether, as it seems clear that the writers had little interest of connecting it to the broader world of that story.

In the end, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game. Watch videos of it, read articles, look at stories, but the actual experience is long, arduous, and just not entirely worth the sheer amount of time and effort it asks of you.
