Beware! Some MalÃ¡kas optimized this, especially FoA episode 3

1. Graphics and Optimization

The game looks colorful and great visually, especially some islands and certain DLC locations such as Elysium and Atlantis. Although this game runs mostly at 60fps with Vsync on (to prevent screen tear), this game has some serious stuttering. The game stutters randomly and frequently, which is quite frustrating. Although I did not face any crashes in the base game, when I got into the 3rd episode of the FoA DLC, the stutters became very frequent, and the game started crashing abruptly many times. If you google "AC odyssey Atlantis episode 3 crashing", you will see that it is a common issue.

My specs: RTX3060, AMD Ryzen 5 3600, 16 GB RAM. I tried changing the settings, especially the ones people recommend changing (lowering volumetric clouds, disabling fullscreen optimizations, updating drivers etc.). I have done a lot of research and watched many videos to fix these frequent stutters, only to realize that many face these random stutters even on high end machines. I even played and tested it on another system (GTX1060-6GB, i7 8th gen, 16GB RAM), but I found stutters on that as well.

And recently, during a free weekend, I tried AC Valhalla and it ran at solid 60fps with no stutters! If I have an RTX3060 and the latest AC game can run at 60fps with no stutters, why is this (the previous AC game) stuttering a lot? FFS, even RDR2 runs at constant 60fps. I heard that the devs have made a 60fps patch for new gen consoles, but why are they not optimizing this game for the PC platform or fixing the crashes in FoA episode 3 that many are facing? . Why is there a partiality? Do studios not care about PC users?

2. Story and gameplay

The story is interesting as it involves some cultists targeting your in-game family and it gets personal enough to keep playing. While the story is engaging, the mid to end game is a chore. You must kill 42 cultists across the map, and it is all rinse and repeat stuff. After some time, you would get fed up with clearing forts, clearing camps, fetch quests, etc. In short, the quests become repetitive. Ya want proof? The game itself acknowledges it ğŸ˜Š:

When the game itself admits that the quests are repetitive :) 
A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Odyssey
By: AnandNW


Combat might feel a bit sloppy, and the combat animations (especially some animal animations during fights) might look a bit janky, but it is ok as you would get used to it. Early on, the enemies would be like bullet sponges. Even basic enemies would require a lot of hits to take down (even after levelling up and upgrading weapons/armour). However, during the mid to late game, you would get some great legendary weapons /armor sets and by then you would have some OP abilities and a great CRIT chance. I got the deluxe edition which has those temporary XP boosts which helped me level up fast. If you are getting the standard edition, get ready to grind (do copy-paste missions on message boards over and over), unless you are planning to purchase the XP boosters and other microtransactions to level up faster or gain resources instantlyğŸ˜Š.

3. DLCs (non-free ones)

Fate of Atlantis

This DLC offers 3 episodes and all 3 are set in 3 separate locations, 2 of which are gorgeous. Although it looks good, the story is cringe-inducing and nonsensical. Also, the whole animus stuff and bringing back to modern day thing is so unbecoming that the story creators do not seem to have any innovative ideas to create a good lore. Even in the base game, there are these animus missions which sometimes start after doing some quests and take you to long loading screens and then you do some generic puzzles or walk to a place only to be rewarded with nonsensical dialogues. As I mentioned in the optimization section, 3rd episode of this DLC is where I experienced the worst FPS drops, stutters and crashes.
Legacy of the first blade

This is actually a decent DLC. I like how they added Persian cultists and Xerxes (Do not expect historical accuracy, their masks look cool though) to the story. Some people donâ€™t like this DLC because some choices donâ€™t matter, but it is an alright DLC considering how the Persian cultists play mind games with the protagonist and how personal it gets.

4. 100% completion

This game is a chore to 100% and it is going to take a lot of time. One day, I decided to 100% this game, not just all the achievements but all the side missions across the base game and the DLCs. It took so much time and it became so repetitive that I regret that decision even now. If you are targeting just the achievements, I would say around 150-200 hours considering all the DLCs. If you are targeting to complete all the achievements as well as all the side quests from all DLCs, then I would say around 300 hours, unless you are trying to rush through the game.

Some side missions are funny, and some are interesting, but most of them are repetitive fetch quests. But the good thing is that there is only one missable achievement in the whole game and that is in the FoA DLC. So, you wouldnâ€™t need to replay the whole game to get any alternate ending achievements etc., which is weird for an RPG, but it is fine from a completionistâ€™s perspectiveğŸ˜Š. Also, you would need both the DLCs to 100%.

5. Final words

Overall, the game is a bag of mixed feelings. The story is engaging enough up to a point and depending on how much you can tolerate repetitive tasks; you might end up either punting this to backlog or finishing it. I was planning to not give either a thumbs up or a thumbs down review. However, the problems I mentioned in the first section are severe and the fact that every major release or console port released is coming out unoptimized needs to get attention. We are paying for these products, and we expect them to be optimized.

This game is a complete different re-imagination & huge open world rendition of the original Assassin's Creed series games!

Set in ancient Greek during the Peloponnesian war, the game takes you through an odyssey filled with magnificent and beautiful open world set on a huge scale. It's filled with an immersive & impressive storyline that sometimes have such twist & turns which makes you wonder what is true & what is lie!
You are a misthiosâ€¦.in a land of adventure, war, love, courtship, friendship, betrayals, joy, sorrow, fear & surprises. You can either be an Spartan or an Athenian or simply a soldier of fortune moving from one location to another in search for riches, it's up to you to be what you want to be. After all its your own Odyssey!

Here are some general pros & cons as per me.
Pros
Huge open world scale filled with beautiful & breathtaking landscapes of ancient Greece.
Pretty long & immersive storyline filled with so many choices that will dynamically alter your path & your story. Easily takes 50+ to complete the storyline & adding side-quests to that will drastically increase your playtime.
The game never feels boring. There is always something new to be discovered, something new to be encountered. Every settlements, every beach, every road, every stones tells an interesting story of time.
Graphics is really great. The details, the landscapes, the beaches, the sea, the mountains, the plains are all very aesthetically pleasing. The general graphical fidelity of the game is awesome.
Gameplay is pretty decent as well. Player controls like combat/ movement/ diving are pretty decent.
Good gears are not that hard to find & not very hard to upgrade either. Various resources are also distributed decently in the world map. More harder & more challenging missions gives more precious rewards.
Photomode is really cool & is very powerful. You will be able to capture beautiful virtual photographs if you decide to spend some time in the in-game photomode.
Custom quest maker seems awesome but I have not personally tried it yet.
DLC was pretty good & had a very good amount of new contents (new maps, quests, stories, weapons, armors, etc.) & Ubisoft kept pushing new contents for a decent amount of time.

Cons
Levelling up without is extremely painstaking! Ubisoft intentionally did it to push people towards their online store where you can buy XP & Coins boost. Kind of a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ move!
Game is not very well optimized. Huge areas & cities like Athens will bring your cpu & the framerate down to their knees on higher graphics settings....doesn't matter what CPU you have in your system.
Some gameplay features like horse riding through the towns & cities can be improved & polished even more.
Prices for various cosmetic items, weapons, armors, consumables, etc. in the microtransaction store are absolutely atrocious.
The fiasco regarding the custom quest maker exploit could have been handled by Ubisoft in a much better way than it was in my opinion.

Overall Ratings: 8.5/ 10

Not Recommended
117.8 hrs on record
Posted: 17 March
TL;DR: Assassin's Creed Odyssey is a great example on how you can iterate on mechanics throughout a franchise and still end up with a product that is significantly worse than any of its predecessors.

I'll first start speaking about the few things that I thought were good about this game. The environments are pretty and the historic structures are marvels to look at. I also appreciate the addition of a soft enemy lock on when you initiate an attack that was not present in Origins. This is beneficial to keyboard players as it allows you a measure of precision without having to rely on the lock on. The abilities that were added made combat scenarios more dynamic and enjoyable.

And now, the bad, and there's a whole lot of bad. Since I'm already on the combat I'd like to take a moment to address how it feels when compared to Origins. Both games mostly shy away from stealth and rely more on action rpg elements but Origins doesn't suck to play. Unlike the game before Odyssey draws out its combat scenarios by giving enemies larger health pools, attacks also lack the audio impact that they did in Origins. This leads to a situation where you every engagement just feels like you're chipping away some damage until the target dies. The personality that the different bow types had were instead replaced by abilities which are tied to a resource meter, making archery not as fun and free. The upgrade system instead of just being money only now requires materials which scale to ridiculous amounts. The rate at which you gain xp in the base game practically makes it necessary to grind the boring sidequests in order to progress in the main story. Quest design gets old very fast, there was a certain point in the story where every quest was *Talk to X person for information, X person says do something for me and I will help you, complete these 3 side objectives.* Also nobody in Ubisoft thought that you should be able to track multiple quests at once rather than switching between each? This has been a feature since at least games like Skyrim came out. Ship combat was brought back yet again but instead of being a fun experience like it was in Black Flag it merely feels like a means to pad out the large world map with copy pasted bases and camps. And finally the story, oh boy is it bad. Despite all the problems I mentioned I was kind of enjoying the story up until the third act. This is where the game becomes fetch quest simulator just so you can find one character and then after all of that it feels like it ends kind of abruptly and even in a contrived manner. Elysium DLC story was wack as well but at least the new environments are very pretty, though they are ruined by the same map filled with enemy camps design.

And for the last bit of my review I will quickly list off some minor annoyances:
Map design is as wide as an ocean but as deep as a puddle.
No sprint button means a fixed on foot movement speed
Horses have no sprint either even though in the first game they had it
Horse speed is slowed down automatically in cities unless you use mods to change it
Layla real world story makes me laugh

In conclusion, I don't like this game, Origins was actually fun and didn't waste my time. If you like run of the mill ubisoft open world games then this might suit you though

Angelos79
6,521 products in account
0
7 people found this review helpful 2

Recommended
211.1 hrs on record
Posted: 6 September, 2020
AC Odyssey is a RPG developed and published by Ubisoft. It's completely different from earlier installment of AC games - since it ditches the stealth based mechanics and adopts the concept of an open-world .

Starting with the narrative set in the modern day, the game follows characters named Layla Hassan and her friend Victoria, who with the help of assassins, manage to find DNA of 2 "Misthios". Using the DNA of one of the misthios, they activate the "ANIMUS", in-order to find the location of the Staff of Hermes - there by kick starting the odyssey in Greece.

The game's historical story is set in Greece, a few hundred years before the events of Assassin's Creed Origins which was set in Egypt. AC odyssey time-line occurs during Peloponnesian War, which was fought between Sparta and Athens. The player takes on the role of a young misthios and can chose between Kassandra or Alexios. AC odyssey tells us the "greek tragedy" of the protagonist and how the character continues with his "journey" to find and mend his fractured family. .

PROS:
-----
- A visual masterpiece - The visual depiction of Greece in its full glory is unbelievable. Greece is split into multiple regions and each region looks breathtaking. The level of accuracy, attention to detail is second to none. I have spent countless hours, in awe, navigation through various areas just for the sake of exploration.

- Memorable Characters - Apart from the protagonist, there is a huge array of supporting cast, which are seen through out the game. Players encounter prominent personas, including Alkibiades, Brasidas, Kleon, Herodotos, Hippokrates, Plato, Pythagoras, Sokrates and many others. Not to mention the countless love interests protagonist has in this game. It looks like ubisoft wanted to get a step further than EA when it came to romantic interests.

- Combat - AC odyssey combat is different from its predecessors. It features an in-depth combat mechanic - which comprises of 3 major trees. Hunter (Ranged), Warrior (Melee) and Assassin (Stealth). There is another additional option named "Mastery" which is available to the player after a certain level. Mastery will help the player sharpen hunter, warrior & assassin skill trees further by increasing their stats. Players can build their characters the way they want. Last but definitely not least, NAVAL COMBAT, which is brings an additional dimension in combat.

- Weapons and Armor - AC Odyssey presents the user with insane amount of weapons and armor. The user has the option of collecting armor sets (which is bit of a grind) that boosts stats of the player in an unique way or mix n match with armor pieces. Weapons, like Armor, are divided into four types of rarity - Common, Rare, Epic, and Legendary. This is a very broad topic to discuss and also depends on the play-style of the individual.

- Mythology - Greek mythology started as purely academic for me but I fell in love with the legends and the complex stories . The stories of Hercules, Troilus and Cressida, Hector, Ajax, Odysseus, Jason, Theseus, Paris, Agamemnon and many other larger than life characters, their amazing journeys,kept me hooked. Not to mention gods, their power struggle and their complex stories. I am not a greek history or mythology expert, my point of view is purely from a person who used to love these stories/characters as a kid and how the game reminded me that they are more than just stories and I was able to connect with it.

- Mercenary tree - Ubisoft has introduced something which can be related to "Nemesis" system in Middle earth Shadow of mordor. There will be mercenaries out to hunt the player, based on the notoriety the player has caused on a specific region. The more notoriety the player has created, the higher the bounty that will be placed on the player. Once the bounty is placed/accepted, the mercenary starts to track down the player. A maximum of five mercenaries can hunt a player at any time. Some of the best weapons in this game can be obtained from these mercenaries.

- Story - Greek mythology, with amazing characters, family conflict and many more aspects are wonderfully inter-woven and presented as a complete package. Not to mention, great side stories, which makes the game even more interesting. Player choice is worth the mention - as the story becomes distinctly different based on the choices that the player makes throughout the game. The story tends to get deviating at times, but at its core, it is an extremely competent narrative which is better than most of its predecessors - IMO.

- Open world - The open world which contains stunning Greek landscape, ranging from forests with predators/animals, to the caves, temples and tombs the player can explore, to the majestic white marble buildings in cities, finding artifacts and everything in between. The journey from one city to another, with dolphins and whales the player can view while travelling on sea - is amazing.An open world like no other. See it to believe it.

NEUTRAL:
-------
- Story creator - Story Creator Mode is a utility that allows an user to create customized missions. This mode allows you to select characters, tasks, areas & items that will be part of your mission. In addition, you can write your own dialogues to make your quests unique. I didn't use this feature at all, so i do not have an opinion on this.

NOT SO GOOD:
-----------
- This game is long, i mean very very long and it took me 211 hours to finish the game - along with all DLC's and side quests. Ubisoft wanted this game to be "never ending" and I , for one, am not at all complaining. But there is a good chance that some people may find this a little frustrating or off-putting - since it can tend to get repetitive.

- "Siege / conquest battles" or battle in general will fail to provide any sort of challenge and will tend to "look" the same - when the player reaches a certain level - even at extreme difficulty. Plus, the player becomes a "demi-god" who deals insane levels of damage, at some point of time in the game, which makes most battles trivial. These things can be a bit off-putting to many players.

CONS:
----
- One of the things which bothered me is that the game doesnt "conclude" on completing the vanilla variant of the game. The "real" ending can only be accomplished by playing a dlc called "The Fate of Atlantis" - which the user needs to buy additionally. This should not have been the case and Ubisoft has a set a very bad trend by making the user pay more so as to finish the game.

-Micro transactions - Micro transaction shop uses Helix Credits, which are bought with real-world cash or Ubisoft Club points - to obtain many gear sets(which are not available in game) and cosmetics (especially skins).Ubisoft also introduces a way to "help players save time" - a pay to win method of gaining experience quickly, since the game is bit of a grind. Let me be honest in saying most of the resources needed to upgrade/progress are available in-game and you would need to grind to get it. The grind not impossible or even extreme, but is one hell of a grind nonetheless. The grind can get to some players and ubisoft providing this "optional" method of quickening player experience can entice a lot of players into buying them. It looks like they created this "problem" to sell you the solution. A horrible practice IMO - Malaka.

CONCLUSION:
-----------
Is this the best AC game? It's subjective. I have only played AC1 and the exceptional AC Black Flag - which puts me in the casual category. Personally, for me, AC Odyssey is a tie with Black Flag. A beautifully crafted Greek world, great story,amazing open world, with countless hours of fun, with un-forgetable characters, mixed with greek mythos - in-short an exceptional RPG experience, despite the "Not so good" & "Cons" mentioned above. To the AC casuals like me, I would say, go for it and you will have an unforgettable experience.

Posted: 4 January, 2021
The game is huge, packed with content with vast and beautiful world to explore.

Main story is pretty decent with multiple endings.

Side quests are plenty, some are long chain events that have interesting characters that you get to know and meet again multiple times through the game and there are also filler quests that are less interesting, but part of any game of this size.

Voice acting is pretty good, especially two playable characters did great work.

There are plenty of armor and weapons with nice skins that you can apply at any time once you discover them.

Combat is kinda mixed bag. I mostly like it, but difficulty is unbalanced. I usually play game on highest difficulty, but here it's a chore and looks ridiculous as you stab enemy 50x and he's laughing at your face. Only at the end game when you are nearing level 50, you'll be able to have a build and gear to take spongy enemies down quickly enough.

One of the most frustrating annoyances are civilians, who randomly aggro and join the fight against you for no reason. You are fighting guards or bounty and suddenly a guy with a broom decided to play a hero and comes poke at you.

Romances are terrible. They are basically all one night stands and are just cringy and akward.

Micro-transactions have no place in single player games!

To everyone who like long games, exploration and taking their time with first playthrough, I can recommend the game. To those that just want to rush main story and maybe a side quest here and there, game might feel "grindy".

PastHaze
588 products in account
3
7 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
98.2 hrs on record
Posted: 11 December, 2018
Perhaps a bit too late, but the developers of Assassin's Creed have at last released their Magnum Opus.

I am no stranger to Assassin's Creed. I own most of the games, including Bloodlines (that PSP exclusive), 2, Brotherhood, Revelations, 3, Black Flag, Rogue, Unity, Syndicate and now Odyssey. That being said, my relationship with the franchise is... interesting to say the least. Being a history buff, my main appeal to the franchise is the ability to explore open-world cities from history. I enjoyed the franchise for many years, but that peak was probably around Black Flag (my personal favourite). After that, I lost interest. I bought Rogue because it wrapped up the Kenway trilogy. I bought Unity simply because of my fascination with the French Revolution and consequent Napoleonic Wars. I bought Syndicate because I am British myself and wanted to explore London as it was in the Victorian era. After Syndicate, however, I stopped. I never bought Origins. Even though Ancient Rome is one of my favourite periods in history (Origins being set in Egypt at the same time as Caesar rose and fell from power), I no longer felt compelled to play the series.

Fastforward to Odyssey. By this point, it's a few years since I have last purchased an Assassin's Creed game. I have little-to-no interest in the franchise. I don't watch any of the trailers, I don't even know the names of the main characters. I see the game on sale, a month or two after release, and decide to try it out. Why not? The game series has rarely been a disappointment in the past.

With my expectations at rock bottom, prepared to use the game as a filler whilst away from uni for Christmas, I started up Odyssey.

My, oh my, was I blown away.

Further research answers many questions. It appears as though after the controversy of Unity, the developers took extreme measures to re-direct the franchise. It is evident, though I don't want to draw too many similarities, that they took a lot of inspiration from The Witcher games. Odyssey is, quite clearly, a narrative driven RPG and very different to previous installments. I, personally, feel as though this was a good decision.

This has, it must be said, divided the fan base. There are many (and I am sure you have seen them scrolling through the reviews) who are upset at this game because it's not really an Assassin's Creed game. And, to be fair to them, it isn't. But that doesn't matter. There is no Creed, there are no Templars, there are no hidden blades, not much from the start of the franchise is left standing by Odyssey. However, this was a necessary loss. The franchise was becoming dated and Ubisoft made the executive decision to evolve into the RPG that Odyssey is.

The first thing that hits you when you play the game is how beautiful it is. The graphics are incredible, especially on PC. It runs very well, there are almost no bugs or glitches, even without mods it looks and runs better than most other games I own that I have decided to mod. The map is huge. I honestly think it is the largest open-world map I have ever played, spanning all of Greece from Themoplaye in the North to Krete in the South without a single barrier or loading screen seperating regions or city entrances. It truly is remarkable and the attention to detail is mind-blowing.

The characters are incredibly varied and well written, the story is compelling. The combat, though poor by the standards I am used to (see: Mount & Blade: Warband), is certainly more challenging than previous Assassin's Creed games (and better than the likes of The WItcher 3). All in all, I am thoroughly impressed (and suprised) by Odyssey. Ubisoft evidently worked hard on this title, and to be frank, if it didn't have the words 'Assassin's' or 'Creed' in the title I am sure it would be gaining far more receptions. In a year when Red Dead Redemption 2 was released, Ubisoft have not messed around and have made a genuine attempt to compete.

There are, of course, some issues with the game. From a franchise perspective, it has very little in common with the other games which, as already mentioned, does upset some people. Other issues include the fact that there is a levelling system. This is in some ways beneficial, because it forces you to do the side-quests and things in order to progress with the story or even to get to a high enough level to safetly explore certain regions. However, my gripe with it includes the fact that it limits the exploration and freedom allowed in the game and it also means that certain items - armour and weapons - become obsolete the moment you level up. Some people are apparently complaining about pay-to-win and spending money on exclusives? I am thoroughly in to this game without spending a single Â£ more than when I initially purchased it, nor have I been hinted to do so. I don't know where people are coming from with this.

All in all, a thoroughly ambitious, enjoyable and unexpectedly impressive entry to the Assassin's Creed universe.

Posted: 30 May, 2020
So I played about 80+ hours I think, long enough to complete all of the main quest, and whatever side quests were required so that I could level up and continue main - I did not buy the DLC because the base game was deeply dissatisfying and I won't give it any more of my money.

This game has a litany of issues: The combat is confusing and not as weighty as Origin's - if you want to stafe literally ever you have to use their weird toggle lockon (seriously, give players the option to strafe or make the lockon a hold-button option), The story occasionally waxes interesting - but the premise of mercenary goes out into the world is stale, and the story takes dozens of crappy shortcuts because apparently properly grounding the story in good dialogue and solid sci fi themes was too much. This game is also much buggier than Origins - which leads me to my next, much bigger point:

This game is too damn big - it's so big picture oriented that the small picture moment-to-moment gameplay suffers deeply because of it. The sheer size of the game is a massive contributing factor to why the combat, story, and resiliancy of this game have suffered - by the simpler virtue that on the dev side there was too much to do, too much to test and in the end it apparently could not all get done.

AC: Origions, in my opinion, was an excellent change of pace - it was atmospheric, gripping, and rewarding to play. Odyssey did not have any of those things in comparison. There's very little atmosphere beyond greek capitalism, the story is clunky and trips over itself, and after a while finding gold and mats feels less like a reward and more like a grind.


This game is not all horrible, and I hope the good parts carry forward:
- Visual customization of the character is good
- Having the character react more often to Isu ruins helps ground the player in that character's view, and gives us context for how those ruins should make us feel - the era of the silent protagonist is over, give me perspective.
- Once you level way, waaaay up the combat becomes bearable and even a little fun - being able to spartan kick dudes or insta kill them is the big good feel.
- Sailing is still awesome, not really much to say there. Thought Origin's had better ship combat but only because their combat was new and weird - Odyssey ship combat was still good, liked cutting other ships in half.

In conclusion, save your money for Valhalla - go watch this game on Youtube

"ÎŒÎ¼Î¿ÏÏ†Î· ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î•ÎºÏƒÏ„Î±Ï„Î¹ÎºÎ®" -Beautiful and Ecstatic


Assassin's Creed Odyssey goes way back to 430 BCE taking to Ancient Greece while in its Glory 2500 years ago, where the Fathers of many fields were born amidst the iconic wars between Sparta and Athens. With a lot of famous people including Leonidas, Pericles, Hippocrates, Socrates.. The game never ceases to provide depth to whatever it offers, not just the main story but also every single side quest, you will always find yourself dazzled and totally immersed in the game. The huge 256 - 260 sq.km Map of ancient Greece has everything to offer in its own glory and each location you visit, welcomes you with a unique twist of culture and you can literally feel the satisfaction your heart gets when you visit them. Now why this happens might be due to the fact that every structure in the game is totally true to the real structures found in modern Greece. The Temples, Arenas, Theatres, The seas, vegitation, fauna, mountains, districts, cities, villages, forts, etc. are all very true to reality.

Now, to talk about the features of the game... so we have a BIG AF Map with sufficient Water for you to travel on your Ship, yes you get a Ship like in AC4 BF to fight and salvage other ships, and many islands and vast lands to conquer and explore with all the structures true to real life Greece back in 430 BC. The missions are very immersive. I played as Alexios to keep that original Assassin's Creed Vibe going on and spent around 77 hours in the game at the time I wrote this review, of which, around 50-55 hours were spent on the story which explains how big the game quite is. There is a hige list of around 50 "Cultists" who are also targets and you must kill them. Some of them are encountered via main story quests while others are found via side quests and some are discovered by acquiring clues to their hideouts and whereabouts.
The level up system is well built and you can level up by grinding on with many side quests and bounties. You are basically a mercenary (Misthios) who can fight alongside Sparta or Athens and that's a choice you can make that won't actually affect the main story. BUT, The choices you make are certainly gonna decide the fate of the story. And many such choices, are to be made with precise decisions. Wrong choices can end up killing certain main characters and the story progression might go sideways or other ways.. As you go through the quests(main, side, bounties, exploration), you unlock various weapons and a lot of Legendary weapons, armors and such customizable equipments which can all be upgraded to the highest level you are on with certain looted resources and this gives you the option to make your character look as you like them to. Along with this is the ABILITIES, there are certain abilities that can be used for combat on the press of a button. For your archery, you can use up to 4 abilities among many you unlock and for melee you can use up to 8 abilities among the many you unlock and each can be leveled up to 3 levels of power and maxing it all out and using them in combat, changes the whole combat mode and makes you feel like you are the one man army. The enemies can be less forgiving and you surround yourself with too many of them, you might not be able to make it out alive.

I guess that should summarize the game and to know how the Heavenly world of Greece has been cinstructed in game, you can check out my profile for screenshots I have captured using the in game photo mode. Totally Recommend this game and I value it 10/10. The game definitely deserves Game of the Year for its wonderful and magnificent build, and also the Optimization is very good, performs well on most machines without taking up much juice. So stop Stopping and head over to the store and buy the game. There's absolutely no regret. It is super safe to say this game is one of the best in terms of everything that the Assassin's Creed Franchise has ever built.

168.5 hrs on record
Posted: 14 March
This is the first Assassin's Creed game I've played, so I knew little about the story arc of previous entries, the mix of modern tech and historical storytelling, or of the RPG-style changes this game has had over the earlier ones. All I know is it sucked up a lot of my time and I'd happily revisit it all over again. It really is incredible stuff.

I came into this game off the back of Witcher 3, which obviously has many similarities, but which I didn't even enjoy half as much as Odyssey. It helped that I'm a big fan of ancient Greek history - and if that's you as well, get into this game on the strength of exploration mode alone.

The level progression feels neatly organic, and your skills and the world available to you expands smoothly in line with your familiarity with the controls and mechanics of the game. Hunter, Assassin and Warrior upgrades all felt like they were making a solid difference to my fighting style during combat. And combat isn't a button-mashing borefest - sure, you'll be doing a lot of dashing, but combined with parrying, attacking and pulling out some superpower moves, every fight was really enjoyable.

The story is fantastic; a blend of true history and fantasy, with everyone from Pericles to the Minotaur making an appearance. Some of the cutscenes were a little corny, but this is nitpicking compared to the more sophisticated elements of storytelling. The map is huge - dauntingly huge; I clocked up 168 hours and there are still islands I have to visit. The weapons, armour, clothing, ship upgrades and other perks all have meaningful input into the way you play the game.

And oh ... it's gorgeous. From a purely aesthetic perspective, this game is astounding. From white sand beaches to volcanic islands to bustling agoras, every pixel is lovingly rendered. I could just sit back and watch a bunch of Ikaros cinematics one after the other.

Totally immersive, engrossing and challenging, this is a game I'll head back to more than once.

This was a hard 6.9/10

Pros:
-Beautiful graphics displaying the colorful culture of ancient Greece
-Combat is fun
-It like the AC4 of the current gen line (because you actually have a ship complete with naval combat)
-You get to control an Eagle like in origins.
-The proto-Templars (Cult of Cosmos) were a interesting group.

Cons:
-The huge map is a big plus, but there's no incentive to explore it beside side-quests.
-Occasional glitches but not too big to impact performance.
-A ridiculous paywall
-The time it takes to complete it is way too long. I wouldn't mind it if the game was interesting enough.
-The story is meh.
-It doesn't feel like an "Assassin's Creed" game
________________________________
This is one of those games you sort of.... "own."
You've played it to completion and then forget about it. It sits idle in your game library never to be touched again.
Was it a bad game? no. Was it a good game? no. Do you remember what happens in the game? sorta.
Sure it was a little fun, but nothing too memorable. It wasn't bad either, it was just... "ok."
This is one of those games. The "Oh yeah, I forgot I have this one" game.

Time will tell if Valhalla impresses me, or becomes another one.

Damascus Steel
220 products in account
0
7 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
98.7 hrs on record
Posted: 9 May, 2020
Assassin's CreedÂ® Odyssey: Where the hell is my hidden blade?!

Let me answer that question right off the bat. You will not have a hidden blade at any point in this game. Why? Because the only one who had it at this point was Darius. But let's roll back a bit. Many times you might be hearing people that this latest installment in the Assassin's Creed franchise is not really an Assassin's Creed game. That really depends on the point of view that you take. Yes, you do not have typical robes and iconic hidden blade in this game. But on the other hand, if you are a fan of the series, this latest game will give you more insight into the lore behind the never-ending conflict between assassins and templars. If Assassin's Creed Origins was about the origins of the assassin brotherhood, Odyssey is about the origins of the overall conflict.

The next destination for the Assassin's Creed is Ancient Greece during Peloponessian War. Player gets thrown right into action with Battle of Thermopylae, taking control of none other than spartan king Leonidas, bearing yet another Piece of Eden, this time Spear of Leonidas. After this action packed tutorial setpiece is finished, player can give into the true bones and meat of this game. Right off the bat, player is faced with choice between two characters, Alexios and Kassandra, who are both grandchildren of the famed Leonidas. Kassandra is the canonical main character, however for the sake of the review, term misthios will be used as it is used throughout the game to avoid general confusion as to who the main character is.

With the choice made, player gets placed on misthios's home island of Kephallonia. Everything starts nice and calm, everyone being full of humour and just overall happy with their life, which in typical Assassin's Creed fashion does not stay true for very long and everything goes horribly wrong. And so our misthios has to embark on an epic quest to stop an evil cult, find his father, reunite his family and many other things, which get revealed as player slowly explores the main story as well as the never-ending barrage of sidequests and side content, all accompanied by an amazing soundtrack, which when it comes to Assassin's Creed, never fails to deliver.

Every good heo, in our case misthios , needs a decent combat to make his epic quest feel truly epic. Does the game deliver in this aspect? Well, yes and no. You have everything that Origins had. Basic attacks, parry, dodge roll and special attacks, which have been changed to supernatural attacks and moves, powered by the Spear of Leonidas. And thus for the first time in the Assassin's Creed franchise (let's forget Tyranny of King Washington DLC in ACIII), player will be able to create shockwaves around him to push enemies away, become invisible, set everyone on fire, rush through enemies and many others. This combat is supported by a skill tree, consisting by three sections, that being bow, direct combat and stealth mixed with passive effects such as poison or fire. This skill tree a bit of an improvement from Origins, however the crux of it comes that you will often find yourself not using most of it as you will find that one insanely broken combination and you will never bat an eye at any of the other options. Moreover, some of the combinations are so overpowered, you will not feel challenged by any kind of combat encounter you will meet. Another issue is that with the expansion of the combat system, the most staple product of the franchise suffered. And that is parkour. It has devolved only into climbing up and down, occassionally doing a leap of faith from a high place. So if you wanted your realistic parkour fix with fluid moveset and fun tricks, unfortunately, that is not happening here.

On topic of meeting, I mentioned beforehand enormous amounts of side content. As Ancient Greece was located in the Mediterranean Sea, player will get to explore different islands, almost all of them filled with something to do, be it quests, famed viewpoints, collectibles or optional bossfight. Considering side quests, direct comparison to Witcher 3 must be drawn, as it is almost impossible to miss the inspiration behind how the quests are structured. You will meet a person who will give you a quest, you will do some part of the quest and in 3/4 of cases you will be faced with some sort of choice. The major difference between how Witcher 3 and Odyssey does its quests is that in Odyssey you will feel like whatever choice yuo made had no impact whatsoever on anything happening in the world. Except for a few better developed quests, most of the side stories in Odyssey will feel like placeholder for experience and rewards with no other value whatsoever.

So you might be wondering: How the hell do you travel between this islands? The answer is very simple, but also a bit horrifying. Player gets a ship. Honestly speaking, I wish we would not be given a ship at all. First of all, it breaks a historical immersion as ships were not as promiment as they make them be in this game, however that is a minor detail. The bigger issue comes with two different things. Firstly, ship combat feels nothing like the combat in Assassin's Creed Black Flag . It is hard to desribe it properly, but the feeling is overall off, almost like they only took combat of Black Flag and sped it up and removed the fun sea shanties. Second issue are the ship upgrades which at the end of the date are there only to prolong the gameplay as the high level upgrades are an endless grind for resources, which will discourage you from achieving max level. Only redeeming thing about ships in this game, is that you can recruit lieutanants, which add different passive bonuses to your ship, giving you that good old Brotherhood feeling back.

Unfortunately, that ship will be used to reach important story elements, which is the final point. Story is, blantly put, okay. It is not as well written and directed as Origins as some parts of the game feel unnecessary and plain out boring, serving almost no purpose whatsoever. The story of our dear misthios is once supported by a web of cultists, which the player has to assassinate as they navigate the islands of Ancient Greece. And honestly, that was the most fun part of the game. Going through these targets, figuring out how to kill them in the most efficient way. This web is also more extensive than in Origins, giving you more targets to practice your comabt and sneaking skills at. However, the story of Odyssey has one major issues. As you play through the game, one thing starts to become more apparent. Do you sometimes wake up and have that super dry feelinging in your mouth and you are just like "This is super meh" and so you go for that delicious content called water. Well the story in Odyssey and mainly with its conclusion is that dry mouth except without water to make it go away.

Overall, I do recommend this game. It is fun to explore all of these islands you read about in the historical books, meet all these important characters and fight endless waves of enemies with your new supernatural abilities. This applies twice for Assassin's Creed fans who will get more insight into why the conflict is still ongoing, why it started and where the true "Odyssey" of the Assassin Brotherhood began.

Should you play this game?

We work in the dark to serve the light. And I want to give you that light with three simple questions:
1. Are you an Asssassin's Creed fan?
2. Do you want a solid RPG set in Ancient Greece?
3. Do you want more Witcher-like games?

If you answered YES to any of thsoe questions, strap on your misthios badge and slip into the origins of the centuries long struggle.

PC specifications for reference

Processor: Intel Core i5-5200 @2.2GHz
Graphics card: GeForce 940M 2GB
Memory: 8GB RAM

Recommended
253.8 hrs on record
Posted: 10 March
That is a one massive game. Odyssey now fully consists of RPG elements: a leveling system, talent trees, and dialog options which may affect cutscenes or the ending. You also will opt to choose either Alexios or Kassandra as the main character of your adventure.

Exploration has never been so amazing in this game series. I was so delighted and mesmerized as I explore the world of Greece in this game. Synchronizing viewpoints was one of my favorite activities. Moreover, you will see various "Historical Locations" which I believe might be real places all over Greece. The world design is so complex, every place is pretty much unique - That's what makes it so beautiful.
Like Origins, this world of Odyssey also consists of various tombs (but of course not Pyramids in this one), and after completing it, you will obtain an ability point.

The new combat system has been revised, which makes it even more complex: Each tree grants you various active abilities where you can assign and then use it during a fight. You now collect every piece of gear (head, chest, hands, legs, feet, bow, weapon) and either replace the old ones by new ones, or upgrade by a blacksmith. Compared to Origins, you were gathering materials to upgrade weapon / bow damage. You still have to gather materials to upgrade your gears when going to the blacksmith. Also a new feature called "engraving" whereby you choose to add some additional stats to one of your piece of equipment according to your style of play.

The Naval system is now a crucial part in your journey in the huge world. You will require materials as well to upgrade your ship. You can now add a Lieutenant to your ship, where each will add a beneficial stat to your ship. You get one additional Lieutenant as you upgrade the hull of your ship - up to 4. Whenever you are boarding an enemy ship, those Lieutenants of yours will be helpful, as they will aid you into battle.

Assassination isn't that simple now in this one. You will probably struggle going full stealth if you do not upgrade various Assassination skills in your tree as your Assassination's base damage sometimes might not be enough to 1-hit brutes or captains, or other high-ranked officers. The game is therefore telling you to be smart when choosing your talents...

Music was also one of the big strengths of this game in the series. It really puts you in the mood whenever you are fighting as a spartan. You will also have a lot of emotional moments at some point in time, and the music really plays a big part in that, which makes your adventure even more memorable.

As you progress through the story, there will be many Assassination targets that you will have to kill. As you kill some of them, you will get a clue which will lead you to the next target. Therefore, you will have to dig your way a lot, until you reach to the final target.

I'd say that this game in the series was a pretty big change, and Ubisoft still has room for progression, especially in enhancing the RPG elements. But to this day, this is one of the most impressive games I've played in terms of exploration. It's definitely worth playing, with full of excitement and worth playing again maybe on harder difficulties for new challenges.

Posted: 20 August, 2020
In short:
If you haven't played AC:Origins, don't read further and go play AC:Origins.
If you played AC:Origins, and did not like it, or liked it just for Bayek, don't play this.
If you played AC:Origins, and liked everything about it, play this.

If you are still not convinced, you can read the rest.

Actually, I am quite disappointed with this game - not because it is bad, but because it could be so much better.
The main differences with AC:Origins are:
- Obviously, the country. It's hard to say whether Ancient Greece or Ancient Egypt is better; both are done well. I don't think there is a better depiction of Ancient Greece in video games or in media, for that matter.
- Unlikable main protagonist. Well, maybe likable to some. You are playing as a person of a sex of your choice (I suggest to play as Kassandra), that only cares about money and finding members of his/her family. The game is set during the war between Athens and Sparta, and your daily routine will include weakening one side of the war (by destroying food, stealing money and killing their commanders) so that the other side can attempt to capture the region and will hire you to fight for them. Other activities can include killing innocent people for money because they had business/personal disagreement with your employer, or murdering chicken on a farm just because. Basically, it's an Assassin's Creed without the Creed. It is quite fitting that "CREED" on the logo is smaller than the other words, but it shouldn't be there at all.
- The gameplay is more RPG-like than ever before in the series. However, many elements are either confusing or hard to manage. The inventory / quest management is pretty bad: there are absolutely no sorting options in the inventory, which has a cap ~650 with storage; and poor sorting options in quest log, which can easily reach 50-100 quests. There are choices in dialogues, but they are (with very few exceptions, mostly counter-intuitive) inconsequential. So, good ideas, poor execution in this department.
- Introduced save system. This was a good move.
- Music is worse, in my opinion. But that's just my opinion.
- Naval battles are back, pretty similar to AC4:Black Flag, but probably a bit worse, Not my kind of thing, so I won't talk much about it.

If you are still reading, here is some rant about bad things that remain the same:
- The game is pretty heavy on resources (and together with the game you will need to run Steam, Uplay and Denuvo).
- Ubisoft does not fix bugs, even the most annoying and easy to fix ones (for proof, just google "please move Herodotus to a different spot"; spoiler: he is still there). Also, as with their older games, in couple years you can expect no support at all.

Pros:

- Insanely beautiful. Seriously, as someone who values good visuals, there wasn't much to criticise. Fires had a weird red shine though. Coming from Origins, it also felt like a visual downgrade to me. I used Reshade to desaturate the game a bit, that helped.

- About 70% of the gameplay consists of mindlessly running around, clearing out enemy camps and it was so boring that my brain went off to other worlds. It was weirdly relaxing and productive to explore while brainstorming ideas for a story I was working on and murder various enemies in the background. Kind of a bad sign for a single player game though, if it's so boring that you need to occupy your brain with something else while playing.

- The Atlantis DLC was okay. Quite funny at times.

- It made me want to play Origins again. I love that game.

Cons:

- This is not an Assassin's Creed game. It's a meme-around-in-Ancient-Greece game with no interest in a grounded, historical setting whatsoever. Or in Assassin's Creed.

- The story is so boring, bland, and predictable that I missed Syndicate. Yes, Syndicate. After playing Origins, I had high expectations and Odyssey delivered on absolutely none of them.

- Everything was too long. The quest chains were too long, the DLC was too long, the levelling was too long. Oh hey, I completed one quest objective. Time for another bunch of extra requirements and two new fetch quests on the other side of the map.

- The bloat has gone beyond what I had thought possible. Prepare yourself for hundreds of fetch or kill-ten-of-this-type quests with generic, recycled dialogue. Wanna skip them? Better whip out your wallet and buy the XP booster, lol.

- The Legacy of the First Blade DLC was a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ joke. I did not consent to this.

- Microtransactions in a single player game. Screw you, Ubisoft.

---

Origins made me cautiously optimistic about this new open world RPG spin on Assassin's Creed (although I still prefer the old games). Odyssey made sure to copy everything except for the good bits from Origins and implemented a grind fest instead.

This is a particularly hard game for me to review, i LOVE Assassin's Creed deeply - but Assassin's Creed Oddysey isn't an Assassin's Creed game its something else.

But is it good? Thats a difficut question to answer again i LOVE Assassin's Creed so to begin with i hated this game, i hated pretty much everything about it. I hated it so much that initially i stopped playing it and if i had posted a review then i would have given it a thumbs down.

but now after completing the main campaign and seeing most of the map? i'm willing to just about give it a pass. i spent 60+ hours playing it so obviously i liked something about it.

The story is pretty bad infact when it ends you're not quite sure if it actually has ended. it doesn't resolve itself in any satisfying way doesn't even run credits just drops you straight back in the world so it doesn't really feel like an ending. I understand why they did this but it left me completely unfulfilled and i hope this is addressed in Valhalla.

Characters, the characters are overwhelmingly just kind of meh. Kasandra is the stand out protagonist her voice actor is much better and sounds more natural plus she is the canon way through the story. Phoibe is a nice character but felt like she should have had more character development. The new modern day protagonist Layla is actually pretty decent we need to see alot more character developer for her which seems to be promised in valhalla.

Gameplay is mostly fun. i liked the combat but the traversal is more autopilot then ever before i don't hate it but i also don't feel great doing it. The combat is fun BUT this is also why it's not Assassin's Creed by far the best method of playing is to dump everything into Warrior and run into camps and killing everyone. Stealth has been badly nerfed and is therefore not worth doing.

This game is EXTREMELY grindy if you like that kind of game then you'll be fine for me i hate grinding in most things so i felt compelled to purchase the exp boost from the shop after which the game felt a million times better to play for me.

Finally i HATE level scaling it just means that i level up my character but i don't feel like i've really improved which is a real shame for me, there are arguments both sides for level scaling i fall on the side of WHY?!

In Conclusion Oddysey is a BAD Assassin's Creed game, probably the worst in the series, but it is an enjoyable video game that has plenty of content to keep people busy.

You can kill an entire village yet still be the good guy in the end. Furthermore, there is the bounty system which you get for seemingly no reason be increased by killing innocents. Thatâ€™s not a penalty for killing civilians, thatâ€™s just a pseudo punishment cause they donâ€™t know how to make an actual meaningful RPG with consequences and consistency, they are damage spongy annoying enemies who even break the game at points. In my case I actually hope the game to last 80 hours but would not be too angry if it just takes me to play somewhere between 60 to 80 hours. I call it the AckermanValue. If you buy a game for 20â‚¬ and you play just 8 hours, then your Ackerman value is just 20/8=2,5. If you buy ACO GE for 100â‚¬ and you play 180 hours than you have a AckermanValue of 0,56 which is preeeeetty neat!!! You should always try to have an AckermanValue of not more than 0,8!! And yes it might differ, when the experience of playing changes your opinion. Positive Experience is affecting the AckermanValue and is called the AdvancedAckermanValue (AAV). Developers can hardly predict the general AAV which is why they should focus on a nice AV. I think I made my point clear enough here.

Back to the game - just buy it already and stop reading reviews. You are most likely going to enjoy it!!

AC ORIGINS

Before I start I want to talk about AC Origins.
Ac Origins made me love egypt despite me hating egyptian culture and landscape. They made boring places like deserts and pyramits so much fun to wonder around. Quests Dlcs and content itself was goodly balanced in Origins and I got over 100 hours in Origins.( I played every assassins creed game except chronicles)



ASSASSIN'S CREED ODYSSEY a flawed Masterpiece:

Timeline, places, Content:

Odyssey is set on Peloponnesian war Era of Ancient Greece and I love that timeline and its Mythology. This is a perfect setting for me to play in. Story in my opinion was better than Origins due to all that family stuff. Also characters and people we interact are so much fun and relatible than boring Egyptians. On the other hand I loved greek architecture and cities. World is so colorful and every city looks different.Cities are full of temples of Greek gods and their statues. Outside sities are even more beautiful to look at. There are
misty greedy forests, snowy mountains, volcanic islands, pink threes as well as Orange and brown forests. Map itself is so big I still have places I never went yet. I still did not played dlcs and lost tales of greece. I also did not killed all cultists. In the middle of the game I lost myself due to searching for cultists and those damn merceneries. I hate mercenery system.
There is always conflict and when you cause trouble merceneries came to hunt you. I remember countless times that I got killed by a mercenery when I cleared a camp. All my progress in that camp goes back to where I started because it does not save inside conflict areas. I also got killed by merceneries before I confirm kill cultist which also sucks. I think mercenery system is unnecessary. I always paid my bounties to keep me out from trouble when I started to get rich because it is the only thing in this game that bothered me so much.

Mythical Creatures:
In our journey to find seals we fight 4 mythical creatures:
Cyclops
Medusa
Sphinx
Minotaur
There was also another Cyclops I saw behind a temple which was not bound to seal quest line so I believe there is more Mythical beasts around. Dont worry this beasts are related to ISU so game keeps the realty.


WHAT A EXPERIENCE:

I compited in Olympics
I told stories of Perseus to little spartan kids
I slept with a cultist
I fought in Peloponnesian war
I killed Medusa
I met Sokrates and Hipokrates.
I killed beasts send by Apollo
I overthrew Kings
I sealed Atlantis
I walked in the land of gods

This game made me do things that I could not do in reallife.


Ship Warfare is back

It is the same old blackflag experience with some adjustments due to timeline.
There is a new cleaving mechanic thatI liked and I also liked finishing animations of throwing javalins which pierce through enemy crew in slow motion.

What is the Flaw of this game?

Simply Too much of everything. There is too much grind too much mateiral you need to loot too much quests and too much people to kill as cultists which made me tired of doing same stuff sometime. Because of the new stuff they added some other aspects does not look polised like Ac origins. For example Gladiator Arena looks like a joke in Odyssey. In origins there was 2 Arenas with all cutcenes and option to spare or kill. All of the Gladiators felt unique in Origins. In Odyssey it is here just to be in the game.
There is no animations or option to spare. Another example is skill three. There was different type of bows in Origins but in Odyssey there is only one bow you can use and you can use bow skills as diiferent bows. So Ubisoft just added bow mechanic as skill three and it is just pure laziness. also making skills level up rather than different skills is also not interesting. There so many unnessecery skills that I am sure nobody uses. Origins skill three were much better. Despite all that I liked the new use of adrenaline bar with being able to do more with combat abilities which was repetitieve in Origins.
Lets dont forget we can have sex with characters but it game does not show you everything like witcher 3 did which is also a bad impression.


FINAL CONCLUSION
Despite some repetitive and grindy stuff. I really enjoyed this game. I love the beauty of this game. This game is pure art in itself. New dialogue system is really good and makes you play more and more. Story is really interesting and keeps you going. Historical Figures are here as always and their quests are fun. Mythical Creatures are also a plus for me

My Score is 92/100

Buy gold edition in sale.
Gold edition gives you all of the DLCs plus AC 3 Remastered.

I can't recommend this game for various reasons. And I'll try to justify why I can't recommend this game.

- The story is pretty decent and the main quests are good but what holds it back is the progression system. So basically you have to be reach a certain level to attempt the main quest and to level up you have to do boring side quests which have no variety whatsoever and are basically of three types Fetch quests, Fort infiltrations and Assasination quests. It's fine at the beginning but it gets annoying at the latter stages of the game because of its repetitive nature. Another point I'd like to make is the voice acting, they're pretty bad and it feels like a significant downgrade from Origins. And Dialogues seem way too Cringey at times.

- Combat is decently satisfying to be honest. But enemies on the other hand are enemies are like sponges and can take lots of damage before going down and another thing you should be concerned about is the level of your armour and weapons because even if you fight an enemy of your level but you have lower level weapons it's like fighting with a toothpick as the enemy takes very little damage and you get killed pretty easily. And it's a chore to upgrade your because you need a fair amount of money and resources in order to upgrade and you don't get it easily. I personally believe it's an intentional design choice made by Ubisoft in order to make their Microtransactions more appealing. Microtransactions should not exist in single player games.

- Gameplay and graphics: There's a lot of exploration and the map is huge and pretty. But if you pay attention you'll sooner or later realize the lack of details compared to origins and the world is more or less a copy paste job as most of the areas other than landmarks like Athens and Sparta have no distinct features and mostly look the same. Another prominent feature I'd like to talk about is the naval combat. Its alright but the thing holding it back is the fact that it's a chore to upgrade the ship, you'll have to grind a fair bit to upgrade your ship and this is again an intentional design choice by Ubisoft to incentivize their boosters, resource packs and other â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ microtransactions. Another topic I'd like to touch is the optimization for this game, it is simply terrible. I have a fairly powerful pc and I had to spend some time to fiddle with the graphics settings to make it run at a consistent 60FPS.

I'll conclude by saying that this is a good game ruined by questionable design choices by Ubisoft. I usually dont write long reviews but I had to make an exception here.

Average playtime of around 75 hours (and many at 110+) and so long as you play it like the open world rpg it is - which is to say you explore and do side missions - you will never need to grind in the game. Not that it would feel like a grind, the combat is fun and fluid, turning what is usually the least enjoyable part of any game for me into a fun and engaging experience which rewards skill.

The ship travel and combat are both very smooth and engaging, while the mercenary system adds a little spice and consequence to breaking laws.

I have enjoyed the game so much that I've easily played 400 hours over multiple playthroughs (I played a long time offline as well) and thrilled when New Game+ was finally offered.

On my Game+ playthrough I chose not to use fast-travel and either ran, rode, or sailed everywhere I went and I came to appreciate the beautiful setting even more than I already had.

Now that all the DLC are out, I advise you to get the Gold Edition, so you gain access to everything. The Atlantis DLCs offer another 30+ hours of gameplay and are as good as the base game.

(Updated to reflect changes since my original review)

Not Recommended
29.7 hrs on record
Posted: 22 April, 2020
After dumping 90 hours in Origins i was hesitant going into Odyssey because i felt very fatigued towards the end of Origins after doing everything in the game and playing through the DLC because i knew that the mechanics and gameplay in Odyssey would be very similar, and i got exactly what i expected. Odyssey is just more of Origins but with a Greece setting instead. This wouldn't normally be a problem but they've made these newer Assassins Creed games so long that it does become a big issue for me personally. This combat is not that engaging for the amount of hours they want you to sink into these games. It feels floaty and weightless, the attacks lack impact and it's missing that style and flair that the old games had, i criticised origins for the same thing and it's more of the same here just with small additions that don't add much. I also heavily miss the stealth focus that the older games had, it felt core to the Assassins creed experience and that's another problem i have, this just doesn't feel like an Assassins Creed game. It just feels like i'm playing a very average action rpg and i struggle calling it an rpg because it's very surface level stuff, level gating to stretch the length out with dialogue choices that don't add much to the game. Story wise there are a number of videos online detailing how they break the lore of the series and it overall never feels like the story warrants it's existence. The parkour just sucks now too, in the older games they bothered creating every crack to climb onto and you couldn't just grab onto any flat surface like you can in this game, you had to look around to see what you can grab and that added a sense of exploration and strategy. You might as well be Spiderman in this game the way you can just grab onto anything you see, it just doesn't look right.

Kassandra is a blank slate and the dialogue choices suck because she has no character traits or personality in general so you can't role play as her the way you can Geralt from The Witcher for example and i'm assuming Alexios is the same. The game can look great visually at times but the draw distance is pretty awful, Origins was able to hide it because of the Egyptian setting because it's all just sand in the distance but the grass and hills in this game look very bad from afar. This game is very quantity over quality with all the generic side missions and question marks on the map just like in Origins, it's all just very disposable content to stretch out the length of the game by making you do them to level up and progress with the main story. I did the bare minimum possible to get through this game and that did require doing a whole bunch of those boring side missions. Origins felt fresh at the time because it felt like a decent departure from the formula but now they are back to doing the same thing again. I really hope they can go back to the roots of the franchise with the future games, like a game heavily focused on the Creed like the original did for example but i just don't see that happening after the success of this game.
5/10 (Average)

I must say that i was positively suprised by Assassin's Creed Odyssey. I bought it after having completed the previous entry, AC Origins, and was expecting it to be very similar and almost indisctinguishable from it's predecessor. What i got was a totally different game, with 2 divergent stories and many RPG mechanics.
Like many people have already remarked, AC odyssey feels like a perfect mix between Back Flag, Origins, and the critically acclaimed Witcher 3, but still manages to keep a very distinguishable "Ancient greece" feeling. The open world is one of the biggest and most magnificent ones to date in the history of video games and the different choice options, although not revolutionary, do manage to change up the game a decent amount. AC Odyssey is also way more intuitive gameply-wise (especially with the new abilities), while being at the same time way less clunky as previous titles. Many new additions were made such as mercenaries, crafting, and private ship crews as well as a lot of meaningful little details (such as getting detected more quickly if you are carrying a torch at night).
All in all, this game is in my opinion one of the best Assassin's Creed games to date and i really do like the direction that this franchise is taking.
A MUST BUY if you like stealth games or open worlds!
9.5/10

Kurt-Stefan
79 products in account
0
13 people found this review helpful
1 person found this review funny 0

Not Recommended
92.4 hrs on record
Posted: 23 December, 2018
After completing the game and pushing myself to the end of the Cult of Kosmos, I've walked away feeling just a tad bit hollow about Odyssey. It's tough to call it a crappy game considering the amount of effort that went into the world and it's different islands. Ultimately I don't recommend this game to fans of the original Assassins for a few very select reasons.

The first thing that bothers me is the setting-i love the war between Sparta and Athens and the time period definitely feels good to visit, but I'm bothered that they chose Greece directly after Origins. Its predecessor nailed a pretty assassinesque location with Egypt and I was very excited to see where they would go next. Now I'm disappointed that they left at all because Odyssey feels a lot like Origins but with some unfortunate subtractions. The game is told on the eve of the spartan occupation of Athens and deals with Kassandra and Alexios, two very special individuals belonging to a very mystical line of important people. Below I list spoilers so if you're not bothered than keep on reading.

In short, the point of the story is to highlight the occupation of the guardian of Atlantis-a librarian/protect of the lost city. The side quests dealing with this include mythic beasts, which were honestly the only thing "Odyssey" about this whole thing. Essentially the point is to secure all the pieces of Atlantis' library that were stolen and return them to the gates, just to be told that you cant actually explore the ruins or go past the gates. This left me pretty jaded as they seemed to hype the occupation of Atlantis a fair bit only to tell me that's it. I'd thought originally that maybe they just dropped the ball with it, but nah-they were skirting the Atlantis occupation so they could sell it to us as DLC almost a year later. This sort of means that Odyssey is a game that not only doesn't recognize its identity as a game, it doesn't recognize its identity as an Assassins game.

Sure, it's very large and expansive and has a number of different locations to treat your inner explorer and I dug sailing around Greece with my female pirate crew. The missions are numerous yet short, and mostly just feel like lazy fetch quests tasking me with going to X to do Y. This is the essence of game development but here it is just so uninspired and bland that you often wonder why you're helping a lady retrieve her lost necklace in a forest. Do we excuse fetch quests for the sake of long hours to add to a game's objective quality? Of the 80 or so hours I spent with it, I would say 40 of them I understood where I was and why.

It just doesnt make sense, and much of the time I wondered where I was or why I was there. I would say half of the side quests have some substance in that they have actual story, but again that story is so lazily told and threaded together it makes the quest feel like a chore rather than an adventure. It's just constructive enough to give you a task to occupy yourself with, but the gusto to inspire you to do the task isnt really there other than XP.

Which is kind of a speed bump in a game about trying to emanate RPG elements. Past AC games have suffered in their combat and skill trees in that they have made it too watered down and mainstreamed for complex gamers. Here the combat isn't so much improved as it has been just stretched out. I remember being able to kill crowds of Italian soldiers as Ezio with a few choice button presses and good rhythm. It was probably best to move on from those days but I cant help but feel that we've lost the feel of intricate and lethal combat. It plays far more like a Devil May Cry game than anything and it blows. They've taken away the variety in bows that we had in the previous game which I think is the biggest disappointment, s I really enjoyed ranged game play. In Odyssey it hasn't been so much watered down as it just been unnecessarily changed.

It's also not like they decided to take those things out-Odyssey is developed by a separate team from Montreal, the real rock stars of Assassins Creed. Quebec seems to have taken Odyssey and selfishly replicate elements from its sister game and make it's own dive at trying to be a story driven RPG. In some places I welcome this but in others it's just changed for the worse, and I think combat is one of those areas.

We have the addition of power combos assigned to different buttons, if like dragons dogma. It's alright, but not really what I was hoping for when I thought of future AC combat. And for that matter, it doesn't really appeal as an RPG that well although it's certainly better than most generic games of that type. I could've done without honestly.

To finish, I would say that this game is a disappointment because it assumes that adopting RPG and story driven elements like dialogue and such are somehow excusing it of having poor quality mission structure and story or being incohesive with its RPG elements. If you ignore the immersion problems I guess you'll enjoy it. But personally I feel like I shouldn't have even bothered, and I just wish that I didn't have to play through the whole game just to realize that.

TLDR: Received as a Christmas gift, but would consider it worth the full price - this game is gripping. It has been a long time since I've been this excited about playing a game throughout the day while busy doing other things.

Comparison with rest of series:

I have not really been able to get behind an Assassin's Creed game since AC II and Brotherhood, the latest one I have tried being Syndicate (which I remain very very far from finishing and don't know if I'll go back to).
While it is a bit more difficult to play pure stealth because your level may determine whether you can one-hit kill someone, this just makes it all the more interesting rather than being as easy as previous games.
