Assassin's Creed Odyssey is a typical Ubisoft product and a perfect example of what's going wrong in the gaming industry for years now.
I've never liked the AC franchise, even back in 2007. The only reason why I bought Odyssey is because of the historical period and the lack of games which have in it. I have finished every single quest up to The Fate of Atlantis: Episode 1 (DLC) including. A lot of people like to point out how much content it offers but in truth is quantity over quality, in an old Ubisoft fashion.

A question, that is often asked when it comes to historical inspired games, is how historically accurate it is?
Although the world is true to history (more about it below), there are a lot of historical inaccuracies for gameplay's sake like Sparta magically having a big navy and Athens can magically hold it's own in all these open land battles. For some reason, both armies don't know anything about strategies, doctrines or even combat formations. Big conquest battles are chaotic 1v1 fights. A lot of the weapons look too big and I don't understand why? It doesn't even make the look "cooler" or "more epic". The majority of Greeks look like modern Arabs from North Africa.

The good:
â€¢ Odyssey's world is the best recreation of Ancient Greece that you will find anywhere! This is the main reason why I have spent so many hours. Ubisoft included so many small details that truly make the world historical accurate. The best example is probably colored statues. The world is filled with recreations of real monuments and buildings. It is huge and diverse with plenty of content in it. The game also has a database function where you can visit and learn all about the Greek world.

â€¢ The inclusion of mythical creatures is done very well and doesn't break the immersion. They are all on remote locations, can be missed and don't affect the overall story. A fun addition.

â€¢ A wide variety of gear. Most of it is historically accurate but some of it is inspired by Greek myths and Greek heroes. For example the Agamemnon or Achilles armors.

â€¢ I really liked the idea behind the Cult of Kosmos controlling both sides in the war for their own purposes.

The bad and the ugly:
â€¢ The story is weird.  But you never really care about any of the characters or feel connected to them.

â€¢ Far from being a true RPG! None of your choices matter or have any consequences except when it comes to your family members - kill them or spare them. That's it! You don't even have a role to play. People consider you a demigod. No classes. You can be a good assassin, hunter and warrior at the same time.

â€¢ Arcade mechanics and gameplay with little to no challenge. The AI is terrible. Enemies are often blind and deaf. They won't even alarm others when they find bodies. There is no fall damage! You can jump from wherever you want and won't die. You eagle can spot and mark everything even if it's underground. How about being ambushed by 2-5 damage sponge mercenaries? Very good idea, right?

â€¢ Most NPC look the same and the characters are very poorly animated in cutscenes. Far from AAA quality for 60â‚¬. The emotional reactions and face motions are simply terrible.

â€¢ I'm not against representing females more in different media but how exactly constantly killing women, some of which look like males, help?

â€¢ Odyssey is poorly optimized and people have been complaining since launch. Texture popping, crashes and stuttering are common even on a high-end PC.

â€¢ Ubisofts greed got bigger with every patch. Increasing the level cap (twice already, almost doubling it from 50 -> 70 -> 99) and lowering resource gain from in-game mechanics with every update is just to be explained with them trying to force you either into a needless, unnecessary grind that is frustrating or into spending money on their helix credits and in-game boosters. This, considering we are talking about a full prized singleplayer game is just infuriating and outrageous.

â€¢ Don't bother with the DLC's! Uninspired, mediocre and more of the same. Not worth the 40â‚¬ (!!!).

Conclusion:
Definitely not a game I will ever replay. This is one of those moments when I wish Steam would add a "neutral" button. Recommend only when on sale because of the world and the amount of content it offers even though it's repetitive.

In my opinion, an almost-masterpiece.

The RPG elements are great, experimenting with builds and paying attention to engravings and the gear you carry, all the while you can visually customise all the gear you are wearing (I've always hated games that forced you to wear gear that just looked so ugly but had great stats - this game fixes that).

I enjoy the combat and the large battles, effecting the power of the different nations between Athenians or Spartans, and much of the 'demi-god' powers/abilities you unlock are quite satisfying.

Not to forget that the world is just stunning, with many locations just so pleasing to take in and explore or walk around in as you take in the scenery.

The downside for me is that it just lacks an 'Assassin's Creed' story, and seems more like it should just be a spin-off game within the franchise. However, don't get me wrong, the story itself is engaging and interesting, with multiple endings based on your choices throughout the main quest-line.

I write this after over 900 hours of my life on this game, and I have no regrets. I also write this after playing Valhalla for some time... and seeing how much of a step back Valhalla is for me. If you're conflicted between buying Odyssey or Valhalla, I would strongly recommend Odyssey.

Recommended
559.1 hrs on record
Posted: 28 December, 2020
This Assassin's Creed is practically a spin off of the series, it stands out a bit in everything but it does it in a big way by bringing out an excellent gameplay (which however can be tasted REALLY in the ABOVE normal difficulty), an absolute thrilling narrative. best of the series both in terms of direction and plot (which INCREDIBLE, is not trivial)

Speaking of everything else:
-the setting is really beautiful, lots of green and many cities that are all beautiful and well characterized, you can see that a very in-depth study has been done to reach such levels. In addition, the map is immense and there are many regions to explore or islands.
-The secondary quests instead are like in Witcher 3, they are divided between the classic hunts for bandits and bounties with 0 subplots up to more iconic quests with developed plots or very funny gangs.The system of choices is done well and leads you to a total of 9 different endings.
The boss fights as seen so far are put in a coherent way and are fun.
-The skill trees and the various abilities, are all wonderful and allow you to play a little as you want (personally I love the bow) and to follow your fighting style, the feeling with the weapons is really well done, you notice a lot of difference when you wield a different weapon instead the feedback of the shots (and sometimes the hitboxes too) are slightly confusing.
-For the AI â€‹â€‹instead, a significant step forward has been made, the game is much more complicated than its predecessors but mainly because they stopped attacking you one at a time and do more damage than usual, thanks also to an rpg component that creates even more difficulties especially if you face enemies with a few levels higher than you, but there is still a lot to do
-The social and interactive component is interesting, it allows you to weaken an enemy region and cause the invasion of the opposite force (e.g. if the region is from sparta and you weaken the Spartan army in the area, the Athenians will invade after a while) which leads to a pitched battle for control of it. Same thing happens at sea with ships.
- Speaking of the latter, the visual impact with the water is fantastic and fighting at sea makes its effect, moreover the feeling with the spur of the ship or with javelins is absolutely fantastic, for the rest from this point of view, nothing brand new from what we saw in Black Flag, just a more of the same of the naval part improved but with fewer weapons available.
-The grinding (without xp boost) is not frustrating but only enjoyable, there are so many things to do and a huge world to explore which is easy to get lost and level without realizing it.
In conclusion I highly recommend this game

Recommended
161.8 hrs on record
Posted: 15 January, 2019
This game is easily one of my favorite games. The story drags you in and keeps you wanting to know what happens next. The graphics and lighting are stunningly beautiful. The female protagonist that I chose to play as, is also easily one of my favorite protagonists that I have ever played as. The game is extremely more of an RPG compared to the previous Assassin's Creed games. This iteration gives you a lot more control in regards to choices in terms of the character you play, and how you carry out your missions.

This game includes ability trees just like previous games, but it definitely allows you to cater more towards your own playstyle. There is also a large array of weapons and armor to provide perks and aesthetics that cater better to different people's preferences. Another feature that I greatly appreciate, which was added in an update a few months after release, is that you can change the appearance of your armors/weapons to the appearance of other armors/weapons that you have collected in your adventures, so that you can keep your favorite perks from the original set of armor/weapons that better suits your playstyle, without causing you to hate how your character looks.

The fighting mechanics are also a lot like how it was in Assassin's Creed: Origins, except for the shields, as you can not block in this game. It is extrmely important to dodge and/or parry when fighting in this game, but I never felt that it was overly difficult for me, when playing at my selected difficulty. In regards to playtime, I put in over 100 hours before completing the main game including all of the side quests, and I have maybe only done half of the miscellaneous locations. Plus, if you want to play for even more time, there are DLC that will add even more hours and lore to your gameplay.

Regarding bugs, there were a few times that my character did not do as intended or an ability that I have made a required action funny by making a dead body invisible, but none of those issues were game breaking. I will admit though, that there was one bug that I encountered that prevented me from playing a certain side quest, but an update resolved that problem for me.

In terms of performance, the fps was very stable but it is a fairly tasking game. I play at custom max settings, and usually get an average of 60 fps, when playing at a 3440x1440 resolution.

If you played Assassin's Creed: Origins, and you loved it, I can extremely recommend this game as I was surprised that I ended up loving this game more than how much I loved that game. If you are new to Assassin's Creed or are just a casual adventure game player, I still would highly recommend this game!

SiDzinhu

Recommended
121.3 hrs on record
Posted: 11 December, 2018
I have played every game in the Assassin's Creed series since release, and I'd say that Odyssey is the best game in the series arguably overall, and at least since AC2. Would highly recommend purchasing the base game either on sale or at full price, however the DLC pricing concerns me.

Positives:
- Actual RPG elements added; different dialogue options and choices to make inside the game that directly influence the outcome of quests (many questlines, including the main one, have multiple outcomes depending on your choices)
- Beautiful graphics, set in gorgeous locations - by far the prettiest AC game aesthetically to date. Textures seem to be slightly upgraded from Origins, although fire physics are worse for some reason. The game runs better overall for me on an i7 6700 + GTX 1080, despite having a larger world and higher textures than Origins
- Good storyline overall, with extremely likeable protagonists - in my opinion, the best ones since Ezio (I played as Alexios, but Kassandra is also very likeable). The voice acting is only "good" though, compared to Abubakr Salim's *incredible* voice acting of Bayek.
- Easily able to amass over 50 hours of playtime in the base game alone, making it great value for money. If you're the type of person that likes to grind out every single objective, quest and location marker, you can expect to almost double that (although grinding isn't as necessary as in previous games, simply via exploration and the odd sidequest I found myself overlevelled in almost all areas)
- Melee and ranged combat feels smoother and more refined than in previous games, naval combat is largely optional but extremely fun (and this is coming from someone who *didn't* like it in Black Flag)
- Greatest level of customization possible with character perks/inventory/ship/etc. featured in the franchise to date

Negatives:
- Some controls still feel a little clunky, as though they were optimized for consoles rather than PC players (big no-no)
- Some events in the main storyline were easily predictable
- The infinite number of mercenaries in the nemesis system becomes laborious rather than fun/challenging once you've worked your way to the highest tier
- They've removed instant fast travel to cities. I'm usually not someone who likes fast travelling, but in a 130km2 sized map it can sometimes be inconvenient to only travel to the nearest synchronization points


Overall, I'd give this game a solid 8.5-9/10, and would highly recommend it to anyone who is at all familiar with the genre or franchise. It's the first game in a long time where I've been motivated to actually play it for any longer than about an hour at a time. 9/10.

At the time of this review, I have about 80 hours into Assassin's CreedÂ® Odyssey. In my opinion this is the best Assassin's Creed since Assassin's Creed Black Flag. ACO is a gorgeous game with quite a bit of depth. There's so much more to do and experience than prior AC titles. The world is absolutely massive and detailed beautifully. I've found myself completely immersed in the era and attached to the protagonist. I would get lost sometimes for hours just exploring and taking awesome screenshots with the Assassin's Creed Photo Mode, which freezes time in game. This allows you to free-roam with your camera around your character to take fantastic pictures. The combat in this game does take some getting used to, it's completely revamped from the last AC title I played (Syndicate). That being said, once you get it down, the combat is so fun and satisfying. There is also a new crime penalty system. Basically there's all these very strong mercenaries, and if you commit a crime in sight of civilian or soldier, you will accumulate a bounty. With enough witnessed crimes, these powerful mercenaries will come for you to claim that bounty, all with their own traits, skills and sometimes furry companions. Depending how much bounty you have acquired you can have 1-5 of these guys coming after you. They will show up wherever you are randomly which can get you in some tough situations if you're in the middle of a mission. The sea battles are quite fun, I was hesitant about it with the lacking of cannons but it's amazingly fun. All in all, very fun and interesting mechanics. If you like Assassin's Creed, any of them, or a fan of the historical setting, this is the game for you.

- Combat system and skill specialization (Hunter, Warrior, Assassin).
- Sea battles are extremely fun.
- Graphics are beautiful.
- Runs flawless on my average PC.
- Play in a world where you can easily lose yourself in a historically epically immersive experience.
- The new bounty system.
- Campaign has been great and enticing. (I'm about half-way through the story at the time of this review)
- Assassin's Creed Photo Mode.

Bads-
- Ubisoftâ€™s microtransaction store
- Friends and family will hate how much time you end up losing playing this game.

Not Recommended
387.9 hrs on record
Posted: 17 October, 2018
Origins did it better.


Pros
- Graphics have been further improved as well as options. The game gives you more choices for tweaking to help improve your FPS (Frames Per Second).
- Main Story: The main story will keep you interested and wanting to know what happens next.
- Different Abilities: you have new abilities to choose from and your choices do matter.

Cons ( Brace yourself)
- Side Missions:
They are boring and tedious. While the main story quests give you important options to choose from, side mission's choices do not. The NPC/people in the game view you as a god, yet send you to find X object, kill X person, or even find their damn husband.

Travel Time:

Some missions require extensive amounts of travel time. One such shinying example is a side quest where you must take an athlete to where he will compete. Sounds simple enough. You have to travel by boat, over waves, 2,000-3,000 meters to get to him. Then to take him to the area where he will compete is another 7,000 meters. I found myself watching either youtube or messing around on Facebook more than actually playing the game.


- Combat
Combat feels like it was made more simplistic. In origins you had to time your parry well to be able to get a good counter attack in. However in Odyssey when parrying, you get a 3 second window in which if you are attacked, even by multiple enimies, you will parry. You don't even need to be facing the enemy either to parry.

- Less Abilities
While the abilities given do bring new play styles to combat, origins had extensivly more options. The menu and options feel once again dumbed down like the combat. To make matters worse unlike in origins, after reaching max level (50), you can no longer earn ability points. The amount of ability points you get is all you will have and you CANNOT unlock all of the abilities. Hence why your choices matter.

- Damage
Damage is split amoung different types now. You do not have a hidden blade to level up like in origins, rather a single value. The armor pieces you wear can increase the value as well as some abilities. But you will notice that the damage values are all on steriods. Enimies have over 100K health, Enemey Ships have over 500K health. Your damage for you ship is about 50K to start off with, and gets exceptionaly higher. However if you look at the health bar of your enemy, you notice you are doing the same amount as if you where in origins. So why are the damage values on steriods? To make us feel powerful when really nothing has changed?


- Bounty Hunters/Mercenarys
These enemies will be the single most annoying part of this game. If your bounty is high enough, a Merc (Mercenary) will be sent after you. Except the system is horribly broken. They will spawn 50-60 Meters away from you and auto route themselves to your position where they will attack you on site. Bounties will increase if you kill, or steal. Even when a quest has you defend yourself from enemies who start a fight, if you kill them, you get the bounty. If you decide to defend yourself from a merc, if you take to long, another will come along to join in on the fun. Soon you will find yourself facing 4+ mercs/hunters when it all started with one. You can pay off bounties from the Map screen but as you level up, the cost goes up.

- Quest within a Quest within a Quest
While the main story line does keep you interested, that is only happening if you are actually doing a main quest. More times than I can count the main story would have me do a side quest. Problem is that side quest has 3 quests of its own, and to top it all off, even some of those quests have their own to do. These sides quests follow the same pattern as any other side quest. Kill, Find, free X person/object. It feels like useless padding of the game when you are having to travel all over just to complete what started out as one quest and has turned into 10 of them.

- Enemy Damage VS Yours
Some targets and grunts can use Posion, and Fire. IF you are hit by their weapon you have the status effect immeditly applied. However when you attempt to posion or set an enemy on fire, you have to build up a meter above their head before it is applied. To make matters worse, if you have an effect applied by an enemies weapon, you take large amounts of damage to your health while if you manage to apply one to an enemy, he/she only takes upwards of 500 damage. Totally makes sense to have an enemy take 500 posion or fire damage every 2 seconds when he/she has 100K health.


I kept playing this game hoping it would get better. It didn't. Unless the cons are addressed in some way, avoid this game. If you want to still get it, wait for a sale first. It wouldn't be a ubisoft game without Digital and Gold packages after all.

Assassinâ€™s Creed Odyssey begins more than 2,400 years ago at the onset of the Peloponnesian war: a decades-long struggle between Athens and Sparta for dominion over the ancient Greek world. Odysseyâ€™s world is the biggest and most vibrantly colorful of the series. Of course, as with virtually all grand-scale game worlds, flaws lurk just under the surface. But the facial animation of the marquee characters is superb, and you can sense the subtle disgust or confusion on the face of Alexios or Kassandra without them having to say a word.

These protagonists are easily the most flexible characters in any Assassin's Creed game to date.
These protagonists are easily the most flexible characters in any Assassinâ€™s Creed game to date when it comes to their personalities. As a mercenary, my Alexios was free to be whoever I decided he should be. For example, a desperate fisherwoman pleads to find her husband she fears was overtaken by pirates: I could agree to help find him for the sake of love and reconciliation and all the brownie points, or tell her I donâ€™t work for free and watch her hopes dashed to pieces like the body of her former spouse upon the rocks. But some of those choices do affect the greater world around you: varied side missions become available according to your deeds, and certain characters could live or die â€“ all the way through to the multiple possible endings. I never felt like I screwed myself out of something I wanted to do, but I had the freedom to be who I wanted to be.

I had the freedom to be who I wanted to be.
Who I wanted to be was someone whoâ€™s often too lazy or self-assured to hide his murderous ways, which put me in conflict with Odysseyâ€™s new notoriety system. Itâ€™s a simple, common-sense approach: the more crimes you commit, the more likely it is that someone in the world puts a bounty on your head, and then a relentless cadre of procedurally named mercenaries begin to hunt and track you down.



While I initially found the mercs who were sicced on me to be little more than loot pinatas, as I leveled up the generic names and descriptors â€“ like Ilona the Agile (who was admittedly quite agile until I sunk her vessel and she drown in the Aegean) â€“ began to get more bombastic and threatening. For example, Mariah the Glimmering dogged me throughout my level-30s and her flaming spear and voracious pet lion worked in tandem to skewer or maul me into sweet oblivion on multiple occasions. I eventually just started running away when she had tracked me down, before finally ending her reign of terror some ten levels later. Sure, the loot wasnâ€™t great, but it was worth it.

The mercenaries sent to kill me eventaully earned my respect.
With a high enough bounty, this endless procession of relentless pursuers began to show up in force to complicate matters while I was in the middle of sieging a fort â€“ and before I could finish fighting one another would join, eager to hunt my head for coin. Then another, then another, and soon I had to choose between battling five headhunters while I tried to complete my objective in a defended fort, or turn tail and run. They eventually earned my respect, and I appreciate the chaotic X-factor they bring to Odyssey. Rising through their ranks to gain the attention of their legendary warriors is a fun meta-game in and of itself.



Similarly, the nation struggle system allows you to help the war effort for either Sparta or Athens in each region. By destroying supplies, pillaging war chests, or deposing a national leader, youâ€™ll trigger a conquest battle. While these huge melee or naval battles are thoroughly excellent combat scenarios and reward you with some good loot, they mean disappointingly little to the story. Regardless of whether youâ€™re attacking or defending, which side you join, or who ultimately wins, the war machine keeps turning. Eventually, I got to a point where I was able to weaken a region and trigger a conquest battle rather quickly, which made these mini-wars effectively farmable. That sucks some of the grandeur out of them, but seeing a hundred soldiers, captains, and mercenaries locked in combat is always a sight to behold.

Plying Your Trade
Weapons behave just differently enough for meaningful nuance.
Odyssey continues what Origins started last year, moving combat to a free-flowing dance of light and heavy attacks. The weapons are swords, daggers, axes, maces, spears, and staves, all of which behave just differently enough for meaningful nuance. In the heat of battle, itâ€™s an easy-to-grasp system of slashes and skills, and Iâ€™m still picking fights just for the joy of it â€“ especially against improbable odds, like the Greek legends of old.

Thereâ€™s a staggering amount of equipment to find, upgrade, and engrave with powerful perks. Odyssey smartly offers you the chance to upgrade an old piece of gear to your level for a hefty fee, depending on its rarity. Thanks to that system, I didnâ€™t have to say goodbye to my favorite sword and axe that I used throughout much of the adventure â€“ but that attachment cost me a small fortune in resources to keep them up to date every few levels. But even if I didnâ€™t always have the crafting materials or currency needed to upgrade my old reliable Spartan War Hero helmet to my current level, a constant stream of new viable gear continued to pour in, giving me options unt

Recommended
134.9 hrs on record
Posted: 23 November, 2018
The culmination of all the best parts of the other Assassin Creed games resulted in this epic, well-crafted experience inspired not only by their own games, but by the best in the industry.


Story
The writing and different dialogue options from The Witcher 3 are present. Narrative elements are definitely improved from previous entries, and the new writing team they have hired have done a great job, and it shows. Side-quests range from your generic fetch quests to actual hour-long stories with well-written characters, twists and turns. The story is especially long, but is interesting enough to warrant my playthrough. There is a great greek family drama to be experienced here, with some very emotional and dramatic events.


World/Graphics
The open world is enormous - too big in fact. Going from one place to another can sometimes feel like a chore, but every single area is filled to the brim with details, has its own artistic representation and feels different from others areas. The amount of effort here is outstanding and deserves praise. I still haven't explored the whole map after over 70 hours of gameplay, and I am not bored of it. Not to mention how beautiful the game always looks, day and night. Be ready to take amazing screenshots.


Photo mode lets you take personalized screenshots of Greece. 
A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Odyssey
By: BlackSymmetry

Gameplay
The gameplay is solid and is inspired by the Dark Souls formula, with the added mechanic of abilities like spartan-kicking your enemies and watching them fly off the edge of a cliff. There's a lot of variety here, especially since they added the ability to upgrade and drive your very own ship. Gameplay elements are abundant : sword-fighting, naval combat, stealth, bows, epic large-scale battles. It also heavily relies on RPG elements, like making sure your loot is up to speed with your character level, upgrading your armor and weapons, crafting, enhancing your items, managing your inventory, etc. They have also introduced a new mercenary system where these powerful enemies will hunt you down if you commit a crime, which can be fun since they always drop powerful loot. They have also introduced a system where you hunt down members of a cult after discovering clues hidden around the map. Lots of fun content separate from the main story really blows this game out of the water in terms of quality and variety.


Naval combat and exploration is a core feature. 
A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Odyssey
By: BlackSymmetry

Overall
Of course, like always, Ubisoft had to shoot themselves in the foot by adding some insulting microtransactions, forcing you to have to do sidequests in order to level up your character enough to be able to continue with the story. Although it's very annoying and deserves to be criticized, the game has more than enough to warrant your purchase, and really outshines recent Ubisoft games in terms of world quality, story and gameplay.


Go anywhere, from the highest mountains to the depths of the ocean. 
A Screenshot of Assassin's Creed Odyssey
By: BlackSymmetry

Recommended
85.6 hrs on record
Posted: 18 January, 2021
---{Graphics}---
Looks pretty good, areas start to look samey after a while but still good graphics all around

---{Gameplay}---
Solid, plenty of depth between the classes, quest structure is repetitive with padding added to make quests feel longer than they could have been

---{Audio}---
Audio is solid, plenty of queues and decent quality, music gets hella repetitive after a while.

---{Audience}---
This game is either for people who want a really long RPG to play, if you don't have time this game can feel very grindy

---{PC Requirements}---
Expect around 60-50fps if you don't have a strong pc build regardless of settings

---{Difficulity}---
This game's difficulty is determined largely by levels, anything at your level will be easy to fight, but you'll notice enemies even 1 level higher than you will be a bit harder to fight, enemies can feel very spongy when they are 2+ levels higher than you, unless you have a full stealth build then you one shot anything when not in combat

---{Grind}---
This game's grind can be pretty bad at times. You can tell the game was made and balanced around making you buy XP boosts. Without any boosts you can need as many as 5 quests per level which really adds up after 40 levels.
---{Story}---
The story is good, a humanizing tale about a greek peasant who ascends to greatness. There are 3 stories within the full game, and each builds on the character development from the previous ones. Much better than previous AC games.

---{Price}---
The game is worth buying at any price under 50 dollars. Though if you don't like long games you'll be hard pressed to buy the permanent xp boost for 15 bucks. this is by far the worst part of the game

---{Bugs}---
I have had some crashes randomly, no progress ever lost. other than that nothing to report sir.

Recommended
296.0 hrs on record
Posted: 10 October, 2018
Assassin's Creed Odyssey is the successor to last year's Assassin's Creed Origins and it improves on it's predecessor in almost every way. Assassin's Creed Odyssey now puts a much greater emphasis on role playing elements than it's predecessor. The game now has dialogue options, branching quests and multiple endings which can be decided by the players in game choices. Like traditional RPGs stealing and killing civilians will earn you a bounty which results in mercenaries hunting you throughout the game world. Odyssey now has a romance feature which allows you to develop romantic relationships with NPCs in the game.

Odyssey does a great job expanding on the RPG elements seen in Origins and also brings back a beloved feature from one of the previous games. Making it's return is the much loved naval combat from Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag. Just like in Black Flag, you are free to roam the world in your ship, which can be upgraded along the way. Using your ship you can take down enemies and board them in order to gather resources. This was something I loved about Black Flag and to see it back in Odyssey is amazing!.

Assassin's Creed Odyssey is set in 431 BC during the midst of the Peloponnesian War fought between the city states of Ancient Greece. Players have the ability to choose between two main protagonists, Alexios or Kassandra. Both these characters share the same story so choosing one over the other will not impact the narrative. The story follows you attempting to reunite your family while attempting to uncover an evil cult called the Cult of Kosmos, who are attempting to take over the Greek world. The game's world feels and looks amazing. You have the ability to take part in massive conquest battles as well as join forces with Athens or Sparta. There are so many different locations in the game world and each has it's own objectives in order to complete that location.

Despite being set 400 years before the birth of the Assassin Order, AC Odyssey somehow still manages to feel like an Assassin's Creed game without Assassins. The familiar mechanics of AC are still here but this time the assassins do not exist. You don't have the iconic Hidden Blade but instead the Spear of Leonidas a legendary relic belonging to the Great King Leonidas of Sparta. The game's parkour and combat feel fluid and smooth and provides players with a pleasant experience while playing. Overall Assassin's Creed Odyssey is a step in the right direction for Ubisoft.

Verdict: 9/10 Fantastic!.

Review: My Assassins Creed: Odyssey experience so far

The new Assassins Creed as a promised fullblown RPG game.
Which is set in the peloponnes war in greece (404 to 431 b.c.).
IÂ´ve played almost every AC game, expect Syndicate. Because AC felt boring and out of ideas, gameplay wise.
But behold, Origins was a very good game, which I enjoyed to the end.

Now Odyssey picks the formular which made Origins a good game and mixes it with some new gameplay elements.
Decisions that really have a impact, for example.
I had to make a decision if I would kill or save a family that seem to have somekind of virus.
Of course I spared their lifes, just to see the whole land get plagued with their sickness, later in the game. I was shocked and amazed at the same time. I thought that my decision wouldnt make a difference in the Game.


World:
The Gameworld is larger and even more beautiful than the World in Origins.
It is packed with locations to discover, boss animals to defeat or beautiful cities to explore.
And dont even get me started with the sea which can be sailed with your own ship.


Combat / Gameplay:
The Combat is the same as you are used to AC games, expect the adition of â€œabilitiesâ€ that can be leveld up and be used while in combat.
Its too bad that you cant use a shield like your enemies do.
Depending on the location where you are, enemies are on a higher or lower level than you are.
Which makes some fights really hard and challenging. Some enemies can only be slayed, if you have got a almost equal level as them. Just like in Origins.
The â€œGod Challengesâ€ and â€œPapyrus Riddlesâ€ from Origins make a return in Odyssey.
The Challenges are mighty and majestic animals that you need to track down.
But the â€œPapyrus Riddlesâ€ are only extra perks for your weapons instead of legendary equipment and weapons.
Which is kind of a let down.


Story:
The Story is interesting and versatile. I have played around 36 hours to this date of this review and it feels like that the story is almost as good as the story in AC 2.
Alexios (The protagonist) has character depth to him and even some humor, based on your answers to the NPCÂ´s.
I am curious how long the Main story will take me to finish and how it will end.


Graphics:
The Graphics are just as good or even a bit better than in Origins.
The Lighting is vivid, textures are highly detailed and the performance seems good.
I get around 40-60 fps on a 1920Ã—1080 resolution, with a GTX 1060 (6 Gb), at High to Ultra Settings.
But there is a problem with the texture streaming sometimes.
Some textures seem to take a longer time to load and appear blurry and messed up for a short period.

Conclusion:
A first review of this game, even if I am kind of early in the game.
The Story and gameplay is very good and just got some minor flaws until now.
Alexios is a charismatic and likeable guy, who acts based on your decisions.
The gameworld is vivid and one of the most beautiful I have ever seen.
Even if the Game has some Ghost Recon: Wildlands vibe to it,

I would recommend this game to every Assassins Creed fan or newbies to the franchise.

9/10

Not Recommended
251.1 hrs on record
Posted: 20 July, 2020
The good:
It's a beautiful game, the map feels large and rich with things to explore, and this is about as enjoyable as it gets.
Branching dialogue is also a nice touch, and your decisions can have consequences later on.

The bad:
THIS IS NOT AN ASSASSIN'S CREED GAME! It may be flogged as such, but the way you encounter enemies (be that by stealth or in a fight) is nothing like the assassin's creed games I'm used to (i.e. AC 1-4). Instead of focusing on being defensive, countering attacking against the various distinct types of opponent you're now fighting a sponge with a health bar, which arbitrarily gets higher with the tier of opponent, but visually looks the same.
There are no longer any visual clues about how tough an opponent will be. A tiny little guy (or woman, because according to Ubisoft apparently egalitarianism extends back in time) in a toga can shrug off an axe blade if they're a higher tier than you, that would fell (or at least do significant damage to) a guy who rivals Goliath for size and is decked out in full armour, just because he's your tier or lower.
But you get some absurd (...ly frustrating) situations, like being unable to assassinate someone of a higher tier WHILE THEY'RE SLEEP! Or shooting a guy 20 times in the face with a bow and arrow and he's still alive and chasing after you.
Then there is the dumb stuff like taking all the challenge out of navigating your environment. So you can climb ANY shear cliff/wall/100ft high bronze statue with such ease, gone are the days when you need to look for geometry (e.g. a window ledge) which you could grab onto. And while you take fall damage, you can't die from it, so you don't have to plan your free-running routes anymore, just hold shift and run in a direction and everything will work out.

I'm not against all levelling systems in games, but when there are 50 tiers and it's practically impossible to fight someone just 1 or 2 tiers higher than you (and for reference 30hrs in, I am only at level 15), just so Ubisoft can flog a premium thing to make you level up quicker, I think we need to not just accept that "it's part of the game" but ask why? Because it's a fun game mechanic, or to make you frustrated and hand over more money to Ubisoft?

As unfinished as the first assassin's creed was, at least it made more sense than this pile of rubbish does.
I'd give it a 3/10

Assassins Creed Odyssey picks up where Origins left off expanding upon the newly designed AC game play, this is no longer just another cookie cutter Ubisoft formulated franchise.

ACO follows the rich story line of Alexios or Kassandra depending on your choice with the other character mirrored as the main protagonists. The journey through ancient Greece is engaging through a series of complex and intertwining story lines of more than a half a dozen allyâ€™s you form along the way.

Unique story and side quests with characters that come full circle and reinforce the main story and ideas of ACO rather than previous titles and franchises using the same remodelled quest formats that nobody has been interested in for the past 10 years. The main story follows a level system requiring you to explore and quest between major story arcs which some had dubbed as a â€œgrindâ€, however, with the high quality of side content and quests this couldnâ€™t be further from my experience.

The open world is truly one of the best open worlds in any game to date. Never once in any of the dozens of zones did I feel content was reused constantly or out of place with each area giving their own vibe and local. There really is just so much to explore and interact with as you slowly tick off points of interest and collectables along the way.

These are all significant steps above Assassins Creed Origins which already took the series to new heights and expectations after breaking the mould of a stagnant series and reinventing itself to a true RPG experience, providing just as many hours of game play after the main story is completed in about 50-70 hours.

Assassins Creed Odyssey is no longer a short story driven game with the open world just tacked on, it is a true RPG open world experience and rivalling in many aspects some of the best.

9/10

Triglett
218 products in account
0
6 people found this review helpful 1

Recommended
76.3 hrs on record
Posted: 20 August, 2020
I studied Ancient Greek + Latin for 6 years in high school and all those myths, gods and monsters always seemed a bit abstract to me and inside this hazy head of mine, I could never seem to bring e.g. the Minotaur or even Crete to life. I simply could not do it justice.

That is why they've always remained merely "just stories" I would read about and translate. But oh boy, AC Odyssey embodies everything I studied; it's like the climax of all that I have learned for the past decade. Beautifully crafted into a single videogame.

From standing face-to-face with my holy savior Socrates to just wandering through historical sites I've only experienced in the magnificent opera - such as the likes of Herodotus and Thucydides - is a fantasy come true. It gives me chills and it's a surreal feeling because all the places seem incredibly familiar, in a way. It's as if I'm a Parisienne playing AC Unity: I feel right at home.

However, I can't help but mourn the fact that my classical studies teachers (who are your typical "what's a pc?" boomers) never got to witness this piece of art. Truly tragic. It should be mandatory for classicists to experience Ancient Greece in Odyssey (and make it to Sequence 9 ;)) before even thinking about graduating !!

The game itself is visual eye-candy and the world is accurately presented. This was my first AC game since Syndicate (then I took a break from the franchise). It is both refreshing and made me question the status-quo that I had in mind in regards to the whole series. Not once did I get bored. In fact, I enjoyed the "grind" most people complained about, simply because I was not in a rush. I took my time soaking all of it in.

The side stories albeit lackluster and predictable, still proved themselves a welcoming addition since they tend to keep my OCD occupied, along with the endless amount of explorable question marks scattered throughout the map. Playing as Kassandra was cool and felt natural. I grew fond of her in the end. The ending was perhaps a little weird and cringeworthy, but that's because I got the "good ending". Oftentimes Kassandra would act as the deus ex machina in sticky situations, but it adds to the charm of the narrative and setting, I guess.

Tl;dr: overall solid game that's worth your money if you're a Greco-Roman history nerd like me and into games that offer hundreds of hours of gameplay. If the game is on sale, do not hesitate.

Not Recommended
114.9 hrs on record
Posted: 10 October, 2018
Great direction for the series but poorly executed. Takes a step back from Origins.


They're trying to make a more RPG style game which I'm totally on board with but they've made a lot of bad choices. The talent system is weirdly dependant on how far through the story youve progressed which results in you not being able to level skills or abilities to match your playstyle. The map is similarly gated which is a necessary evil but it's wayyy too extreme. Naval battles are pretty similar to Origins with the addtion of some meh crew mechanics. I'm 20 hours deep and I've been forced to waste several points on skills I don't need and don't use.

The animations for this game are...strange. The female character is weirdly masculine because I'm pretty sure they've just reused the skeleton and animations from the male lead, facial animations are the usual disaster. Fighting and freerunning both feel slower and less fluid, it's awkward and there are a lot of mistakes. There are lots of terrain bugs and stuff you should be able to climb but for some reason can't. When sailing it's pretty easy to get stuck on the coast or have trouble turning around in the harbor. I haven't gotten trapped in any geometry but I've been killed several times because I leapt into a corner and then just hung there which is a staple of AC games but it's happening way too much in this one.

The story and dialog so far are a mixed bag. I'm not far enough in to really judge but the game hasn't made it very clear when you're making a big decision and when it's just flavor. The main characters so far are kind of meh and the voice acting is ok. I'm playing as Kassandra and so far she seems really shallow and I don't see much changing. She's also crazy aggressive with the ladies and ultra cringey. So far the absolute worst part of the game is the writing.

I'm not sure I'm sold on the gameplay loop which is funny because it's not very complicated. There's tons of busy work to do but it's not very interesting. Mercinaries is a bastard mix of the Phylakes and the Nemisis system and is so far completely useless.

Of course the game looks great. Running on Ultra it peforms better than Origins did on the same build and I'd say looks just a bit better. i7-7700k and 1080 both water cooled and I maintain a rock solid 60fps @2k. I get occasional tearing and I have also noticed several options resetting themselves.

Overall I like the ideas and RPG elements they're trying to work into the game but I wish they'd taken a year off and really thought about what they were doing and why instead of just cramming a bunch of stuff together and calling it a game. The gameplay is half baked and considering how technically similar it is to Origins the amount of things that they got wrong or got worse at is pretty amazing.



I'm sure they'll take care of some of my complaints with patches but unless you're a big AC fan wait for the Winter Sale. I was bored and had the cash but I'll probably get about 25% through this and then drop it for a month or two while they fix all the bugs.

Odyssey is a big downgrade over Origins. Origins was excellent and revolutionized the series entirely, it was perfect in my opinion, but Odyssey is just a copy paste from that game with bad story and bad leveling progression.

Good things are:
Very good port. Runs at 1080p30/High (AA, AO, Volumetric Clouds on Low) on i5-8300H and GTX 1050Ti, 8GB RAM. Very stable, only a few rare drops on cutscenes. Graphics are incredible and very detailed.
It keeps all good technical aspects from Origins. Origins was an incredible game that revolutionized the series. Improved combat, dialogue choices, parkour, stealth approaches and RPG elements were great things that came with Origins, and they are exactly the same in Odyssey. If you like the way AC is after Origins, Odyssey keeps the same trend.
The map is really very big. There's a lot to discover and explore.

Bad things are:
There is no story basically. If you're expecting some Athens/Sparta story, just forget about this game. The game is just you doing favors for some random people in exchange of unacurate information and nothing more. Everything just feels like a side mission thrown at you randomly while you explore the world. And there is absolutely nothing about the assassins guild in this game, you aren't even an assassin lol
This game is very very grindy (much more than Origins). You need to spend hours doing side stuff to level up quite slowly. The gap between sequential story missions is huge, which is ridiculous. You need to level up like 5 levels until you can continue the story, forcing you to do A LOT of side content; The developer should've made story missions progress correctly to the player's level. Very disappointing, indeed.
It doesn't matter who you choose to side with in the war. You need to kill whoever is dominant in a region to complete locations and quests; if you don't do it, you won't earn XP.
Nemesis system copy (hunters/bounty) is incredibly annoying. These guys won't stop chasing you as they always spawn close, and they can ruin all your stealth approach or story missions because they are usually above your level and will always attack. Doesn't matter if you kill the hunter or not, your bounty doesn't lower and he get's replaced by another one instantly, even repeated guys start to appear lol

The developers increased the level cap and reduced the ammount of XP earned to force XP booster microtransactions making the game very grindy.
As the story is not intresting at all with zero representation of the assassin's guild and almost nothing related to the the history about Athens/Sparta, I didn't really feel motivated to spend hours slowly grinding levels by doing side content to progress the story.

The game is not bad, it's the developer's greed that ruined it.
Reduced XP and copy pasted previous game for quick cash grab.

Posted: 12 August, 2020
To begin with, I must say I never got into the Assassin's Creed train from the beginning. The games just did not compel me to play them at all and they seemed a bit boring to me. The last game I touched was the 2nd game in AC line of games before trying it up again after so long with Odyssey.

I was blown away by how big the map was now and the controls now feel very fast paced and fluid even with a keyboard and mouse. The underlying tone of the Greek mythology was interesting and the game now seemed quite pleasant to play.

After finishing the game and most quests, I feel like I can add my own personal review of the game now.

Do note I played using an I7-8700K, 32GB of DDR4-3466 RAM, EVGA RTX 2080 FTW3 Ultra GPU and a Dell S2716DG monitor (1440p, 144hz, 1ms, TN panel, G-Sync)

Pros

- Game looks beautiful
- Fluid and fast paced roaming
- Easy to control and master combat
- DLCs are very interesting
- Ship combat wasn't too tedious and often could just be skipped
- Lots of places to explore, tons of quests to complete and bounties to do
- Gear can be upgraded with you if you do not mind investing materials in the process


Cons

- G-Sync seemed to cause screen tearing so I was forced to use V-Sync to prevent it but it capped my game to 60fps
- Some of the legendary monsters and hunts fights were a bit too hard even if you try lowering the difficulty (for me at least)
- Upgrading the ship fully required more materials that it feels like it should have
- Was able to tell who the Cult of the Kosmos Mastermind was midway into the game (but not the reasons why it was that person though)


To summarize, I would give this game a solid 9/10. I was quite surprised at how much I liked the Oddysey entry in Assassin's Creed line-up of games despite never having enjoyed the games at all before. I just wish they would fix the G-Sync issue to allow a higher framerate cap and buttery smooth gameplay.

This is my favourite game in quite some time.

Tip - play as Kassandra

It takes a little to get used to the controls, but once you have it dialed, it's great. So much to do. So many different ways to get xp. So many places to go. There are some 'go deliver this' or 'go kill that guy' quests, but I think that every open world game has them and after a while, you learn you can ignore most of them. If you get bored of something, you have so many options of, 'Well, you know, I guess I'll just try this other thing for a bit then.' (Story, extra quests, legendary animals, mercenaries, Sparta V Athens battles, DLC, exploring, ship battles, collecting sets, etc)

I bought Origins (and others) after this, because people said it was better. I disagree. Odyssey is better in terms of gameplay, controls, story and voice acting. Origins and Syndicate felt like a chore to get through a lot of the time. Often it just felt a slog to get to 'the good stuff', or had these little added in time wasters that don't add to game play, but are there just so you end up playing 'longer'. For me, in Odyssey it felt like they instead added more content to make you play longer.

I also found the controls of Odyssey more intuitive compared to previous games. (I use a mouse and keyboard.)

I guess the best thing I could say, is that I bought this game on the summer special, where I got the platinum (or whatever) version with all the DLC for like $45cad. However, having now played it, I would have happily spent $100+ on this game....and am in fact looking at getting the next one on release because of the experience I had.

But play as Kassandra!

30 Hour REVIEW

If you were a big fan of Origins you're going to love Odyssey, it does more with the gameplay mechanic introduced in Origins and fixes some problems while not going far enough with some others

The game is huge, overwhelming at times. If youre the sort of gamer that wants to burn thru a game as fast as possible youre going to hit level walls that would require grinding unless you play as a completionist right away, and for some this is exactly the game you want, but if you plan on getting RDR2 in two weeks you better be rethinking it because this game will pull you in for 40+ or more, WORKING PEOPLE OUT THERE you've been warned, this isnt a bad problem and Odyssey does a good job at keeping you going

My thoughts

+Side Quests greatly improved with interesting characters (vs Origins)
+One of the best Stories in the series
+Beautiful game world, with great vertical elements and awesome underwater biomes
+Great Merc system (Similar to the Nemesis system in SOM/SOW)
+Addictive Gameplay with a abundance of Loot
+Large Scale battles are awesome
+Combat system improved, much faster pace and difficult

-Present Day storyline is lacking, (I loved the present day storylines from earlier games)
-Ship Combat isnt as deep as in AC4, probably due to the timeline
-Picking factions doesnt have any storyline impact, you pick who you like
-Hunting has a smaller impact in gearing up

Fathar
190 products in account
0
7 people found this review helpful
3 people found this review funny 0

Recommended
45.0 hrs on record
Posted: 18 July, 2019
Assassin's Creed: Odyssey released a year after Origins thus the first thing that came to my mind was that it was going to be a copy/paste of Origins but boy was I wrong. It's basically an improved versions of Origins that is bigger in scope. This time around you have the choice of playing between two characters Alexios and Kassandra. Kassandra is the better character to play as, mainly because I feel like her voice actress did a much better job than Alexios and the fact that it's more interesting to play as a female than the generic tough guy.

Odyssey is a very gorgeous and detailed game with a lot of things going on in the cities and villages to make it feel very alive and active. A couple of the music tracks give a Witcher 3 vibe, although i'm not sure if that's a good or bad thing. Exploring on a ship feels nice but slow. The ship combat on the other hand I wasn't a fan of at all and avoided it at all cost. Microtransactions are present in the game, in the form of cosmetics, XP & drachmae boosts as well as map packs that add icons to your in-game map to make hunting for certain things easier. Honestly the cosmetics and map packs could have easily been part of the main game as rewards. The XP and drachmae boosts however shouldn't be a thing. The game is easy enough without them anyways.

As you would expect from a game of this size, it has TONS of exploring and quests. But for the most part a lot of the quests are bland fetch quests that serve no purpose other than to pad time. From my experience you can skip most if not all without being under leveled for the main quest line. However on the bright side there's a good handful of fun and interesting quests. The dialogue choices in most of the non-main quest line (and even some main quests) suffer from the Telltale syndrome. Where every option leads to the same end result or the choices doesn't matter in the end.

There's 3 main styles of combat in Odyssey. Hunter is mainly ranged abilities that use a bow. Warrior which is close-quarters combat and the stealthy Assassin. You can obviously mix and match your skills to either be jack of all trades or be proficient in 1 or 2 roles. The combat for the most part is really easy regardless of which route you take. Hack/slash, evade and repeat or shoot arrows and kite around your enemies while using your abilities whenever you have available action bar. Luckily the game allows you to easily reset your skills indefinitely so as long as you have the small drachmae it charges.

No longer do you have to worry about equipping a new and better piece or armor that would ruin the look you were going for! The game has a very nice system that allows you to change the appearance of any of your weapons or armor pieces, assuming you have looted the armor piece or weapon in the game world. The system keeps track of everything you have looted so far as well as everything available in the game. Although don't expect every item to have a unique look. Most of the items have small differences from one another, while a small few are fully unique.

Despite the size of the game, at times it can feel somewhat lifeless. Apart from the occasional frame drops in some crowded areas, the performance is smooth otherwise. There's some minor glitches, but nothing serious or game breaking. I recommend you play the game with a controller since it feels more natural. The problem with using a controller is the bow aiming, but can be fixed by enabling lock on. It's a bit cheaty but you're pretty much OP for most part of the game so it really doesn't matter in my opinion.

Pros:
+ Interesting story & setting
+ Lots to do
+ Male & female protagonists
+ Very gorgeous and detailed

Cons:
- Microtransactions
- Repetitive and grindy (at times)
- Ship combat & exploring

SPOILER ALERT - SPOILER ALERT - SPOILER ALERT - NO, REALLY, SPOILER ALERT -

Combat and stealth are fun and can be fulfilling when you successfully infiltrate a fortress and complete your objectives and slip away unseen.
However, the RPG elements are poorly implemented and a huge letdown for me.

I wanted to roleplay an embittered Kassandra: who no longer considers herself a Spartan and accepted a life as a mercenary. One whose life was dictated by that one moment on the mountain -and getting thrown off.
When you finally confront the man who threw you off said mountain I merely wanted to return the favor; but the game would not let me. Instead she releases him and seems conflicted about her revenge (no no no no; just [Spartan-]kick him off the ledge already !). When he mentions he loved both Kassandra and her brother, she snaps and runs him through (right, that apparently was the straw that broke the camel's back; I mean really?)

There is spoken dialog in a cutscene of how you wished you had finished off a certain character -and when you finally have a confrontation with this person, my character starts to apologise and couldn't we all be friends. WTF?
When I get a chance to say I'm no longer Spartan. mother says otherwise and I immediately agree with her.
I play several missions a specific way that will rub someone the wrong way; but I just don't subscribe to their suggested path. When my character gets berated, instead of justifying herself, she starts a rite of contrition.

Every possible path that seems to divert from the middle of the road experience, is somehow automatically funneled back onto the main road; as if the game wants you to tread a single path that was laid out by the designers of the game. The illusion of choice is just that: an illusion -and a bad one at that. My suspension of disbelief quickly became just disbelief.

When my character berates Barnabas -the captain of your ship- for being too looselipped towards a stranger (who turns out to be Herodotus), the next sequence that plays out leads up to some major silly if not stupid dialog: my character does not wish to divulge anything they've discovered to Herodotus and he calmly explains that while there are many people who cannot be trusted, he is not one of them -okay, so my character immediately does a 180 degree turn and trusts him implicitly.
Also, apparently the best possible ending is when everyone of your family -old and new- are spared/saved; WHAT?
Nikolaus chose duty over his family and for me that warrants no happy end for him; his newly adopted son is a devoted fool who -as far as my character is concerned- can share his step-dad's fate.

When in Sparta before the two kings I wanted to tell them to take a hike and that I would see Sparta be brought to its knees; instead I have to fulfill some lame quests to reclaim the old family house -I would've rather torched the place down.

Throughout the game my Kassandra was dancing a routine that was choreographed in total silence and then had a strangely chaotic instrumental track tacked on, showing a performance that was both out of sync and coiling around itself, constricting and choking the very life out of it. It feels like a roller coaster ride that -instead of being fun and thrilling- leaves you nauseous and reeling. Opening Pandora's Box would probably have been a good thing, if it meant a game-over screen.
All of my character's motivations seemed one contrived contradiction after another.

The game would've been more coherent -and consistent- if my character's replies and responses were all of the same vein. And not veering off on a very promising tangent, only to make a U-turn and return to the inconsistent swamp where you slowly but surely get mired down.

And the game would have been so much better if you could actually make deliberate choices that would steer you either left or right -and not all just filtered down the middle. It's like watching grains of sand passing through an hourglass.
Over time I became less and less involved with my character, until I eventually stopped playing.

So, in a nutshell -or straightjacket- combat and stealth: excellent.
RPG elements / dialog choices: a jumbled, inconsistent and contradictory mess.
A slightly buttered scone, but eventually not my cup of tea.

What a game! I extremely enjoyed this game and the 90+ hours I have put into it. I believe that the Assassin Creed series is heading in the right direction as this is a big improvement since syndicate and unity.

The game itself is huge. The map consisting of the Greek Islands is incredibly expansive and I have had a lot of fun exploring each area. The time period that this game is set is something that really interests me anyway. The history, architecture, military, mythology etc. are only some of the things I can list that have drawn me further into this game. The RPG genre that Ubisoft have adopted now I think personally has moved the series the right way. The ability to change weapons, gear, upgrade your ship by collecting materials is truely a lot of fun. The story is good. Some parts were sometimes lack luster but overall I was interested in the development of the characters. The addition of the historical figures was something I liked. Seeing these idolised people either through quests or lore defined the game further.

The land and naval combat was nice. Land combat with the use of the ability tree I had no trouble with and I thought that the different trees that you could explore into gave a lot of freedom and would allow you to approach your own playstyle. Naval combat I reminisced with Black Flag. Love boarding other ships and also ramming boats in two was brilliant. The level and material system personally for me not an issue. I didn't have any problem with levelling up and I didn't necessarily have to grind. Other features such as the mercenaries tab and the cult of kosmos I enjoyed working through.

My only downsides with Odyssey is a couple of things. Some of the quests were a little repetitive in the sense of basically doing the same thing. As I played as Alexios, I felt his dialogue could've been improved with a little more emotion and facial features.

Overall this is my game of the year no doubt about it. I have really enjoyed playing this game and it makes me hopeful and excited for future content that Ubisoft plan to create. I highly recommend.

9 / 10

Whether or not this is the best game in the series it's sad that i payed full price when this was launched blinded by the ign and steam reviews.

Problems:
1. Side quests are forced to complete the main quest (which is quite interesteing although no masterpiece) but as soon as the joy of riding your house and the combat system (which is pretty solid minus a few flaws) wear off you realise there's no backbone and its point a to point b with no substance.

2. Combat is initially fun and i had mine set to hard and confidently say it is completely ruined. The damage enemies deal and damage you deal is petty. Having been used to dark souls 2/3 hit kills would be perfect and fair but instead it takes you about 5 hits to die and you can easily heal within combat. The worst however is that your weapons are so flimsy you pretty much have to hit a regular enemy with 30 hits (about 10 combos) before killing him and this isn't even a joke unfortunately. So when you are facing 3 enemies good luck finishing them off in under 2 minutes. In fact this is the worst when it comes to legendary animals on hard it is laughable spending 15 minutes fighting a 'boss' with about 3 different uninspired attacks.

3. Armour and weapon system is a shambles. I love collecting good armour sets then not having to worry about my gear for the next 5 or so hours, unfortunately here you just pick up and roll with whatever set happens to be the highest level. So that nice shiny legendary sword you just got will be used for a single level before being cast aside. Want to level it up to keep using it? Well good luck paying the massive price to level up and customise it for a single extra level before its once again thrown out. I love that feeling in witcher 3 and skyrim when you just got that new weapon/armour set and you feel at your strongest before in another 5 hours of gameplay you replace it again. Here its just frustrating to have to keep upgrading i would have even preferred no armour weapon/system where everything just levels up itself it would be still poor but less tedious than the current system.

4. Microtransactions are awful. I find it sad that people pretend this didn't happen as if they didn't find a way to insultingly jam pay-to-win into a singleplayer game. Microtransactions for cosmetics are bad enough for a completionist when you just spent Â£60 but paying money to avoid tedium is some free to play mobile game scam not triple A.

Not Recommended
104.4 hrs on record
Posted: 14 October, 2018
This game is beautiful and fun as hell for the first 25 levels. That's when the grind begins. I don't mind, and even enjoy, a certain amount of grind. But this level of grind is a game breaker for me. Despite breaking down virtually all non-legendary gear and buying materials from blacksmiths, I never have close to enough material to keep my legendary equipment current. To upgrade a legendary torso to level 38 costs 442 iron, 885 Soft skins, 133 obsidian glass and 8846 of the currency. It's the same cost regardless of whether you are upgrading a level 16 torso or a level 37 torso. You get soft leather by hunting animals and a deer gives you 3 soft skins. Even the larger and less common animals such as the lion or bear only yield between 10-15. You do the math. It's a brutal grind.

The RPG aspects of the game are strictly based in the gear the character wears. We invest time and resources kitting out our gear to develope a character and then are forced to wear other non-legendary gear that may or may not fit in with the RPG character we have developed. Or . . . we can pay real money for resources. I mentioned earlier that a level 38 torso requires 885 soft-skins. It will cost you $10 to get 420 soft-skins, 420 iron and 14 obsidian glass. $10 will not get you enough materials to level a 38 torso! Including weapons, we wear 8 items, and I've only talked about the torso, admittedly the most expensive piece to upgrade.

I'll keep my eye on the game notices to see if Ubisoft makes any changes, but I'm done.

- Customizable outfit, gear, horse skin, ship skin etc.
- Amazing soundtrack (but I guess that's not why you wanna buy this game)
- Decent story but doesn't quite feel like an Assassins Creed game

Cons:
- Side Missions are very repetitive (for eg: STOP asking us to get 3 seals from Spartan or Athenian generals 8 billion times!)
- Selecting one opponent system during combat is broken, frustrating and stupid
- I'm almost at my target location by the time Phobos arrives (the stupid horse gets stuck behind everything)
- riding Phobos in cities, town, villages or any sort of restricted areas is frustrating because the horse basically starts jogging slowly
- The game still has a ton of stupid collectible treasures which are repetitive and do not provide any good gear. The only time these treasures are worth opening is at the beginning of the game when the main character is not developed enough. After level 30 or after the completion of the main story these treasures are worthless and only serve as area completion objectives.
- worst voice acting amongst all AC games.



Would I recommend it?
Absolutely, despite of it's shortcomings, the game is still a ton of fun.

139.6 hrs on record
Posted: 6 January, 2020
First off I have to say nuts to the reviewers who said this was a "good RPG, but bad Assassin's Creed game." I heard that phrase tossed around A LOT while reading and watching reviews about AC: Odyssey and looking back now, I am annoyed by that sentiment. Having played so much of it now, I think people said that just to sound clever because it is one of those phrases that MASKS itself as clever by saying one positive thing about a genre and one negative thing about an entire franchise, so it almost sounds believable.

I'd say they're horribly wrong. This is as AC as AC can get with how your main character, whoever you choose to play as, has a friggin Piece of Eden with them at all times, first of all, and second of all, if these people paid attention to the cutscenes, particularly the ones in Athens, the supporting cast as subliminally training you on how to become an assassin in terms of how you conduct your business. Yeah, sure, you're a mercenary in Ancient Greece who also happens to use stealth, but doesn't use a hidden blade. Fine. But again this is a pre-prequel to Origins and you are playing the precursor to what would later BECOME assassins.

Not to mention we finally have a 3rd person to see the modern story through, and although she's kind of boring, it's a nice step in the right direction after all these 2nd person experiences that felt disconnected even though the modern era characters were addressing you, the player, directly. We just need a better modern era character to play through who is actually an assassin descendent and it would literally save the entire modern era part of the franchise, I don't get why Ubisoft doesn't see that. Did they forget how awesome Desmond Miles was as a character?

Anyways narrative aside, I can say with absolute certainty this is one of the best Assassin's Creed games I've ever played. There's a lot of systems to get acquainted with and it is overwhelming, but overall I think this is the best gameplay an AC game has ever had so far. The combat has been reworked to be more challenging and engaging, along with ability oriented that you can develop through the RPG levelling system.

The stealth is still pretty good, but I don't like the overuse of bushes for this, I miss just peaking around walls like in Unity and using hay bails. It's also not as satisfying to use a broken spear instead of a hidden blade. The animations could've been cleaned up too, I hate seeing the weapon missplaced in the enemy from where they actually bleed and got stabbed from. I don't get why Ubisoft opted for this loose way of handling animations because in earlier AC games iirc, the stealth kill animations had the player and enemy locked in a fixed animation together instead of two animations happening at once by two separate sprites.

Otherwise the stealth is still good with the air kills, the wall kills, and despite my hate of bush overuse, I do love me some bush kills where you take the enemy into the bush, kill them and then BAM no need to carry the body and hide it somewhere, your kill does that for you.

Ever since it was introduced in ACIII I kind of hated the naval battle system. I just feel like it's a whole different game, but I can see why people like it. This time around you can upgrade the hell out of it and I dunno, docking other enemy ships should've been done better like it was in Black Flag where you can swing onto their ship instead of waiting for this slow and awkward docking animation to get you close enough for you to hop on. Honestly, I hate this battle system as it feels clunky and awkward, but I can see why people would enjoy it as it has been vastly improved since ACIII.

Oh and I gotta say, the map looks cleaner as interest spots are spread further apart. Compared to Unity's mess of a map, this is pristine. The SIDEQUESTS are actually fun and engaging this time around, rivalling the likes of Witcher III where the stories actually kinda matter, and the rewards are mostly worth it to feed that greed for more loot you can either equip, sell, or break down for parts for crafting. There were some sidequests where I actually got invested in these side characters' stories which is very rare in AC games to do because before it was just talk to some static NPC who doesn't even look you in the eye, that you can even walk away from while they're talking, but no. This time around, there are cinematic camera angles to deliver actual looking dialogue between assassin and NPC. ABOUT TIME, UBISOFT! GAWD!

Anyways, very damn good game, highly recommend. Odyssey vastly improves on all previous titles and cleans up the feel of the controls. However, combat is awkward on controller as you have R1/RB and R2/RT for light attacks and heavy attacks respectively. It's a strain on my fingers, personally, so I remapped them to Y and B on my Steam controller, along with making X my assassinate button because wtf is Y the assassinate button this time around? That makes no sense. Mapping the controller controls is kind of weird as a button used for several functions might not be useable if you map your controls in a way that conflicts the game's several situational controls (ie combat vs stealth, navigation vs interaction etc).

I think the next game should address this control issue as well as remove naval battle (PLEASE), and maybe even clean up those kill animations so they look like they're actually part of the same interaction, then that would be a perfect Assassin's Creed Game.
