Assassin's Creed Odyssey Review

The Assassinâ€™s Creed franchise is a one of the greatest franchises in
gaming history, but has also been aâ€¦Less than mediocre franchise at
times, to put it nicely. I still remember when I first played the original
Assassinâ€™s Creed game, it was an entirely new and unique genre at that
time. There was no other game like it, and since then it has inspired
most of Ubisoft games to be like it in design and gameplay. But then the
bad years of the AC franchise came when a new AC game was an annual
event and every new game just felt more and more like the previous
game, but with more bugs. I canâ€™t stress how great of a choice it was to
take a break a few years back from making a new AC game. Last year,
they came out with Assassinâ€™s Creed: Origins and that was a fresh new
installment. It had all the good mechanics from past AC games while
adding new ones. All in all, it rejuvenated and breathed new life into a
once dying series.

So now, what about this yearâ€™s title? Odyssey - Is it back to the
monotonous and dull games of years past or does it match up with what
Origins had to offer?

Is this still Assassinâ€™s Creed?
One stark change to the franchise (since Origins), is the fact that the
game has moved to a much more of a focus on having RPG elements
than being Hack and Slash-like, like in the original. This game also has a
huge importance on collecting unique and fancy loot. While it may not
be like the loot collecting in games such as Destiny and Warframe, it
does hold its own. In the end it is not in the same genre as these other
games and is not designed to be a looter game. Therefore, for a game to
not be a â€œlooterâ€, yet have the astonishing variety of loot found in this
game is a huge positive.

Combat and Gameplay Mechanics
Something that is common to RPGs, but not to most previous AC games
is the level system with skill points to put into various abilities. At the
start you will not have many abilities or skills and the game may feel like
a hack and slash game, but as you progress through the game, the
combat will also get better. I can say with certainty that this game has
one of the best combat mechanics you will see in any game. You have a
wide variety of blocks, attacks, assassinations, etc. at your disposal.

There is a bounty system, if you harm innocent lives and commit crimes
then there will be a bounty on your head. And at times when you least
expect it, you will be notified that 1 or more bounty hunters are after
you. Now these arenâ€™t the same as the tiny, trash mobs you fight most of
the game. No, these bounty hunters are more like boss fights. And when
you see them you better run as fast as you can unless you want to risk
your life.

There are many more unique gameplay elements that I will touch on in
other parts of this review.

Story
I will try and give a brief summary of some parts of the story without
spoiling anything. You have a very basic character creation system with
the main choice being whether you choose male or female character.
Throughout the story you are trying to reconnect with your past while
also trying to change the future of Ancient Greece for the better.

You face a cult throughout the story and you are given this flowchart
with various members of the cult but with their identities hidden. You
can perform missions and other quests to uncover more information

about these members and once you have identified them you can take
them out. One by one, you try and take down the entire cult. But keep in
mind that most of these members arenâ€™t easy to kill, they are extremely
challenging and there is a hefty reward for killing them with exquisite
loot drops.

You also have Greece split up into various regions and in each of them
you can influence a particular faction such as the Spartans and Athens.
Once you have earned enough influence you can wage war on the other
faction in the area. These triggers a war-type mission which is a huge
scale battle. Once you have defeated enough of the enemy you have to
fight a final boss to finally defeat the faction and gain control for your
allies. This is a unique game mode not seen in other games and is a
wonderful addition to this game.

Naval Combat
Now earlier in this review I said that they added new elements but kept
good ones from previous games, and one good decision was to bring
back the naval combat from Black Flag. There are a few changes such as
no cannons, since there werenâ€™t any cannons during the period the
game is set in. But they have replaced them with things such as a javelin
barrage. All in all, there are small changes to the naval combat, but it is
just as good as in Black Flag. One thing that adds to the experience, is
the gorgeous water textures and graphics. Sailing through this huge
open world looks, as beautiful as you can imagine.

Graphics and Performance
This game has some of the best graphic design and artwork you will see
in any game. Yes, some of the assets are reused from Origins, but that
just tells you how beautiful Origins looked and this one is even better. To
add to the amazing graphical quality, the game runs, as smooth as
butter. And this isnâ€™t just for me, but for most people on the internet.

This just shows how much has changed since the days of AC: Unity
where the game was a bug infested mess on release.

Go and get the game ASAP!
What are you waiting for? This game is a masterpiece. While there are a
couple of issues when it comes to the leveling system being a bit too
much of a grind towards the end game, a couple of side quests will help
you on your way. Donâ€™t buy the microtransaction currency to boost your
character, donâ€™t support this corporate greed. Just play some side quests
which wonâ€™t be an annoying thing to do, as this game is truly enjoyable.
Itâ€™s a game you will come back to time after time and enjoy over the
period of months rather than rushing through the game in a weekend.
This game is definitely worth the money for old fans and new ones too!

Rate: 10/10

Posted: 28 August, 2021
Can't spell assassin without twice the ass and a little bit of sin
Standard fare open-world hacky slashy "RPG" from UBISOFT, hot off the heels of AC: ORIGINS; Odyssey seeks to further expand on the Isu side of things by introducing you to an even older ancestor but also giving you the choice to choose whether or not it will be a man or a woman (though canonically its supposed to just be the woman Kassandra)

By now you will have already read a ton of reviews or even videos about this game so let's keep it kind of brief.

Combat is more or less the same from Origins except you can't block anymore, only parry and dodge. The skills / perks / abilities or whatever you wanna call them will help you traverse, murder, scout and track as you explore the greek isles. Voice acting and sound design is pretty good, can be quite immersive sometimes and it really gives you that greek feel.

Graphics are pretty great, optimization can use a bit of work as you will notice a lot of frame drops in certain areas (most especially in DLC areas) but they don't stick around or happen to often that it becomes an issue. Well at least not for me during my 100+ hour run.

The side missions aren't as optional as I'd like because you kind of need them to grind EXP just so you can survive the next story mission. The level / exp scaling is off a bit so it can get pretty tedious. If this game didn't hook you with first few minutes, you're likely not gonna have a good time.

They have transmog in this game so long as you've picked up that armor/weapon before so that's always a plus in my book. The story has a lot of good moments but they aren't as memorable as past AC releases, you might finish the game and find that the DLC story stuck to you more than the main story.

All in all, I would rate this game a solid 3/5 cause it does have a lot of moments where its dull and it also has a lot of moments where you really enjoy what you're doing. Does this make me hopeful for the next few AC games? If they stick to the assassin motif, sure. But i'm not holding my breath.

Catch this on a sale

Decent game, but shockingly buggy, given both it's triple A status, and the fact that it uses basically the exact same game engine as Assassin's Creed Origins, which seemed to have none of these bugs. I've had UI elements disappear randomly (including my health bar, and tags above enemies - those are pretty rare. Much more common is the popup information about inventory disappearing). Another common bug is the eagle breaking so it can't be using to find tablets. The game is also a bit too repetitive, and features microtransactions. The item UI also makes selling large quantities of junk items (Which inevitably build up in your inventory) and buying large amounts of wood, to upgrade your ship, needlessly aggravating.

The map is also pretty bad - quests will often tell you what region they're in, but the map desperately needs a search function, given the large number of regions and the unimportance of the region and subregion names mean you won't be learning most of them.

Otherwise, it's a decent game, certainly more colorful than its predecessor. The writing for the main questions and "yellow exclamation mark" is consistently good, the voice acting is fine. The gameplay is just like the previous one, albeit with a more interesting skill tree, and a smattering of tiny new gameplay elements.

I would not recommend paying full price for the game, but think it's good enough to be worth picking up on sale. I wish there were a more neatral option, but I'm marking this as not recommended.

Recommended
390.8 hrs on record
Posted: 4 October, 2019
Odyssey is not your typical Assassin's Creed title and will disappoint long-time fans who expect it to fit into the same criteria they came to expect from these titles.

Assassin's Creed Odyssey fits more into the world of Witcher or Skyrim than anything. The world is beautiful and vibrant. Size wise, it is definitely larger than any of the titles that came before it. The world does not feel empty. There is always something to do as you are traveling between towns and cities on your quests.

Similar to Assassin's Creed Syndicate, this game offers a male and female protagonist to play as, however the choice whether to be one or the other is made at the beginning of a new game. There is no option to switch back and fourth. Personally, the female protagonist Kassandra appealed to me the most. Her voice acting was done extremely well, unlike Alexios, who sounds goofy and off time to time.

The story line captivated me to keep playing for hundreds of hours. Your role is not one of an assassin, but rather of a mercenary who sets out to help others with their problems. You will be saving villagers, raiding forts, taking down wild animals, pillaging tombs, and more as you set out to explore ancient Greece.

There are many fun perks to play with that will enhance your character and provide you with different options to handle your enemies. You may choose to specialize in close range brutal combat setting your weapons ablaze, kicking people off ledges with the infamous spartan kick, or ripping enemy shields out of their hands and smashing them with it. Perhaps a more stealthy approach is what you will go with, utilizing poisoned weapons and smoke bombs, assassin daggers, and more. Finally, the bow is another option for those scared to fight toe to toe with the ancient legends of Greece.

As you play you will discover new weapons and armor and gather supplies to upgrade your trireme, Adrestia. Unfortunately, the new equipment quickly becomes meaningless after you gain a few levels and outgrow it, requiring a lot of materials to upgrade it to fit your level. This may come off as a bit grindy and put some people off. It's definitely not a system that is quick to navigate. Prepare to spend hours gathering supplies and money from exploration, quests, and looting enemies to get what you need.

As far as the actual game play elements. No gripes. The game is fluid. Combat is great. It's easy to learn and understand. Climbing has been made easier and less frustrating. However, it feels a little stupid sometimes. For example, falling from heights will no longer kill your character. No longer how high up. Will always leave your character on a sliver of health left. For some it may be great as it will save the frustrating of wasting time to climb down, but for others it may ruin the immersion.

Speaking of immersion, the game handles it beautifully. The graphics are amazing. The character progression is done well. I spent a long time just listening to conversations between characters and was given choices by the game, that actually mattered in what happened in the world around me. These were some of my most exciting parts of the game. I looked forward to those cutscenes.

At a quick glance:

Combat: 10/10
Graphics: 10/10
Immersion: 8/10
Quests: 8/10
Story line: 10/10
Characters: 10/10
Character Development: 9/10
DLC content: 6/10
Grind Level: 5/10

Hope this review helps! This game is definitely a must play!

Edit. To be clear. I really dislike the way Ubisoft has been releasing games far before they are ready. If this game launched as it is now, I would have originally recommended it. My original experience with this game can be found below but it essentially was full of bugs, had a bad script and facial animations, and a lack of content other than chores that are an exact copy of a looter/shooter like Ubisoft's The Division. The issues with the script and facial animations can be avoided by playing as Kassandra instead of Alexios (I seriously do not understand how two main characters can be so different in animation quality). And Ubisoft rebalanced the loot and combat system while including new content that makes the game less of a grind and more enjoyable to play. Overall, if you can get the full game (the DLC here should have been included in the base game) for $60 or less then it is worth it.


A Franchise Gone Wrong:
To be very clear for anyone who loves the assassins creed franchise and playstyle, this is not that kind of game By Far. Repetative as a spinning wheel.
Oeverall: This is an amazing looking and sounding game about grinding for the next item/weapon/armor to grind to the next level through repetative side quests so you can see the poorly written cutscene (that is well acted and looks amazing) so that you can grind for more money and resources to upgrade your gear to grind to the next level and get better gear so you can get to the next cutscene. Repeat this for 25-50 hours depending on how much you want to explore and complete. And my biggest gripe is that it is almost impossible to play as an assassin until mid-late game. I would not have minded the grind if the combat was more balanced or if the story was half decenent but overall this game felt like work for unapealing rewards. In hidnsight, I would most certainly purchase the game again, but only on sale because even if the amount of content is equivalent to the purchase price, most of this games content felt like repetative work. I probably won't come back to it for a second play through for a very long time.

The good:

- The RPG elements are more dominant here than they were in Origins

The bad:

- Upgrading weapons is way too expensive.
- KEY PLOT POINT ARE ONLY EXPLAINED IN THE DLC. As such, the game is only worth its salt as an Assassin's Creed game if you get the season pass.

All in all, I recommend getting this game, it is sure to captivate you and keep you playing for a good while. The graphics and gameplay mechanics are good. The season pass is a must, and for what you get, I think it's double worth it.

chamathamara
80 products in account

2 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
98.8 hrs on record
Posted: 21 November, 2018
It's probably the best Assassin's Creed because it's so unlike an Assassin's Creed game. Much of the gameplay is still there - the stealth, assassinations, and combat (though the combat is different from older AC games). But because it takes place before the canonical founding of the Assassins and Templars, they aren't present in the game. Furthermore, the modern branch of the story is reduced to 4 very short sequences, and one of them is entirely skippable.

About 5% of this game is rooted in Assassin's Creed - talking about Abstergo, the animus, the first civilization, the modern story, etc. These are easily the worst parts. The dialogue is terrible, the characters are poorly written, and ultimately it's just not interesting.

The remaining 95% is absolutely amazing. The dialogue is usually pretty solid, the characters are interesting and memorable (they did such a good job here it frequently felt like playing a BioWare game), and every location is beautiful. The story is pretty great, and it really does feel like playing through an epic about a Greek hero. It has enough twists and turns to keep things fresh, but it still isn't too self-serious or self-important (other than the Assassin's Creed tie-in garbage).

I'm not really absolutely sure why the "grindy" criticism is so prevalent. I was consistently 5+ levels ahead of the curve by doing all of the secondary quests, and the micro-transaction boosts were entirely unneeded. So I never had to grind - I just had to keep playing more of the game with fresh, hand-crafted content, and it kept me ahead of the XP curve.

That said, are 2 kinds of side quests. There are loads of simple, "infinite" quests such as "kill 5 wolves" or "kill that nameless commander over there," and these can and should be ignored. Then there are secondary quests which are extra hand-crafted content outside of the main story. In Skyrim terms, these are radiant quests (which are bad and should be ignored) and non-main quests (which are great and you should do them). Just like in Skyrim, if you ignore the non-main quests, you are missing out - you'll both fall behind in XP/gear and you'll skip some really great story/characters/content. Just like in Skyrim, you shouldn't play the radiant quests because they are horrible and grindy and you aren't really missing out on XP/gear or content.

Another criticism I've seen for this game is that it isn't enough like the other Assassin's Creed games. Gameplay-wise, it's definitely a solid improvement and iteration on the AC formula (which is another thing that makes it unlike an AC game, because the franchise is notorious for not innovating or improving). But story-wise, it is absolutely a far cry from other AC games. This, to me, is only a positive thing - I didn't actually know that anybody liked the AC story/canon, because I (and most people I know) think it's kind of garbage. But it's true that if you want a game heavy on the AC canon, this game might disappoint you. Perhaps if they just kept the same exact gameplay, but removed all references of Assassin's Creed and its canon/story, I would like this game more and so would AC fans.

Ultimately, like almost every game on the planet, you will run out of things to do. But it took me 90 hours to get to that point, so... It's got some good longevity. Its replayability is somewhat lacking, and I think that's mainly because it doesn't have mod support. Ubisoft are releasing new content, such as some small side quests and a boss fight, but they're sort of underwhelming. There are other open world games that I can keep coming back to because I can completely change the experience (Elder Scrolls), but it's impossible for this one.

Just finished the main storyline and I can say that this is not only my favorite AC game but one of the best games that I've ever played. The open world experience is so immersive, this is one of the few times that I feel this much immersed while playing. I'm a big fan of Ancient Greek and seeing Sokrates, Sophokles, Pythagoras, Plato, Hippokrates, Herodotos, Democritus, Aristophanes and many others was amazing. The RPG aspect of this game is absolutely amazing. You literally can play these historical personages' questlines, talk with them and have an individual journey with them.

The cities and platos are amazing too. In some cases, you climb somewhere high and look really far (I mean kilometers far) and then start riding there without any loading screen or interruption. It has a HUGE map including Makedonia, Athens, Mykonos, Kephallonia etc. and you can travel through these places without any loading screens. And I have to mention the citizens' idle animations. I'd like to give it an example. After finishing a quest in Arkadia, I was walking throught the streets of Ancient Greek and I saw a man, teaching two kids how to fight. I stopped and started watching to see how much they invested on animating them. They listened their teacher and then started fighting and It kept going. There are musicians on the streets, salesmen, bounty hunters, sometimes region leaders, normal citizens, drunk people, fishermen etc. The game is full of immersive elements that keeps you in the game for a really long time.

I'm a big fan of this combat system too. Shadow of War is one of my favorite games of all time and Odyssey's combat style is really similar to that but much realistic with less brutalism. In the other hand, the ship fights are amazing. I loved Black Flag and It was really groundbreaking at It's time but this game took sea traveling and sea combat to another level for me. The system is pretty similar but with more features. You can upgrade your ship and get stronger and fight other ships. You can either destroy them from far or you can anchor their ship and have a death battle. And the gaming experience amazing.

I haven't completed or started the DLC content properly yet so I'm not capable of reviewing those but from only the base game's experience, It was AMAZING. I started the game and started doing a side quest storyline and lost myself into it, thinking It was some part of the main storyline because they were too good to be side quests. After completing some few quests back to back, I've said farewell by having an affair with my quest giver and the questline was over. At that moment, I've realized that It was just a sidequest and I knew this game is going to be amazing.

Overall, just discovering new places and walking in the cities is so much fun by itself. And the maps are beautiful. Beautiful environment design! I'm probably going to be completing all of the achievements after completing the DLC contents.

I loved Origins too by the way. It was a great game too and really fun but this is on another level. Even If you're not a fan of AC series you should definitely try it. It's just beautiful to be able play a game set in Ancient Greek era.

Recommended
277.1 hrs on record
Posted: 1 May, 2020
It's a great game, one of the best in the entire franchise. It has a great story, a great protagonist (regardless of which one you choose), and a great environment and world. AC Odyssey has wonderful RPG elements to it, making for satisfying fights in boss battles and conquest (war) battles. Although the series has leaned heavily towards the RPG genre, it still expects the stealth and strategy from the previous games in the franchise through its mercenary system that is more forgiving to the silent-assassin type players that loved the previous entries to the franchise. It uses skill trees, making the player have personalized experiences in the game, while still allowing an easy shift in play style but allowing it to be reset for a seldom, almost negligible drachmae. Additionally, there are numerous unique and often hilarious side quests that allows the players to enjoy even a quick session of the game. Admittedly, one of the major criticisms towards the series is its plethora of side-quests, which can be overwhelming but it could also be satisfying, depending on how the player takes them on. For instance, when I could only dedicate minutes of my time towards playing the game, I just do a chain of side quests that often leaves me satisfied and entertained once finished. The naval battles are entertaining, and it is very satisfying to either board an enemy ship or just cleave it in half. It's also very user-friendly, it allows for older fans (especially AC Origins players) to jump right into action and for new players to learn the game mechanics (of both keyboard and controller) easily.
That being said, I'm aware that, like many games, Odyssey is not everyone's cup of tea but I can truly say that I love this game.

Not Recommended
497.8 hrs on record
Posted: 13 May, 2021
"Wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle....."

At least that's how I think someone else described this game, and it's quite apt. The game is gorgeous graphically, there is some good voice acting in places, a lot of work has obviously gone into it, and for that, the developers deserve credit. However, there are a number of reasons why I can't recommend this game, unless you can get it on sale like I did.

- The levelling system. You never really feel a sense of progression in this game as everything more or less scales with your character's level. Most enemies can generally kill you in just a few hits, unless they are several levels below you. Archers and warriors with poisoned or flaming weapons are always a big threat, regardless of your level. You are constantly forced to upgrade or buy new gear as the level 7 sword you have now at level 7 is markedly inferior to the level 8 spear you can buy from a merchant when you reach level 8. For some inane reason, the game does not allow you to get rid of legendary items or sell them. Instead, you have to lug all this junk around with you or else store it in your personal chest on your ship. I guess this was done because, heavens forbid, some people might get upset if they can't complete their legendary armour sets because they accidentally sold a piece of it.
- Brain-dead AI. With enough time and patience, you can assassinate most of the soldiers in any fort by simply hiding in the same bush, whistling until someone comes over to investigate, then assassinating them. Rinse and repeat. Lone Athenian soldiers will recklessly charge into outposts of Spartan soldiers that outnumber them 5 or more to 1. Any time someone attacks you in a village, the locals all seem to whip out brooms from nowhere and fearlessly take you on as well, with no regard for their own safety. Villagers and, occasionally,their pet dogs, will stray too close to a flaming brazier, catch on fire, then proceed to burn to death while everyone else just ignores them and carries on as usual even when their charred corpses are lying on the ground.
- In-game microtransactions. This is already annoying in itself, but does Ubisoft really have to insist on advertising their other games in this one? I noticed that when I tried playing this game again after a long break, I suddenly had complete sets of Viking armour and Renaissance era armour in my inventory, and some of the characters from other Assassin's Creed games are now available as lieutenants on my ship. Even if you don't assign them to your available lieutenant slots, you can't dismiss any of them, and you can't drop or sell any of the armour either. I don't like having all this forced on me without earning it - I'd prefer to recruit lieutenants and find/buy armour myself over the course of the game.
- Repetitiveness. The game is great fun to begin with, but rapidly becomes extremely repetitive. There is little variation in the general gameplay. You sail across the sea, arrive in a region suitable for your level, take on quests from notice boards or NPCs which generally involve you giving them money, sinking X number of ships, delivering a message, or killing some bandit/soldier/politician, just so you can accumulate enough XP to be of sufficient level to follow the main story, which seems a bit tepid in itself. Occasionally you will have to infiltrate a fort to rescue someone or retrieve something, which usually involves you bumping off most or all of the resident soldiers by hiding in the bushes and assassinating them. There are also conquest battles, most of which are thankfully optional and involve you fighting for a specific side and killing as many enemy soldiers as quickly as possible so your chosen side can win the battle. Rinse and repeat.
- The writing. Very basic and seems to be aimed at 16 year old console junkies with raging hormones and limited attention spans. Example is the cringy dialog when you try to recruit Odessa in Megara, with every second dialog option being an "I want to shag you" option.
- Other stuff. Why can't I use a shield when the classic Greek warriors of this era generally used shields?
- Having to have UPlay installed in order to run this game. 'Nuff said.

I don't have Assassin's Creed Valhalla, but it sounds like Ubisoft have already attempted to address some of these issues (like levelled items and repetitive quests) in that game, so good for them.

surprise ham
295 products in account
0
3 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
56.5 hrs on record
Posted: 9 July, 2019
A breathtaking game, and for all the right reasons.

Assassins creed Odyssey strays so far from the original games, yet still manages to be my favourite, a game with endless possibilities that I can keep coming back to.

Graphically, it really does not get better than this. Stunning landscapes and seas, with an ever-present dynamic skyline and colours so true to reality. Travel the seas or explore hidden caverns, and still experience the eye-catching details that this game brings to the series. From the breaking and ebbing of waves to the glowing of a splint, graphically, this game is close to flawless. Let it be said, however, that it does require a hefty computer. Would definitely not recommend playing on a low end PC.

Second, I want to touch on the story and the characters. I don't believe that this game brings the most lovable or the funniest characters of the series, but I must say that the overall storyline is definitely intriguing. The way the assassin ancestry comes into play is very interesting, and catches you at the perfect time. Sometimes, voice acting in cutscenes is not amazing, I should add, although there are one or two well done performances among the rest. Overall, however, the story does stand out as a good one among so many rushed narratives in today's market.

Now, the gameplay and variety in this game is second to absolutely none. I'll say it again, there are no limits to what you can do. I am amazed that they managed to make the sailing and swimming experiences so lifelike, yet still have an outstanding combat system. Battles, whether large or small, are always satisfying and always rewarding, and you will never feel as though it is burdensome. Everything outfit is customisable, upgradable and there is no end to what is put in front of you in this game. In previous AC games, I have to say I was bored of side quests and bored of the constant grind. It often felt like a chore. In Odyssey, however, Ubisoft presents something so different. There are not only main quests, side quests, bounties, contracts, deliveries and more, but also a system of mercenaries and a system of occultists. Everything you do, whether assassinating an occultist or taking out hordes of Athenian ships, has an incredible reward and progression system. Everything is pointing towards a certain end goal, and so everything you do has worth and meaning. That is exactly what I have been waiting for in a large title like this.

And just as i thought the game couldn't get better, Ubisoft delivers one of the best soundtracks ever in a video game. The way it varies between an eery, intense assassination melody to an open-seas naval battle anthem is just incredible, and the music keeps you gripped and divulged in what exactly you are doing. Environmental sounds are also incredible, again immersing you into the surroundings.

So, onto the historical aspect. Awesome. I had always dreamed of living in the past, and that is what Odyssey brings to life. The Ancient Greek world is fascinating, and I believe very true. I love sailing Greek waters, bumping into pirates, Spartans, Athenians, and seeing what it really was like to live in the Greek world. Obviously, no representation can be perfect, but I really like the approach odyssey has taken to depict the legendary civilisation.

I am reluctant to say something is 10/10 because that theoretically means it is perfection, but right now I believe that Assassins Creed Odyssey is the best open world game out there in 2019, and I definitely recommend purchasing it, as it results in endless adventure and endless fun.

The game is actually OK in the beginning but eventually becomes too repetitive.

The level scaling doesnâ€™t work well. On the highest difficulty you get weaker with every level (long grindy fights). On the second hardest difficulty you become unstoppable at high level (boring). There is no balanced difficulty setting. I preferred the old game design, which didnâ€™t include leveling. No leveling is better than a bad level system.

There is a lot of content. Actually, there is too much content. As a completionist, I tried to finish this (DLC included) but got bored at some point. The gameplay gets stale at some point and is not adequate for such a long game. The gameplay needs to be deeper and more complex. Even the skill trees are not fitted for the end game (you just add you skill points in some minor buffs like +0.4% sword damage).

It also doesnâ€™t feel like an assassin's creed game, especially on the highest difficulty. At high level and max difficulty I need critical assassinations for everything (even for fragile archer). This is an example of becoming weaker as you level. Normal assassination worked fine at level 1.

The active abilities are very powerful. This is why enemies must be so durable. The active abilities are problematic as they are driving force in combat instead of a complementary part (feels like a MMO not an action game). Overwhelmed by a powerful mythological creature? The cooldown waiting game awaits! Abilities like "you cannot fall bellow 1 health/die for 20 seconds" don't belong in an action+stealth game.

This game is not only repetitive, but also very generic! So you can get bored quickly!

Conclusion: OK at first (first 40-50 hours) but eventually turns in a generic MMO experience. There is a ton of mediocre content. Might be worth playing for the first hours but not at the full price. This is a decent option if you want to waste many hours. Or you could play a better game.

Not Recommended
267.8 hrs on record
Posted: 6 September, 2019
To give a little bit of a background on my experience with the franchise I played from the first Assassin's Creed to Unity and then stopped because I was burnt out and the story from Black Flag and Unity disappointed me (I was expecting them to wrap it up honestly or something).


The visuals,
it's very pretty and well balanced nothing hard on the eyes sometimes the light sources can become weird but it's nothing that will last usually. Also the game runs pretty well, at least on my machine I know it's not much of an indicator but at least you don't need to be scared that it's a poorly optimised game and you'll want to throw your computer out of the window.

The world,
It's very big but if you are one to explore you will quickly notice that it's quickly repetitive and will feels very empty since there are not enough side-quests that don't feel like fetch quests to do. The locations and enemies will quickly feel the same as well, everyone fight the same generally. The AI is pretty bad and their path finding is a joke to the point that it feels immersion breaking when you see it. There were mythical creatures that had their own little quest and those were actually fun to do but there are only a handful of them to beat so it's short lived. It is fun to navigate with your ship but I felt very little incentive to use it since it felt like there were very little interesting underwater content or events to do. Side note, the horse can be annoying to use when going uphill as it turn left and right randomly.

The gameplay,
that's the bad part sadly and I can't really excuse it as much as I want to love the game.

1. The combat system feels dated and at times unresponsive, I'm standing and spamming the key for an ability and it takes 5-6 presses for the game to finally react. Dodging and parrying suffers from that same randomness and I wanted to believe it was on my end but I honestly tried my damn best to do something about it but nothing. I had to resort to change my build to avoid combat as much as I could because it would drive me insane.
2. A lot of strange mechanics like you can jump as high as you want and never suffer from fall damage or abilities that makes you nearly unkillable just pushing you away from being an assassin but another fantasy game hero.
3. There is some build diversity between the Hunter, Warrior and Assassin abilities but a lot of them are sort of useless if I'm being honest so it's not so crazy like it would make you want to start a new save for it probably.
4. You are not an assassin anymore, you need a good build to do that because the game has levels and RNG loots.
5. The parkour/climbing is dumbed down way too much to the point that I don't even feel like I'm playing the game anymore, I hold shift and look somewhere and off you go, there is no jump button, no sprint button it's all with shift which is another aspect of the franchise that I loved lost. Also it stops working sometimes as my character would just not do anything and I would need to climb somewhere else or with a different angle. Lastly it will stick too easily to climbable surfaces near my character when I would run in tight spaces which led to some really clunky looking parkour or simply frustrating navigation.
6. The gear comes with rarity and random stats there are legendary items that are not thankfully but the inventory management is still annoying in my opinion and also thank god for visual customisation you don't have to look stupid for wearing pieces from 5 different looking armors.
7. The level system is pretty bad, if you are fighting an enemy 1-2 levels higher than you it will reduce your damage and increase their damage ridiculously and vice versa.

The story,
it's not a masterpiece but not bad, most characters have their charm and the storytelling is good. The main character (I played Kassandra) is likeable and everything is voiced perfectly. However like most of the game it's not really an Assassin's Creed anymore as you don't get to play much of the growing up phase. It did feel drawn out at some point if I'm being honest.

The side-quests,
20% good, 80% generic/boring and I'm not talking about the repetitive quests. Also the repetitive quests are a plague, too many and they feel as if they are only there to fuel some kind of grind added with the levels.

Side note,
there are micro-transactions but they are not mandatory however they are p2w but you can "magically" get a 100% discount on everything if you are a wizard. It's still scummy and if you are going to buy this game, just don't feed into it so they can maybe understand how stupid it is to monetise a SP game with an in-game store.


Overall, it's a really watered down AC if you can even call that an AC game anymore, it's pretty but bland in content. You are paying for the visuals more than an actual good game and if you are going to buy it despite this review do it on a big discount at least because it's not worth the money.

Not Recommended
60.2 hrs on record
Posted: 1 January, 2019
Review: An Odyssey

The giant boar has killed me again. What was that, the dozenth time? I lower the difficulty again, but I'm not enabling enemy health bars. I don't even want to know how much it has. How many arrows have I put directly into its face, 43? 67? It was a lot. Of course, that was before the fight even started, as I hid in a bush, trying to take it out from stealth... but you have to start the fight by letting it see you. Otherwise it won't actually take any damage, and start the long slog through multiple waves of smaller boars and makeshift bullfighter gameplay.

A bounty hunter shows up out of nowhere halfway through, interrupting the fight and providing a much-needed distraction. The bounty hunter and their pet wolf get gored by the giant boar and his little pals, but I missed one of the smaller boars, and I'm dead again. How many times have I tried this fight now?

Eventually I end up killing it easily by spamming its face with Devastationg Shots and ignoring the smaller boars entirely. Apparently it was always that easy.

Since when was Assassin's Creed about multi-stage boss fights, spamming your spacebar to dodge around while whittling away at enemies' absurdly high health pools? Health pools so high that even Spongebob would cringe in shame at some of the bullet sponges in this game, especially on higher difficulties. This isn't Dark Souls! Apparently this isn't Assassin's Creed, either.

And let's not forget the time that 2 bounty hunters came after me at level 15. After getting demolished a few times, I re-enabled the enemy level and health bars to figure out why. Both of them were a couple levels higher than me, and each would take countless dozens of hits, knicks, stabbings, bludgeonings and lacerations to kill, hitting them repeatedly for over a minute or two to actually deal enough damage to kill. Is that supposed to be fun?

It's annoying to be tracked down across the world by a constant stream of mercenaries, which makes it seem like you're being punished for simply playing the game. Sometimes one will show up nearly every mission, just to get in the way and cause you grief. Sure, you can outrun them, and apparently you can simply pay down your bounty on the map screen, but does that defeat the purpose of the entire system? When a feature is aggravating at best, it's not a good feature. The Shadow of Mordor/War games did this *infinitely* better.

The Slow Decline

After a couple hours messing around in Odyssey on Google's Project Stream beta, I was convinced I would continue to enjoy the game after purchasing it for myself. And, to Ubisoft's credit, I did continue to enjoy the game. Kind of. When it actually let me.

I started off playing on Nightmare, with as few HUD elements as possible. I wanted to have just a compass, since switching to the map to determine direction was a bit much, but of course that isn't possible to have without also showing points of interest on it.

Then, saddened to learn that Nightmare difficulty just multiplies enemies' health pools and makes them two-shot you, I lowered it to Hard. After some issues fighting higher level enemies, I enabled enemy levels. But that also shows their health bars, and every enemy gets marked by your bird while scouting, so I disabled that again.

Eventually I lowered the difficulty again to Normal, and simply settled for only playing in one region at a time, treating each like I would in a standard level-gated RPG, exhaustively clearing each point of interest, doing all side-quests for EXP and progressing to new areas only as the game (clearly) wanted me to.

For Sparta! Or not.

This game is an unapolagatic pile of contrary design that doesn't respect either the player or the platform.

This is woefully apparent when looking at basic options, like rebinding keys. For instance, you can't rebind important keys like Parry. Q is an awkward key to press while moving around, especially when you also need to hit shift to break an opponent's block.

You can disable most or all of the HUD elements in the game, but the game design makes you feel punished for doing so, because without them you have no way to tell if a single attack on an enemy is enough to wound or kill them, without getting close enough to actually do so. Tougher and higher ranked enemies are usually dressed in more extravagant armor, but wi

Want to see only enemy levels, but not health bars? Too bad.
Want those without your bird marking every target in an area while scouting? Tough luck.
Want to have a compass, but not see points of interest on it? Oh well.

And the list goes on. The HUD options, combined with the arguably weak implementation of "Exploration mode" with its painfully simple descriptions, provide the players with the illusion of choice without actually offering actual gameplay. In fact, I'd argue that disabling certain HUD elements actually detracts from the game as a whole, due to actual gameplay mechanics, Better not miss your character's warning, or you'll get slaughtered by high-level enemies in an area you're not supposed to be in yet.

The level system is the Number One cause of frustration in the game. You fight higher level stuff, you die. That's usually how it goes. It keeps you playing in the same region, progression through specific quests. The open world portion of the game isn't very open in this regard.

The equipment rarity system is borderline useless when you factory in item levels, since one or two levels is a big difference when it comes to DPS and armor, despite losing out on an additional modifier or two, which usually consist of some single-digit improvement that's otherwise unnoticeable during play.

The Conclusion

Whenever I found myself closing the game, it wasn't just because I felt my play session had come to an end, but because I'd rather quit out of frustration than deal with yet another instance of baffled irritation. That's never a good sign.
Assassin's Creed: Odyssey is an open world with invisible borders, mired in conflicting mechanics that lead to frustrating scenarios at every turn. This isn't Assassin's Creed, it's something worse... it's Assassin's Greed.

I was right on the fence when it came to giving this game a Positive vs. a Negative review, because there is just as much good design as bad, if not more. How it all works together, though, leaves a lot to be desired, and I think a Negative review is a better indication that some of us expect better.

Recommended
167.1 hrs on record
Posted: 14 August, 2021
Late to the party, on the last sale on Steam, I decided it was time to play this entry in the series. After 167h and getting 100%, here I am.
I grew up with these games and I was sad to lose interest in them after Ubisoft kept pushing one out every year regardless of quality and while the modern story after Desmond was a cringe-fest that leads nowhere. Let me reassure you, the latter it's not any better in this one.
This game is so different than what Assassin's Creed has always been.
I review it positively though because that's exactly what made it good for me.

THE GOOD

This game is so far from being an AC that it doesn't even feature assassins. In this game, you play as a misthios, a mercenary, in Ancient Grece. It's somewhat connected to the other games, with one of the expansions, but being set prior to Origins, it's not actually assassins.
This makes this game the best attempt of Ubisoft at making a The Witcher 3-like game. I think they might have taken a bit too much inspiration as the soundtrack sometimes sounds extremely similar.
The main character can be chosen between Alexios and Kassandra, and their story, or better, Odyssey is really well written and interesting. The game has a well-rounded combat system, with a nice and detailed ability tree to make your own playstyle shine, in my case, Assassin. The map is big and full of things to do. Moving around is improved by the influence of The Lend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild on the gaming industry allowing the player to climb every possible surface and explore with freedom, but in this case, with no Stamina limits. Quests are really good and well written, sometimes featuring also Romance options which are often just a fade-to-black while kissing scene and have 0 impact over the game. I say often, as it's not always the case, but don't expect Yennefer and Triss level of romancing. From what I understand, the devs after the launch kept adding for free more greek world story arcs that feature a few missions and are written amazingly, easily one of the highlights of the game for me, after the main story. The game has an armor and weapon system with perks and whatnot making it even easier to customize your experience. By the end of the game, I had been using mainly an Assassin build with 100% CRIT Chance and 650% Crit Damage when full health. The game also features a transmog system to always look your best while using the best armors and perks. The expansions are not the best I ever played, but also not bad and they add a new story or new maps. At the time of writing on the last sale, I saw AC: Valhalla - the latest entry - at 30â‚¬ but 90â‚¬ with all expansions and packages. I don't think these were worth 60â‚¬ and I'm sure the pricing was the same at the time. I strongly suggest this game on sale to players who have a few hundred hours in their hands and want to play a game that is somewhat RPG, more in the building the character than the choice options and consequences, even though there are some highlights.

THE BAD

On top of good story missions, this game also features the worst possible missions you could think of. The classic: go there, fetch this, bring it back. Do it 15 times more for no reward other than money. It feels like Ubisoft is scared that if there are not 100 side-missions in the game but only 30 well-written people won't think it's worth the money they ask, which is a lot including the Expansions which are basically mandatory. They may look optional, but the modern story legit doesn't end in the game but inside the second Expansion. This is not just the only scummy-live-service thing in the game. There are boosters you can buy permanently to level up easier and get more money, which seems pointless at first before you see the prices on the last ship upgrades and also realizes after level 99 it actually goes on forever giving the player a chance to min-max perks and stats outside armor and weapons. The store also sells a LOT of unobtainable-in-game Armors, Weapons, and Ship Cosmetics which are amazing to look at and cost often 15â‚¬ each, in a single-player game. There's a way to get them but it requires grinding a resource through bounties almost daily - my Destiny 2 PTSD is kicking in - and waiting for the vendor in the game to rotate and maybe selling what you want. Ubisoft is literally telling single-player gamers: "Log every day and do bounties so maybe you could buy this beautiful looking armor which looks a m a z I n g when available, ooooor...it's just 15â‚¬. It also drops at your level and is epic. ;)".
The game feels like it has mechanics that are taken away from the player for the sake of making it easier. I'll make some examples of some I really didn't like.
The enemies scale to the player at all times, there's no way to disable it and the time it'll take you at level 1 to kill an archer by attacking it will be almost the same at level 99 with 8000 damage. Obviously with abilities and builds you can break it, but that's not the point.
Starting from level 20 falling from heights has no consequences or damage whatsoever. It's not a bad option, but I would rather have a higher fall distance than no damage at all.
Another mechanic the game strips the player of is hiding bodies. Coming from Far Cry 5 I assumed hiding corpses in the bushes would work, but in reality, the AI cheats and will go even outside the camp to find the corpse and then send the alarm. It would be boring, if not that very early in the game the player can access an ability that requires only 1 point to unlock and make the corpses of assassinated enemies disappear into thin air. If you plan on playing stealth it's almost mandatory especially when the option of not using the ability is not possible as the corpses are found regardless of how good you hide them.
Not the end of the world, but I just don't understand why not build on those mechanics but instead almost "disable" them.

CONCLUSION

The game is fun, not perfect, but bought on sale it's absolutely worth it. The microtransactions should not be there, to begin with, in my opinion, but I'm not the only one thinking this way as for these games there are always Inventory Editors and what not to still get those items without paying.
Get it if you're in the mood for a really good story, some beautiful side missions, a nice combat system, and a big world to explore.

6.9/10
Not the best game I ever played, but it's not bad either if you're a fan of open worlds and liked the previous games.

Posted: 18 July, 2020
UPDATE: STILL an awesome game!

NOTE: This is coming from a first time AC Player.

After playing this game for nearly 200 hours and completing almost everything (except some of the tougher achievements) I decided it's finally time to write a review.

THIS. GAME. IS. AWESOME!

Firstly, let me say that the price LOOKS steep but really it's not. Normally the "Ultimate Edition" is $119.99 but that's only if you're crazy enough to buy it off-sale. I paid ~$50 for the Ultimate Edition during a sale which I feel is definitely a fair price for a game that provided me with over two hundred hours of game play.

My favorite parts of this game were exploring the wild, coming across Ancient Greek monuments (that existed in real life!) and legendary creatures to defeat as well as getting the feel for what Ancient Greece was like. That was definitely a pleasure as a history nerd with a particular interest in Ancient Greece/Ancient Rome.

The graphics of this game are extraordinary although you will need a higher end PC to play it at max settings with smooth gameplay. I played on a computer with an 8700K + 2080 Ti and was getting ~85-90 fps with maxed settings @ 1440p.

Some people have complained that the game feels too "grindy", but honestly for me it wasn't a problem at all. I didnt even feel the need to use the "2hr XP BOOST" at any point. If you've ever played World of Warcraft the leveling is much faster than in WoW.

If this is a concern to you I HIGHLY recommend going out of your way and picking up all the fast travel points whenever you can so you can get places quickly and get things done without having to ride your horse all over the map. Sometimes I ended up spending 10 minutes going out of my way to pick up fast travel points but they almost always came in handy when I needed to get back to that point later.

With 204 hours in the game my character (Kassandra) is level 70 and I just started New Game+.

All in all I would give this game 9/10.

The only downside I can think of is that the naval combat wasn't as enjoyable as I thought it would be. It seemed to be mostly luck based and relying on attacking ships only if none of their allied ships were nearby.

Fortunately naval combat is present but it's not a huge part of the game. I just avoided most ships unless I had a quest to attack them.

Sandbreeze

Recommended
75.5 hrs on record
Posted: 27 April, 2020
If AC: Origins and The Witcher 3 had a gay colorful baby this would be it.

Just improves everything that AC:Origins had and picks of pros from the witcher 3 such as intuitive characters with actual depth to their personalities , fortunately this perk exists even in side quests which makes mundane sidequesting a lot more fun given that the game really incentivizes going out of your way and leveling up through side quests like its predecessor Origins did.

Another perk it picks off from Witcher is creating a beautiful scenery , wheras the witcher had a dark mysterious moody theme with heavy fogs and ominous forests with vibrant buildings and cities which made for a very life like environment , Odyssey flips it around to create one of the best most flamboyant and colorful escapade into the Greek world which already inhabits the beautiful Mediterranean pallet. The buildings , the lighting , the vibrance of every area is impactful and most minor cities and towns differ from each other significantly with alot of variety to explore. Coupled with a photo mode with most of the essential sliders is a cinematographs dreams.

Combat wise the game has evolved a lot from AC: Origins fairly mundane skill and static weapon perk system. Skills can be unlocked and upgraded through levelling and adrenaline is used as a fuel to use said ability , with different abilities for all types of playstyles (Melee , Ranged and Stealth) , it really comes closer to the MMORPG type direction that they wanted to take origins in. Abilities actually stand out from each other making them unique and fun to play around with especially when building combo sets for absolutely broken builds which makes combat a breeze if you can plan and execute strategies involving the abilities well.

Static weapon perks still exists but unlike origins , armour in AC: Odyssey actually affects the stats with 5 different armour slots (Helmet, gauntlets, Chest piece, Leggings and waistband). Another system known as engraving has been implemented , this is basically equipment perks such as percentage boost to overall damage or in rarer cases perks which provide significant buffs to certain abilities. Furthermore equipment can be engraved further at a cost from a blacksmith with an engraving of your choice that has been unlocked allowing for much more customization that what AC:Origins provided.

Other pros:
-Actual ship combat from AC: IV Black Flag returns (more on this later)
-HORSIES (Unicorns , Pegasuses , Bulls , Pegacorns ie unicrons x pegasuses etc
-Game incentivises exploration with the cult hunt system which takes you all across the world
-DLC add-ons which are actually worth the cost (Legacy of the first blade and Fate of the atlantis)
-Multiple endings based on your decisions throughout the story
-Alot of things to do even after finishing the main story line , some of which really branch out to integral story parts the game doesnt even force you to do.
-Rewarding sidequests , some of which lead you to important side story objectives such as cultist locations.

Cons:
(P.S I really dont have many , this is one of my favorite games of all time)

Ship combat ! Its back YAY
Actually Edward Kenway would be pretty disappointed , variety of the ships attacks are pretty much non existant this creates a very boring gameplay loop of opening with a ramming attack to do substantial damage, throwing javelins to create weak points , shooting said weak points with arrows for extra damage , and occasionally disabling ships with fire based attacks using the adrenaline bars accumulated from the tedious gameplay loop state before. Furthermore in Episode 2 in the DLC Legacy of the Hidden blade , you get a flamethrower attached to the front of the ship which drains adrenaline to well THROW FLAME.


Premium content and micro-transaction plague: Ubisoft being Ubisoft plagues the store with micro-transactions ranging from snazzy armour sets with fairly unique perk and engraving sets , purely cosmetic ship skins and horses all the way to legendary ship lieutenants with top tier stats and worst of all .... time savers. All of this for premium currency known as Helix credits obtained only by being bought with real money. Time savers passively increase all XP / ingame currency (Drachmae) obtained , some time savers even reveal locations of points of interest across the entire world map.

other minor cons:
- Lazy animations
- Still a lack of melee combo system
- You have to have a very assassin perk centered build to be able to one-shot assassinate even minor enemies in later stages of the game without the use of abilities which cost adrenaline.

Personally i love this game , defo a worth buy along with the DLCs which IMO should just be labelled as continuation of the main story. Id recommend it to anyone who is able to welcome the open world mmorpg world this franchise is heading towards. This has been a huge improvement from AC: Origins a definite 9/10 if not 10/10 in my books.

Good bits:

Stunningly beautiful scenery. The sheer scale of the world you can travel is just phenomenal, all of it above and below sea absolutely beautiful. I will spend hundreds of hours here.
Customizng your equipment is excellent and this system is rich
The movement is phenomenal and intuitive. You jump, climb, drop, get on or off a horse all in a way that is so fluid that I rraely move a way not intended. Fighting mechanics are addicting.
You get to have full scale naval and land battles. Province by province.
The skills systme is good, easy to reset.
The fast travel system is great
Great voice acting

Less good bits:
Some of the forced dialogue is tedious.
You always run out of arrows and rarely have enough resources to replace as much as you'd like. At least you can craft them anyplace.
Besides the beauty, you aren't really rewarded for roaming the endless rocky hills. You will find olive wood and metal, but that's it. It just feels like there should be more resources out in the wilds.

Sometimes to close out a locatino you spend a long time looking for one set of supplies to burn or one loot item, that is a bit un-fun.
The flirty dialogue is a little awkward for me

445 products in account
0
4 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
342.8 hrs on record
Posted: 21 November, 2018
Hi all,

Time to review the latest AC episode!
I have played them all, with some absolute gems along the line (the very first was mind blowing, Black Flag, Origins) and of course some episodes that become very dull very fast. AC Oddessey is in my opinion the best AC game ever created!

As usual there is the main story, a main side line (The cult), a ton of side stories, and an endless stream of short quests, often on a timer. Apart from that there is the greek world to explore as you see fit.
The graphics are fantastic which brings me to one of the coolest addons in this episode: visual armor changes and weapons. The armors are all stunning and each part has it's own appearance. With the latest patch you can now even change the appearance of your armor so you can play with your favorite bonusses on your favorite armor!

This time you play as the grandchild of Leonidas (300) and for the first time you choose gender. Pay attention though: you choose between brother and sister so the other one will play a very important role in the story, additionally, I chose male but the storylines are clearly designed for you to chose the female. Some conversations will always adress you as female so for the optimal experience, you should chose female.
So, not to spoil too much, there is your main story interwoven with a Cult you want dead. You could say it's one story, and not two BUT the fact remains that if you finished the story chances are high not all cultists are dead yet. So after the main story you can continue to hunt them down and finish them.

Ships are back!! Though not as good as Black flagg it's a much simpler and easier version. But it's cool nevertheless, you can upgrade it and enter other ships again. I was excited to see your own ship back in the game and it helps a lot to get rid of mercs ;)

Mercenaries are back again, and this time they add certain value. The best (one of...) legendary armor comes from them. they are divided in tiers now, and you need to climb the ranks one by one. Each tier gives you a serious discount in the shops. They clearly learnt from Shadow of War/Shadow of Mordor here as each merc also has strengths and weaknesses now. As in those games you can adapt and hunt them down.

Athene and Sparta are at war all over the world, and you can (and often must) help one side or the other to conquer the province by joining the batllefield. Literally! it's awesome. If you want, you can even conquer the entire world for one side. Which I did once. Because I didn't like what they did to me in the beginning of the story. Ha!

Con's

-there are still some bugs around, causing crashes and freezes. or quest bugs causing you to restart. Not many more though as the last update annihilated almost all the con's I had written down. They pretty much fixed the few things that where wrong. Well done Ubi.

-Club gear is level 5. As a ubi member you can buy these extra content for their games right? If you didn't know, it's worth it to check as it's always extra content for free. The problem is that it's low level. I didn't know that and got it when I was level 50 (the maximum at that time) only to find that the gear is lvl5, so worthless. However if you get that gear at the start of the game, you'll get a nice advantage!

That's it for con's... I had more but they updated last week and fixed the level cap from 50 to 70 (YESSS), added extra legendary fights (oh I forgot about those, well you'll see if you play :)) and stability.

Pro's


+Magnificent graphics, both in the world as your gear.
+Mercenary system as in Shadow of War.
+No fall damage!!!
+Engraving lets you "craft" your own gear with stats that suit your own playstyle best.
+content is insane. I was lvl 50 and was only halfway the stories. Now they raised the cap to 70 which is perfect.
+levelling is perfectly balanced, not too fast, not too slow. It kind of forces to really roam around and do quests which makes you see the entire world and all content. I did not rush the game and it took me around 300 hours to completely finish it.I'm sure you can rush it and half that time but it shows you the insane amount of content it has.
+no inventory issues
+excellent support from Ubi. They add daily quests, weekly legendary monsters/ships/mercs. Updates that really help and fix things.

Total: 9.5/10
Graphics: 10/10
Difficulty: easy to learn, very hard to master (the higher settings take away quest marks etc!)
Content: 9/10
Price/quality: 8/10 I admit it's expencive. But the game is worth it.
Story: 9/10

Absolutely must buy game! The best in the AC franchise for me, a good combination of shadow of war and Black flag.

Not Recommended
27.4 hrs on record
Posted: 6 October, 2018
Let's start with the obvious: the game is fun, and the story is the mediocre AC style story. Grinding and micro transactions are also part of the game, exactly like SW Battlefront 2; but let's start from the beginning.

Most of the assets has been lifted from Origin; which is neither a good or a bad thing. Performances are mediocre; and considering what you see on screen, and comparing it to other AAA games like the Witcher, runs pretty well. Better than Origin for sure, so that is a win.

The choice between the 2 characters has no meaningful reason to exist. Beside the fact that in Sparta there were no women that would fight or wear armor, and not all the men were stereotype of the caveman; you are left with the same exact story; minus some differences here and there in the dialogues. Even the animations are mostly recycled; which is ridiculous, espoecially if you play as Cassandra and lift a woman in a romance scene, exactly like Alexios did. I was hoping for 2 different point of views and some differences in the story; but forget about it. So play with whatever character you like; they are both obnoxious and caricature of real people.

On the contrary, the other NPC are well done, you care about them and get a connection instantly. Voice over is nicely done, altough the accent seems to disappear at times. I just wonder why don't they just speak English (or allow to pick whatever voiceover track you like), and leave NPC speaking ancient Greek, except when they interact with you. Makes no sense to hear someone from ancinent Greece, speak in English with a Greek accent; but this is what we have.

Gameplay is fun; although, it won't last too long. You have a huge map but the activities to perform are fundamentally variation of the same 4 activities. Like in Origin, if you don't like repetitive gameplay, this won't make you change your mind.
Combat is fun and mostly arcade; once you get few skills that are quite powerful, you will mow tons of adversaries easily. Until you hit the level wall.

Yes, this game has micro transactions; as such; the grind is implemented as form of frustration for the player. It is not a game that has X difficulty, and linear progression, and micro transaction offer you the chance to non-play the game (because some people buy games to finish them ASAP, not to enjoy them, but that's their choice). Here the grind is set on purpose; you can't pass levels beyond 14; without an insane amount of grind, doing over and over the same 4 activities.

But of course, you can buy boosts, to solve the problem; so on top of the 100 bucks to buy the high tier version of the game, you need to pay another 20-40 bucks for boosters; unless you want to spend between 4-10 hours grinding for materials, money and XP to finally pass the wall and finish the last few campaign missions.

Don't get me wrong, the game is fun; but it is fun for a limited amount of time. Then it gets tedious and boring; and unless you live to play these games, and are brainwashed by the current AAA companies that release games made to frustrate players on purpose, to then make extra cash; then you will put the game down once you reach that level wall, and probably won't touch it anymore.

So, for that, I can't recommend this game; but I can say if you get it for 50-60 % off, then get it. Origin like Odissey, is not worth more than 20-30 dollars; unless they start to think that people would gladly buy extras and expansions if the game would let you progress linearly, like it used to be in the times before micro transactions.

Recommended
149.9 hrs on record
Posted: 26 March
Played most AC games in the past three years, and finally got around to playing this one. It was quite a long adventure, but I can say I enjoyed every minute.

The visuals immediately stand out, the game looks wonderful. The cities of Ancient Greece with the giant temples, small streets, and lively squares are amazing, but so are the wild areas, with forests, hills, and valleys and of course the seas, which are once again an integral part of the game. Despite taking place entirely within the Greek cultural sphere, the devs managed to give each region their own character and atmosphere. The colors deserve special mention, the sunsets and mornings are beautiful, especially in rainy weather. Just like in Origins, many times I didnâ€™t use fast travel and instead rode or sailed to my destination, just so I can see the world. The character animations, both of the combat, and the climbing are top-notch, this has always been the strength of this franchise. Iâ€™ll also have to mention our equipment this time: our armor is made up of multiple parts (helmet, chestpiece, etc.), and this combined with the free transmog makes for a massive fashion potential. Itâ€™s pretty unique too, as there arenâ€™t many Greek-fantasy games out there with customizable equipment.

The gameplay is based on Origins, a stealth action hybrid in an open world, with some changes and improvements. The first big change is the save system. The strange objective based checkpoint system that has been the staple of the franchise has been changed to a normal save anywhere method. This was really needed.

Another change is that the rpg aspect has become much more emphasized. There are three main builds, archer, warrior and assassin, and you can build your character by learning and upgrading the appropriate abilities and choosing armor pieces and weapons with stats that support your playstyle. At the beginning of the game, I wasnâ€™t a fan of this, but as I leveled up, got more abilities, I ended up liking it. They really expand your options, both in combat and stealth. As a consequence of this, whether you can one-shot someone with assassination depends on your â€™assassin damageâ€™. However, by using various assassination abilities, you can still get guaranteed kills on stronger enemies. So what was one button press in the previous games, now has gameplay added to it, which I ended up really liking.

The combat is simple, you have dodge, parry, light and heavy attack, but the various combat related abilities spice it up. It is more fluid that in Origins. As usual, there are a few bossfights and various situations where you have to fight, but the core gameplay is still â€™sneak into a fort, take down guards and loot stuffâ€™ which, for me, just never gets old. Stealth works well and itâ€™s fun. By the way, we now have the ability to do non-lethal takedowns, both as assassination and in combat, but this didnâ€™t feel developed enough. It only matters in specific quests, but there are situations where the game should account for it, but it doesnâ€™t.

The ship related gameplay is fully developed here. As with the rpg system itself, this had a rough start, but once I upgraded my ship and got legendary lieutenants, I started to enjoy it. Had fun with the sea battles, but just sailing was also enjoyable. Thatâ€™s quite something, considering that I wasnâ€™t a fan of Black Flag. Sea shanties return, this time we have Greek ones. I loved them.

The mercenary system is also worth mentioning. If you get caught committing crimes, you get a bounty on your head, and mercenaries start to hunt you. They always know roughly where you are and can complicate your life and get you into unpredictable scenarios, which I actually liked. You especially have to be careful in cities, since getting into fights there can end up involving guards and civilians, which can lead to more bounty and more mercs hunting you. The aggression of the civilians is an annoying addition though. I appreciate that it encourages you to be careful in cities, but having some random peasant attack you after you just annihilated a squad of guards is just absurd. The mercenaries, the player character included, are part of a hierarchy. If you take some out, you gain rank, which gives you various bonuses, so itâ€™s worth it to actually hunt them.

The game takes place during the Peloponnesian wars, the main character being a mercenary who sets out to find their family and to confront the secret organization which is hunting them. Of course, this is an oversimplification, as the story is quite complex and layered. I found it interesting and gripping, with memorable characters, including the main character (Kassandra for me), who became one of my favorites in the franchise. Her voice actor did a great job. Despite having serious, dramatic moments, I felt that the game is more lighthearted, has more humor than the others, which suited it really well.

Big difference compared to earlier games, it that now we can choose our response during dialogues, and in many cases this has major consequences on how the story plays out. I also liked that there are situations where a character tells you something that you have to remember in a subsequent dialogue.

Apart from the main quests relating to the main story, there are side quests, often forming secondary storylines, memorable episodes, that help flesh out the world. A bunch of historical people (Socrates, Herodotos, etc.) are also part of the story. They are a bit caricaturistic, but fun additions.

All in all, this game was a fantastic experience, and an epic journey (â€™epicâ€™ is really a fitting way to describe a game called â€™Odysseyâ€™). One of the best games in the franchise.

Recommended
52.9 hrs on record
Posted: 14 February
The way-too-long Greek experience
World
Assassins Creed Odyssey has one of the largest and most beautiful worlds of any game I have ever played. The colour and vibrancy of Ancient Greece is really breathtaking. Each river looks clear and pure, and the pale limestone cliffs look like they were carved by the gods. I can tell you that every screenshot you take of this world will be wallpaper worthy, its amazing. There are loads of small, mystical islands for you to discover, vast caves to explore, and temples to admire.

Scale of open world
Herein lies my first issue with the game - the world is simply too big. I know that sounds like an odd critique, after all, everyone wants a big open world. However, in my experience there are simply too many places to visit on the map to possibly see them all in a reasonable amount of time. The sheer scale of the world also lacks depth, as I felt a lot of the world was padded with lots of hideouts and forts to just make the world look fuller. For me, if the world was a bit smaller, but had more interesting places and people to meet, in off the beaten path areas, it would feel more alive and realistic.

Gameplay
The gameplay in Odyssey is a mixed bag. The core combat system is quite simplistic and easy, but the abilities that you unlock as you progress can make it more varied and enjoyable. The parkour element of the game really let me down. Ancient Greece is not a great setting for an Assassins Creed game, simply because it was such a rural society. Perhaps if it focused on a specific city like Athens it could have worked. The lack of connected buildings in the world means you will be doing very little parkour, and a lot of horse riding from point A to point B.

Story
The main questline for the first 10-20 hours of gameplay is quite compelling. You feel driven and you really have a sense of purpose. The further into the game you get though, and the more side questlines open up, you really lose this purpose. The story gets quite boring, and a lot of the side missions are poorly designed too. Admittedly, I did really enjoy tracking down and killing the mythical beasts and monsters. I thought those missions were more fun and exciting than delivering random letters to people whose name you can't remember. The quests in the game just seem to be never-ending, and the story just drags on way too long without any emotional attachment.

History
The historical value of this game should not be disregarded either. If you can look past the usual weird Assassins Creed elements (a man requiring 5,000 stab wounds to die), you will find a really educational experience. If you are in any way interested in Ancient Greek history, I can assure you that this game will not disappoint. There are many real world places in the game, recreated amazingly, such as the Parthenon, the Athenian Acropolis, and the Oracle of Delphi. There's even a specific mode just for sightseeing and learning about all these places, which is a nice touch.

Conclusion
You'll notice despite a lot of negative aspects of the game that I have still recommended it. I think that if you can pick this game up cheap enough on sale give it a go, I would especially recommend it if you are interested in the time period, or if you just love nature. Although it's not one of my favourites, it is still a worth while experience that I enjoyed.
