Not Recommended
180.7 hrs on record
Posted: 28 October, 2021
Let's start from the fact that it is a Ubisoft game and as we all know, they are "copy and paste" of previous chapters, not free from bugs and badly optimized code.
That said, it's not all to be thrown away, quite the opposite. The story, as always, is compelling and interesting. It lets us know how the facts happened in those years, obviously adding a little imagination to make it more exciting, but basically it doesn't distort the facts very much. And this is a plus because you learn by playing.

Why a bad review? Don't I have to buy it?
First of all, I immediately say that this is subjective and depends on the price. As I said before, the story changes but the game mechanics are always the same recycled from previous chapters (naval combats taken from Black Flag; You can remove the HUD and missions bookmarks as in Ghost Recon; etc ...), so paying 60â‚¬ seems to me like a theft. In fact, I waited for the discounts and took both Origins and Odyssey including all the DLCs for just over 40â‚¬, and let's say this is the right price until Ubisoft brings something new, but really new.
So, to answer the previous question, yes, you have to buy it, but not at full price and don't expect different mechanics from the previous chapters.

PROs
Graphically better than the previous ones and with the largest map ever.
Also in this chapter there are guided tours that teach us the past history, wonderful! But unfortunately the PROs end here.

MIDs
Horses are not that great, either with manual or automatic "driving". You can easily get stuck anywhere and if there is a small boulder to climb, they start to turn on themselves making the journey much longer than it would be if you went on foot. In fact, they are so useless that 90% of the game (look at my hours) I walked.
Throughout the game map there are 2 factions (the Peloponnesian War) Sparta and Athens. These continue to wage war in each region and it is common for regions to switch factions several times during the gameplay. Don't dare to side with only one faction is useless. A few hours later or after loading the save, you will have all regions controlled again randomly. (Anyway, side with Athens! I know that Sparta had a movie, glory, 300 men against the Persians, etc. But they were just a belligerent faction, always resolving everything with war, while Athens has always been more diplomatic and inclined to culture and democracy. In fact, today Athens is bigger and more famous than Sparta). 

CONs
The classic and old leap of faith is useless. Because despite falling from inhuman heights, the character does not die, he simply resets his life to 0 but will be cured immediately afterwards. After level 5-10 there is no more fall damage, under any circumstances. So it no longer makes sense to throw yourself into the haystacks. These have also been revised and finally fixed. Remember the old days when you ran away from an enemy and the character, instead of running away, walked into the haystacks? Here, this has been solved! Well done Ubisoft! Long last! But how was it solved? Simple, you can no longer enter in them. Only with the leap of faith (useless) but once you go out you cannot enter them again.
Due to the countless amount of game objects, such as buckets, torches, tables, chairs, stalls, etc ... escaping from enemies will be like playing Pinball, that is, running and getting stuck between various objects.
As with Origins, assassinating a higher level enemy to death is impossible. We will only do him maximum damage for the "assassin" class. Enhanced assassination can be unlocked later, but this is used by holding down a key until it charges and many, many, many times the enemy will move while you are charging, causing you to be discovered or forcing you to charge again. Especially if you don't have the ability to slow down time as soon as you are discovered. Annoying!
Mercenaries! A nice addition (also copied from Middle-earth: Shadow of War) but which is really annoying because in case you have a bounty on your head, the mercenaries will keep coming indefinitely. Often in the least opportune moments, causing only the increase of the bounty itself and consequently the arrival of more mercenaries.
It does not end here! This feature is really bad because if you kill someone in the presence of another person, the bounty will increase even if you then kill the witness. It doesn't make sense, the witness didn't tell anyone about my murder! (as happen in Red Dead Redemption 2). To conclude with the mercenaries, the icing on the cake is that as soon as you have a bounty on your head, one or more mercenaries will "appear" nearby you. Even if you are in the middle of the woods on an isolated mountain. If you run away (with fast travel) the mercenaries will always follow you, as if you have a GPS tracker. Example: You have killed people and now you have the bounty, a mercenary appears a few meters away from you, run away and take a fast travel 8 km away, silently enter an enemy camp, kill an enemy WITHOUT BEING NOTICED, and here is the mercenary comes running into that camp and starts walking around there waiting for you to make a false step. But why? Nobody saw me, how does he know that I'm here?
Finally, worst CON of all, I have an Intel i9 10900k fixed at 4.9GHz; GPU MSI RTX 2060 Ventus; 32 GB DDR4 RAM; Game inside an SSD Samsung 850 Evo; but the game, in the presence of many NPCs, has a frame drop from to 50-45!! While the CPU is used at 20% and the GPU at 60% (with ultra graphics). The same problem also occurs with graphics at a minimum and 800x600. After several researches and support tickets it turned out to be a game engine bug, incompatible with high-core CPUs. In fact, by installing the game on another PC with i7 6700k CPU (2016); same GPU; SSD; etc ... the game does not have frame drops, but the CPU is used over 50% with all cores active. While on my i9 10900k only 6 cores out of 10 are used and there is no possibility to force the use of all 10, making the game unstable in the presence of many NPCs where everyone has a scrip to run. Such as walking, shopping, talking, playing, dancing, etc...

Basically, it's not the best of the Assassin's Creed chapters, but it's not the worst either (Rogue I'm talking about you). Personally, if I had to choose, I prefer Origins, graphically simpler but with far fewer bugs and above all the story involves more. In Odyssey, everything seems to be there "just for play" and you have that constant feeling of not being involved in the story. And this, in my opinion, is the worst thing in a videogame, not being attracted to it, to the story, to the narrative ...

81.9 hrs on record
Posted: 17 July, 2021
AC:Odyssey is a simplified third person action RPG with typical AC mechanics. I do not consider it a full RPG as it lacks some depth but it is not as rigid and limited as previous games from the AC franchise were. I stopped all AC games I played before at some point because I felt too limited to what I can do and it always got boring at some point. I always felt sad about it since I really like what AC generally has to offer. Odyssey significantly increased in that point by including more traditional RPG elements. But it also makes use of the typically top class AC presentation. The character animations and the freedom of movement are perfect as usual. Also the integration of Greek mythology and the appearance of historical figures in the story (but please don't mention Alexios, the misthios, in your next history class) into an almost perfect world are very well made as for all AC games I played before. The world looks so nice, truly believable.

What I like most is that AC: Odyssey allows for multiple playstyles. I personally prefer the exploring playstyle. I like to walk around discover everything (and there are many points of interest, literally everywhere) and occasionally do some quests or follow the story. This playstyle is perfectly viable; I was really surprised to see that. Exploration gives you enough experience to level at a decent speed to easily keep up with difficulty of new areas or the main story.

If you are not into that, the game offers a lot of (smaller) side missions (in the form of boards or NPCs in the cities. Also, player created content and in the form of stories or (daily) challenges can be accessed from everywhere. So if you donâ€™t like exploration and would rather level by doing quests, that is also possible.
I consider it more an RPG â€˜lightâ€™ than a real RPG. The quests are pretty linear and I am not sure I have seen real choices so far. It also still has a ton of action and assassinations. It is still a game of the AC franchise, do not forget that. At first sight, AC:Odyssey offers a huge amount of weapons and armor (and also of different quality). However, there are no different armor types and all weapons of the same level have the same DPS so you should rather focus on the extra benefits coming from these. They all look different, though, when equipped. A nice feature is that you can upgrade them to keep using them when you levelled up.

AC:Odyssey has a few draw backs as well, only minor ones, though. I cannot really understand the sheer amount of brutality the AC games always require. Yes, you are a misthios (mercenary) but is it really necessary to brainlessly to kill every single being that crosses your path? The main character seems to be a nice person, you can see that in the dialogues. I seriously doubt this man/woman would really be such a ruthless murderer. You can take over a region and just start killing the people you helped conquering the regionâ€¦

Secondly, I do not really like the shipping part of the game. I understand, Greece is a country with many islands but for me it does not fit into the game. I prefer going everywhere on foot and try to avoid the ship as much as possible. It also plays heavily like an arcade game and feels very unrealistic.

So if you like third person open-world RPGs and typical AC mechanics but also Greek mythology, AC:Odyssey is definitely a recommendation!

From quests and side missions to mercenery and cultists hunts, exploration and sea battles - all of which is simply good. But as of now, i'm done. I do recommend Odyssey at discounted price as it offers dozens of hours of fun, amazing scenery (especially Elysium), and decent enough challenge on higher difficulties, but still tires you out and makes the game feel like work.

I've never given AC series a proper go, until Origins, which i actually prefer over Odyssey, and after beating these two games, i do want to check the back catalogue of the series, even if my order is all messed up.

Hope Valhalla loses all the bloat, but retains and improves upon all the interesting aspects.

I cannot say I wasted my time with AC Odyssey and its addons but I surely feel like Ubisoft didn't respect my time.

The world is beautiful, one of the big strengths of all Ubisoft games but I swear, if I have to climb one more tower, clear one more generic cave/camp/outpost/stronghold or hear the cry of the eagle one more time while diving in a haystack I'm going to lose it.

I hope Gods&Monsters not only copies the Breath of the Wild artstyle but its open world design as well.

Combat is fun at first but becomes business as usual if you are going to spend as much time with the game as I did.

Story is not worth talking about, side quests and part of the main quest can be good fun from time to time though.

Graphics and sound/voice are superb.

If you are going to play one modern AC part, which I think is enough, I would highly recommend playing AC Origins instead. The Egyptian/desert setting is more refreshing and the main character(s) more interesting and likeable.

And I'd recommend to enjoy the game and the world in episodes. If you got enough just put the game aside and come back a few days/weeks/months later and enjoy the game again.

Recommended
56.2 hrs on record
Posted: 26 April, 2020
AC:O is the latest in the Assassin's Creed franchise that's of a totally different style as compared to the older AC titles. With this, there's a greater focus on a larger open-world exploration RPG similar to how Witcher 3 is played, with a map spanning a great expanse along with multiple side quests, as well as multiple similar mechanics.There's an effort in making the world feel alive such as through patrolling guards, as well as a bounty hunter mechanic where you rise through the ranks, similar to the one found in Shadow of Mordor.

The main campaign here is just good enough to keep you going and has some decent surprises packed into it, with different major overarching narratives. The majority of side quests had some flair added to them, similar to the ones found in Witcher 3, and were often worth doing. However, some of these got repetitive after a while so don't expect them to be the best.

Overall, the game is extremely beautiful and well optimized, while loading screens were minimal and well hidden, with proper loading often only had when you quick travel. The game's definitely worth a play but get it while it's on sale, perhaps not at full price.

Recommended
111.0 hrs on record
Posted: 22 February, 2020
Diary: Assassin's Creed Odyessey

Day 1 - 2/16/2020
It looked like an "assassin game" where you are a character that could have been from the movie 300, so I was like, why not. The game right out of the gate made me feel awesome since you get to play as Leonidas right away. The leader of the Spartans wrecking your enemies in huge numbers with powerful abilities. This provided a nice taste of what end game character would feel like and, at the same time, let me enjoy some of the skills offered in the game.

Once I picked my character, I was off on my wild adventures, of just doing random side missions for people on the island, and having fun messing around. I like how they mapped out this game. It looks like there is plenty of islands to explore. The game seems dang nice, I must say.

The eagle is my best friend. He swoops down and murders animals for me. He scouts areas for treasure, enemies, and collectibles. The eagle is so dope to use, and I enjoy seeing how he does infinity more damage than me when he randomly swoops down and kills an animal.

The horse makes going from point A to point B simple and easy. You can relax, sit back, and have a sweet little snack while you wait to reach the destination point. I was just chilling, talking to my friends while I was expecting to do a quest on the other side of the island.

Some of the choices in the game are pretty rough when it comes to how you want to handle a quest. For example, there was a sick family that the doctors didn't know how to cure and wanted to execute to prevent the sickness from spreading. I had to choose between letting them kill the family or siding with them to save the rest of the island. The choices in this game are not so clear cut, which makes choices more meaningful as a result

I like how when a plot twist was revealed as I was leaving the first island, even the music was like "OH OH OH OH" I thought it was rather a comical moment, Like what the heck game, how am I suppose to take you seriously, with timing like that you should be on a comedy show!

Day 2 - 2/18/2020
It's time to be a captain. Son of a gun, I fought a lot of boats. Today, I didn't even bother to go to any islands. I just wanted to keep rampaging across the sea and attack random boat weather they were a faction or a trade boat, it didn't matter. I'm stealing all that loot to craft my arrows, upgrade my equipment, and make my ship even stronger. Stealing captains off other ships is also a fun way to increase the strength of your crew.

Day 3 - 2/21/2020
Today, I learned how to wage war against the other factions. It was pretty nice that I could pick what side I wanted to fight for and cause chaos until they were vulnerable enough to go into a huge battle royale match, destroying several of their captains until they lost. It also gives you nice rewards, etc. There is always that nice benefit too!

Recommended
89.9 hrs on record
Posted: 16 July, 2019
This is a review of the latest Assasins Creed game, Assasins Creed: Odyssey.

Intro:

Assasins Creed: Odyssey, was released October 5, 2018. It is the next game after Assasins Creed; Origins, which came with a new combat system, and a new way to treat the Assasins Creed series.

Gameplay:

The game mechanics have improved a lot from Assasins Creed: Origins, which, with its new combat system, completely changed the way you play Assasins Creed. The game captures the beauty of the new combat system, combined with the naval combat system from Black Flag (in which they definitely hit the sweet spot on this game). The RPG elements in it with levels and gear also makes it a bit of a grind, which i love. Because you just can't go into any mission and expect to beat if, because you now can be 10 levels under the recommended level, and you WILL die!

And if you're worried about having nothing to do in this game, do not worry, this game got you covered. As seen i got around 60 hours in game. In this time i only have completed what the game has to offer for main story quests. There is still a lot of side missions, and also DLC's (if you got those). All in all the game has a lot too offer in content, and the game does well to make you interested all the way through. Even though that after ending the main story line the travelling becomes tedious. But just remember to do the synchronisation, then the travel part is not so bad. (You normally get all around with the main storyline, so don't worry)

Pros
- A lot to do
- Combat system and naval battle
- Big map
- Great characters and story

Cons:
- Travelling becomes tedious after doing main story line
- Sad because of doing wrong decisions! :(

Conclusion:

Great game, and would recommend buying it. Sadly steam sale ended, but would still recommend it for it's asking price before steam sale.

Ñ hiteÑ olf
1,792 products in account
0
3 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
218.7 hrs on record
Posted: 31 May, 2019
This is the first Assassin's Creed game I've played since Revelations came out way, way back. I know, I've probably missed out on some gems that came after, but I am particularly interested in the Ancient Greek setting so when this one was announced I was keen to try it out. Now that I have, I can safely say that it is quickly getting a spot in my Top 10 games, and there's some fierce competition in there.

I'm way out of touch with the modern-day side of the story, so I'm glad that doesn't play a major role in Odyssey. (And when it does it's like watching paint dry, so no big loss.) Otherwise the game world, which encompasses most of Ancient Greece, is incredible and well worth exploring. Sailing the Aegean on the Adrestia, your very own Trireme, is amazing and the ship combat is excellent. Nothing is more fun than ramming a ship and cleaving it in two, or boarding and Spartan Kicking the captain over the side! xD There's never a shortage of things to find at sea or on land, which for someone like me who enjoys the exploration and discovery side of games is a big plus. You can dive down to find shipwrecks and sunken temples, fending off sharks and finding treasure, as well as explore caves and ruins on land. Everything feels meticulously detailed with stunning visuals; I even saw a little frog hopping around on some rocks in a village, and little things like that make the world come to life. Some of the caves feel like they have been marginally recycled, but it's not enough to be a big distraction.

Odyssey (as its name suggests), offers you unlimited freedom in how and where you let your adventure unfold. Fine, there are certain regions that may be too high level when you first start out, but nothing is stopping you from going there. In a sense, this is good; you have to be more careful in these areas, using stealth to get around or simply not causing any trouble whilst you are there. I also love how the whole world is interconnected like a giant web: you can do a side quest somewhere and discover new locations which lead you to new characters and new quests. For example, I went to the island of Euboea with the simple intentions of killing a cultist. I did so, then went to the nearest city, Chalkis, to sell some of my gear and upgrade what I was using. There I started a side quest where you have to help this slave and his master put an end to a crime ring called The Dagger. Whilst investigating, I ended up having a big bounty placed on me which meant I had three mercenaries looking for me. As I was completing one of my investigations, the three of them found me and ganged up on me (interesting really, as I think they find you by tracking your last movements, rather than they automatically know where you are.) An epic battle ensued in the ruins of Eretria, with me killing all three mercenaries and a pet lion that was tagging along with one of them. By then I was pissed at still having such a high bounty on me. I finished up the side quest and went to my map to see who the sponsor for my bounty actually was. (That's how bounties work in this game - there is someone in the world, a tangible character, who has put the bounty out on you and can either be paid off or killed to remove it.) Turns out the sponsor was the leader of the Abantis Islands, a Spartan warrior who I had considered having as a Lieutenant on my ship because of the bonuses he gave. I was a little sad because I couldn't afford to pay off the bounty what with upgrading my gear earlier (drachmae is easy to get in the game but quickly disappears when you have stuff to improve, like your gear and the ship), so I resigned myself to saying goodbye to him by ending his life. One assassination later, and I'm amazed to find that this guy was a member of the cult I was hunting, and that by killing him I am one step closer to unveiling more members that need assassinating. Two birds: one stone. Hard to think that I wanted him on my crew and then he turns out to be one of the evil ones. Skylax the Fair my arse! xD Still, this shows just how intricate this game is and how unexpected twists like this make it all the more enjoyable to play.

I've seen reviews that say the voice acting is bad - in some cases, yes, it can be. But I think most of it is more funny than anything else. Some lines are recycled for bounty quests where you have to go to X location and kill X number of people/creatures, but there are so many of these that it's to be expected. At least the actual side quests and main story have original dialogue. As for complaints of the game being grindy, I have had no such experience, possibly because I play games slowly and like to do as much as possible in one place before moving on. If you rush through the story, not bothering to do side quests and explore, then yes I can imagine the game will become grindy because you haven't levelled up enough. However, if you play the game as it is intended to be played, by taking your time and immersing yourself in the world and its characters, you will find your experience all the more satisfying. My only gripe is that combat becomes a heck of a lot easier when you've reached higher levels. I'm level 23 and facing opponents of similar level and finding that I can cut them down no problem. Fine, I may have got used to the controls but I found it much more challenging at the start of the game whilst still on Kephallonia. Regardless, combat is fun and the abilities you can unlock extremely satisfying to use (Spartan Kick being, of course, my favourite and probably the most famous one in the game.)

The mercenaries system is also very good - you can move up tiers as you defeat other mercenaries who roam about the world as you do. All are unique, reminding me very much of Shadow of Mordor where all the Orc Warlords you could face were different every time. They all have their strengths and weaknesses, some have animal companions that help them fight, and defeating them usually lands you some decent gear, particularly parts of legendary sets which offer you massive bonuses when you wear the entire set.

All in all, I am very impressed with this game and can see myself playing it for 100+ hours. I will definitely be purchasing the Season Pass when it comes on sale again as I have heard good things about the expansions. Well done Ubisoft for releasing a very, very good Assassin's Creed game - possibly my favourite since ACII!

Overall, nothing new or original but very solid and entertaining game with good amount of content.

Some quick comments:
-The environment is fantastic - this can be the sole reason to play the game! You walk in the ancient Athens etc - awesome (as good as in Witcher 3);

-Playing on "hard" is challenging enough to use my brain, until I get most of my abilities.
My point: you can customise the game and fights you have as challenging as you want to by simply not picking too strong abilities.
Therefore, I purposely opted out from "bazooka/machine-bow" hunter tree abilities to increase the assassin feeling. I also tend to leave out all AoE stuns and explosions (even in combat tree) as they tend to be just a combat deux ex machinas ruining all the fun.

-Characters and story - well... it is a combat driven game with RPG addons, so as usual - "meh" or just ok; Quests are not challenging and conversation options often surprisingly not in line with what I thought I was choosing. Also, my choices do not seem to have big impact on the story. It is a poor illusion of choice. The challenge comes mostly from fights (mechanics) with "bosses" (e.g. epic beasts, mercenaries or cult members);

-Get used to throwing away legendary equipment due to fast leveling - feels like leveling up a character from WoW, just leave everything behind after playing with it for 5 minutes as it is too expensive (laborious) to keep upgrading it;

-Horse riding sucks and I prefer to run;

-There are battles: they are fun to play BUT they remind more gladiator fights than the actual Greek battles (no formations, to phalanx, no tactic, just "Black Flag ships boarding" fight);

- Naval battles - very similar to what was in the Black Flag, although it is hilarious to see how those triremes speed and navigate like motorboats...

Ive loved Assassins Creed franchise from the very first game. Almost obseesively so. But even a fanboy like me couldnt deny the series was getting stale by the time Syndicate came around. It was a good game, but it was more of the same one too many times.

I wholeheartedly feel the shift of Origins to a more RPG-ish game and the eventual release of Odyssey as a full blown RPG was exactly what the series needed.

They've done so much right with this game. The gameplay is top notch. Exploration is fun as all hell. Combat (which has always been a weak point of the series till origins) is now even better, and for a change they put some focus on modern day story and first civilisation story. Its no Ezio trilogy in the lore department, but its not like the games after AC3 where modern day/first civilisation lore was all but abandoned.

Suffice to say, this game was a dream come true.

If i had to complain about one thing, it'd be that the game is too big for its own good. If a couple islands and some area like phokis/lokris didnt exist, it wouldnt take anything away from the game, and infact would make the game look NOT bloated. Bigger isnt always better. And im not saying make a small map and pack it better. The packing of stuff to do is PERFECT. Just making it smaller will mean less forts (so every fort you clear has more meaning) and less caves (again, since caves arent a dime a dozen every cave you clear makes you feel accomplished), you can only feel good about cleaning some fort or cave or camp so many times before the diminishing returns begin to creep in.

apart from this small thing. I love this game and would recommend it to everyone i know.

If you don't mind playing a refurbished AC: Origins mechanics, then this game is for you. The gameplay is almost identical to that of AC: Origins, meaning it's more RPG and Witcher 3 rip off than an AC game as we knew them before Origins. So, past this dillema, we are left with an absolutely amazing setting set in Ancient Greece during the Peloponese War, aka 490BC. Since in Origins we witnessed the birth of the Assassin Order, in this game, since it's already a couple of centuries before those events, we have some sort of prequel to the birth of either the templar order and the assassins. Becuase of that it doesn't feel very Assassin's Creed. Enough said about that, get the game if you want to know more.

Now... as for the graphics and the world, it's amazing and the pictures don't do it enough credit. You have to play to actually understand how awesome it is. You get to travel to various parts of Ancient Greece, including lots of islands. I myself have visited several of those places, actually the majority and the experience was even better. I could navigate around the world without using the map most of the time due to my knowledge of the geography lol.

You also get to sail with a Trireme kind of ship equiped with bows, javelins and fire. Quite great sea battles but not as good as Black Flag's.

Something that would require the attention of the design team, especially those in charge of the Ancient Greek, is the words "pater" and "mater". People, these two words are latin, the actual Ancient Greek are "Ï€Î±Ï„á½´Ï (patir)" and "Î¼á½µÏ„Î·Ï (mitir)". It felt a bit out of place hearing them. I won't comment on the history misinformation since this is a fantasy game and it has the appropriate warning in the beginning. Enjoyable nevertheless.

Last, but not least, you get to fight actual mythical monsters!! Hell yeah (see? more fantasy than a typical AC game)!

Oh and it's quite huge; actually the biggest map in a game ever. However the map could use a bit more attention from the team, for example the island of Delos... is actually really tiny compared to Mykonos :)

Recommended
132.6 hrs on record
Posted: 18 December, 2018
Figured that after sinking 100+ hours into this game and completing the Odyssey storyline, hunting down the entire Cult of Kosmos and before starting the DLC, it was time for me to write a review.

As a massive fan of the Assassin's Creed franchise, I was sceptical about this game, as I previously was with Origins. The move away from the default game and moving towards an RPG based game was not what I expected, but I'm glad they did. The storyline is strong, being able to play as both Alexios and Kassandra allows you to make difficult choices that heavily impact the ending(s) of the game.

Your Odyssey

The story places you as being a Misthios of Kephallonia, with the main goal of reuniting his/her family. There are multiple main storylines that you can pursue throughout the game, one being your Odyssey, and the other to hunt all of the Cult of Kosmos members - those who split your family apart.

Pros

Over a good 80 hours of gameplay - including the main storyline along with many sidequests to get distracted by.
Graphics are amazing - Photo Mode allows for some stunning photos to be taken.
Unlike some previous games in the series, game easily runs at 60fps with smooth gameplay.
Naval Battles - one of the many things I loved about Black Flag was being able to engage in smooth naval battles, being able to customise your ship throughout the game, and this game adds to the love of being able to island hop, engage in many naval battles, and just sail the seas to your heart's content.
Being able to call your ship no matter the Dock can be massively useful, if you've been off exploring an island or city.

Cons

One problem, which is the same I faced in Origins, that the wait time after Fast Travelling can take ages, whist either being left on the hint screen, or just the entire screen being blank.
Sometimes, the voice acting can just seem to drag, especially with the side quests where it seems like some characters have been talking for ages. This isn't really a massive problem as it usually explains where certain quest items are which is always a positive.

Season Pass

Considering I never usually purchase a Season Pass, I was surprised when Odyssey's ended up in my basket. I enjoyed this game so much, I didn't want to stop playing.
The Season Pass is going to include two DLC stories, spanning a total of six episodes, as well as including remastered editions of both Assassin's Creed III and Liberation, so for the price tag, is definitely worth it.

Overall, highly recommend this game to anyone who is either a fan of the Assassin's Creed franchise, or anyone interested in a good RPG.

Not Recommended
319.7 hrs on record
Posted: 22 November, 2018
the more i played this game, the more i realised just how empty the open world is, and how heartless the characters feel. Every NPC has a forgettable face and every quest is just a fruitless box-ticking exercise. Characters are not memorable and feel copy and pasted into the copy and pasted cities. The only unique - feeling city is Athens, and even that, being the largest city in the game, what should be a bustling hub of life feels dead and empty
You can trod for ages i the open world and find nothing but repetitive caves and outposts, where you can find about 5 variations of damage sponges, or "guards" as the game refers to them
RPG mechanics are misused, and leveling up feels like a constant grind to nowhere. Not being able to assassinate a simple guard who is the same level as me in one hit is a ridiculous flaw in the gameplay mechanics
Dialogue options are ultimately meaningless and just an attempt to be like The Witcher 3. Your actions have no effect on the game world or characters, both of which suffer from a significant lack of depth. As mentioned before, the game world feels 2 dimentional, and characters are without soul. This could be from the lack of chatter in cities, simplistic animation routines or the limited diversity in character models.
The superpowers are a pisstake on the first civilisation aspects of the franchise's lore, and reguardless of your character's demigod status, enemies are still damage sponges. This, on top of the lacking open world and characters completely destroys and hope of immersion.
On the plus side, the game's engine provides stunning visuals and the landscape / environment team did a fantastic job recreating ancient Greece in its entirety, even if the content within it is severely lacking depth.
Kassandra / Alexios's running animation feels sort of stiff and rigid, further deducting from immersion
It was clear from the beginning that this would fail to be a good assassin's creed game, with it being set roughly 400 years before the founding of the Brotherhood, but unfortunately this game fails to be a good RPG game as well.
Don't get me started on the DLC.

Recommended
140.1 hrs on record
Posted: 7 October, 2018
Love it so far. Very happy with the direction UBI are taking the franchise.

Performance is pretty bad if you're trying to run on Very High/Ultra High. To be honest there really is no need.

With some tweaking and a mixture of Medium/High/Very High (Volumetric clouds on medium) I get 55-90fps (55 being the minimum) at 3440x1440 (100hz G-Sync) with a 1080ti. It looks stunning.

Certain settings such as Character Detail and Environment Detail and even AO and AA (at higher resolutions) have very little visual different from Very High - Ultra High or High - Very High but have a significant performance hit... especially to your minimum FPS.

Volumetric clouds also have a major impact on FPS.

Dropping clouds to Medium, Character and Environment to Very High and Shadows to High took my minimum FPS from sub 30 to 55, increased my maximum a little and my average was 70ish FPS.

Comparing Screenshots at these settings to all out Ultra showed very little difference. Certainly not enough to worry about.

Recommended
396.9 hrs on record
Posted: 5 October, 2018
(First Impressions review.. will update later)
I would say that AC is now very close to regaining its long lost crown after the AC 2.. This game as many of u have heard is MASSIVE.. am abt 50 hrs in and I have only done abt 10% of the game.. Which doesnt mean that the game is too grindy.. I'd say that it will feel lyk it only if u r a type of person who'd jump from main quest to main quest w/o bothering abt anything this game has to offer.. In my 50 hrs I have never felt the need to increase my lvl through grind jst to catch up with the main quest as I was doin every side quest (some of which are in a way related to main quests) and felt that leveling works more organically..

A huge improvement in the side content department.. They have interesting stories, characters and on top of that player choices adds a bit more fun to reel you in.. Other than the side quests per se there are other side contents that plays in tandem such as the mercenary system (an updated form of the Phylakitais in Origins) feels reminiscent of the Nemesis system in Shadow of war.. They show up in strange places at tyms where u dnt xpect for eg in Conquest battles (another side content) that makes the player on their toes whenever they are hunting u.. U can choose to hunt them as well for high lvl gear.. There are other interesting features (one of the best really) which I dont want to spoil.. A quick note : use exploration mode and u will thank me..

I felt lyk the whole Conquest system feels pointless.. U jst do it to gain rewards but it doesnt really change anything as u can repeat the whole battle over and over again in a region.. The battle itself feels shallow.. After one or two battles it might get a bit boring.. I chose to avoid it if I can..

Combat is more fast paced than Origins.. The whole abilities system would make way to create builds.. Parry and dodge or easier and they are essential.. No more button smashing.. The abilities add an interesting layer to keep every enemy encounter unique.. Nothing is more satisfying than kicking high lvl enemies off the cliff and watch them utter their last growl.. Varied enemy types including beasts require different strategy to effectively finish them off.. Legendary beasts and ships are a treat..

Naval battle is reminiscent of black flag although not as fun as black flag.. The ship controls feels a bit sturdy than the Jackdaw.. Other than that its still the same.. They could have included some junk loots on ships which we could have sold via message board as it was in black flag.. Customisation is limited.. But the lieutenant feature makes up for it..

Roundup
Pros:
Graphics
Story
Characters
Choices (and their impacts)
Side contents (especially the one which I cant spoil)
Exploration
Combat
Naval

Cons:
FPS drops in certain cities like Athens (regains after a few minutes)
Conquest systems are a bit shallow, repetitive and has no impact
In a big rpg world full of characters there is no ingame Glossary/Database
Microtransactions (avoidable but have to mention it)
The new loot box merchant is worse than the Heka chest system
Weird walking animation for Kassandra

Kuno
33 products in account
0
6 people found this review helpful 0

Recommended
165.7 hrs on record
Posted: 3 August, 2020
Pros:
-Vast and detailed open-world. It's huge.
-Beautiful graphics and environments.
-Story that starts out simple, but gets really good later on.
-In-depth RPG elements to build your character and control their stats.
-Interesting and engaging combat that never gets stale, and allows many different play styles.
-Ship to ship combat as good as Blag Flag.
-A progression system that makes it so you always have multiple tasks at hand.
-Dialogue choices will affect the world and characters.

Cons (minor things):
-Voice acting is meh. Probably because there is an absurd amount of dialogue in this game.
-While to world is very authentic to ancient Greece, the story has some fantastical/sci-fi elements that some people may find breaks the immersion.
-PC optimization could be better
-On nightmare difficulty enemies sometimes feel like damage sponges,
-The prices of ship upgrades are a bit much
-Microtransactions. Not necessary at all, but they try to take advantage of people with limited time to play with their "time savers." e.g. xp-boosts, materials, money, and collectible maps.
___
Some people say this game gets a little grindy, but if you do the side quests and take advantage of message boards, leveling up should not really be a problem. You won't be able to get away with just doing the main story quests, you have to engage with the world a little.
This game is not very "Assassin's Creed like," so all you diehard fans might not feel right at home. Rushing into a crowd and swinging your sword has been made just as viable as quiet stealth strategy.
The story is technically tied to Assassins vs Templars lore, but not by much.

From what I have seen so far.

This game also has optional Microtransactions, they are not a must yet but I wonder... Just don't support that kind of thing,

Overall I think this game might be a fun game to play if you can get over the negitives.
But not at full price. buy it on sale is my advice. or atleast wait for more reviews.

Recommended

Posted: 25 May, 2020
This is a truly giant open-world game filled with a plethora of interesting stories, a captivating Ancient Greek setting, and beautiful landscapes. Though the game has its occasionally annoying features, such as a messy inventory system, it would be hard to argue that this massive game is not overall worthy of a recommendation. The game allows for a variety of play-styles, plot choices, and difficulties, making it easy for any gamer to find the approach they seek. Whether you want to casually explore the Greek world and learn about its history and mythology, challenge yourself with stealthy assassination missions, or indulge your blood-lust as you cut down warriors, Odyssey will provide the experience you seek.

For anyone considering buying it, I would highly recommend purchasing the Gold Edition on sale because the additional story content does provide many new experiences and the Fate of Atlantis DLC includes three amazing new areas. The DLC packs are also required to unlock all of the achievements.

PS: I did not experience any significant bugs, but achievement hunters might want to check online sources for obscure completion requirements. Also, anyone who has played Assassin's Creed: Origins will notice improvements to many of the game mechanics in Odyssey. I will note that the archery in this game seems to have been simplified; the player can only use one standard bow and slightly modify it with special engravings and arrows. Lots of the previous class-unique behaviors of bows have been implemented as obtainable abilities.

Posted: 29 October, 2018
This was money well spent. Best immersive world experience I have had since Witcher 3. I loved Withcer 3. I am a bit of an rpg and exploration die hard and it seems the AC games are slowly evolving that way.

The dialogues are usually well put together. Character voices and acting are mostly great. (One exception are spartan commanders for battles, they sound like try hard bad boys)

The quests are mostly endearing, thoguh I have not quite seen twists and such to W3 levels.

The scenery is amazing, the detail is second to none. I once sat and watched three characters go through an entire religious ritual to a god, without my involvement and all. Characters laugh, sleep, joke, dance fight and so on, all around you.

The cities do start to blur, but that is very finelining. Most of them feel unique and have a true character to them.

I enjoy the combat, though as the game goes on it leaves historical and moves into mythical (I have no problem with that, but some may).

Travel is great, horse, ship, swimming and feet. There are less things to climb other than some impressive temples, but that seems less of an issue, except when you really like death from above.

Mercenaries and cultists are a great add.

There are relatively few bugs, but they do pop up now and then (I once had to take on the entire Athenian navy myself and thoght it was silly, but on a reload my Spartan allies actually joined the battle)

I have enjoyed the direction the franchise has been going. I thought it was a bit weird at first to set this 400 years before Origins, but then I realised that they do not actually mention Assassins or Templars within the Greek world parts of the game and it made a bit more sense.

Though there are a lot of well thought out missions, it could do with a bit more diversity in general pick up mission types, and I could probably do without the over the top sexual advances from a few characters. Not that I mind sex in games, but a bit of seduction or hints rather than straight up proposals clumsily thrown at me would be nice.

All in all I highly recommend.

What do I even say about this game? It's a great game, it is what it says it is. Sure, there's a couple memes in there, but not really anything political or modern day that's in your face like some similar games. The gameplay is solid and fun, the story is pretty good, though a couple voice actors are sorta hit or miss sometimes, but all the main characters do fine.

EVERYTHING IS SPELLED WITH K

Some complain about Ubisoft sometimes, but I have had no issue with this one whatsoever. The game also runs pretty well as long as you respect your computer's graphical limitations which a lot of people seem to ignore these days. I also have never had a crash in 150+ hours so far. I really, really have enjoyed this game a lot and I still haven't even finished 60% of it or so. Oh and some people were worried about microtransactions. They're there and they exist, but they're not required or even recommended to play the game. You can get along without them just fine. I actually found myself wishing I could lower the xp gain rate instead of increasing it. I often times would level up before my gear had a chance to update, but it's not a big issue later on. Overall, the balance of the game feels fine. The radiant quest system is there to generate extra xp options but I almost always get along fine with the normal sidequests which are sometimes very surprising in how big of an arc they are. Like at one point I hopped onto an island to explore that didn't seem like much and suddenly I'm overthrowing an entire corrupt underground gang society thing. The game has a lot to offer if you let it. I don't mind buying this game at full price, but if you still don't feel comfortable with full price, pick it up at 30% off or more, it is worth it.

Lavigne
265 products in account
0
48 people found this review helpful
24 people found this review funny 0

Not Recommended
443.0 hrs on record
Posted: 17 January, 2019
It's really just deeply unfortunate that I'm writing a negative review for a game in one of my favorite series of all time, and what was - before Title Update 1.12, and the release of Legacy of the First Blade Episode 2 - likely going to be my current favorite game of all time. Long before October 2nd, 2018, I preordered the Gold Edition of Assassin's Creed Odyssey. I love Shao Jun, Evie Frye, and Aya of Alexandria dearly, but specifically knowing that a female protagonist would finally lead an entire mainline Assassin's Creed game if you chose them as your protagonist, just made me beyond excited. And when they showed that choices would be brought into an Assassin's Creed game for the very first time - all of that excitement was gone. Choice in an Assassin's Creed game went against everything we were told in the lore. I was racking my brains as to how they would make this work when the basis of an Assassin's Creed game, that you are experiencing the memories of someone long gone, was giving way to dialogue choices. And when they told us they were adding multiple romances to this formula too, as an AC fan, I was nervous. But I trusted that they would treat this game, and the fans who love their games, with respect, and honor the series as a whole. And I went against all my better judgment (and usual personal practice), and preordered the game. Because the more gameplay I saw, I felt like this game was something special. I felt like Ubisoft was trying something bold and fresh for one of their most beloved franchises. And I wanted to be part of that. And after seeing the premises of promised DLC, I knew I'd be genuinely upset if I missed out on them too.

Assassin's Creed Odyssey is the third game I have ever personally ever preordered for myself. When I say it's usual personal practice, I really do mean it.

And after 370 hours with this game, I wish I never had.

Before I get into why my review is negative, I just want to clear up a few things here. None of what I'm about to say is driven solely by my personal feelings and opinions. Rather, everything I'm about to say is because the product that Ubisoft has sold is not the product that I have received. In multiple ways. And I'm writing this review to bring that to peoples' attention. Because what Ubisoft has done, regardless of personal feelings, is wrong on a fundamental level of ethical business practice.

As a major part of the marketing for the game, creative director Jonathan Dumont and narrative director Melissa MacCoubrey talked about choices and romance within the game. Dumont said, "Since the story is choice-driven, we never force players in romantic situations they might not be comfortable with. Players decide if they want to engage with characters romantically. I think this allows everybody to build the relationships they want, which I feel respects everybodyâ€™s roleplay style and desires."

In Legacy of the First Blade Episode 2, no matter the dialogue options you choose, no matter the actions you take when completing the quests for that DLC episode, your character ends up with a child, with someone they are clearly meant to be romantically in love with. No decisions are made in this romantic situation, they are all made for you. And in designing the DLC to end this way, and no other, Ubisoft has lied. Your character reacts romantically in every interaction with their unchosen partner, with even the musical cues that played each time you romance a character smacking you over the head each time, just in case you missed it. Your character pines for this partner, cries over them, snuggles under the stars with them, and has a child with them - without a dialogue choice in sight. It's the only romance in Assassin's Creed Odyssey where you do not have any choice. On the most basic of levels, you are forced into this romantic situation. Even if you reject them outright, your character engages with this character romantically. Ubisoft, in marketing this game, sold a product on certain promises. Would I be writing a negative review if player choice was never in this game? If this was a game with fixed choices and romances, like every Assassin's Creed game before it? No, I would not. But Ubisoft did not honor promises made while marketing this game. As it stands, please don't give any of your money to this game, as the devs clearly shown that they do not deserve it. And if you need more reasons: The game's environments can be very copy-and-paste in a lot of areas, and the world, while filled with some unique areas, suffers for this. The optimization issues are frustrating, and I still experienced them no matter what settings I played at.

Now, the rest of what I'm about to say is driven solely by my personal feelings and opinions.
I'm a lesbian.
I hesitate to say this because I personally believe that there is so much more to me than being a lesbian. I love campy horror movies, I play guitar, and I have a bowl of the same cereal basically every day for breakfast. Also, while we're talking about food: pineapple on pizza debate? I really hate it.

I say this because, throughout my time with AC Odyssey, my Kassandra was played, from start to finish, as a lesbian. As I said above, I was just excited that I could play as Kassandra. That would have been enough for me. But when Melissa MacCoubrey said, "If you want to be a woman and romance a woman, you can do that. If you want to be a man and romance a woman, you can do that. If you want to be a man and romance a man and a woman, you can do that. Weâ€™re making a game that offers choice, and this is something that matters a lot to people. It matters a lot to me. And it matters a lot to the team," it really was with those words that I knew for absolute certain that my Kassandra would be a lesbian, like me. And I was totally free do exactly that. It almost didn't feel real, in a way. There was no ambiguity in the choices, no, "Are you really sure. though?" Once I made a decision within a romance, that was it. Decision completely respected.

And this DLC absolutely spits in the face of that. It was jarring to have my Kassandra visibly fall in love with this man, get pregnant with his child, and have to sit there and watch it all. It was jarring to have all of this happen only via dialogue-free cutscenes, accompanied by the music that played during some of my favorite romances of the game. And it is jarring for lesbian and bisexual women, whose decisions are not respected, who are told that they'll grow out of their little phase, who have been told they just need to find the right man, or who have literally undergone corrective r*pe to "sort out" their attractions. This DLC sends such a dangerous message, especially to women and the LGBTQ+ community; and, to make matters worse, the achievement for completing the DLC is titled "Growing Up". I shouldn't have to explain why that's wrong on multiple levels. Every time I loaded up Assassin's Creed Odyssey, it reminded me that, "This work of fiction was designed, developed, and produced by a multicultural team of various beliefs, sexual orientations, and gender identities." I don't know, then, how this team let this DLC be produced. I really don't.

I've never called any character in any Assassin's Creed game "my" anything. But I called the protagonist of Assassin's Creed Odyssey "my Kassandra" because I chose to play as her. Because I chose who she romanced. Because she was a Kassandra I could relate to and see some of myself in. Because I always had agency over her dialogue in some way, however small, and because player choice, specifically within romances, was highlighted so majorly as a selling point of this game. As of TU 1.12, I have uninstalled Assassin's Creed Odyssey, and on a matter of principle, I will not be purchasing any more Ubisoft games until you fix this. These were your own words, Ubisoft. And I can guarantee that the community that you lied to will hold you accountable for them.
 

Kaedwenii
132 products in account

Not Recommended
124.7 hrs on record
Posted: 23 November, 2020
(Actual hour count is ~30 hours less than Steam shows - left idling many times)

I am extremely conflicted on Assassin's Creed Odyssey. As I write this review, I'm not sure which way my binary choice of "recommend" or "not recomment" would lean... So let's list out some points, and by the time you read this review you'll see what I decided ultimately.

Assassin's Creed Odyssey is many things;
First and foremost it's gorgeous. Well, the environments anyway. Animations are often janky, there's something off with all the character's faces and lipsync. But man, the environment and world is stunning to look at

It's also overflowing with content. Content which, with some exceptions, is fun for the entire duration of the game. Scouting out various temples and bases, deciding on the best route to infiltrate/complete objectives/kill everyone is engaging and enjoyable.

However, to get to that content you need to navigate the game (have I mentioned how beautiful the world is?). By this I mean lengthy periods of time of holding "W" on your keyboard. Sometimes Shift too! How exciting! Interacting with the menus within menus within submenus. And of course, the quests.

The quests turn this enjoyable checklist romp into a painful experience. I often found myself thinking "man, I could totally go for some more stealthy-combaty-gameplay" only to be blocked by boring, drawn out, poorly written, forced conversations and side objectives, to the point of turning the game off and coming back another day.

None of this is interesting or particularly well executed. Playing through this game made me yearn for a base-hunting roguelike, with all the unnecessary "fat" of Odyssey cut out and removed. No dialogues, quests, NPCs, levelling power creep... Just planning, assassinating and fighting.

I played this game over the course of 11-ish months, and had to take frequent breaks to prevent boredom and frustration - a trait I don't encounter in the many 100+ hour long games I play.

So why did I keep playing? The checklist-satisfaction factor is executed wonderfully in this game. Also it was something to do. A game to jump into in between playing other, better games.

I don't think I'll remember anything about playing this a few years from now. It's the kind of video-gamey fast food which you jump into to relax after a long day - something which was sorely needed in this year.

Anyway, ramblings aside and TL;DR:
Gameplay good but repetitive
World beautiful but too big
Systems introduced but underutilised
Gear customization fun but gear pointless once you acquire set bonuses
Abilities varied and interesting but enemies scale their health so much, it doesn't really matter
Quests have unique set ups, but abysmal execution

For every positive in Odyssey there's a negative to throw at it. To it's credit, it's the first Assassins Creed game I've been able to enjoy and actually finished- though I think I'll take a break before playing Origins/Valhalla/whatever is next for a long, long time.
At the end of my review I still don't know whether I "recommend" this game to others. There's a thousand more interesting, more risk taking, more medium-evolving games to try out and play. But there's also this game which will last you months and leave you sort of satisfied-but-constantly-wishing-it-did-these-other-things-like-better-games-do-it and coming back for more.

Yeah, idk.
Play as Kassandra if you do get it though.

Have I mentioned how pretty Ancient Greece is?

I was about to hit "Post Review" but thought of the parts where you play in modern day and how a w f u l they are. Maybe it's because I haven't played the other AC games, but interacting with Layla and crew feels like it was just wedged in there to attach the game to the AC universe - it would have been a much, much better experience without it.

Ultimately as I'm about to hit don't recommend, I don't think this is a "good" game. It is "fun" but doesn't do anything particularly interesting or particularly well. Other than the world. Man is it pretty.

+ Choices actually have consequences, some being small and some big.
+ Game is downright gorgeous to the detailed backgrounds and characters, making for some nice screenshots.
+ Huge open world where exploration is a must since there are so many interesting and beautiful areas to discover, full of exp, npcs with quests, treasure and things to kill.
+ Lots of Romance Options.
+ Like the gameplay with versatile combat and movement. Especially since the enemies no longer wait around taking turns for you to just counter attack them and no I did not play Origins so I have no idea if all these changes were implemented then. I also did not watch any videos in case I ever wanted to give it a try after this playing this game.
+/- The usual microtransactions crammed into a single player game which makes no sense, instead of just allowing the player to unlock everything by actually playing the game. I say that as a person who has no problem spending a few more bucks to get the cosmetic look I want in a game but only in a multiplayer/mmo always online game like For Honor or PoE. - Having to use Uplay at the same time as Steam, it just isn't as responsive as Steam. I mean there's a reason I bought it on Steam instead of Uplay but I still end up having to use Uplay, lol.

Overall the game is amazing and I recommend it to anyone new or old to the Assassin's Creed series. Here's to hoping the next one is actually set in feudal Japan!

Recommended
196.4 hrs on record
Posted: 12 November, 2020
I pre-ordered this paying full price + the season pass, then like a moron waited 2 YEARS to get around to playing it when I probably could have picked it all up on sale for less than $20, but I can still say I don't regret it. The last Assassin's Creed game I put any serious time into was 2 but after dabbling in some of the other iterations I've noticed that the connection to the word "assassin" is getting less and less relevant with each game and I think that's a good thing. I also haven't seen hide nor hair of the ridiculous modern day story that connects the whole series together since the initial cut scene and I say good riddance to that as well. What this series has become is an excuse to do open world combat games in historical time periods and it does it exceeding well. So what you've got here is an opportunity to run around ancient Greece during the war between Sparta and Athens and just doing that is way fun. Seriously, I get my money's worth just sailing around at the helm of my very own warship enjoying the scenery while my sailors sing sea chanties in Greek. "Spartan kicking" enemies ala The 300 is awesome too, and of all the armored helmets in history I challenge you to name me one that's cooler than the big "I'm so badass I can wear a scrub brush on my head and nobody laughs" version.

To my action-game-adverse friends I say pick it up on the cheap now that Valhalla is out, put combat on easy mode and just enjoy it for the scenery and history. This one is definitely worth your time if only just for that.

**************

Update: A couple of thoughts deeper into the game. Yes, the modern day story has reared it's head a couple of times now and it's full of callbacks and nods to the other games that I don't understand but they've been thankfully short. An underlining current of the story does seem to be designed to connect all the games together but I'm confident that it's still going to be able to be taken as a sideshow and the main story is going to have it's own satisfying conclusion independent of all that.

Second, my main concern going into this was which main character I should play, you get to choose male or female. Every review I read raved about the female voice actress and having gone that route I tend to agree... I really like her delivery. My worry was romantic options. I like to think of myself as open minded but I've never been able to get invested in romantic plots outside my own gender and sexual preferences. (Which makes me really appreciate what things used to be like in gaming for women and members of the LGBT community.) However it really hasn't been an issue here. I'm far enough in that I'm fairly certain there's no Mass Effect Tali or Fallout 4 Piper in this game. The options of that sort seem to all be quick "wham, bam, thank you ma'ams," so if Kassandra wants to have a quick romp in the hay with a noble or a priestess every now and then I say "you go girl." Aphrodite would be pleased.

Also, I know some of my female gamer friends have very valid concerns about how women are portrayed in fantasy, so I'll tell you this: Kassandra wears the same armor that everyone else does. Yeah, she shows leg, but so do the men. Greek armor is all about the skirts. But while she's definitely feminine she's athletically built so there's no need for custom made breastplates, and certainly not ones with big vulnerable points built in so the gals can show cleavage. That contoured muscle-ripped stuff Greeks are always portrayed wearing looks good on her. Definitely as badass but even more respectfully portrayed than even the recent Wonder Woman movies. Given that everyone else is running around wearing togas, you'll see much more chest from the male NPCs giving quests. Geez, this game's got more chest hair than a hillbilly water park, but I digress...
 

Moose Thirteen
821 products in account

Recommended
100.1 hrs on record
Posted: 12 July, 2020
Assassin's Creed Odyssey is my 8th AC game (not counting the ones I haven't finished yet, like Liberation and AC1). It is incredibly enjoyable. There's so much stuff to do, and the world of Greece is just so much fun to explore. In saying that though, I do believe the main questline is lacklustre, and the modern day parts in this are some of the worst this franchise had to offer (long post):

The good:
- The world is gorgeous and is an absolute treat to explore. Greece was so beautifully recreated. I spent a lot of hours just running around and exploring.
- The combat! Even better than AC Origins! I absolutely loved the different abilities, especially those in the Assassin branch.
- YOU CAN SPARTA KICK ENEMIES. IT'S OVER, YOU HAVE THE HIGH GROUND.
- Like AC Origins, you can climb almost anything,
- There were some absolutely AMAZING support characters (and associated quests) like Barnabas, Herodotos, and Alkibiades. I love all their interactions with Kassandra.
- The cult system was an interesting way of implementing an "assassination" list kind of mechanic. It could have been improved, but I think it had great potential, and should be revisited in future games.

The meh:
- Kassandra (or Alexios') story is very lackluster. I'm not saying it's horrible, it's definitely not the worst story, but there wasn't a single point in it that made me go WHOA, or "HOLY SH**.
- Kassandra was rather bland, but I think this was a conscious decision due to the fact that there are "branching" paths to take in this game based on your choices.
- I was not a huge fan of having dialogue options. Ignoring the fact that the choices presented in this game are uninteresting, there are very few parts where your actions have any impact to the world, and some of them don't really make a lot of sense. Plus, you can be a total â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥, but still end up a good guy?
- The writing in this game is generally just bland. There aren't any profound lines or parts that would impress. A large part of the story and the sidequests are forgettable.
- Naval combat. I don't really have much to say about it except that it felt like a chore.
- HOW CAN YOU HAVE ROMANCE OPTIONS AND NOT LET US SLEEP WITH 

The bad:
- Assassinations are not insta-kill, even if the target is sleeping. I mean come on? How do you survive a knife to the neck?
- You don't have a hidden blade. Which is understandable, but also still kind of disappointing.
- All of the modern day parts are duller than a butter knife. Layla is absolutely the most boring character I've ever had the displeasure to play as.
- There is very little interaction with the world. You can't sit on chairs to hide or blend with crowds (an issue I also had with Origins). You can't really interact with the people on your boat and start conversations.

Overall, AC Odyssey is a really fun game. But it did not amaze me or touch me in the way that Origins did. When I play an AC game, I do not want to decide how it's going to end, I want to be taken on a wild ride. I think having "choices" forced the story to go in certain directions that were bland or boring, and didn't allow the devs to take more risks with it. Still, I enjoyed this game A LOT. And I think people who are on the fence should give it a chance, because the gameplay is really good.

- running (or horsing) around the world, exploring, fighting few opponents
- main guests or side guests (those are not very good most of the time),
- fortresses, which generally means changing the pace and playstyle
- conquest battles
- sailing, sea battles
- managing your inventory and character

It does not have the strongest mechanics, but they are doable. The combat is enjoyable, but it doesn't register all the inputs, which can be infuriating, especially if you are fighting a lot of opponents and it doesn't register your parry.

It's a game in which you can sink hundreds of hours. It gets repetitive, but the sheer amount of different things to do helps.

It has one HUGE problem though. The balance of currency and experience was sabotaged by developers themselves, to make you buy "time savers". That's a real pity. They deliberately made their own game worse. By a lot.

Still, it's a great game.

TheServerOfLife

Recommended
95.5 hrs on record
Posted: 12 November, 2018
I usually write in depth reviews, but it's late - so bear with me.

-Graphics and Sound-
The graphics in the game are honestly really phenominal. I have a GTX 1080 and a i7-8700k, ran it on high for a solid 60 frames with a 3440x1440p 21:9 ratio monitor. Armor is extremely well detailed, characters are amazingly done, and the effects - oh my god the effects. At first you don't notice it because of all the sounds of combat, but I took a listen in on the "flame" effect when you slather your sword in fire - holy gods (pun intended) it sounded so damn realistic to actual fire behavior when you swung it. The game's pocked full of those little, minute details that make you giddy when you recognize what they are, just for that little bit of immersion - despite how unrealistic the game is, not that that is bad.
But I digress.

-Gameplay-
This is not a traditional Assassin's Creed game. This is most certainly like Origins, and is totally unlike my childhood; the childhood being hundreds of hours collectively on Brotherhood, Revelations, III, Black Flag, II, etc. However, you can still do Assassin-esque things, such as (whad'ya know) assassinations! However, you need to spec your build right, albeit you can have balance between "Warrior" and "Assassin" to be able to do good damage in combat, but also stealth-kill enemies. Otherwise, you'll end up just doing a "stealth attack" that doesn't instantly kill the enemy for you. I was a bit dispassionate to see this so early game, where your Assassin damage was commonly so low that it only took enemies down to 25%-40% health. But, at end-game, you'll be fine.

Either way, the combat is fun, flows well, and has little to no glitches or bugs to iron out, at least in my experience. Abilities and overpower attacks are satisfying, finishers are brutal (but not too brutal, to some people's dismay), and overall it was a very enjoyable experience.

It should also be noted that I was never forced into combat throughout the entire game; as in, I always had that choice to stealth or run in flaming-sword-ablaze. You could assassinate your target after getting rid of all his guards first, then lure him out and whack him in a bush, or you could simply dive head-first into a full crowd of elite enemies and hope your strategic way of bouncing around works. If you play on the hardest difficulty, you die in /literally/ 2-4 hits, so I would take the more tactful approach.

-The Cash Shop-
Never needed it, didn't dabble in it, never even clicked on it. As soon as the game was finished and over, I had my character build, my armor set, and no need to address anything from there. Yeah, some decent customization was prevalent. but I was never encouraged enough to buy them or need it otherwise. No need to buy EXP boosts, no need to buy upgrades for my ship in the form of Captains. Nothing. Ever. You getting my long, drawn-out point for all those who are saying "MuH cAsH shOp iN sInGlE pLayEr gAme?" Yeah, it sucks ass that they did it - but as long as it doesn't interfere with the gameplay, and I still get god-like looking armor regardless; what's the point of complaining? When it starts doing either, that's when you have a problem. But this is a review, not a 4chan board!

-The Experience and Story-
Some things were kind'a predictable, but a lot wasn't. Oh man when you figure out who the head of the antagonist faction is, my jaw dropped with a loud "WHAT". But, I'll say I learned a /ton/ about Greek culture and mythos. Obviously, not on-par representation as reading into the actual Odyssey, or other stories that have been foretold; but even so, it infatuated me over the course of the game. Was truly interesting to look into, especially after reading a book about Greek philosophy.

Anyways, overall it was a good game. Heartfelt moments at times, even by just simple side characters. Heart-string tugging. Would rate it a solid 9/10; the 9 because it's an RPG stamped with the AC name, so a bit of disappointment still lingers in me. But that's just my bias.

zeko

2 people found this review helpful 2

Recommended
88.3 hrs on record
Posted: 15 October, 2018
AC: Odyssey was the first game I've played in a long time where I actually had FUN. I'm new to the AC franchise so I can't compare this to previous AC games, but as a standalone I really like it.

RE: Exp grind
There has been plenty of criticism about the exp grind and stuff. Personally, I don't find that to be the case at all. I hit max level about 65% into the main quest, and I'm not even OCD about completing every objective before moving on. If you do a couple of location objectives / sidequests alongside the main quest, you shouldn't have a problem with exp. There are also plenty of repeatable (albeit boring) 'side quests' that offer a ton of exp for something simple, like killing an NPC or delivering an item.

RE: Microtransactions
I'm someone who's quite liberal about spending on lootboxes, but I haven't felt the urge to make a single microtransaction in this game. I was worried that the game was balanced around microtransactions, but upon finishing it I can say that I haven't spent anything extra on microtransactions, and have needed nothing from the cash shop to thoroughly enjoy the game.

RE: Resource grind
Resource cost for upgrading gear is pretty insane. If you're upgrading your gear at the blacksmith every level for some reason, then yes, you will run out of resources. However, gear upgrades drop all the time in the game. If you replace your gear with upgrades that you find (like in a regular RPG), and only upgrade your "endgame gear" when you're near/at max level, then resources aren't much of a problem.

----

Pros:
+ Kassandra <3
+ Overall, the 3 'main' plot lines were interesting; they kept me intrigued despite the length.
+ Really large game, huge map, good amount of content and exploration, long quest chains.
+ Beautiful graphics!
+ Plain FUN: Sparta-kicking people off cliffs, scaling every imaginable surface, chain assassinations, blowing people's heads off with arrows that hit like cannonballs, naval battles, investigating a cult, etc.
+ Romance options are mostly hilarious. They're definitely shallow as far as RPG relationships go, but the blatant flirting and general horniness from the MC/NPCs make me laugh every time.
+ Voice acting is pretty good overall, although there were some moments where I felt like the voices were over-dramatised.
+ Kassandra <3

Cons:
- Illusion of choice: Unlike 'full' RPGs, only a handful of options throughout the dialogue actually has consequences.
- Some of the animations look a little clunky / repetitive
- Personally, the endings / conclusions of the main plotlines were kind of a let down for me. The journey definitely >>> the destination in my case. This was the biggest flaw for me, because I had so much fun during the 100 hours of gameplay, only to be let down at the end by a mediocre ending. YMMV though.
- Replayability: Considering that dialogue options matter so little, I wouldn't be replaying it to see different outcomes. I also haven't seen much of endgame content at the moment.

----

Overall, compared to a 'proper' RPG, the story / choice elements are lacking a little, but overall, it's still a great game that provided me about a hundred hours of solid fun. And a new pixel wife, because Kassandra is amazing.

Recommended
143.9 hrs on record
Posted: 20 December, 2018
This is probably my favorite and most time invested RPG since Fallout 3. I know people have varying opinions about Ubisoft, but in my opinion, they have done an awesome job sticking by and supporting their games, and ACO represents the pinnacle of their work. There are literally hundreds of things you can do in this: Main Quest line, side missions, ship battles, take on epic beasts, hunt down weekly targets, or just explore the world.

For me, this is a great chill game after a tough day. You can literally just ride your horse around and find something on your map that will further along the 10-15 different quest lines you are part of, from the main story (which is a great tale of revenge and redemption) to the typical MMO style- kill 10 wolves and get a reward. This game feels like a MMO, minus the other players, which works fine for most lone wolf type players. I also appreciate the ship game play IS NOT tedious and actually makes you want to design/upgrade your ship, especially the ones you defeat as part of weekly quests. It is very fun firing arrows into enemy ship then boarding them to fight the crewman.

Another good aspect of this game is armor and weapon customization. You can definitely look and play like a Spartan from 300, and the armor is absolutely awesome in this regard: various helmet designs with almost anything you would see in a movie or history book to custom swords/staffs/bows that have a variety of designs (my favorite is the "vine bow"). Also, if you want to rock the whole old school assassins look, there are outfits and abilities that match this style as well.

My only real negative is the repetition of the side missions, but honestly, how many unique mission types can you put into a game? There is bound to be some repeats, even in the Witcher 3 (love the game like everyone else).

If you are looking for Dark Souls like difficulty, then pass on this because you will find it too easy. But for the majority of us casual gamers who like historical settings and easy to root for heroes, then this is definite BUY. Ubisoft does not skimp on you at all, fully worth the $100 I paid for the Gold Edition and a crazy good deal for those who waited for a sale.
