Not Recommended
194.4 hrs on record
Posted: 16 July, 2020
Odyssey, an Assassin's Creed spin-off...

Ubisoft, made this game from the cut content of Origins. Which, was supposed to contain a huge chunk of Greece as well. And didn't bother to market it as such, out of fear that some people might not buy it. Now, if you've played every single AC game, you'll notice from the get go, that Odyssey isn't even close to being one. Which contrary to its title, has nothing to do with the Assassin Brotherhood nor the Templar Order. Though, I appreciate the furthering of lore, with the whole Cult of Kosmos. And even so, Odyssey is simply put, as but a virtual tour of Ancient Greece, with a decent story and RPG mechanics.

Therefore, this should settle the argument that Odyssey isn't an AC game. It is and isn't at the same time. It is perhaps, an unintentional spin-off (doubt it). Who knows...It's entirely up to the player to decide what an AC game is. If some consider this one to be a valid entry into the series, then I guess it is. Other won't. And Ubisoft must've been aware of this. Mind you that before Origins came out, the magic of series started to be wear off for at least a couple of years. Therefore, they made a choice to make their next game a bit different, could be why Odyssey sold better than Origins...

But, obviously, I think it could've been so much better if they would've given me a Hidden Blade from the beginning, instead of that horrendous Spear of Leonidas...
Which ! By the way, Kassandra or Alexios, for that matter, along with Ubisoft. Can shove up their-

Anyway...

I bought the game in 2018, when it released, and later did the same for its DLC. Yet, as I kept playing it I found myself more than often, exploring and taking screenshots than doing the main quests. This is the only AC game I have yet to finish. Not because it has a lengthy main story, but rather features, the least compelling AC story to date. It simply didn't hook me alike Origins did, for example. It still doesn't. To be honest I don't think I'll ever finish this one. Which means I've wasted my money on an AC game ! A first for me. I've even finished Syndicate, which prior to Odyssey's release I've considered to be the worst AC game, as far as the story is concerned. I still do in a way. Though it's understandable, because among other Ubisoft studios, the same studio, Ubisoft Quebec, worked on Odyssey as well...

Regarding combat, it's similar to Origins, improved in some areas, yet I found their choice to ditch the shield in favor for a more active combat style, a bit daft. Since it would've offered slightly more complexity to their system. And Spartans used shields in combat !

Thus, in conclusion, Assassin's Creed Odyssey, is a decent open-world RPG, but nothing close to the best AC game. (Ezio's trilogy being the best. Followed by Black Flag, and from there, it's heading downward until Origins, then back into the abyss.). Which could've been a whole lot better if the main character was an actual member of an early Hellenic version of the Assassin Brotherhood instead of a mercenary. Which, (the Assassin part), they poorly introduce in the Legacy of the First Blade, when it could've been something for the main game and explored in greater detail. And by the way, the whole expansion was developed by Ubisoft Singapore.

It's clear that Ubisoft heavily leans towards turning Assassin's Creed into a Witcher-esque kind of a game. A choice with which I've no problem with, The Witcher 3 was a masterpiece. And Assassin's Creed Valhalla seems to further their path into that particular direction. Though, I've an issue with straying from the roots of what Assassin's Creed games used to be, from a narrative standpoint. You know, the fight and struggle of the Assassin cause, against the Templar Order. Which had been pushed in the background in the recent years, for the historical setting, it seems. More concerned with a particular conflict, then the interest of
what the Assassin Brotherhood can gain in influence, while stopping yet another Templar stratagem. More preoccupied on the personal gains of the main character, then what could he or she offer to the Assassin cause. Therefore I fear yet another pointless game, vague as as far as Assassin-Templar war goes.

It did take 2 years to review this game, because I didn't know whether I should bother to do it or not. It was weird, as I've never been as frustrated with an AC game before...

Recommended
177.6 hrs on record
Posted: 9 December, 2018
After how bad the series has been till now, this game is a welcome change. Yes, most of the core Assassin's Creed mechanics are gone, but it's a damn good game; a proper full fledged RPG.

PROS:
- Massive, gorgeous, and rewarding to explore world.
- Beautiful graphics.
- Engaging storyline.
- Fun side quests.
- Character choice.
- Dialouge choices that affect storylines.
- Good combat and perks/abilities tree.
- A lot of customization.
- Naval element that isn't forced onto you (you can choose to barely use your ship).
- NO tail quests (thank the freaking lord).
- Malaka
- You can set your characters walking speed.
- you can change your current armors appearance so that it looks like any other armor that you've previously acquired (while keeping the stats same).

CONS:
- Microtransactions. I wouldn't mind if they were cosmetic only, but they have these "Time savers", that give you in game resources. This naturally results in them put a bit of unnecessary grind in the game to push you to buy them.
- Level gating. Another microtransaction evil. You'll eventually run into quests that are a solid 4-5 levels over you, and if you haven't till then, you'll have to do a bunch of side quests. Sadly enough, there's a permanent 1.5 times XP multiplier available as an in game purchase that prevents level gating for most of the main story line.
- Lazy enemy scaling design. Enemies level with you neck to neck, so the sense of reward is overpowered by the fact that if you don't upgrade your gear every level (or wear any other equally leveled gear), you'll always be weaker than the enemies.

Overall a well deserved 8/10

Posted: 23 April, 2019
Overall, Assassin's Creed Odyssey is a great game.

The historical time period is extremely fun and the level progression within the game itself makes you feel like a Greek demigod after awhile. At the moment of writing, I'm 200 hours in and I still haven't finished the main quest-line or explored every side-quest and region. The Greek world is beautiful and, much like Odysseus, you can spend a great deal of time lost in it, just running and sailing around. The RPG and mythological infusions were a strange, but welcome, change of pace from previous Assassin's Creeds. Likewise, I've enjoyed the new, Shadow of Mordor-like mercenary system, which adds a new challenge when several mercenaries are stalking you at once. In my opinion, the writing is better than in Origins and I've found Kassandra (I have not played as Alexios yet) to be a more likeable character than Bayek. I have found myself laughing hard at several quests. (In particular, the "You killed mater and had sex with pater!" quest.) I love being able to choose my own character and Kassandra, like Evie Frye, is a welcome addition to the playable female assassin roster. At first, I disliked the combat system but I've grown ambivalent about it now. Still not a fan of enemies harmlessly passing through you when you're on a ladder though.

To be honest, this is probably one of my favorite Assassin's Creeds, after Assassin's Creed II and Brotherhood. Unfortunately, I'm still waiting for Ubisoft to take Assassin's Creed to feudal Japan or China...

Recommended
59.8 hrs on record
Posted: 22 December, 2018
I couldn't stand the Assassin's Creed franchise. That is, un till now!

I honestly haven't played Assassin's Creed in a long LONG time, I couldn't stand the gameplay before, albeit yes I haven't sampled Origins (which I hear is also on par with Odyssey) but when I saw this game in my discovery queue I almost hit "Ignore" like I would with any previous Assassin's Creed. But the genre caught my eye, Greece? Greek gods? The scenary, the whole Greek theme really caught my eye, I love this sort of genre. I stuck it on my wishlist, I watched a few trailers a few youtube videos and decided to buy it once it came down in price in the winter sale and boy am I glad I did!

I remember Assassin's creed back in the day, the whole blending in rubbish, the genres were terrible, the look didnt catch my eye, the whole "historic" look back in like 1800's blah blah I didn't like it but Odyssey is fantastic. The look of the game is mind blowing to say the least, I haven't expereinced any horrible screen tearing, or annoying scenic pop ins, everything is unbelievably smooth and that's only the tip of the iceberg.

It plays great, the sword fights are epic, the assassinations are beautful and brutal in equal measure, the use of the Eagle is so damn good to scout out the area your approaching, you mark your targets and areas of interest using the eagle so you can plot your moves. It's a game of strategy before you even enter the area in question, sure you can go in gung ho, sure why not but there's something in scouting the area with your eagle and taking enemies out systematically, one by one, silently, deadly and tossing their bodies out of sight. That's my preference but you can play how you like.

The skill tree is easy to manage and to understand, nothing is over complicated when it doesn't need to be, you skill up, spend ability points in the tree on whichever playstyle suits you. Do you prefer bows? Then add the ability to suit, prefer Sword fights? then add the ability to suit etc etc.

The variety of weapons I've seen, even in the first few hours of gameplay are fantastic, didn't take me long to look like a typical sandal wearing noob to having nice shiny mercenary armour and even upgraded them at the blacksmith using ores and materials i found on my travels.

Everything seems worth it and that's a huge plus for me, I've found myself in the last few hours just doing a few side quests in Sala (The first town you're in) just to boost my Xp and generally hone my skills and they're great, meaningful side quests with nice lore and decent story telling.

The voice acting is really good too, sometimes in games the voice acting and the mouth movements are terrible but not here, looks and sounds great.

It's also not easy btw, I've been playing on normal and i've died quite a few times but usually more so because of my own stupidity and trying to blast thru a quest, be patient, be smart and the game will reward you.

Everything from graphics, gameplay, Xp, weapon types and upgrades, the general look and feel, the genre, everything is a 10/10.

A solid 10/10 If I had 1 gripe it's that there's no shields......... I find that a little bizarre considering the genre but meh, it's not affecting my fun or gameplay it's just something i'd have liked.

Oh and I climbed up Zeus's statue and hung from his balls........ So there's that.

10/10

25.0 hrs on record
Posted: 25 November, 2018
Although the game starts off as fun to play, you tend to repeat the same actions over and over and it feels like a grind to get through the story. It feels like a slightly better looking version of Origins. Some improvements were made to the skills tree, but it's still the same model where you have to grind your level up to play certain story missions.

Additionally, this game markets itself as being "Assassin's Creed", this is nothing further from the truth. The game has no links to the series' story line, the only possible link can be associated with artifacts. It has no assassin nature nor does it connect to the templars in any sense. It seems that Ubisoft focused so much on making an RPG style game they forgot to connect the game to its roots.

Everyone will find a way to have fun in this game, I just don't think that your entertainment value will last. It will slowly turn into the feeling of a grind that tires you out from even wanting to play the story.

Recommended
139.4 hrs on record
Posted: 10 October, 2018
Edit: I am changing my review of this game "would recommend", as the developer, Ubisoft, made good on their promise to include support for older CPUs. They said the issue would be resolved by next patch, and I just logged in to find a new patch and voila, the game is playable. My settings are admittadly a mixture of low and medium but the game has not crashed once and is fairly smooth at around 40-50+ FPS consistently.

I would like to thank the Ubisoft developers for taking the time to resolve this issue. It was hard not to feel dismissed, as developers of other games have done in the past in similar circumstances. Ubisoft actually listened to their player base, and found that a quick fix could and would allow even more people the chance to buy and enjoy the game.

They deserve respect and kind words for a decently quick turnaround. While I would have loved to see the game released in this state, I understand that it can be difficult to know what percentage of people will still be affected and by what problems when a new game is released.

I'm going to leave the previous "would not recommend" review underneath for transparency even after changing it to "would recommend", but I am happy to report I've been playing the game with no issues and am looking forward to enjoying a hundred hours in what already feels like the best Assassin's Creed game to date.

Again, thank you to the Ubisoft developers for resolving this quickly. Thank you to "ubiunicorn" for a quick response, and the hard work to include a smaller but vocal group of gamers to the supported hardware. My faith in your company and your support staff has been restored.
-------------------------------

My hardware met the system requirements, and I have not been unable to play any other game previously. Issues with first generation intel CPUs (which benchmark comparable to later generations) make the game unloadable and crash at the start. Ubisoft has blamed the users for having out of date hardware, even though the same hardware runs AC: Origins, and any other game on the market right now.

The issue seems to be with first gen CPUs not supporting AVX. Previous game titles have set this as a requirement and later patched the requirement out, allowing those first gen CPUs to run the game. After more than a week of forum complaints from gamers who play every other game with no issues, Ubisoft finally realized it could no longer blame the user, and agreed to patch the previously unmentioned requirement out in the next patch. No news whether that will fix the issues for everyone, but if you buy this game (which I've heard is wonderful) be prepared for the game to crash at startup. Be prepared to spend much of your own time troubleshooting why this AAA title wont run despite meeting the initial system requirements. Plenty of gamers playing every other title out right now have had to return the game for a refund and wait to see if the AVX issues patching fixes most of the crashes.

Hoping one day soon, I can edit this review after actually being able to play the game, but for now it's put a bad taste in my mouth regarding Ubisoft. They are currently in the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ with EA for dismissing a good chunk of their player base and then blaming the user for the issue while they scramble to resolve it behind closed doors.

GrimmJack
19 products in account

2 people found this review helpful 2

Recommended
272.5 hrs on record
Posted: 3 December, 2020
SPOILER-FREE REVIEW

Assassin's Creed Odyssey is the second instalment in the RPG trilogy after Assassin's Creed Origins and before Assassin's Creed Valhalla. The game takes up a lot of mechanics from the previous instalment, and works upon them while also introducing more. The game is set in the setting of Ancient Greece (431-432 BC), right after The Peloponnesian War. As a student of Vellore Institute of Technology, Bhopal, India, we, students of the Game Development branch were made to post a detailed review of a game of our choice on a public platform as an activity, and this will be an in-depth review of the controversial 2018 RPG instalment of Assassin's Creed.


CONCEPT

This action role-playing game offers players a branched, varied and vast open world experience with one of the biggest game worlds of all time. The game directly inherits RPG elements from The Witcher 3 and other hits in the genre, and tosses them into a mix with classic Assassin's Creed ones (or at least some of them). With the side quests included, the game is sure to keep you hooked for over a 100 hours, and that is just the base game without any DLC.


PARADIGM

How does the game allow a player to reach their goal?
âœ”ï¸PROS:
Odyssey features an extensive campaign that is branched into 3 main odysseys, one of which, offers more than 8 endings in itself. The game is tailored by the choices the player makes. It makes sure that if you have reached from point A to B in the game in a certain way, it will be totally different from the method taken up by somebody else. This calls for a lot of memorable experiences and varied narratives.

âŒCONS:
The game can easily feel bloated at times. The quantity over quality scheme becomes transparent when the player is faced with lazily-written side quests, boring story arcs and just a slow-paced narrative in general.


FEATURES

â—˜ Amazingly stunning graphics.
â—˜ An extensive story campaign sure to keep you occupied for hours.
â—˜ A massive open-world. Bigger than any you might have ever seen.
â—˜ Easy to master combat.
â—˜ A mercenary system which was most likely inspired by the nemesis system in Middle Earth: Shadow of War.
â—˜ A ship-crew building system that allows you to recruit any mercenary of your choice thrown in with tons of naval adventures.

â—˜ A weekly reset feature that rewards you with exclusive items for simply playing the game.


MECHANICS

A densely integrated RPG system
âœ”ï¸PROS:
Assassin's Creed is no stranger to RPG elements. The game takes up all the memorable elements from Origins, and works upon them to make them even more fitting for this instalment, be it the levelling and XP system, the weapon rarities with overpowered legendary weapons that you can find by digging around here and there or even the multiple dialogue options. You can even choose the gender you want to play as. The game offers its players a moral compass this time around. You can choose to be violent and harsh, you can choose to be a trickster and lie your way out, or you can even choose to simply romance through it all. Every player is ensured to have different stories to tell.

âŒCONS:
How much RPG is too much RPG? The number of choices thrown at you CAN feel a bit too much at one point. Often, you may find yourself wishing for a more linear experience than having to pause your game everytime you find another sword with a higher rarity.

The Mercenary/Bounty System
âœ”ï¸PROS:
What seems to have been a direct nod to the Nemesis system fro Middle Earth: Shadow of War, is the exclusive feature to the second instalment of this RPG trilogy. Players can hack and slash their way to the top of the mercenary chain as they progress in the game. These are usually randomly generated, but there are also a lot of memorable ones, each with their own traits and skillsets, ensuring that you switch up your strategy everytime you encounter a new one.

âŒCONS:
The mercenary system can easily become a pain in your normal play routine. If you have a high bounty on your head, you'll have mercenaries pouring all over you even when you're just trying to relax and have fun. This seems challenging at first, but can become a nuisance later on when all you're trying to do is just progress in the story.


INTERFACE

Most of the interface is directly borrowed from Assassin's Creed Origins. However, this time around it has been a bit simplified. The skill tree branches out to three main areas - Warrior, Hunter and Assassin, each of which have their own specific skills designed for their own specific situations. The inventory screen has also received a major overhaul, giving players a proper preview of the gear they would want to equip. The map is detailed, and offers pointers wherever you need them. Overall, the game does a good job of making sure you're not lost.



FINAL VERDICT
My personal rating for the game would be a solid 8/10
Although the game seems to have strayed away from the classic Assassin's Creed formula, it has made sure to keep you hooked for over a course of several hours. The RPG mechanics are not exactly polished and could've been less bloated, but they offer you a branched playstyle. The game also seems to perform pretty well on most modern machines, although there may be a little frame drops here and there and especially in largely populated places. Overall, the game is a solid successor to Origins and a ton of fun to play.

~Abhinav Thakur
Student at VIT Bhopal, India
